text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
morphine
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
advanced cervical dilation
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
vaginal delivery
 
History of Present Illness:
___ y/o G3___ presents to triage at 24w4d from ___ office where 
she was being seen for a fetal arrhythmia and subsequently found 
to have a CL 7mm with membranes funneling to the external os. 
she denies contractions or cramping. No vaginal leaking of 
fluid. Active fetal movements.

On speculum exam in triage, noted to be 2-3cm dilated visually 
with bulging membranes.

 
Past Medical History:
PNC
*) Dating ___ ___ by 17 wk u/s 
*) Labs:O pos/Ab neg/R-I/HBsAg neg/RPR-NR/GC and chlamydia neg.
*) FFS: isolated echogenic bright spot of right ventricle
otherwise unremarkable, 3 vc, placenta anterior no previa.
*) Quad screen low risk
issues
late entry to care at ___+6 WGA
tobacco use
marijuana use

OBHx
SAB at 12 WGA x 2 both demise at 9 WGA

GYNHx
LMP uncertain and irregular
denies abn pap/STI's  

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: 
  1. ADD. 
  2. Anemia. 
  3. Depression: Stable. 
  4. Migraines. 
  5. Eczema. 
 
PAST SURGICAL HISTORY 
  1. Appendectomy. 
  2. D&E: X2. 
  3. Derm excisions. 
  4. Wisdom Teeth. 

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
BP 115/68  HR 85  RR 18  temp 98.3 po
RRR
CTAB
ABD gravid, soft, NT

SSE cx appear open 2-3 cm with Bulging membranes

FHT 140 ___, AGA
toco no contractions noted here in triage

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 04:04PM BLOOD WBC-16.3* RBC-3.75* Hgb-11.8* Hct-35.3* 
MCV-94 MCH-31.4 MCHC-33.3 RDW-13.1 Plt ___
___ 04:04PM BLOOD Neuts-79.5* Lymphs-14.9* Monos-4.5 
Eos-0.9 Baso-0.2
___ 04:04PM BLOOD Plt ___
___ 04:04PM BLOOD Glucose-81
___ 08:12PM URINE Blood-NEG Nitrite-NEG Protein-TR 
Glucose-NEG Ketone-40 Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-6.0 Leuks-NEG
___ 08:12PM URINE bnzodzp-NEG barbitr-NEG opiates-NEG 
cocaine-NEG amphetm-NEG mthdone-NEG

___ GBS neg
CT/GC neg
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ was admitted at 24w4d with advanced cervical dilation. 
 She was given betamethasone for fetal lung maturity and 
indomethacin until steroid complete.  there was no evidence of 
PPROM or abruption.  She was seen by the NICU and ___ 
consultants.  On ___ she went into labor with presentation 
consistent with abruption and had a vaginal delivery of a 
liveborn male of 970 grams, admitted to NICU for prematurity.  
She was discharged on postpartum day 2 in good condition.  
Placental pathology is pending.
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain 
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth four times a day Disp 
#*30 Tablet Refills:*1

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
preterm labor 
preterm delivery
abruption

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
see instruction sheet
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Radiculopathy
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ L5-S1 Microdisc

 
History of Present Illness:
___ female who has back pain and leg pain.  The back 
pain has been present for ___ years and is ___ and 70% of her 
symptoms.  She has pain in the legs following a right S1 
distribution, which is ___ and currently
is ___, and 30% of her symptoms.  She is trying hot and cold 
compresses, massages and up to 14 Aleve a day to deal with 
thepain. She also reports that her right leg sometimes swells.

 
Past Medical History:
arthritis
hypertension
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
EXAM ON DISCHARGE: 
A&OX3, BUE ___, radiculopathy improved, ? right foot drop but 
___ ___. sensation intace. Incision cd&i w dermabond. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ presented electively on ___ for micordisc of L5-S1. 
Her intraoperative course was uneventful, please refer to the 
intraoperative report for further details. She initially was 
going to be discharged home from PACU but the patient was 
experiencing "too much pain". She was then transferred to the 
neurosurgical floor for pain management. 
On ___, the patient remained neurologically and hemodynamically 
intact. She expressed readiness to be discharged home. She was 
ambulating without difficulty. All discharge instructions and 
follow up were given prior to discharge home. 
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN for fever or pain 
Please do not exceed more than 4 grams in 24hrs.  
2. Bisacodyl 10 mg PO/PR DAILY:PRN constipation 
3. Diazepam 2 mg PO Q8H:PRN muscle spasm 
___ cause some sedation please hold medication if sedation 
occurs.  
RX *diazepam 2 mg 1 by mouth Q 8hrs Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
5. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
Please do not drive or operate mechanical machinery while taking 
narcotics.  
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth Q 4hrs Disp #*60 
Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right L5-S1 Disc Herniation

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions

Spine Surgery without Fusion

Surgery
Your dressing may come off on the second day after surgery. 
Your incision is closed with dissolvable sutures underneath 
the skin and surgical glue. You do not need suture removal. 
Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site. 
Please avoid swimming for two weeks after suture/staple 
removal.
Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 

Medications
Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
You may take Ibuprofen/ Motrin for pain.
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain 
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace. 
Pain medications can cause constipation. 

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: PLASTIC
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
mangled right index and long fingers from a rock-crusher injury
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
1. Debridement, full-thickness skin and tendon right index and 
long fingers.
2. Application of VAC right index and long fingers.

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old gentleman who first presented to the 
ED ___ with mangled right index and long fingers after his 
hand got caught in a rock crusher at work.  He was taken to the 
___ ___ for open reduction, pinning, and full-thickness 
skin-grafting.  In clinic ___ it was noted that most of his 
skin graft had not taken, and that he would need to be taken 
back for debridement and revision of his skin grafts.
 
Past Medical History:
Otherwise healthy.
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory.
 
Physical Exam:
97.1 66 107/66 16 98% on RA
Gen - A&O x 3 NAD
Pulm - CTAB
CV - RRR
Abd - soft
RUE - skin defect 3x3 cm along ___ and ___ digit at base of 
phalange. wound vac in place, to suction
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was taken to the OR ___ for debridement and 
revision of his right index and long finger skin grafts.  
Intra-operatively it was determined that he would need extensive 
debridement and repair with free flaps.  The non-viable tissue 
was debrided and a wound vac was placed to the fingers.  He was 
admitted to the Plastic Surgery service for IV antibiotics and 
pain control.  He was given IV dilaudid with adequate pain 
control and transitioned to oral oxycodone POD 1.  He was given 
a regular diet immediately post-op, which he tolerated well.  He 
did not have any other health issues during his hospitalization. 
 He was discharged home on POD 2 with a wound vac and ___.  He 
is to keep the home wound vac placed at ___ by the plastic 
surgery team on until ___. he will have ___ go to his home 
and assure the vac is to suction. His vac will be changed this 
coming ___ and he will return next ___ for definitive 
repair of his wounds.
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day): Take this medication while you are using the 
narcotic pain medications.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain: Take stool softener while using this 
medication.
Disp:*80 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Cefadroxil 500 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a 
day: Take this medication while the wound VAC is in place.
Disp:*20 Capsule(s)* Refills:*1*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
___ Diagnosis:
Complex open wound secondary to crush injury right index and 
long fingers

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Elevate your right hand above your heart as much as possible.
2. No heavy lifting or strenuous activity until your follow-up 
appointment.
3. Keep your wound vac in place at all times.
4. Take your pain medications and antibiotics as prescribed.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
multinodular goiter
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Total thyroidectomy, transplant left lower parathyroid to left 
sternocleidomastoid.

 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ year old woman with history of multinodular goiter 
with some pressure symptoms. The symptoms are persistent and she 
cannot sleep in certain positions as a result. 

FNA of one dominant nodule near the isthmus was benign. There is 
no known family history of thyroid malignancy or other endocrine 
neoplasia. There is no history of exposure to low dose ionizing 
radiation such as was formerly used for thymic enlargement, 
acne, ringworm, or chronic tonsillitis. 

The patient is otherwise well.  She has had back surgery in ___ 
and that went well.

 
Past Medical History:
Pmhx: multinodular goiter,arthritis, migraines, hypertension, 
bipolar with paranoid delusions

pshx: microdisketectomy ___

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
There is no known family history of thyroid malignancy or other 
endocrine neoplasia.
 
Physical Exam:
GEN: A&O, NAD
HEENT: No scleral icterus, mucus membranes moist, incision site 
c/d/i, no surrounding erythema or swelling
CV: RRR, No M/G/R
PULM: Clear to auscultation b/l, No W/R/R
ABD: soft, nondistended, nontender, no rebound or guarding 
Ext: No ___ edema, ___ warm and well perfused
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 01:30PM BLOOD Calcium-8.5
___ 05:30AM BLOOD Albumin-3.6 Calcium-7.7*
___ 09:30AM BLOOD PTH-22
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a ___ year old woman with history of symptomatic 
multinodular goiter who presented on ___ and underwent 
total thyroidectomy, parathyroid autotransplantation. Reader is 
referred to the operative note for details of surgery. The 
patient was transferred to the recovery unit and admitted to the 
floor overnight for observation.

Neurological: The patient had adequate pain control and was 
transitioned to oral pain medication.
Cardiovascular: The patient remained stable from a cardiac 
standpoint.
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint. Gastrointestinal: The patient diet was advanced from 
clears to regular which was tolerated well.
Genitourinary: The patient voided without difficulty and had 
adequate urine output.
ID: The patient remained afebrile and her surgical site had no 
evidence of infection.
Endocrine:POD 1, serum calcium level was 7.8. She was started on 
calcium and vitamin D supplement. She denied any perioral or 
extremity paresthesia. Her repeat calcium in the afternoon was 
normal 8.5.
At time of discharge,the patient was stable, tolerating an oral 
diet, and voiding appropriately. She was discharged home with 
explicit follow-up instructions and verbalized good 
understanding.
 
Medications on Admission:
 amlodipine 5' (not taking other medications prescribed)

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
multinodulat goiter with symptoms

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You were admitted to the inpatient general surgery unit after 
your total thyroidectomy. You have adequate pain control and 
have tolerated a regular diet and may return home to continue 
your recovery. 
You will be discharged home on thyroid hormone replacement, 
calcium and vitamin D supplement, please take as prescribed. 
Monitor for  symptoms of low Calcium such as numbness or 
tingling around mouth/fingertips or muscle cramps in your legs. 
If you experience any of these symptoms please call Dr. 
___ for advice or if you have severe symptoms go 
to the emergency room. 
Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication and take any new 
medications as prescribed. You will be given a prescription for 
narcotic pain medication, take as prescribed. It is recommended 
that you take a stool softener such as Colace while taking oral 
narcotic pain medication to prevent constipation. You may also 
take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as directed, but do not exceed 4000 
mg in one day. Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk 
several times per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. 
Please call your surgeon or go to the emergency department if 
you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the 
incision site. You may shower and wash incisions with a mild 
soap and warm water. Avoid swimming and baths until cleared by 
your surgeon. Gently pat the area dry. You have a neck incision 
with steri-strips in place, do not remove, they will fall off on 
their own.

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

sternocleidomastoid.
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ year old woman with history of multinodular goiter
with some pressure symptoms. The symptoms are persistent and she
cannot sleep in certain positions as a result.
FNA of one dominant nodule near the isthmus was benign. There is
no known family history of thyroid malignancy or other endocrine
neoplasia. There is no history of exposure to low dose ionizing
radiation such as was formerly used for thymic enlargement,
acne, ringworm, or chronic tonsillitis.
The patient is otherwise well. She has had back surgery in ___
and that went well.
Past Medical History:
Pmhx: multinodular goiter,arthritis, migraines, hypertension,
bipolar with paranoid delusions
pshx: microdisketectomy ___
Social History:
___
Family History:
There is no known family history of thyroid malignancy or other
endocrine neoplasia.
Physical Exam:
GEN: A&O, NAD
HEENT: No scleral icterus, mucus membranes moist, incision site
c/d/i, no surrounding erythema or swelling
CV: RRR, No M/G/R
PULM: Clear to auscultation b/l, No W/R/R
ABD: soft, nondistended, nontender, no rebound or guarding
Ext: No ___ edema, ___ warm and well perfused
Pertinent Results:
___ 01:30PM BLOOD Calcium-8.5
___ 05:30AM BLOOD Albumin-3.6 Calcium-7.7*
___ 09:30AM BLOOD PTH-22
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a ___ year old woman with history of symptomatic
multinodular goiter who presented on ___ and underwent
total thyroidectomy, parathyroid autotransplantation. Reader is
referred to the operative note for details of surgery. The
patient was transferred to the recovery unit and admitted to the
floor overnight for observation.
Neurological: The patient had adequate pain control and was
transitioned to oral pain medication.
Cardiovascular: The patient remained stable from a cardiac
standpoint.
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary
standpoint. Gastrointestinal: The patient diet was advanced from
clears to regular which was tolerated well.
Genitourinary: The patient voided without difficulty and had
adequate urine output.
ID: The patient remained afebrile and her surgical site had no
evidence of infection.
Endocrine:POD 1, serum calcium level was 7.8. She was started on
calcium and vitamin D supplement. She denied any perioral or
extremity paresthesia. Her repeat calcium in the afternoon was
normal 8.5.
At time of discharge,the patient was stable, tolerating an oral
diet, and voiding appropriately. She was discharged home with
explicit follow-up instructions and verbalized good
understanding.
Medications on Admission:
amlodipine 5' (not taking other medications prescribed)
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
multinodulat goiter with symptoms
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You were admitted to the inpatient general surgery unit after
your total thyroidectomy. You have adequate pain control and
have tolerated a regular diet and may return home to continue
your recovery.
You will be discharged home on thyroid hormone replacement,
calcium and vitamin D supplement, please take as prescribed.
Monitor for symptoms of low Calcium such as numbness or
tingling around mouth/fingertips or muscle cramps in your legs.
If you experience any of these symptoms please call Dr.
___ for advice or if you have severe symptoms go
to the emergency room.
Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically
advised not to take a particular medication and take any new
medications as prescribed. You will be given a prescription for
narcotic pain medication, take as prescribed. It is recommended
that you take a stool softener such as Colace while taking oral
narcotic pain medication to prevent constipation. You may also
take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as directed, but do not exceed 4000
mg in one day. Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk
several times per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.
Please call your surgeon or go to the emergency department if
you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the
incision site. You may shower and wash incisions with a mild
soap and warm water. Avoid swimming and baths until cleared by
your surgeon. Gently pat the area dry. You have a neck incision
with steri-strips in place, do not remove, they will fall off on
their own.
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care.
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: PLASTIC
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
traumatic hand injury
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ - temporal-parietal fascial flap revision/STSG
 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old gentleman who first presented to the 

ED ___ with mangled right index and long fingers after his 
hand got caught in a rock crusher at work.  He was taken to the 
OR ___ for open reduction, pinning, and full-thickness 
skin-grafting.  In clinic ___ it was noted that most of his 
skin graft had not taken, and that he would need to be taken 
back for debridement and revision of his skin grafts.  Went to 
OR ___ for debridement and revision of his right index and 
long finger skin grafts.  Intra-operatively it was determined 
that he would need extensive debridement and repair with free 
flaps.  The non-viable tissue was debrided and a wound vac was 
placed to the fingers.
 
Past Medical History:
Otherwise healthy.
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory.
 
Physical Exam:
97.9 65 108/71 18 97% RA
Gen - A&O x 3, NAD
Pulm - CTAB
CV - rrr
Abd - soft NTND
Extrem - LUE w/ cast covering digits ___ in place. Sensation and 
motor function intact
LLE - splint in place, sensation and motor intact, good cap 
refill

 
Pertinent Results:
none
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ and had the following procedures: Debridement right 
index and long fingers; Free vascularized temporal parietal flap 
transfer to right hand; Neuroplasty right long finger; 
Split-thickness skin graft to right hand (plantar surface of 
foot donor site); Application short-leg splint; Application 
short-arm splint. The patient tolerated the procedure well. 

After the procedure his distal LUE pulses were monitored 
routinely and were dopplerable throughout his hospital stay. 
Sensation and perfusion to the affected fingers was also intact 
throughout his hospital stay. He was taken to the OR on POD 7 
for a dressing change and on POD 8 a walking cast was placed to 
ease ambulation once the patient was sent home.

Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received Dilaudid IV/PCA 
with good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral 
intake, the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications. 

CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored. 

Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.

GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake. His diet was advanced when appropriate, 
which was tolerated well. Foley was removed on POD#1. Intake and 
output were closely monitored. 

ID: Post-operatively, the patient was started on IV cefazolin, 
which was continued throughout his stay. The patient's 
temperature was closely watched for signs of infection. 

Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin during 
this stay, and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as 
possible. 

At the time of discharge on POD#8, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 
hours) as needed for pain for 14 days: Please do not drive while 
taking this medication. .
Disp:*100 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day for 
14 days: Please take to prevent constipation while taking pain 
medication.
Disp:*28 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Augmentin 875-125 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a 
day for 6 days.
Disp:*12 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Aspirin 162 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO once a day for 1 months.
Disp:*30 Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.)(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
crush injury

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Return to the ER if:
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you.
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds as ordered.
* Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber.
* No strenuous activity 
* No pressure or weight bearing pressure on your right hand 
until you return to clinic in 2 weeks.
* Okay to shower, but no baths until after directed by your 
surgeon, please keep the casts dry

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Home

Acute appendicitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were hospitalized with appendicitis requiring an operation 
to remove your appendix. You have done well following your 
surgery and now being discharged home with the following 
instructions:

You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain from 
your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and 
impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate 
machinery safely. You MUST  refrain from such activities while 
taking these medications. 

 

 

Please call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you 
have any of the following:
 

 * You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
 tightness.
 
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
 medications.
 
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
 diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
 mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
 
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
 bowel movement.
 

* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
 degrees or 38(C) degrees.
 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
 concern you. 
 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
 as ordered.  

Activity:
No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may 
resume moderate
exercise at your discretion, no abdominal exercises.

Wound Care:
You may shower, no tub baths or swimming. 

If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with 
clean, dry gauze. 
Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,  

You were admitted to the hospital for preterm contractions. You 
were given betamethasone, a steroid which helps the baby's lungs 
among other benefits. Your contractions and cervical exam 
remained stable and you are now safe to be discharged home.  
 Please call the office for:  
 - Worsening, painful or regular contractions  
 - Vaginal bleeding

intrauterine fetal demise
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
dilation and evacuation

 
History of Present Illness:
___ G3P1 @ ___ with fetus known to have cystic hygroma
presented to ___ for fetal survey and found to have fetal
demise. She reports having some cramping last week, but no
contractions, bleeding, vaginal discharge, or fever/chills.

 
Past Medical History:
PNC:
*) Dating: ___: ___ by ___
*) Labs: A+/Ab-/RPRNR/RI/HbsAg-/HIV-
*) Routine:
- Genetics: normal ___
- U/S: ___ US with cystic hygroma
*) Issues
- cystic hygroma: normal ___

POBHx: G3P1
-G1: ___, SAB
-G2: ___, pLTCS, elective for macrosomia on US
-G3 current
PGynHx: Denies STDs or abnl paps
PMH: denies
PSH: LTCS
Meds: PNV
All: bactrim (hives)

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
noncontributory
 
Physical Exam:
afebrile, vital signs stable
Gen: NAD, comfortable appearing, husband supportive
___: soft, nontender
Speculum exam: Smooth vaginal walls without discharge. No
cervical discharge or lesions.
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:10PM   WBC-8.0 RBC-4.14* HGB-12.0 HCT-34.1* MCV-82 
MCH-29.0 MCHC-35.2* RDW-13.7
___ 05:10PM   PLT COUNT-303
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service after 
undergoing placement of laminaria on ___ for an 
intrauterine fetal demise. She was monitored overnight and 
underwent dilation and evacuation on ___. Please see 
operative report for further details. 

Immediately following her procedure her pain was controlled with 
oral oxycodone, tylenol and ibuprofen and her diet was advanced 
without difficulty. By post-operative day 0 she was tolerating a 
regular diet, pain was controlled with oral medications, she was 
able to ambulate independently and voiding spontaneously. She 
was then discharged home on post-operative day 0 with outpatient 
followup.
 
Medications on Admission:
PNV
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
take with food 
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 6 hours Disp 
#*50 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth pain Disp #*50 
Tablet Refills:*0
3. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  5 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
do not drive or drink alcohol while using this medication 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 4 hours Disp #*10 
Tablet Refills:*0
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID:PRN constipation 
use while taking oxycodone to prevent constipation 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice daily 
Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0
5. Methylergonovine Maleate 0.2 mg PO TID Duration: 3 Days 
Please start this medication the morning of ___ 
RX *methylergonovine 0.2 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every eight (8) 
hours Disp #*9 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
intrauterine fetal demise

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecology service prior to your 
procedure. You have recovered well from the procedure and the 
team believes you are ready to be discharged home. Please call 
Dr. ___ office at ___ with any questions or 
concerns. Please follow the instructions below.

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 2 
weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Chief Complaint:
fever/chills

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Dilation and curettage

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo G3P1 POD ___ s/p D&E ___ for IUDF presenting with
fever/chills and abdominal pain. Since last night, she reports
feeling fatigue and malaise with worsening abdominal cramping
___ and chills. She reports temp to 101 today at home with some
nausea, non-productive cough, urinary frequency and 
constipation.
She reports only minimal vaginal spotting today, no clots. She 
is
tolerating reg diet at home. Denies dysuria, hematuria, 
diarrhea.
She is passing flatus but no BM. She has sick contacts at home
with flu like symptoms. Denies CP/SOB, palpitations, abnl 
vaginal
discharge, HA, or vision changes. 

 
Past Medical History:
POB: G3P1
- ___ SAB
- ___ primary elective cesarean section for macrosomia on
ultrasound, birth weight 3990g, no complications.
- G3: D&E at 17wks

PGYN:
- Menarche at age ___ with typically irregular menses.  
- STIs: denies
- Pap history: denies h/o abnormal Pap
- Last Pap: ___ at ___, negative
- Contraception: has used Mirena IUD 

PMH: denies, no HTN, DM, CAD

PSH: LTCS x 1

Medications: oxycodone, ibuprofen

ALLERGIES: Bactrim -> hives

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
noncontributory
 
Physical Exam:
On day of discharge:
afebrile, vital signs stable
Gen: NAD
CV: RRR
Pulm: normal work of breathing
Abd: soft, nondistended, appropriate TTP
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:18PM   WBC-7.6 RBC-3.95* HGB-11.2* HCT-32.6* MCV-83 
MCH-28.4 MCHC-34.4 RDW-14.9
___ 07:18PM   NEUTS-80.8* LYMPHS-14.9* MONOS-2.4 EOS-1.2 
BASOS-0.7
___ 07:18PM   PLT COUNT-245
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service 
after being diagnosed with endometritis following D&E for IUFD 
on ___. She was started on ampicilin, gentamycin and 
clindamycin. On ___ she underwent dilation and curettage for 
hematometra vs retained products of conception. Please see the 
operative report for full details.

Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. Immediately 
post-op, her pain was controlled with percocet and ibuprofen. 
Her antibiotics were continued until she was afebrile for 48 
hours.

On post-operative day 1, her urine output was adequate so her 
foley was removed and she voided spontaneously. Her diet was 
advanced without difficulty.

By post-operative day 2, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, afebrile and 
pain was controlled with oral medications. She was then 
discharged home in stable condition with outpatient follow-up 
scheduled.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain 
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) hours 
Disp #*45 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Endometritis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the GYN service for treatment of your 
infection. You received 48 hours of antibiotics and had another 
procedure (D+C) to do this. After finishing treatment, the team 
felt like you are ready to go home. Please follow discharge 
instructions carefully. 

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 2 
weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 2
weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.
To reach medical records to get the records from this
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
Followup Instructions:
___

Left knee pain

___: Left knee arthroscopy, chondroplasty, sub-total medial 
meniscectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ presents with left knee pain. Found to have large medial 
femoral condyle osteonecrosis lesion and scheduled for 
arthroscopic debridement and chondroplasty with planned postop 
admission for ___ evaluation and placement. 
 
Past Medical History:
1. Gout/Pseudogout
2. Colitis
3. OA
4. Osteoporosis
5. Hypercholesterolemia
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Daughter with acetylcholinesterase deficiency
 
Physical Exam:
Well appearing female, NAD, A/Ox3
LCTA bilaterlly
RRR, no murmurs
Abd soft, NTND
BLE fully NVI distally, no edema
Left knee with small effusion, pain w/ weight bearing and ROM, 
mild crepitus, stable to varus/valgus stresses.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Orthopaedic Surgery Service on 
___ and taken to the operating room by Dr. ___ a left 
knee arthroscopy and chondroplasty. The procedure was without 
complication and she was transferred to the PACU following 
surgery then subsequently to the orthopaedic floor in a stable 
condition. She was placed in TEDS/pneumoboots and started on 
Aspirin postop for DVT prophylaxis. Physical Therapy and 
Occupational Therapy were consulted and saw the patient for 
post-op functional evaluation. Diet was advanced as tolerated 
and IVF were discontinued when tolerating oral diet. 
 
Medications on Admission:
1. MVI QD
2. Aspirin 81 mg QD
3. Atorvastatin 10 mg QD
4. Evista 60 mg QD
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours).  
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
3. Hexavitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Cap PO DAILY (Daily).  
4. Aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable 
PO DAILY (Daily).  
5. Magnesium Hydroxide 400 mg/5 mL Suspension Sig: Fifteen (15) 
ML PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for constipation.  
6. Bisacodyl 10 mg Suppository Sig: One (1) Suppository Rectal 
HS (at bedtime) as needed for constipation.  
7. Atorvastatin 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
8. Evista 60 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO QD (): 60mg.  
9. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left knee osteonecrosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Touch down weight bearing only to LEFT leg. No ROM 
restrictions to left knee. 
2. Okay to remove dressings and get wounds wet starting 3 days 
after surgery. 

Physical Therapy:
TDWB only to LLE. No ROM restrictions. OOB as tolerated with 
assistance. No brace needed. 
Treatments Frequency:
Removal of knee suture will be performed at follow up 
appointment
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Gluten
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
BPH
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
PVP
 
History of Present Illness:
Meds- flomax, proscar, vytorin
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to Urology service after greenlight 
vaporization of the prostate. No concerning intraoperative 
events occurred; please see dictated operative note for details. 
He patient received ___ antibiotic prophylaxis. 
Patient's postoperative course was uncomplicated. He received 
intravenous antibiotics and pyridium, maintained on bedrest and 
continous bladder irrigation overnight. On POD1, the CBI and 
foley catheter were discontinued, and he passed a voiding trial. 
 His urine was clear yellow without clots with post-void 
residual less than voided volumes. He remained afebrile 
throughout his hospital stay.  At discharge, patient's pain well 
controlled with oral pain medications, tolerating regular diet, 
ambulating without assistance, and voiding without difficulty. 
He is given pyridium and oral pain medications on discharge, 
without antibiotics. He is given explicit instructions to call 
for follow-up.

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain.  
3. Tamsulosin 0.4 mg Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr PO HS (at bedtime).
Disp:*30 Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr(s)* Refills:*2*
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day): while taking narcotics.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
BPH
 
Discharge Condition:
stable
 
Discharge Instructions:
No vigorous physical activity for 2 weeks. Expect to see 
occasional blood in your urine and to experience urgency and 
frequecy over the next month. You may shower and bathe normally. 
 Do not drive or drink alcohol if taking narcotic pain 
medication.  Resume all of your home medications, but please 
avoid aspirin/advil for one week.   Call Dr. ___ 
(___) for follow-up AND if you have any questions (page 
Dr. ___ at ___.  If you have fevers > 101.5 F, 
vomiting, severe abdominal pain, or inability to urinate, call 
your doctor or go to the nearest emergency room.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Gluten
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
SBO with ? closed loop obstruction

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Exploratory laparotomy, lysis of adhesions,
untwisting of the bowel.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ M s/p PVP of prostate ___, in good health until this
morning at 7am when, after eating, he developed crampy
epigastric/upper abdominal pain with sharp, knife-life pains 
that
were constant and progressive. + n/v x many (ending in bilious),
no f/c, no dysuria/diarrhea, last flatus/BM this am. CT A/P 
shows
closed loop obstruction in midjejunum with mesenteric edema, no
free air/pneumotosis

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: HTN, dyslipidemia, celiac dz, dermatitis herpetiformis, h/o
H.Pylori with gastric ulcers in past

PSH: Rt IHR ___ yrs ago, Lt knee arthroscopy, PVP last week

 
Social History:
ex-smoker, 30packyr history
 
Physical Exam:
V - 
A/O x 3, mod distress
RRR
CTAB
distended, + TTP LUQ and diffusely, no masses/HSM, well healed 
Rt
groin scar

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 12:50PM BLOOD WBC-15.8*# RBC-4.93 Hgb-15.1 Hct-43.9 
MCV-89 MCH-30.7 MCHC-34.4 RDW-13.2 Plt ___
___ 06:05AM BLOOD WBC-9.2 RBC-4.04* Hgb-12.2* Hct-36.1* 
MCV-89 MCH-30.2 MCHC-33.9 RDW-13.0 Plt ___
___ 06:05AM BLOOD Glucose-108* UreaN-23* Creat-1.1 Na-139 
K-4.6 Cl-104 HCO3-28 AnGap-12
___ 06:05AM BLOOD Calcium-8.6 Phos-3.0 Mg-1.9
.
Radiology Report CT ABDOMEN W/CONTRAST Study Date of ___ 
2:28 ___ 
IMPRESSION: 
1. Small-bowel obstruction, with appearance concerning for 
closed loop 
obstruction of jejunum and resulting mesenteric edema. This 
indicates risk 
for developing ischemia. 
2. No free air, pneumatosis, or portal venous gas. 
3. Post-surgical change involving the prostate. 
4. Hypoattenuating lesion in liver, too small to characterize. 
5. Bladder wall thickening. 
.
 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ yo male with acute onset of abdominal pain earlier 
today.
He was evaluated in the emergency room and had a CT scan that
demonstrated what was thought to be closed loop obstruction.
General surgery consult was obtained. He was offered surgical 
intervention.

He went to the OR on ___ for Exploratory laparotomy, lysis of 
adhesions,
untwisting of the bowel.

He was NPO, IVF, NGT. The NGT was removed and we awaited return 
of bowel function. On POD 4 he had post-op emesis and a NGT was 
replaced. He also had low urine output, and was bolused for 
post-op hypovolemia.

He reported flatus and the NGT was again removed. His diet was 
advanced on POD 6 after BM x 3. He was tolerating a regular 
diet. His abdomen was soft and nontender. Staples were in place 
and incision was C/D/I.

 
Medications on Admission:
flomax 0.4 mg qday,  vytorin ? dose

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Tamsulosin 0.4 mg Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr PO HS (at bedtime).  
2. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed.  
3. Hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 
hours) as needed.
Disp:*25 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Small-bowel obstruction with closed loop obstruction secondary 
to adhesions.

 
Discharge Condition:
Good

 
Discharge Instructions:
General:
Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the 
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea 
or other reasons. 
* Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid heartbeat or 
feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
* Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or 

back.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
.
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
as ordered. 
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.
* Avoid lifting objects > 5lbs until your follow-up appointment 
with the surgeon.
* Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.
.
Incision Care: 
-Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
-You may shower, and wash surgical incisions.
-Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
-Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted into the antepartum service for 
observation following her episode of vaginal bleeding. She had 
reassuring fetal testing. She had a scan performed at the ___ 
for maternal fetal medicine, which revealed persistence of her 
marginal previa. There was otherwise normal fetal testing. She 
was observed in house until her bleeding resolved. She was 
discharged home in good condition after her bleeding ceased. She 
was asked to have a modified bed rest at home and complete 
pelvic rest. She had adequate follow up in place.

prenatal vitamins

None

Home

Marginal placenta previa

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

You were admitted into the antepartum service for vaginal 
bleeding. You have since stopped bleeding and the team feels 
safe that you can be discharged home.

*) Please go home on bedrest and pelvic rest i.e nothing in your 
vagina, no sex and no tampons.
*) Please keep your follow up appointment with Dr. ___
*) Please keep all your ultrasound appointments

red blood soaked through her underwear, and on her way here she 
used 1 pad and passed 1 golf ball size clot. She denies abd 
trauma/intercourse, abd pain, ctxs, LOF. Reports AFMs. She 
denies dizziness, SOB, CP. Last PO intake was 1 ___.

Labs: A+/Ab-/RPR NR/HepB Ag neg/RI/HIV neg/Varicella immune

=121 and 2hr =89
Issues: marginal anterior placenta previa, most recent EFW 
2874g, 67% ___. Breech

PSHx: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy, osteochondroma on arm

Pertinent Results:
___ 05:55PM   ___ 05:55PM   ___ PTT-26.5 ___

___ 05:55PM   WBC-12.9* RBC-3.97* HGB-11.4* HCT-33.4* 
MCV-84 MCH-28.7 MCHC-34.0 RDW-14.___ y/o G3P2 with marginal previa admitted at 35w5d after her 
second episode of vaginal bleeding. On arrival, she was 
hemodynamically stable and without any active bleeding on exam. 
Her cervix was visually closed. Her hematocrit was stable (33) 
and coags were within normal limits. Fetal testing was 
reassuring. She was closely monitored on labor and delivery and 
her bleeding resolved. She was transferred to the antepartum 
floor for hospitalized bedrest with plans for delivery on ___. 
She remained clinically stable on the antepartum service.
.
She was transferred to labor and delivery on ___ for her 
scheduled cesarean section at 36w4d. She had an uncomplicated 
primary low transverse cesarean section and delivered a liveborn 
female infant from breech presentation, weighing 6 pounds 5 
ounces and with apgars of 8 and 9. Please see operative report 
for details.
.
Ms ___ had an uncomplicated postoperative course and was 
discharged home on POD#4.

prenatal vitamins

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
s/p c/s at 36+ weeks due to placenta previa and antenatal 
bleeding
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
f/u 6 weeks

___

floor where she remained stable.   Her diet was gradually 
advanced. Her pain is controlled with an oral regiment.  She is 
ambulatory  ad lib.   She worked with physical therapy who 
cleared her for home without ___ services on POD # 5.  Follow-up 
has been arranged in 2 weeks for staple removal.
 
Medications on Admission:
___:  
lisinopril 40', simvastatin 20', tylenol prn  

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q6H:PRN PAIN 
2. Famotidine 20 mg PO BID 
RX *famotidine 20 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice daily Disp #*30 
Tablet Refills:*0
3. Lisinopril 40 mg PO DAILY 
4. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN PAIN 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 4 hours as 
needed Disp #*50 Tablet Refills:*0
5. Simvastatin 20 mg PO DAILY 
6. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
7. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
over the counter. 
8. Milk of Magnesia 30 mL PO Q6H:PRN constipation 
over the counter 
9. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN constipation 
over the counter 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right renal artery aneurysm

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Mrs. ___,

___ was a pleasure taking care of you here at ___ 
___. You were admitted to our institution 
after undergoing an extensive surgery to repair the aneurysm in 
your right renal artery. You tolerated the procedure well and 
have since recovered from it nicely. We now feel safe 
discharging home, provided you follow these recommendations.

Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery
Renal Artery Aneurysm Surgery Discharge Instructions

WHAT TO EXPECT:
1. It is normal to feel weak and tired, this will last for ___ 
weeks 
You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
You may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!

2. It is normal to have incisional swelling:
Wear loose fitting clothing (this will be less irritating to 
incision) 

3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some weight 

Eat small frequent meals
It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication
Take all the medications you were taking before surgery, unless 
otherwise directed

ACTIVITIES:
No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications
You should get up every day, get dressed and walk, gradually 
increasing your activity
You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!
No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
You may shower (let the soapy water run over incision, rinse 
and pat dry)
Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
codeine / preservatives in eye drops / adhesive
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Abdominal pain, nausea and fever
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ who recently underwent resection of a right renal artery 
aneurysm with EIA to RRA BPG with dacron presented to OSH with 
nausea, pain and fever and was found to have an infarcted right 
kidey on CT scan. She was transferred to ___ for further 
management.
 
Past Medical History:
high cholesterol, hypertension, obesity 

 
Physical Exam:
PE: 98.5 93  130/63  13 95% RA
AOx3 NAD
RRR S1S2
Lungs clear
Abdomen soft, non tender to palpation, right flank incision well 
healed
Ext without edema

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:20AM BLOOD WBC-11.5* RBC-3.26* Hgb-9.8* Hct-30.2* 
MCV-93 MCH-30.1 MCHC-32.6 RDW-13.2 Plt ___
___ 07:20AM BLOOD Glucose-104* UreaN-11 Creat-0.8 Na-140 
K-4.3 Cl-102 HCO3-27 AnGap-15
___ 07:20AM BLOOD Calcium-9.2 Phos-3.2 Mg-2.2

ABDOMINAL CTA ___
1.  Infarcted right kidney with occlusion of the right renal 
artery and the graft extending from the right renal artery to 
the right external iliac artery. 
2.  No evidence of mesenteric vein thrombosis. 
3.  Thrombosed partially resected right renal artery aneurysm 
now measures 2.2 x 1.5 cm. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old woman who recently underwent resection of a right 
renal artery aneurysm with external iliac artery to right renal 
artery bypass graft using dacron presents to an OSH with sudden 
onset abdominal pain, nausea and fever and total infarction of 
the right kidney on CT. She was transferred to ___ for further 
evaluation and mangement.  

She was afebrile on arrival with a wbc of 19,000 so she was 
started on broad spectrum antibiotics.   Repeat CTA showed 
infarcted right kidney with occlusion of the right renal artery 
and the graft extending from the right renal artery to 
the right external iliac artery.   

Her pain and WBC slowly subsided so her antibiotics were 
discontinued.  Her kidney function and abdominal exam are now 
normal so she is being discharged to home.  She is ambulatory ad 
lib, tolerating a regular diet and pain free. 

She knows that her right kidney is now non function secondary to 
a lack of blood flow from the occlusion. She will followup with 
her local vascular surgeon in ___, Dr. ___. 

 
Medications on Admission:
1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H:PRN pain 
2. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
4. Famotidine 20 mg PO Q12H 
5. Lisinopril 40 mg PO DAILY 
6. Simvastatin 20 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H:PRN pain 
2. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
4. Famotidine 20 mg PO Q12H 
5. Lisinopril 40 mg PO DAILY 
6. Simvastatin 20 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Infarction of Right Kidney 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with nausea, abdominal pain 
and fever.  We did a CT scan that showed that the bypass graft 
that we recently did secondary to your renal artery aneurysm had 
occluded.  This means that there is no blood flow to your kidney 
and it is no longer functional.

Your blood tests to assess kidney function have remained normal 
meaning your remaining kidney is adequate to filter your blood.  
 

We do not need to follow up with Dr. ___ in ___ but 
should follow up with your local vascular surgeon, Dr. ___. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

total laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral salpingectomy, 
cystoscopy

 
Physical Exam:
Discharge physical exam
Vitals: VSS

Pertinent Results:

___ 10:24PM   estGFR-Using this

MCH-26.7# MCHC-31.4*# RDW-17.2* RDWSD-53.3*
___ 10:20AM   PLT COUNT-362
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service 
after undergoing total laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral 
salpingectomy Please see the operative report for full details.

Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. Immediately 
post-op, her pain was controlled with IV dilaudid, toradol.

On post-operative day 1, her urine output was adequate so her 
foley was removed with a trial of void and she voided 
spontaneously (backfilled 300cc, voided 280c, PVR 1cc). Her diet 
was advanced without difficulty and she was transitioned to 
oxycodone, acetaminophen and ibuprofen (pain meds).

By post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was 
controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home 
in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

 
Medications on Admission:
iron, colace
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice 
daily Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0 
2.  Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain 
take with food 
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 6 hours Disp 
#*50 Tablet Refills:*1 
3.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
do not drive or take with sedatives/ alcohol 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 4 hours Disp 
#*20 Tablet Refills:*0 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
hysterectomy, final pathology pending

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the gynecology service after your 
procedure. You have recovered well and the team believes you are 
ready to be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ office at 
___ with any questions or concerns. Please follow the 
instructions below.

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* If TLH/TVH: Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no 
sex) for 3 months.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No tub baths for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 6 
weeks.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No tub baths for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
left flank pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
cystoscopy, left ureteroscopy, left basketing of ureteral stone, 
left ureteral stent placement.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ on active surveillance for prostate cancer with Dr.
___ presents with acute onset left flank pain and chills.
The patient first noted pelvic pain, chills, and dysuria ___ 
days
ago and contacted Dr. ___. He was started on cipro
for possible prostatitis. He then developed acute onset left
flank pain last night at 6pm. The pain was achy in character,
constant, ___, and associated with nausea. He felt this pain 
was
similar to pain he experienced with his previous stone, so he
reported to the ED for evaluation. On his way to the ED at 11 pm
his pain resolved completely.  A UA shows 38 WBC and few
bacteria. A CT scan was obtained which showed a 4 mm obstructing
left UVJ stone. Urology was consulted for further management. He
does report continued dysuria but denies frequency, urgency,
hematuria. 

 
Past Medical History:
PMHx: Active surveillance for prostate cancer, recently found to
have 3+4 disease and is weighing treatment options. History of
sepsis following prostate biopsy in ___. He has passed one
kidney stone several years ago.
PShx: Appy in the ___, Knee surgery, and R ing hernia repair 15

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Fam:  NC

 
Physical Exam:
AVSS
NAD
WWP
Unlabored breathing
Abd soft, NT, ND
No CVA tenderness
Ext WWP, no edema
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 02:30AM BLOOD WBC-11.0# RBC-4.98 Hgb-14.7 Hct-41.8 
MCV-84 MCH-29.6 MCHC-35.2* RDW-13.9 Plt ___
___ 02:30AM BLOOD Glucose-192* UreaN-21* Creat-1.2 Na-137 
K-3.8 Cl-103 HCO___ AnGap-___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Urology service under Dr. 
___. He was made NPO, started on ceftriaxone, 
hydrated with IV fluid, pain was controlled, and he was given 
flomax. The patient did not pass the stone through HD1 and the 
morning of HD2. A KUB on HD1 confirmed the stone in the left 
hemipelvis, a repeat KUB on HD2 showed the stone had not 
advanced. He was taken to the operating room on HD2 for stone 
extraction, please see dicated operative report for details. The 
patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no signs of 
infected urine behind his obstruction. A stent was placed in his 
left ureter which will be removed next week. He was discharged 
after the procedure in stable condition, tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, and voiding without issues. He was given oral pain 
medications and 5 days of cipro. He will follow up with Dr. 
___ week.
 
Medications on Admission:
Zantac
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN for VAS ___. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
3. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 
4. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  5 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
5. Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H Duration: 5 Days 
6. Phenazopyridine 100 mg PO TID Duration: 3 Days 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left distal ureteral stone

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-No vigorous physical activity for 2 weeks.

-Expect to see occasional blood in your urine and to experience 
urgency and frequecy over the next month.

-You may have already passed your kidney stone, or it may still 
be in the process of passing.  You may experience some pain 
associated with spasm of your ureter.  This is normal.  Take 
Motrin as directed and take the narcotic pain medication as 
prescribed if additional pain relief is needed.  

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4.  
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.  Max daily 
Tylenol dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain medication also 
contains Tylenol (acetaminophen)

-Make sure you drink plenty of fluids to help keep yourself 
hydrated and facilitate passage of stone fragments.

-You may shower and bathe normally.

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, 
discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops.

-Resume all of your home medications, unless otherwise noted.

left flank pain
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
cystoscopy, left ureteroscopy, left basketing of ureteral stone,
left ureteral stent placement.
History of Present Illness:
___ on active surveillance for prostate cancer with Dr.
___ presents with acute onset left flank pain and chills.
The patient first noted pelvic pain, chills, and dysuria ___
days
ago and contacted Dr. ___. He was started on cipro
for possible prostatitis. He then developed acute onset left
flank pain last night at 6pm. The pain was achy in character,
constant, ___, and associated with nausea. He felt this pain
was
similar to pain he experienced with his previous stone, so he
reported to the ED for evaluation. On his way to the ED at 11 pm
his pain resolved completely. A UA shows 38 WBC and few
bacteria. A CT scan was obtained which showed a 4 mm obstructing
left UVJ stone. Urology was consulted for further management. He
does report continued dysuria but denies frequency, urgency,
hematuria.
Past Medical History:
PMHx: Active surveillance for prostate cancer, recently found to
have 3+4 disease and is weighing treatment options. History of
sepsis following prostate biopsy in ___. He has passed one
kidney stone several years ago.
PShx: Appy in the ___, Knee surgery, and R ing hernia repair 15
Social History:
___
Family History:
Fam: NC
Physical Exam:
AVSS
NAD
WWP
Unlabored breathing
Abd soft, NT, ND
No CVA tenderness
Ext WWP, no edema
Pertinent Results:
___ 02:30AM BLOOD WBC-11.0# RBC-4.98 Hgb-14.7 Hct-41.8
MCV-84 MCH-29.6 MCHC-35.2* RDW-13.9 Plt ___
___ 02:30AM BLOOD Glucose-192* UreaN-21* Creat-1.2 Na-137
K-3.8 Cl-103 HCO___ AnGap-___
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Urology service under Dr.
___. He was made NPO, started on ceftriaxone,
hydrated with IV fluid, pain was controlled, and he was given
flomax. The patient did not pass the stone through HD1 and the
morning of HD2. A KUB on HD1 confirmed the stone in the left
hemipelvis, a repeat KUB on HD2 showed the stone had not
advanced. He was taken to the operating room on HD2 for stone
extraction, please see dicated operative report for details. The
patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no signs of
infected urine behind his obstruction. A stent was placed in his
left ureter which will be removed next week. He was discharged
after the procedure in stable condition, tolerating a diet,
ambulating, and voiding without issues. He was given oral pain
medications and 5 days of cipro. He will follow up with Dr.
___ week.
Medications on Admission:
Zantac
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN for VAS ___. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID
3. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY
4. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain
5. Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H Duration: 5 Days
6. Phenazopyridine 100 mg PO TID Duration: 3 Days
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left distal ureteral stone
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
-No vigorous physical activity for 2 weeks.
-Expect to see occasional blood in your urine and to experience
urgency and frequecy over the next month.
-You may have already passed your kidney stone, or it may still
be in the process of passing. You may experience some pain
associated with spasm of your ureter. This is normal. Take
Motrin as directed and take the narcotic pain medication as
prescribed if additional pain relief is needed.
-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4.
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication. Max daily
Tylenol dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain medication also
contains Tylenol (acetaminophen)
-Make sure you drink plenty of fluids to help keep yourself
hydrated and facilitate passage of stone fragments.
-You may shower and bathe normally.
-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics
-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication,
discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops.
-Resume all of your home medications, unless otherwise noted.

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: PLASTIC
 
Allergies: 
___
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
right thumb abscess s/p I&D

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Incision and drainage of thumb abscess

 
History of Present Illness:
___ ___ manager at ___ at ___ developed swelling and pain on the palmar surface of
proximal phalanx of right thumb on ___, which worsened
over the ensuing days. He went to the ED at ___ on ___ where
he was found to have an abscess in that area that was I&D'd. He
had no fever or chills, WBC on ___ was 10 and X-ray of right
thumb showed no foreign bodies or fractures. He could not 
explain
how he contracted an abscess in his thumb. He was discharged on
duricef and bactrim for 7 days and to follow up with us.

 
Past Medical History:
none
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
n/c
 
Physical Exam:
AVSS

cellulitis much improved
packing removed
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 01:30PM BLOOD WBC-9.8 RBC-4.54* Hgb-13.3* Hct-38.3* 
MCV-84 MCH-29.4 MCHC-34.9 RDW-12.7 Plt ___
___ 01:30PM BLOOD Neuts-68.2 ___ Monos-7.0 Eos-2.6 
Baso-0.___ was admitted on ___ for right thumb abscess.  The abscess 
was lanced in the ED and cultures were sent.  Patient was 
started on broad IV antibiotic coverage and pain was controled 
with narcotic medications.  The thumb was packed with sterile 
dressing and regular iodine soaks were initiated.  Patient 
recovered without events and the antibiotics were tailored to 
treat MRSA when the sensitivies results came back.  The patient 
is being discharged on ___ afebrile, VSS, pain well controlled 
and cellulitis much improved.  Patient will continue Bactrim for 
an additional 7 days after discharge.
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole 160-800 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO BID (2 times a day) for 1 weeks: please finish 
antibiotic course even if you feel better.
Disp:*14 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Nicotine 14 mg/24 hr Patch 24 hr Sig: One (1) Patch 24 hr 
Transdermal DAILY (Daily) for 1 months.
Disp:*30 Patch 24 hr(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet 
PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain: do not drink alcohol, 
drive or operate heavy machinery while taking percocet.
Disp:*15 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right thumb abscess

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please take antibiotics for one week.  Please finish all 
antibiotcis prescribed
Keep hand in splint.
Please do warm soaks twice a day for one week

Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you.
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds as ordered. 
* Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Haldol
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Hand infection
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Incision and drainage
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo M w/PMHx sx for hepatitis C and IVDU who presents with 
hand swelling, fevers, and chills. Patient states that he was 
seen at ___ several days ago with similar symptoms, and was 
diagnosed with an abscess and had an incision and drainage 
performed. He then received vancomycin IV x 3 doses, followed by 
a full course of Bactrim that he completed at home. Last night, 
after finishing the last dose of Bactrim in the AM, he developed 
fevers, chills, diaphoresis and swelling and pain of the left 
hand, though not has bad as when he first presented to ___. He 
denies any trauma to the joint. 
.
ROS: Negative except as noted above.
 
Past Medical History:
Hepatitis C
IVDU
Right thenar abscess s/p I&D
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
VS: 98.6 BP 112/66 HR 91 RR 18 O2sat 97% RA
Gen: appears well
HEENT: MMM. No oral ulcers
Hrt: RRR. No murmurs
Lungs: CTAB no RRW
Abd: S/NT/ND. Normoactive BS.
Ext: WWP. Left hand is s/p I&D by plastics. +swelling and 
erythema. No areas of fluctuance. No lymphangitic streaking, no 
axillary LAD. Sensation to LT intact. 2+radial pulses. Strength 
symmetric. 
Neuro: Grossly intact. 
 
Pertinent Results:
138  ___   AGap=15 
------------ 
4.1  24  0.9 \ 
estGFR: >75 (click for details)  
CRP: 34.3
 83 
26.4 \ 12.4 / 259 
      ------
       35.3  
 N:88.3 L:6.9 M:4.0 E:0.4 Bas:0.4 
.
Hand x-ray: 
 
THREE VIEWS OF THE LEFT HAND: This exam is essentially normal. 
There is no 
fracture or malalignment and no bone destruction. Intercarpal 
alignment is 
maintained and normal joints. Equivocal soft tissue swelling 
dorsum. The fifth metacarpal has tiny mid shaft cortical 
exostosis/irregularity not felt to be of any significance. 
The study and the report were reviewed by the staff radiologist. 


 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ yo M w/hx IVDU and hepatitis C who presents 
with MRSA hand abscess, likely in the setting of IV drug use. He 
had his scar from prior incision and drainage unroofed by 
plastic surgery at bedside. There was no pus noted. He did have 
a fever, chills, and leukocytosis concerning for persistent 
infection, and he was started on vancomycin. He received two 
days of vancomycin, with good resolution of his leukocytosis. 
His wound cultures were negative at time of discharge. 
Occupational therapy was consulted, and did not feel that he 
needed a splint. His left arm was elevated. He was discharged 
home on a regimen of Bactrim and doxycycline to complete a 7 day 
course. He was initially given IV dilaudid for pain and 
transitioned to ibuprofen. He will follow up with his primary 
care doctor. He was felt by plastic surgery not to require 
outpatient follow up in plastic surgery clinic. 
.
For his polysubstance abuse, he was seen by social work. He will 
attend outpatient detox at the ___. He was placed 
on a nicotine patch during his admission. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Neurontin 100 mg tid
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Gabapentin 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO Q 8H (Every 
8 Hours).  
2. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 8 
hours) as needed for 5 days.  
3. Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole 160-800 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO BID (2 times a day) for 7 days.
Disp:*14 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Doxycycline Hyclate 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
Q12H (every 12 hours) for 7 days.
Disp:*14 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
1. MRSA hand cellulitis
2. Hepatitis C
3. Polysubstance abuse

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with an infection of your hand from MRSA. If 
you develop fevers, chills, numbness, tingling or increased 
swelling of your hand you should come to the emergency room or 
call your primary care doctor.
 
Followup Instructions:
___
