text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Vancomycin
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
L flank pain, low grade fevers
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
Dr. ___ is a ___ female
with a history of kidney stone disease status post recent
ureteral dilation and stone extraction on ___ for
obstructing stone in the left ureter.  She had a stone removed,
but had residual fragments and a stent was left in place.  Her
pain had been relatively well controlled with Motrin, Flomax, 
and
Tylenol, and intermittent oxycodone usage when not working. 
However, she reports that beginning this afternoon, she had
increasing flank pain and what she felt to be left flank
swelling.  She reports her pain radiates to her groin and down
her left leg.
  She denies any fevers or chills.  She reports nausea, no
vomiting.  She denies any dysuria, but has had frequency
following stent placement.  She notes persistent intrermittant
hematuria since stent placement.
  She has received 4mg morphine with improved pain control

MEDICATIONS:  As mentioned above in addition to Pyridium 

 
Past Medical History:
nephrolithiasis
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
noncontributory
 
Physical Exam:
PE
AVSS
Gen: NAD
Abd: soft, NT, ND
no CVAt
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:00PM BLOOD WBC-6.5# RBC-3.78* Hgb-11.3* Hct-34.3* 
MCV-91 MCH-30.0 MCHC-33.0 RDW-12.4 Plt ___r. ___ was admitted to Dr. ___ service after 
presenting to the ED with worsening L flank pain, low grade 
fevers and leukocytosis.  She was initially placed on borad 
spectrum IV antibiotics with a resulting improvement in her pain 
and decrease in her leukocytosis on HD#2.  She was afebrile 
throughout her hospital course and discharged in stable 
consition, tolerating a regular diet withotu nausea and 
vomiting.  She is discharged on a course of PO Bactrim with 
flomax and PO pain medication.  She will ___ with Dr. 
___ on ___ for stent removal.

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours).  
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO TID (3 
times a day).
Disp:*90 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Morphine 15 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Tamsulosin 0.4 mg Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*14 Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr(s)* Refills:*2*
5. Tolterodine 2 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day).
Disp:*10 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
6. Fluconazole 150 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day 
for 1 doses: to use for s/s of yeast infection.
Disp:*1 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
7. Bactrim DS 800-160 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a 
day for 10 days.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
UTI

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
-No vigorous physical activity for 2 weeks.
-Expect to see occasional blood in your urine and to experience 
urgency and frequecy over the next month.
-You may have already passed your kidney stone, or it may still 
be in the process of passing.  You may experience some pain 
associated with spasm of your ureter.  This is normal.  Take 
Motrin as directed and take the narcotic pain medication as 
prescribed if additional pain relief is needed.  
-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4.  
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.  Max daily 
Tylenol dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain medication also 
contains Tylenol (acetaminophen)
-Make sure you drink plenty of fluids to help keep yourself 
hydrated and facilitate passage of stone fragments.
-You may shower and bathe normally.
-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics
-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, 
discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops.
-Resume all of your home medications, unless otherwise noted.
-Call Dr. ___ for ___ for stent removal on 
___ AND if you have any questions.
-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, 
or inability to urinate, call your doctor or go to the nearest 
emergency room.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___.               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right Flank pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
R ureteral dilation and stent placement.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Admitted to Urology for pain control and attempted obstructing 
ureteral calculi removal. Multiple ureteral strictures prevented 
successful stone removal. A ureteral stent was placed. IVF 
given, pain control transitioned to oral regimen, Pt tolerating 
house diet. He will return for definitive therapy following 
dilation of ureter by stent in 2 weeks.  Pt given instructions 
for follow up care.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours).  
2. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every four (4) 
hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) for 15 days: Over the Counter.
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Ibuprofen 200 mg Tablet Sig: Three (3) Tablet PO four times a 
day for 7 days: Take with Food. Over the Counter (Advil/Motrin 
same as Ibuprofen).
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. Pyridium 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day as 
needed for burning urination, bladder pain: Will turn urine 
orange.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Obstructing Right Ureteral Calculi. Multiple Ureteral 
Strictures.

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
-You may take tylenol, motrin, and narcotic together for pain 
control.  Take ibuprofen (Advil/Motrin) with food to prevent an 
ulcer or upset stomach.

-You may shower, but do not tub bathe, swim, or soak for 2 
weeks.  

-No heavy lifting for 4 weeks (no more than 10 pounds)

-___ medical attention for fevers (temp>101.5), worsening pain, 
drainage or excessive bleeding from incision, chest pain or 
shortness of breath.

-Please do not drive or consume alcohol while taking pain 
medications.

-Call to schedule a follow up procedure to remove your stones.

- Follow up with your primary care doctor regarding your 
elevated blood sugars.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

you to go home. Please follow the instructions below:

 - Fever, chills  
 - Decreased fetal movement  
 - Other concerns

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted for nausea/vomiting and preterm
contractions on ___. She received Zofran and IVF with
improvement of symptoms. She also received IVF for her preterm
contractions. Her cervix was not dilated and her contractions
improved following IVF. She did not have any signs of vaginal
bleeding or rupture of membranes.
Patient also had known gestational hypertension. Her
pregnancy-induced hypertension labs, urine protein:creatinine
ratio, and 24-hour urine protein were within normal limits. She
remained asymptomatic, without severe range blood pressures,
headache, visual changes, chest pain, shortness of breath, or
RUQ pain. She was discharged home with precautions and close
follow-up.
Medications on Admission:
Medications:
- Fluoxetine 20mg
- Aspirin 81mg
- Ranitidine 150mg BID
Discharge Medications:
1. FLUoxetine 20 mg PO DAILY
2. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
gestational hypertension
pre-term contractions
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You were admitted to the hospital with elevated blood
pressures. Your blood pressures were monitored and remained
normal to moderately elevated giving the diagnosis of
gestational hypertension. Your urine collection indicated that
you do not have preeclampsia. We think it is now safe for you to
go home. Please follow the instructions below: - Attend all appointments and all fetal scans - Monitor for the following danger signs: - headache that is not responsive to medication - abdominal pain - increased swelling in your legs - vision changes - Worsening, painful or regular contractions - Vaginal bleeding - Leakage of water or concern that your water broke - Nausea/vomiting - Fever, chills - Decreased fetal movement - Other concerns
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the trauma surgery floor on the 
night of ___. After the accident, she also developed 
binocular diplopia in the upper visual fields with no evidence 
of anatomic abnormality. Ophthalmology was consulted and 
recommended out-patient follow up if the symptoms persist or 
fail to improve. Her R tib/fib fractures were evaluated and 
evaluated by orthopedic surgery to be stable. Physical therapy 
evaluated him and considered her safe to discharge home with 
crutches and with assistance from her boyfriend. She was 
discharged home on the afternoon of ___.
 
Medications on Admission:
None.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Vicodin ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Motor vehicle accident, human vs. car
Right lateral oblique tibial plateau avulsion fracture
Right fibula avulsion fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Hemodynamically stable, tolerating a regular diet, pain 
adequately controlled.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were brought to the hospital after being struck by a car, 
sustaining a right lateral oblique tibial plateau avulsion 
fracture and right fibula avulsion fracture.  You also developed 
double vision since the accident.  CT scans and X-rays of your 
head and body showed no evidence of other injuries.

The fractures of your right leg were evaluated by orthopedic 
surgery to be stable, meaning that you do not require surgery.  
The leg should be kept in a brace and you should walk with 
crutches, as recommended by physical therapy.  You may take 
medications as needed for pain and the leg may be wrapped snugly 
in Ace bandage and elevated for comfort.

Please do not drive, operate large machinery, or undertake 
strenuous physical activity while your diplopia persists and 
while your leg is still healing.  You may return to full 
activity when cleared by ophthalmology and orthopedic surgery.

If any symptoms worsen, or if you develop new symptoms such as 
sudden changes in vision, headache, dizziness, lightheadedness, 
imbalance, nausea, or vomiting, please return to the Emergency 
Room.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to Orthopaedic service following above 
listed procedure in stable condition.  Post-op course was 
uncomplicated.  She received routine post-operative pain control 
with IV and then po narcotics.  She received 48 hours of 
perioperative ancef for antibiotic prophylaxis.  She was made 
NWB to RLE initially in ___ braced locked at 30 degrees.  
Leg compartments were monitored and they remained soft without 
signs or symptoms of compartment syndrome.  On POD #2 long leg 
cast was applied with Dr. ___ present to insure slight 
flexion and valgus orientation of knee.  She was then mobilized 
with physical therapy remaining NWB on RLE. She was discharged 
to home in stable condition, afebrile and with pain well 
controlled once cleared from safety standpoint by physical 
therapy.
 
Medications on Admission:
sertraline 25 mg daily
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain, fever.

24H (Every 24 Hours) for 4 weeks.
Disp:*30 syringes* Refills:*0*
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
4. Sertraline 50 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
5. Hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*100 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right lateral tibial plateau fracture, fibular head fracture and 
lateral collateral ligament tear.

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
Call or return to ED for temp >101.5, increasing/intractable 
pain, any new weakness/numbness/tingling, chest pain/shortness 
of breath or any other emergently concerning symptoms.  Keep 
cast clean and dry.  Do not weightbear on operative extremity.  
Elevate right leg as much as possible.
Call office with 48 hours lead time for any narcotic 
prescription renewals as paper prescriptions require mailing.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

IMPRESSION:
1. No free air.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo F with a PMHx of rectosigmoid stenosis s/p resection and
colostomy whose course has been complicated by recurrent
abdominal pain s/p dialtion in ___ who on this hospitalization
presented with recurrent colonic/stoma stenosis. KUB was
unremarkable for obstruction and the patient underwent
dilatation of stoma stenosis by GI/ERCP service on ___. She
did not have any pain, bleeding or nausea afterward and was able
to tolerate a regular diet on discharge.
Medications on Admission:
Vitamine D
MVI
Colace
Discharge Medications:
1. multivitamin Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
2. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2
times a day).
3. Vitamin D Oral
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
colonic stenosis
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with adbominal pain, nausea and vomtting. You
had a procedure done to dilate your stoma which had "stenosed"
(closed up). This resulted in an improvement in your nausea and
abdominal pain.
If stoma stenosis reoccurs, you will need to have a repeat
colonoscopy for dilation.
Please do not take aspirin, coumadin, plavix, NSAIDS for 5 days.
If you notice abdominal pain, fever, bleeding from the stoma,
black stools please call Dr. ___.

text:
Name:  ___            Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Stomal stricture
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Colonoscopy with placement of metal stent
 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old woman presenting with recurrent 
stomal stricture.

She has a history of multiple abdominal surgeries with diverting 
colostomy (___) who subsequently developed severe stenosis of 
the stomal. Underwent dilation (Dr. ___ of the stomal site 
in ___. Readmitted in ___ and ___ with repeat 
dilations each time.

Patient reports continued pain and difficult stooling. Today 
underwent colonoscopy which showed severe stenosis of the stoma. 
The pediatric gastroscope was only minimally able to traversed. 
A biliary wire was then placed and a metal stent was placed 
under direct view. Afterwards, the patient developed severe pain 
at the stoma site and is being admitted for observation.

At present, the patient reports ___ pain, much improved 
compared to earlier.

ROS:
(-) fever/chills
(-) nausea/vomiting
(-) diarrhea
(-) BRBPR or melena
All other ROS negative
 
Past Medical History:
1. Diverting colostomy and previous stomal dilations (as noted 
in HPI)
2. Ovarian cyst status post removal
3. Injured ureter during hysterectomy status post left kidney 
removal

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Reports no history of GI problems.
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: HR ___, SBP 120s, SaO2 100% on room air
General: Comfortable
ENT: Dry MM
Eyes: No icterus
V: Regular; no murmurs; no edema
Pulm: Clear; comfortable; no rales
Abd: Soft; non-tender; ostomy with liquid stool and air
Skin: No rash
Neuro: Alert and fully oriented
Psych: Calm
 
Pertinent Results:
Colonoscopy: The stoma was severely stenotic. The pediatric 
gastroscope barely traversed. The proximal transverse colon was 
reached. The exam of the colon was normal. Because of the 
stenosis refractory to the maximum balloon dilation, a decision 
was made for a fully covered metal stent trial. A biliary wire 
was placed. The scope was withdrawn. A 20 mm x 60 mm fully 
covered Niti-S esophageal metal stent (Taewoong Medial; Ref: 
___) was successfully placed under direct view. The 
colostomy bag was reattached. Otherwise normal colonoscopy to 
transverse colon.

___ 07:10AM BLOOD WBC-4.1 RBC-4.02* Hgb-11.9* Hct-37.6 
MCV-94 MCH-29.6 MCHC-31.6 RDW-13.2 Plt ___
___ 07:10AM BLOOD Plt ___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Problems:
1. History of colon resection with colostomy complicated by 
recurrent stomal stricture
2. Abdominal pain, post-procedure

Plan:  Patient's diet was advance without difficulty, however, 
she had exquisite pain around the ostomy due to dilation.  She 
was seen by Dr. ___ prior to discharge and will be 
followed by their clinic in the outpatient setting.  She was 
given Oxycodone prn for pain.

 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Ostomy stricture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with ostomy stricture.  This was dilated by 
Dr. ___ with an indwelling stent.  You had pain from this 
procedure which is being treated with pain medications.  You are 
permitted to advance you diet to a normal diet. Dr. ___ 
will follow up with you in the near future to remove the stent, 
but for now it needs to stay in place
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___

Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: PLASTIC
 
Allergies: 
Sulfa (Sulfonamides) / Ciprofloxacin / Toradol / Darvon / 
Bactrim
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
breast infection
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
right breast capsulotomy and implant exchange

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with h/o brast CA underwent surgery in ___ and had b/l 
implants after b/l mastectomy.  Over the next few months 
developed increasing redness and induration of the right breast. 
 She was taken to the OR this admission for exchange of the 
implant and capsulotomy.  
 
Past Medical History:
see HPI
appendectomy
knee surgery
shoulder surgery
PTSD
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION
AVSS
NAD
RRR
right breast full, erythema, JP drain holding suction with 
serosang drainage.

AT D/C
AVSS
NAD
RRR
right breast with minimal erythema, none along the incision, JP 
SS drainage, breast nontender, good cap refill, no pus or 
drainage
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Went to the OR for implant exhange.  Had murky looking fluid 
suspicious for infection.  Started on Vanco post-op.  ID 
consulted.  They recommended continuing Vanco for 2 more weeks 
as our suspicion was high even though cultures were negative.  
Her diet was advanced, her pain was controlled.  She received a 
PICC line prior to discharge.  
 
Medications on Admission:
Wellbutrin, montelukast
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Vancomycin in Dextrose 1 gram/200 mL Piggyback Sig: One (1) 
gram Intravenous Q 12H (Every 12 Hours) for 2 weeks.
Disp:*28 gram* Refills:*0*
2. Heparin Flush 10 unit/mL Kit Sig: Two (2) ml Intravenous 
every twelve (12) hours for 2 weeks: flush after antibiotic 
given.
Disp:*28 syringes* Refills:*0*
3. PICC Line therapy
Please utilize PICC line management per NEHT protocol
4. Outpatient Lab Work
Weekly CBC with Diff, AST/ALT, BUN/Cr, and vancomycin trough 
(drawn ___ hour before dose)
5. Montelukast 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
6. Bupropion 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  


 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
implant associated breast infection

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
DIET: regular diet
ACTIVITY: light activity for now, no heavy lifting or exercise
DRAINS: cont your drain care, monitor outputs daily and record
MEDS: cont your home meds, cont Vancomycin IV for 2 weeks
CONCERNS: call if you experience increasing pain, redness, 
swelling, output from the drains, fevers, or chills
 
Followup Instructions:
___

to walk due to weakness along with shaking chills, unfortunately 
she did not take her temperature.

She was seen in ___ clinic the day prior to admission she felt 
better, however she was noted to have fever of 102.

vaginal candidasis which she's treating with milk? In the ED she 
had a vaginal exam which did not note any signs of fungal 
infection.

___ 1:58 am CATHETER TIP-IV      Source: right picc. 

   WOUND CULTURE (Pending): 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
1. Breast Erythema
- Concerning for ceullitis vs. deep abscess
- ID consultation was obtained
- Breast Ultrasound performed with small quantity of fluid 
aspirated from breast, gram stain no-organisms/WBC's
- No antibiotics consult
- Plastics consult
- Cultures of catheter tip and breast aspirate

2. Fever
- afebrile in house
- Concerning given PICC line and level of symptoms for central 
line infection
- Blood Cultures
- This would be also concerning given her history of rheumatic 
heart disease for endocarditis, lack of murmur, fever, 
leukocytosis
- ID consultation

3. Eosinophilia
- Drug reaction vs. primary eosinophilia
- Patient with extensive allergic history
- Allergy Medicine Consult, note to avoid vancomycin in future, 
if required then would reconsult Allergy.
- Entered as allergy
 
Medications on Admission:
Bupropion 75mg daily  
Montelukast 10mg daily  
Vancomycin 1g IV q12h
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Bupropion 100 mg Tablet Sustained Release Sig: One (1) Tablet 
Sustained Release PO QAM (once a day (in the morning)).  
2. Montelukast 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Erythema of the Breast
Possible Catheter Infection
Eosinophilia
Drug Reaction
 
Discharge Condition:
Good
 
Discharge Instructions:
Return to the hospital with fevers, nausea, vomitting, chills, 
worsening redness, breast pain, drainage from the breast
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Right hip surgical dislocation, head/neck osteochondroplasty
 
History of Present Illness:
onica is a very pleasant nearly ___ year old woman who is the 
director of patient care relations at ___.  She 
comes in today for consultation regarding her right hip pain.  
She reports ___ years of symptoms solely in her right hip.  She 
reports locking that happens occasionally, maybe once every few 
weeks.  At times, this causes her significant symptoms where she 
needs to shake her leg for a minute or 2 before she feels 
better.  Her pain is more activity-related and tends to come on 
half an hour to an hour after she walks for extended periods of 
time.  Sitting is not terribly symptomatic for her, but 
occasionally she does have symptoms when she gets up from the 
seated position.  She was previously an avid ___ and really 
has not been able to do this for a number of years.  She is able 
to do yoga and some light exercise activities including limited 
time on the treadmill.  She denies any previous trauma. 

 
Past Medical History:
non-contributory
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
none
 
Physical Exam:
On physical examination, ___ walks with a normal gait.  She 
has a normal stance.  Examination of the right hip, which is the 
symptomatic hip, reveals 90 degrees of hip flexion.  She comes 
to full extension.  In the flexed position, she has 30 degrees 
of external rotation and 10 degrees of internal rotation.  She 
has 30 degrees of external rotation in the extended position and 
20 degrees of internal rotation.  She abducts 30 degrees, 
adducts 10 degrees, has a straight-leg of 60 degrees and has a 
___ of 12 cm.  The ___ does cause some mild groin pain.  
On the right side, she has a positive impingement sign, which 
she says is exactly what she feels when she is having problems.  
She has a negative apprehension sign, negative posterior 
impingement sign, negative bicycle sign, and her piriformis is 
not too tender.  On the left side, she flexes to 90 degrees and 
comes to full extension.  In the flexed position, she has 25 
degrees of external rotation, 20 degrees of internal rotation.  
In the extended position, she has 30 degrees of external 
rotation and 20 degrees of internal rotation.  She abducts 30 
degrees, adducts 10 degrees, and has a straight-leg raise of 60 
degrees.  Her ___ is 15 and nontender on the left.  Her limb 
lengths are 83 cm bilaterally.  Her thigh circumference is 44 cm 
bilaterally.  Today, her height is 160 cm, her weight is 57.5 
kg, and her temperature is 36.8 degrees Celsius. 

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:42PM   WBC-10.9# RBC-3.38* HGB-10.0* HCT-31.3* 
MCV-93 MCH-29.6 MCHC-32.0 RDW-16.8*
___ 05:42PM   PLT COUNT-189
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient tolerated procedure well.  Pain control by PCA for 24 
hours.  Patient switched to PO pain meds once tolerating food.  
She progressed and passed ___ satisfactorily, and had no 
post-operative complications.

Ibuprofen PRN pain

Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

Disp:*84 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
6. Hydroxyzine HCl 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q 8H

Disp:*90 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

Home

Patient is a healthy ___ year old female with no significant past 
medical history that presented with a viral syndrome. Patient 
was seen in ___ and underwent influenza swab, which 
was negative. Since the patient is a ___ employee her swab is

on droplet precautions. In the mean time as per ___ 
guidelines, she is being discharged with a mask, told to stay at

viral illness, initial studies negative for influenza

stable, told to stay at home in self-quarnitine for five days,

return to work until the cultures come back. You will need to be

.

Tamiflu for four addtional days.
.

non-focal
 
Pertinent Results:
___ CT Head- Preliminary Report !! WET READ !!  
Heterogeneous left subdural hematoma could represent subacute or

Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted to the neurosurgery service for neurological 
observation. He was started on Keppra for seizure prophylaxsis. 
A repeat head CT was performed on ___ at 6AM. This was stable 
compared to the outside scan. He remained neurologically stable, 
pain was well controlled and he was tolerating a PO diet. He was 
cleared for discharge home at this time.
 
Medications on Admission:
PRN Ibuprofin

 
Discharge Medications:
1. levetiracetam 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
2. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q4H (every 4 
hours) as needed for headache.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
4. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. 
Tablet(s) 
5. butalbital-acetaminophen-caff 50-325-40 mg Tablet Sig: ___ 
Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for headache.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
chronic subdural hematoma

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
General Instructions

Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, or 
Ibuprofen etc. 
If you were on a medication such as Coumadin (Warfarin), or 
Plavix (clopidogrel), or Aspirin prior to your injury, do not 
resume taking these until cleared by your surgeon.
You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam), you will 
not require blood work monitoring.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: PODIATRY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Left foot fractures
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
s/p percutaneous pinning of fractures, left foot

 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ year old healthy male who presents from OSH ED
with multiple left foot fractures s/p fall from height around
1am. The pt states that after celebrating his birthday at a bar
drinking he jumped a fence that turned out to be a ~10 foot drop
onto a cement stairwell. He doesnt recall exactly how he landed
other than on his left foot falling to his back afterwards. He
has been unable to bear weight since. He was escorted home and
was shortly brought to his local ED due to severe left foot 
pain.
Pt was given ~16mg of morphine and multiple x-rays/ct scans were
performed. He was noted to have multiple fractures in his left
foot, including ___ metatarsal, medial cuneiform, and bases of
several metatarsals. Fractures of other parts of his body ie
ribs, spine, knee, ankle were ruled out prior to transfer. He 
was
transferred for podiatry evaluation. 

 
Past Medical History:
Denies
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
PHYSICAL EXAM
Appearance: NAD, AAO
HEENT: EOMI, PERRLA
CV: RRR, no M/R/G
Pulm: CTAB, no W/R/R
Abd: (+) BS soft/NT/protuberant
VASCULAR
Pedal Pulses:      [x] Palpable  [] Non-palpable [] Dopplerable
Sub-Papillary VFT: [x] < 3 sec.  [] > 3 sec. [] Immediate
Extremities:       [] pitting edema  [x] non-pitting edema left
foot
                   [] Anasarca
LYMPHATIC:         [] Lymphadenopathy [] Lymphangitis
NEUROLOGICAL:
Sensation:         [x] Intact  [] Absent
Proprioception:    [x] Intact [] Absent
MUSCULOSKELETAL:
Right Extremity:   [x] FROM  [] Decreased ROM /5
Left Extremity:    [] FROM  [x] Decreased ROM ___ due to pain
INTEGUMENT: Left foot shows significant dorsal edema with some
ecchymosis at the level of the forefoot. No open lesions noted.
No obvious clinical deformities noted. Sensation is intact to 
the
left foot. 

 
Pertinent Results:
LABORATORY RESULTS: 

___ 03:20PM BLOOD WBC-8.5 RBC-4.32* Hgb-12.4* Hct-36.9* 
MCV-86 MCH-28.8 MCHC-33.7 RDW-13.1 Plt ___
___ 06:45AM BLOOD WBC-7.6 RBC-4.37* Hgb-13.0* Hct-38.3* 
MCV-88 MCH-29.8 MCHC-34.0 RDW-13.5 Plt ___
___ 03:20PM BLOOD Glucose-80 UreaN-8 Creat-0.6 Na-139 K-3.6 
Cl-105 HCO3-24 AnGap-14
___ 06:45AM BLOOD Glucose-145* UreaN-10 Creat-0.8 Na-139 
K-4.9 Cl-105 HCO3-22 AnGap-17
STUDIES FROM OSH:
CT Left foot: Multiple fractures of the midfoot primarily
involving the metatarsals along with the medial cuneiform.
Left Tib/Fib XR and ankle XR: negative
CXR: no acute cardiopulmonary process. No rib fractures. 

STUDIES: 
___   Radiology FOOT AP,LAT & OBL RIGHT: There is no 
fracture or dislocation. Osseous mineralization and joint spaces 

are normal. 
.
___   Radiology FOOT AP,LAT & OBL LEFT: A fixation wire is 
visualized extending through the second metatarsal bone and the 
previously demonstrated fracture fragments are in near anatomic 
alignment. 
Other fractures are seen; a nondisplaced fracture of the 
proximal metatarsal of the fifth and third digits. A compression 
device with screws seen in the first metatarsal bone and in the 
talus is also noted. Some detail on certain views is lost by 
viewing through the plaster material. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old healthy male who was admitted to the 
podiatry service s/p closed reduction, percutaneous k-wire, and 
external monorail fixation placement for treatment of multiple 
left foot fractures. His pain was controlled with IV pain 
medications. He was evaluated by ___ and deemed safe to go home.  
He was given PO Dilaudid and PO Valium with instructions to 
follow up with Dr. ___ in 7 days with ___.
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day) as needed for constipation.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO q3 hours as 
needed for pain.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Diazepam 2 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for muscle spasm.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left foot fractures

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please resume all pre-admission medications.  If you were given 
new prescriptions, please take as directed.

Keep your dressing clean and dry at all times. You will have 
your dressing changed at your follow up visit.

You are to remain NON WEIGHT BEARING on your LEFT foot at all 
times with the assistance of crutches. 

Call your doctor or go to the ED for any increase in LEFT foot 
redness, swelling or purulent drainage from your wound, for any 
nausea, vomiting, fevers greater than 101.5, chills, night 
sweats or any worsening symptoms.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

    fixator.

 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ male who underwent a severe Lisfranc 
fracture dislocation, requiring immediate closed reduction and 
percutaneous pinning and stabilization with skeletal external 
fixator.  After the skin envelop had resolved and the edema had 
subsided appropriately, the plan was to proceed with an open 
reduction internal fixation. This was a planned staged 
procedure.
The patient tolerated the procedure well without complications. 
He was admitted post-operatively for pain control and bed rest.

of a lisfranc's fracture/dislocation and a ___ metatarsal 
fracture of his left foot. He tolerated the procedure well 
without complications. He was admitted post-operatively for pain 
control and bedrest. He remained afebrile with vital signs 
stable throughout his hospital course. Once he was tolerating po 
pain medications he was discharged home with po pain meds. He

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
sulfa antibiotics
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Hyperparathyroidism following prior total thyroidectomy.

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Removal of right-sided parathyroid gland.

 
History of Present Illness:
This patient is status post total thyroidectomy in the ___ for 
papillary thyroid cancer and presented with primary 
hyperparathyroidism, fatigue, memory issues, and some bone 
problems.  The patient was seen by Dr. ___ and ___ 
ultrasound was performed which was negative, and subsequently 
had a 4-D CAT scan, which showed an enlarged parathyroid in the 
right neck, between the esophagus and the spine.There was 
potentially a smaller gland of only 3 x 5 mm seen on the left 
side.The patient was seen by Dr. ___ reviewed Dr. ___. 
___ operative note from ___ in the 1980s,and only 2 upper 
glands were seen and no lower glands.Nevertheless, the fate of 
the lower glands was in doubt owing to the patient's 
multinodular goiter at the time. The patient presented today for 
a right neck exploration.

 
Past Medical History:
Osteoarthritis, hypothyroidism, hypercalcemia, 
hyperprolactinemia, hypercholesterolemia, thyroid cancer, 
hyperparathyroidism, essential thrombocythemia

PSH: Thyroidectomy, tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy.

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
Neuro:alert,oriented,NAD
Cardiac:RRR
Pulmonary:clear
Abdomen:soft NT/ND +BS
Incision:neck soft, steris c/d/i, no erythema, no edema
Extremities:warm well perfused, no ___ edema
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 09:00AM BLOOD ___-49
___ 04:30PM BLOOD ___-77*
___ 03:29PM BLOOD PTH-___*
___ 01:54PM BLOOD PTH-90*
___ 06:40AM BLOOD Calcium-10.0
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a right neck exploration and removal of 
right-sided parathyroid gland. The patient tolerated the 
procedure well and was transferred to the recovery room and 
admitted to the floor overnight.The patient hospital course was 
stable.
The patient had no perioral or lower extremity paresthesia. The 
neck remained soft and there were no signs of wound infection or 
hematoma. Postoperatively, the calcium and parathyroid hormone 
levels were monitored closely.The patient had good pain control 
and was transition to oral pain medication. Vital signs were 
routinely monitored and were stable.  The diet was advanced as 
tolerated. The patient was voiding without difficulty and 
ambulating independently. The patient was discharged home in 
good condition and will follow-up with Dr. ___.
 

 
Medications on Admission:
hydroxyurea 500 mg five times per week, Synthroid ___, ASA 81.

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-500mg) ___ TAB PO Q4H:PRN pain 

RX *hydrocodone-acetaminophen 5 mg-500 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth 
every six (6) hours Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Hydroxyurea 500 mg PO 5X/WEEK (___) 
3. Levothyroxine Sodium 100 mcg PO DAILY 
4. Oscal 1250 mg PO TID
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Hyperparathyroidism following prior total thyroidectomy.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the inpatient general surgery unit after 
your right neck exploration and removal of right-sided 
parathyroid gland. You have adequate pain control and have 
tolerated a regular diet and may return home to continue your 
recovery. 
You will be discharged home on calcium supplement(Oscal). Please 
purchase any OsCal brand tablet (including chewables) is 
acceptable. All of the OsCal products EXCEPT Ultra contain 500 
mg elemental calcium per tablet. Take 1 TABLET THREE times a day 
with food to improve absorption of calcium. Monitor for signs 
and symptoms of low calcium such as numbness or tingling around 
mouth/fingertips or muscle cramps in your legs. If you 
experience any of these signs or symptoms please call Dr. 
___ for advice or if you have severe symptoms go 
to the emergency room.Please go to any ___ lab and 
have your calcium level drawn on ___ Before 12:00 
___. If there is a need to change your calcium dose the ___ 
___ Endocrinologist will contact you.
Upon discharge,please resume all regular home medications, 
unless specifically advised not to take a particular medication 
and take any new medications as prescribed. You will be given a 
prescription for narcotic pain medication, take as prescribed. 
It is recommended that you take a stool softner such as Colace 
while taking oral narcotic pain medication to prevent 
constipation. You may also take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as 
directed, but do not exceed 4000 mg in one day. Please get 
plenty of rest, continue to walk several times per day, and 
drink adequate amounts of fluids. 
Please call your surgeon or go to the emergency department if 
you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the 
incision site.You may shower and wash incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water.Avoid swimming and baths until cleared by your 
surgeon.Gently pat the area dry.You have a neck incision with 
steri-strips in place, do not remove, they will fall off on 
their own.
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

oriented.
Cardiovascular:She was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint. 
Pulmonary: She did not encounter any respiratory issues.
GI/GU: She was given IV fluids until tolerating oral intake. Her 
diet was advanced from clears to regular which was tolerated 
well. She voided spontaneously after surgery and had good urine 
output.
Incision: The right axillary incision was clean dry and intact 
with no erythema or hematoma. The JP drain was intact to bulb 
suction with serosanguineous output. The drain will stay in 
place until follow-up appointment.
ID: The patient's temperature was closely watched for signs of 
infection of which there were none. 
Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin during 
this stay, and was encouraged ambulate as early as possible. 
At the time of discharge on POD#1, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled. She was discharged home in good condition and was 
comfortable with drain care and declined ___ service.
 
Medications on Admission:
Vicodin
colace

 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q4H (every 
4 hours) as needed for pain.  
2. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
3. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Infiltrating ductal carcinoma,right breast.

 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Personal Care: 
1. Please keep your right axillary incision clean and dry. 
2. Clean around the drain site(s), where the tubing exits the 
skin, with soap and water. 
3. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) ___ 
times per day. 
4. A written record of the daily output from your drain should 
be brought to every follow-up appointment. Your drain will be 
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to 
an acceptable amount. 
5. You may shower daily. No baths until instructed to do so by 
___
6. You may wear a soft, non-restrictive camisole but no tight or 
underwire bras. 

Activity: 
1. You may resume your regular diet. 
2. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in 
strenuous activity until instructed by your durgeon.
Medications: 
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered. 
2. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol 
for mild pain as directed on the packaging. 
3. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol. 
4. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking 
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softener if you wish. 
5. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber. 

Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following: 
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s). 
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s). 
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF 
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication. 

Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications. 
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you. 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 

DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS 
You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a 
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm 
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice 
a day. Try to empty the drain at the same time each day. Pull 
the stopper out of the drainage bottle and empty the drainage 
fluid into the measuring cup. Record the amount of drainage 
fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain suction.
 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Chief Complaint:
s/p assault with abdominal pain and nausea/vomiting
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ G4P3 at 7w4d presents with trauma and N/V. This began 
___ with altercation with FOB whereby he picked the 
patient up and threw her back/tailbone onto floor, and also 
slammed the left side of her ___ into a wall. Since that time 
she has had nausea with vomiting and has been unable to keep 
down food since ___. Last PO attempt yesterday, broth, 
vomited. Emesis nonbloody, nonbilious. No sick contacts. No 
emesis with prior pregnancies.

Also since ___: dizziness with extreme gaze to left or sudden 
___ turn to left. No LOC throughout. No vision changes, no 
hearing changes, no difficulty speaking or swallowing, no gait 
changes, no paresthesias, no coordination difficulties. Full 
range of motion including in neck.  

Following this incident on ___ patient called ___ 
(___) to arrange a safe house. ___ was planning to 
pick up patient on ___ afternoon to bring her to a safe 
house. Her children are staying with her mother but patient 
plans to pick them up on the way and bring them with her as she 
has custody of them. Pt now plans for ___ to pick her up at 
___ instead.

Today pt calls with continued N/V after FOB punched her in the 
lower abdomen. No vaginal bleeding or cramping. No dysuria or 
hematuria. No other trauma.

Pt's mother unaware of her location, patient states that she is 
"a snitch" and will not tell mother where she is now or when she 
gets to safe house.
 
Past Medical History:
PNC:
  -___ ___ by first trimester u/s
  -Labs: A+/abs-/RI/RPRNR/HBsAg-/HCV-/HIV-/GC-/CT-
 
OB Hx: 
- SVD x3, complicated by DV with SW involvement; no other
pregnancy complications; different FOBs
- G4 current: unplanned, ambivalent about keeping pregnancy; new
FOB
 
GYN Hx: 
- h/o gonorrhea, trichomonas, chlamydia, s/p treatments
- IUD placed ___ fell out ___

 
Social History:
Lives with FOB in his apartment. +DV as above. FOB not 
monogamous. Sometimes "gives in" to vaginal intercourse b/c 
easier than fighting, denies forced anal/oral intercourse. 
Children live with her mother, pt has custody of all of them. 
Smoked 1ppd until 1 wk ago, then 5cig/day. No tob since ___. 
Drank ETOH until late ___ when found out she was pregnant. Had 
"a sip" of liquor on ___ during altercation. Denies other 
ETOH during pregnancy. Denies illicits. 

 
Physical Exam:
T 97.4 HR 57 BP 91.57 RR 18 Sat 100%RA
Physical exam:
A&O, NARD
NCAT, no ___ lacerations
RRR
CTAB
abd soft +BS, mild TTP diffusely in lower abd, no R/G
No CVAT, mild TTP over sacrum in midline
ext FROM x4, no edema/calf pain
skin old bruises over R shin only, no lacerations or abrasions
neuro CN II-XII intact, EOMI, no nystagmus, sensation grossly 
intact, ___ strength x4, 2+ reflexes bilaterally, gait normal, 
finger-to-nose normal, Romberg normal

SVE L/C/P, uterus appropriate sized, no fundal/adnexal 
tenderness, no blood on glove

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 11:10AM BLOOD WBC-3.9*# RBC-4.61 Hgb-13.5 Hct-39.4 
MCV-85 MCH-29.3 MCHC-34.3 RDW-12.4 Plt ___
___ 11:10AM BLOOD Glucose-91 UreaN-8 Creat-0.7 Na-136 K-3.9 
Cl-104 HCO3-24 AnGap-12
___ 11:10AM BLOOD Calcium-9.0 Phos-3.1 Mg-2.2
___ 11:10AM URINE Blood-NEG Nitrite-NEG Protein-TR 
Glucose-NEG Ketone-TR Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-4* pH-7.5 Leuks-NEG
___ 11:10AM URINE RBC-1 WBC-1 Bacteri-NONE Yeast-NONE Epi-4

URINE CULTURE (Final ___: 
      MIXED BACTERIAL FLORA ( >= 3 COLONY TYPES), CONSISTENT 
WITH SKIN
      AND/OR GENITAL CONTAMINATION. 

CT ___: No acute intracranial process, including no hemorrhage 
or other traumatic sequelae.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted for observation overnight in 
anticipation of SafeLink provision of a domestic violence 
shelter bed on ___. Social work saw her upon admission and 
prior to discharge. A shelter bed was ultimately not able to be 
obtained, but she was transitioned to a safe location outside of 
___ where she will reside until further arrangements are 
made.

Medically, for her nausea and vomiting, she received IV 
antiemetics and 3L IVF in triage.  She was able to urinate, 
tolerated PO, and was started on zofran PO, which controlled her 
nausea.  She had no emesis in triage or on the antepartum floor. 
 Her labs were wnl and a CT ___ showed no acute intracranial 
process.  Her pain resolved after tylenol 1g, and there was no 
evidence of organ damage or other adverse effect of trauma.  She 
was give prescriptions for Zofran and Metoclopramide. 
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. ondansetron 4 mg Tablet, Rapid Dissolve Sig: One (1) Tablet, 
Rapid Dissolve PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for nausea.  
2. metoclopramide 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every six 
(6) hours as needed for nausea.  
3. Prenatal Vitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a 
day.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*6*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Hyperemesis
DV

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted for a safebed. We also prescribed you several 
anti-nausea medications that you can take as needed.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Recurrent right lower extremity ganglion cyst
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Removal of ganglion cyst from right tibiofibular junction
 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old male with recurrent right lower extermity ganlion 
cyst at tibiofibular junction.
 
Past Medical History:
see admit H&P
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
see admit H&P
 
Physical Exam:
General: no acute distress, resting comfortably
Cardiac: regular rate and rhythm by palpation
Pulmonary: No increased work of breathing
Right Lower extermity: dressing in place - clean dry and intact. 
Drain in place with serosanguenous output. Motor intact to 
___. Sensation intact to light touch over SP/DP/T 
nerve distributions. 2+ ___ pulses
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient admitted status-post removal of right lower extermity 
ganglion cyst removal. The procedure went well, patient was 
placed in a bulky dressing with drain left in place, and patient 

was admitted post-operatively for observation and care. 
Overnight patient had high post-residual voids so the foley was 
reinserted. The foley was again discontinued the AM of POD1 and 
by 1 pm patient was able to void ___. His drain continued to 
have significant output (~165cc/24 hr) so it was left in place 
and patient was discharged with instructions to stay on oral 
keflex until the drain is removed. Patient was educated 
reguarding the signs of urinary retention and told to return to 
the ED with concerns. By POD1 patient was taking an oral diet, 
pain was well controlled on PO medications, he was voiding and 
ambulating independantly with crutches. He was discharged on 
POD1 with plan to return to clinic on ___ for drain 
removal.

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Avapro *NF* (irbesartan) 150 mg Oral Daily BP 
2. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
3. Simvastatin 40 mg PO DAILY 
4. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain 
5. Aspirin (Buffered) 325 mg PO Q 12H Duration: 14 Days 
6. Cephalexin 500 mg PO Q6H Duration: 5 Days 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Removal of gangion cyst from right tibiofibular junction
 
Discharge Condition:
Patient admitted status-post removal of right lower extermity 
ganglion cyst removal. The procedure went well, patient was 
placed in a bulky dressing with drain left in place, and patient 
was admitted post-operatively for observation and care. 
Overnight patient had high post-residual voids so the foley was 
reinserted. The foley was again discontinued the AM of POD1 and 
by 1 pm patient was able to void ___. His drain continued to 
have significant output (~165cc/24 hr) so it was left in place 
and patient was discharged with instructions to stay on oral 
keflex until the drain is removed. Patient was educated 
reguarding the signs of urinary retention and told to return to 
the ED with concerns. By POD1 patient was taking an oral diet, 
pain was well controlled on PO medications, he was voiding and 
ambulating independantly with crutches. He was discharged on 
POD1 with plan to return to clinic on ___ for drain 
removal.
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires ambulatory device for 
assistance - otherwise independant
 
Discharge Instructions:
Orthopaedic Surgery Instructions:

You were admitted post-operatively following your ganglion cyst 
removal from your right lower extermity.

Activity: weight bearing as tolerated to right lower extremity 
with crutches or walker for balance and protection as needed. Be 
sure to keep your leg elevated and place ice on the surgical 
area to help with swelling and pain relief.
Anticoagulation: Please take aspirin 325 mg two times daily for 
two weeks to help prevent blood clots.
Antibiotics: Please take the prescribed antibiotic (Keflex ___ 
mg 4x/day)as directed while your drain is in place to help 
prevent infection.
Dressing/wound care: Please keep your dressing clean and dry at 
all times. It may be easier to sponge bath in the short term 
until your dressing is removed. Cover your dressing with a 
waterproof barrier whenever bathing to keep it dry.
Drain: The drain will remain in place until the output has 
decreased to avoid fluid from collecting at the surgical site. 
Please measure the output of the drain daily and bring it to 
your next appointment so we can make a decision as to whether or 
not to remove the drain then.
Urine output: During your hospital stay your urine output was on 
the low end of normal. This was likely from a combination of not 
drinking as much as usual and irritation of your prostate from 
the foley catheder during the surgery. We expect that this will 
improve over the next ___ hours, but please make sure to note 
any signs that you are not urinating as much as usual or if it 
seems to be difficult to urinate. If you have any concerns 
please go to the emergency room to be evaluated for urinary 
retention, which sometimes occurs after surgery.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Activity: weight bearing as tolerated to right lower extremity
with crutches or walker for balance and protection as needed. Be
sure to keep your leg elevated and place ice on the surgical
area to help with swelling and pain relief.
Anticoagulation: Please take aspirin 325 mg two times daily for
two weeks to help prevent blood clots.
Antibiotics: Please take the prescribed antibiotic (Keflex ___
mg 4x/day)as directed while your drain is in place to help
prevent infection.
Dressing/wound care: Please keep your dressing clean and dry at
all times. It may be easier to sponge bath in the short term
until your dressing is removed. Cover your dressing with a
waterproof barrier whenever bathing to keep it dry.
Drain: The drain will remain in place until the output has
decreased to avoid fluid from collecting at the surgical site.
Please measure the output of the drain daily and bring it to
your next appointment so we can make a decision as to whether or
not to remove the drain then.
Urine output: During your hospital stay your urine output was on
the low end of normal. This was likely from a combination of not
drinking as much as usual and irritation of your prostate from
the foley catheder during the surgery. We expect that this will
improve over the next ___ hours, but please make sure to note
any signs that you are not urinating as much as usual or if it
seems to be difficult to urinate. If you have any concerns
please go to the emergency room to be evaluated for urinary
retention, which sometimes occurs after surgery.
Followup Instructions:
___

and her cervical exam changed from closed to 1cm/50%. Given the 
cervical change and positive fetal fibronectin, she was started 
on magnesium sulfate for tocolysis. She was afebrile and without 
any evidence of infection or abruption. Urine toxicology screen 
was negative. Her contractions spaced out significantly and her 
cervical exam was stable. After prolonged monitoring on labor 
and delivery, she was transferred to the antepartum floor. MFM 
and NICU consults were obtained.
.
The magnesium was discontinued once the patient was 
betamethasone complete. She was monitored closely off tocolysis. 
Her cervical length was 3cm. On ___, she developed contractions 
every 6 minutes. Her cervix was unchanged on digital exam. Per 
___ recommendations, she was started on po Nifedipine every 8 
hours. She was monitored closely without any further uterine 
contractions. 
.
She remained stable and was discharged home in stable condition 
on ___ on modified bedrest. She will continue on PO Nifedipine. 
She will follow-up with ___ in the outpatient setting closely.
 
Medications on Admission:
prenatal vitamins
 
Discharge Medications:
1. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) as needed for Constipation.  
2. nifedipine 10 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO Q8H (every 8 
hours).
Disp:*90 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
preterm labor

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Modified bedrest

 
Discharge Instructions:
You came into the hospital with painful contractions and were 
treated for concern of preterm labor. You should continue the 
Nifedipine 10mg every 8 hours to help prevent uterine 
contractions. You should stay well hydrated and continue 
modified bedrest as discussed by Dr. ___.

You should continue kick counts daily. You should feel 10 
kick-counts per baby over the day. If you notice decreased 
movement, you should contact your doctor.

You should contact your doctor if painful contractions return, 
vaginal bleeding or leakage of fluid from the vagina.

Call with any further concerns.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

endometriosis and chronic pelvic pain

abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, 
cystoscopy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo G1P1 with chronic endometriosis. ___ has been on lupron for 
several
years and would like definite treatment. Patient also reports a 
rash that spikes following  is also getting a rash that flares 
after lupron injections.
 
Past Medical History:
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: 
  1. Asthma
  2. Endometriosis
 
PAST SURGICAL HISTORY 
  1. Umbilical hernia: Repair and subsequent excision of
endometriosis from incision scar. 

GYN HX: 
Menopausal symptoms: pt with menopausal symptoms and amenorrhea 
on lupron
Last pap: ___. Result: NORMAL. 
Last mammogram: ___. 
Last bone density: ___. 
Infection/STI history: None. 
Contraception: Nothing. 
  
OBSTETRICAL HISTORY
1. G1P1 SVD (___)           

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Noncontributory  
 
Physical Exam:
Exam on day of discharge
AFVSS
NAD, A&O x3
CTAB
RRR
AB: nd/nt, no rebound, no gaurding, incision c/d/i
___: nt/ne/no cords

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ underwent a laparoscopic converted intraoperatively to 
a total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, 
cystoscopy; see operative report for details. She had an 
uncomplicated recovery and was discharged home on postoperative 
day #2 in good condition: ambulating and voiding without 
difficulty, tolerating a regular diet, and with adequate pain 
control using PO medication.  
 
Medications on Admission:
MEDICATIONS 

ibuprofen
leuprolide 
oxycodone
triamcinolone acetonide
valacyclovir
docusate sodium [Colace]
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
take when taking oxycodone to prevent constipation 
2. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q4H:PRN pain 
Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen per day. Do not drive 
or drink alcohol. 
3. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q8H:PRN pain 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
endometriosis, pelvic pain  

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You were admitted to the gynecology service after your 
procedure. You have recovered well and the team believes you are 
ready to be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ office with 
any questions or concerns. Please follow the instructions below.

General instructions:  
* Take your medications as prescribed.  
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.  
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.  
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.  
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.  
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.  
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 6 
weeks.    
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.  
* You may eat a regular diet.  
* You may walk up and down stairs.  

Incision care:  
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.  
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.  
* If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
visit.  

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.  

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted for preterm labor at ___ 5d estimated 
gestational age and progressed to an uncomplicated vaginal 
delivery of a 3035g male infant with Apgars 6 and 8.  Her 
postpartum course was uncomplicated.  She was evaluated by 
inpatient social work as she lives at a homeless shelter 
part-time and had difficulty obtaining sufficient resources for 
taking the baby home.  She stayed an extra day postpartum in 
order to confirm the availability of resources once she leaves 
the hospital.  On discharge, her pain was well-controlled on 
oral medications, and she was ambulating, voiding, and eating a 
regular diet.  She was given instructions to follow up in 2 and 
6 weeks with her OB/Gyn's office.

term pregnancy delivered

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ presented to the ___ ED with abdominal pain and 
nausea. KUB in the ED demonstrated a non-specific bowel gas 
pattern with some mild air fluid levels in the upright position. 
She was admitted to the General Surgery Service overnight for 
observation and was kept NPO with IVF. She remained clinically 
stable overnight with resolution of her abdominal pain and 
nausea. Ms. ___ diet was advanced to regular which she 
tolerated without difficulty and she was dicharged to home in

.

text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Known left MCA aneurysm
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Recoiling of Left MCA aneurysm

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ y/o female who had a subarachnoid hemorrhage in 
___ from a left MCA aneurysm which was coiled. She returns on 
this hospitalization for recoiling of the left MCA aneurysm 
which had recanulized.
 
Past Medical History:
Subarachnoid hemorrhage ___
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
On admission and on discharge patient is neurologically intact 
without any focal defecits.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted and evaluated by anesthesia. She was taken 
to the angio suite, intubated and underwent a flouro guided 
coiling of her Left MCA aneurysm. Angio puncture site was closed 
with angio seal; no complications were noted. Patient was 
extubated in the angio suite and taken to the PACU post 
procedure. She remained on a heparin drip at 700units an hour 
until 7am.  

The day after the procedure, patient was eating, her foley was 
discontinued, she ambulated and was discharged home from the 
PACU to home.
 
Medications on Admission:
Asa 81mg
Enalapril 5mg daily
HCTZ 
Zocor 10mg daily
 
Discharge Medications:
1. aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
___ also resume all pre op medications
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left MCA aneurysm

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Angiogram with Embolization and/or Stent placement
Medications:
Take Aspirin 325mg (enteric coated) once daily.
Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any 
post procedure pain or discomfort.

What activities you can and cannot do:
When you go home, you may walk and go up and down stairs.
You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, 
rinse and pat dry)
Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or 
band aid over the area that is draining, as needed
No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 
1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal).
After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity.
After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance 
walked as you can tolerate.
No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications

What to report to office:
Changes in vision (loss of vision, blurring, double vision, 
half vision)
Slurring of speech or difficulty finding correct words to use
Severe headache or worsening headache not controlled by pain 
medication
A sudden change in the ability to move or use your arm or leg 
or the ability to feel your arm or leg
Trouble swallowing, breathing, or talking
Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities 
Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours
New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or 
green drainage from incisions
Bleeding from groin puncture site

*SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING 
(Groin puncture site)
Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm pressure 
to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call our office. If 
bleeding does not stop, call ___ for transfer to closest 
Emergency Room!

 
Followup Instructions:
___

History of Present Illness:
___ yo G1P0 at ___ presenting with worsening headache over the 
past few days, unrelieved after taking Tylenol at noon today. 
She denies visual changes and RUQ pain, although she does report 
mild cramping and lower pelvic pain c/w her usual pubic 
symphasis pain. She denies regular contractions, vaginal 
bleeding, and leakage of fluid, and reports very active fetal 
movement. The headache is occipital and associated with some 
nausea, no vomiting. She does note mild photophobia but no 
associated neurologic symptoms, and denies any h/o migraines or 
headaches. 

PNC: ___ ___ by first trimester u/s
- O+/Ab-/RI/RPRNR/HbsAg-/GBS positive

___

non-contributory

Vitals - T:97.1  BP:124/82,127/77  HR:87  RR:18
General: NAD, resting, appears mildly uncomfortable
Neuro: CN II-XII grossly intact, no pronator drift, PERRL, 
strength ___ in all extremities, sensation to light touch 
intact, patellar reflexes 1+ b/l
CV: RRR
Lungs: CTAB
Abdomen: soft, gravid, mild groin/lower quadrant TTP, no RUQ TTP
Extremities: no calf TTP, mild b/l edema

FHT: 120/mod var/+accels/no decels --> reactive, category I
Toco: q ___ min, irregular, not felt by patient

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 01:00PM BLOOD WBC-8.3 RBC-3.06* Hgb-9.2* Hct-26.8* 
MCV-88 MCH-30.1 MCHC-34.3 RDW-13.2 Plt ___
___ 07:56PM BLOOD ___ PTT-25.9 ___
___ 07:56PM BLOOD ___
___ 01:00PM BLOOD Creat-0.6
___ 01:00PM BLOOD ALT-18 AST-24
___ 01:00PM BLOOD UricAcd-5.___ G1P0 at 37w1d initially presented to L&D for a 
pre-eclampsia evaluation secondary to persistent headache.  In 
OB triage she spontaneously ruptured.  She was brought down to 
L&D for further management.  HELLP labs were obtained and noted 
to be within normal limits.  No proteinuria is noted.

Initially she was managed expectantly, however made little 
cervical change and was started on Pitocin. She remained on 
Pitocin overnight and in the morning was noted to have made very 
little cervical change.  An intrauterine pressure catheter was 
placed and her MVUs were noted to be greater than 250.  After 
two hours of no cervical change with adequate contractions, the 
decision was made to proceed with cesarean delivery.  

Her delivery was uncomplicated and then patient was transferred 
to the postpartum floor.  Initially her blood pressures were 
noted to be elevated and she was started on Labetalol 100mg BID. 
 Her blood pressures then normalized and the Labetalol was 
discontinued on POD#1.  On POD#4, her blood pressures started to 
increase again.  Another set HELLP labs were noted to be within 
normal limits. Labetalol 200mg TID was restarted.  Blood 
pressure improved.  

The patient remained in the hospital for one additional night to 
closely monitor her blood pressure.  On POD#5, she was 
discharged home in stable condition with follow up in 2 weeks 
and 6 weeks.

 
Medications on Admission:
albuterol, pulmicort

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain: Do not take more than 
4000mg acetaminophen in 24 hrs.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) as needed for Constipation.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every six (6) 
hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Labetalol 100 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO three times a 
day.
Disp:*80 Tablet(s)* Refills:*3*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
cesarean section for arrest of dilation in labor

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please place nothing in your vagina for six weeks - this 
includes no sex, no tampons, and no douching.
 
No heavy lifting for six weeks
 
Do not drive while taking narcotics

Continue your blood pressure medication (Labetalol 200mg three 
times per day).  If you feel dizzy after taking the blood 
pressure medication, please call our clinic because we may need 
to decrease your blood pressure medication.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Pertinent Results:
___: Cerebral angiogram-official read pending dictation
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ elective admission for stent assisted coiling of the R ACOMM 
aneurysm. In angio it was noted that coiling the aneurysm would 
obstruct flow to adjacent vessels which would cause an infarct. 
At that time it was decided to just place the stent in the R 
ACOMM to help reduce the pressure to the aneurysm and reduce 
risk of rupture. Post-angio the patient was angiosealed, 
extubated, and transferred to the Neuro ICU. On post-op exam she 
remained nonfocal. She was continued on ___ and ___. 

On Post procedure day one the patient was neruologically intact. 
Her foley catheter and A-line were removed, she was ambulatory 
and taking a diet and was discharged home on ___ and ___.

 
Medications on Admission:
HCTZ, Simvastatin, ___, Enalpril 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
3. simvastatin 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
4. hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
DAILY (Daily).  
5. enalapril maleate 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right ACOMM aneurysm (unruptured)
Left MCA aneurysm (previously coiled)

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Angiogram with Stent placement
Medications:
Take Aspirin 325mg (enteric coated) once daily for 1 month.
Take ___ (Clopidogrel) 75mg once daily for 1 month. 
Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any 
post procedure pain or discomfort.

What activities you can and cannot do:
When you go home, you may walk and go up and down stairs.
You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, 
rinse and pat dry)
Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or 
band aid over the area that is draining, as needed
No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 
1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal).
After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity.
After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance 
walked as you can tolerate.
No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications

What to report to office:
Changes in vision (loss of vision, blurring, double vision, 
half vision)
Slurring of speech or difficulty finding correct words to use
Severe headache or worsening headache not controlled by pain 
medication
A sudden change in the ability to move or use your arm or leg 
or the ability to feel your arm or leg
Trouble swallowing, breathing, or talking
Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities 
Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours
New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or 
green drainage from incisions
Bleeding from groin puncture site

*SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING 
(Groin puncture site)
Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm pressure 
to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call our office. If 
bleeding does not stop, call ___ for transfer to closest 
Emergency Room!

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ presented to the ___ on ___ from Dr. ___ 
office with concern for an infection in her right knee.  She was 
evaluated by the orthopaedic surgery service and admitted, 
consented, and prepped for surgery.  Later that day she was 
taken to the operating room and underwent an I&D of her right 
knee.  She was placed on Ancef postoperatively until operative 
cultures were finalized On ___ Infectious disease was 
consulted for antibiotic recommendations.  
Her cultures are negative but per ID recs she will be treated 
empirically with vancomycin and ciprofloxacin. Rheumatology does 
not think this is rheumatologic.
She is stable and going home with ___ line.

Cymbalta
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for fever > 100.4, pain.

times a day).

DAILY (Daily) for 4 weeks.
Disp:*30 syringes* Refills:*0*
4. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q4H (every 4 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*120 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

Sustained Release(s)

Please draw weekly CBC, BUN, Cr, Vanco trough, and fax results 
to Infectious Diesase at ___

Normal Saline flush ___ daily/prn/SASH
Heparin 10units/ml flush ___ daily/prn/SASH
9. Ciprofloxacin 250 mg Tablet Sig: Three (3) Tablet PO Q12H 
(every 12 hours).

arthritis.

Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Nut Flavor
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Nausea, diarrhea, malaise
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a ___ year old woman who is s/p Right knee 
meniscectomy ___ who then developed knee pain/swelling post 
operatively.  She was taken to the OR on ___ for a washout and 
pus drained, but cx negative.  She was started on IV vancomycin 
and oral ciprofloxacin for presumed septic arthritis.  However, 
since being on the antitibiotics, she has felt unwell.  She has 
had diarrhea, and the vancomycin in particular makes her very 
nauseous.  She is eating very little.  She was prescribed an 
anti-emetic by the ID doctors and she ___ very sleepy 
afterwards.  In addition, she had chills, fever to 101 at home 
yesterday, so decided to come to ED.
Denies cough/dysuria/backpain/rash.  Knee pain minimal.  
 
Past Medical History:
Depression

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non contributory
 
Physical Exam:
T 98.5 BP 132/77 HR 67
Gen:  WD female, very pleasant, in NAD
No cervical ___:  CTA B 
CV:  RRR, no m/r/g
Abd:  nabs, soft
Right knee:  + surgical scar, sutures intact, no warmth, no 
swelling.
+ pain on flexion of knee
Left arm:  PICC line in antecubital fossa, no swelling, warmth, 
induration.  
Skin:  No rashes or lesions
Neuro:  AO x 3
Psych:  Calm, appropriate.  
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 11:00PM BLOOD WBC-6.0 RBC-3.95* Hgb-11.6* Hct-33.2* 
MCV-84 MCH-29.4 MCHC-34.9 RDW-13.1 Plt ___
___ 11:00PM BLOOD Glucose-93 UreaN-10 Creat-1.4* Na-137 
K-3.8 Cl-104 HCO3-20* AnGap-___.  Nausea.  Patient attributes nausea to vancomycin.   Her 
nausea much improved on cessation of vancomycin.  However, she 
still had mild nausea after taking ___, which improved 
with zofran. 

2.  Septic Arthritis:  s/p washout of knee in ID, pus drained 
but cx negative.   ___ d/w ID fellow Dr ___ 
advised continuation of ciprofloxacin until ___ and to d/c 
vancomycin and to start ___ ___ mg po bid until ___.  
Patient needs CBC f/u while on the ___, and has f/u at ___ 
clinic where that will be done.

3.  Diarrhea:  C diff negative x 1 prior to admission, and 
repeat cdiff negative as well.  Likely abx associated diarrhea; 
this also improved during hospitalization.

4.  Acute renal failure:  Likely secondary to poor po intake.  
Creatinine 1.3 on arrival, dropped to 1.1 on discharge.  
Baseline is .9.  Will need to follow this to ensure renal 
function resolves completely.  ID clinic provider notified to 
get recheck at f/u.  

4.  Ortho:  Had surgical sutures removed during hospitalization. 
   

5.  Depression:  Patient takes both celexa and wellbutrin.  Per 
pharmacist, she is at increased risk of serotonin syndrome while 
on these meds and ___.  Will continue low dose celexa and 
hold wellbutrin.  She was advised to meet with PCP after 
finishing ___ to discuss resumption of wellbutrin.  

6.  Fever at home.  Afebrile in hospital.  

7.  PICC line removed at end of hospitalization.
