Diagnostic laparoscoy
Laparotomy
Excision of left cornual/adnexal heterotopic pregnancy
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo G4P1 at 5 weeks by IVF dating presenting with likely 
heterotopic pregnancy. Has had prior ultrasounds at ___ IVF 
that showed a live IUP and left ectopic pregnancy; initially 
thought to be cornual but now imaging is more consistent with 
adnexal/tubal ectopic. She has mild LLQ pain but is otherwise 
feeling well. 

 
Past Medical History:
OBHx: G4P1
- ectopic x 2 -> spontaneous resolution x 1, MTX x 1
- SVD x 1

MedHx: denies

SurgHx:
- open appendectomy (appendix was ruptured)
- hysteroscopic uterine septum resection

 
Social History:
denies T/E/D, is a ___
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals - T:97.0  BP:122/82  HR:80  
General: NAD, resting comfortably
CV: RRR
Lungs: CTAB
Abdomen: soft, non-distended, no TTP
Pelvic: deferred

Exam on discharge:
NAD
RRR
CTAB
abd soft, NT, ND, +BS, dressings C/D/I
ext NT NE
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 03:28PM BLOOD WBC-7.3 RBC-4.43 Hgb-13.4 Hct-38.6 MCV-87 
MCH-30.4 MCHC-34.9 RDW-12.1 Plt ___
___ 03:28PM BLOOD Neuts-68.9 ___ Monos-7.9 Eos-0.4 
Baso-0.4
___ 03:28PM BLOOD ___ PTT-26.8 ___
.
TVUS ___: 
A retroverted uterus is present that measures 10 x 4.8 x 7.7 cm. 
It has an arcuate shape. Within the right portion of the arcuate 
uterus, a gestational sac is present, and embryo is seen with a 
heart beat at 127 beats per minute. This places the pregnancy at 
around 5 to ___ weeks. 
  
In the right side of the arcuate uterus, some blood is present.  
Both right and left ovaries are normal, both containing corpus 
luteal cysts.In the left adnexa, adjacent to the uterus, a 
further gestational sac is present, consistent with a left-sided 
ectopic pregnancy. This is thought to lie within the tube as at 
least two-thirds of the sac shows no adjacent myometrium. No 
evidence of embryonic cardiac motion is seen within this 
ectopic.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ presented to the hospital on ___ with a 
heteroscopic pregnancy in the setting of IVF, at approximately 5 
weeks GA. She underwent diagnostic laparoscopy, laparotomy, and 
excision of the approximately 2-cm unruptured left cornual 
ectopic pregnancy at the junction of left fallopian tube and 
cornu. Please see the operative note for details. She had an 
uncomplicated recovery, voiding and ambulating without 
difficulty and tolerating a regular diet. She was discharged on 
post-operative day #1 in stable condition.
 
Medications on Admission:
Multi-vitamins
Tylenol prn
 
Discharge Medications:
1. oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
every ___ hours as needed for pain: do not drive while taking 
this.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain: do not take more than 4000mg 
tylenol/acetaminophen in 24h.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. B complex-vitamin C-folic acid 1 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Cap 
PO DAILY (Daily).  
4. folic acid 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  

5. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*28 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
heterotopic left adnexal pregnancy
live intrauterine pregnancy

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
It was a pleasure to take care of you while you were 
hospitalized at ___. You were 
admitted following the operation for ectopic pregnancy. You 
recovered well without complications.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs
* No strenuous activity, nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no 
douching, no sex), no heavy lifting of objects >10lbs until 
approved by your doctor. 
* You may eat a regular diet.

Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision.  No bath tubs for 6 weeks.
* Take your dressings off tonight but leave the steri-strips on. 
They will fall off on their own or be removed during your 
followup visit.

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service after blood 
cultures obtained during her prior admission for septic abortion 
returned positive for GBS bacteremia. She had additional blood

culture which was negative. She was started on IV vancomycin

additional week of oral antibiotics and outpatient followup 
including repeat CBC in 1 week.

stable

you.

Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___

Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: PLASTIC
 
Allergies: 
Bactrim DS
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right arm pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Right radial shortening osteotomy

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a a ___ RHD female who works as a nurse 
with ___ history of depression, anxiety and ___'s disease now 

POD2 from a radial shortening on the right who presents with 
uncontrolled post-operative pain. Patient left AMA on ___ 
secondary to being unsatisfied with her care. She returns today 
in pain.  

 
Past Medical History:
___'s, Depression, Anxiety 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non contributory
 
Physical Exam:
GENERAL: Alert oriented x3, tearful, anxious complaining of 
pain. 
CARDIOVASCULAR: Regular rate, rhthym. 
CHEST: CLEAR TO AUSCULTATION
EXTREMITIES: Right arm in a short arm cast. Tender to palaption 
diffusely. Incision clean, dry, intact. Compartments soft. 
Radial and ulnar pulses +2 and symmetric. Radial, ulnar, 
superficial palmar artery all dopplerable. Sensation intact in 
the radial, median, ulnar nerve distribution. Capillary refill 
<2 seconds in all digits bilaterally. Pain to AROM to 
flexion/extension at wrist. PROM nontender.  
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient requesting to be discharged against medical advice
secondary to inadequate pain control. Patient was seen by the
acute pain service on ___ and put on a pain regimen including 
dilaudid
PO 6mg Q4H:PRN, Dilaudid 1mg IV Q3H:PRN, celebrex ___ BID,
gabapentin 300mg TID, tylenol ___ Q6. After being explained
the risks and benefits of leaving including infection, further
pain, compartment sydrome and associated complications, and
death, patient understood these risks and decided to leave.
Patient did have a physical exam performed both by myself, as
well as Dr. ___ showed intact arterial flow to the
radial, ulnar and palmar arch via doppler, adequate capillary
refill to the digits, and no evidence of compartment syndrome.
Patient had volar splint placed prior to leaving AMA. Instructed
to get emergent medical attention if symptoms persisted or
worsened. Prior to signing AMA paperwork and recieving
prescriptions and discharge paperwork, patient eloped despite
verbal requests to wait until paperwork was printed.
 
Medications on Admission:
1. CeleBREX (celecoxib) 200 mg Oral BID acute pain 
RX *celecoxib [Celebrex] 200 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a 
day Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*0
2. Gabapentin 300 mg PO TID 
RX *gabapentin 300 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth three times a day 
Disp #*45 Capsule Refills:*0

 
Discharge Medications:
1. CeleBREX (celecoxib) 200 mg Oral BID acute pain 
RX *celecoxib [Celebrex] 200 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a 
day Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*0
2. Gabapentin 300 mg PO TID 
RX *gabapentin 300 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth three times a day 
Disp #*45 Capsule Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Uncontrollable pain after radial shortening of right arm

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Patient eloped prior to getting discharge instructions
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: PLASTIC
 
Allergies: 
Bactrim DS
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None this admission

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a a ___ RHD female who works as a nurse 
with ___ history of depression, anxiety and Kienboch's disease now 
POD2 from a radial shortening on the right who presents with 
uncontrolled post-operative pain. Patient left AMA on ___ 
secondary to being unsatisfied with her care. She returns today 
in pain.  

 
Past Medical History:
___'s, Depression, Anxiety 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: 98.1 60 106/68 14 100RA  
Gen: anxious, tearly eyed and uncomfortable. AAOx3  
Upper extremity: RUE splint removed. Incision intact without 
erythema or induration. Some scant sanguinous drainage on 
palpation of forearm from incision. No purulence. Tenderness to 
palpation of entire forearm and with passive ranging of digits 
and wrist on right side. 2+ radial pulse bilaterally with 2 
second capillary refill. Dopplerable radial, ulnar, superficial 
palmar branch pulses on right and symmetric on left. 
Compartments soft, tender.  

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:40AM BLOOD WBC-7.4 RBC-3.67* Hgb-11.4* Hct-31.3* 
MCV-85 MCH-31.0 MCHC-36.3* RDW-12.0 Plt ___
___ 05:40AM BLOOD Glucose-80 UreaN-4* Creat-0.4 Na-141 
K-3.9 Cl-108 HCO3-27 AnGap-10
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ for treatment of uncontrolled pain s/p radial 
shortening on the right on ___.  The patient had thorough 
focused exam of right upper extremity to rule out compartment 
syndrome and also had forearm films that showed fixation device 
intact.
.
Neuro: The patient was commenced on tylenol, neurontin, dilaudid 
po, morphine IV for breakthrough pain and ativan prn for 
anxiety.  On the morning of ___, the patient reported a poor 
night sleep and inadequate pain control. She also reported that 
'Morphine works better than that dilaudid'.  At that time, 
patient was commenced on toradol IV and dilaudid was 
discontinued in favor of oral morphine.  Patient reported 
adequate pain control with this regimen. 
.
CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
ID: The patient was maintained on keflex PO while in house and 
discharged home with instructions to finish up the PO cefadroxil 
prescription she was previously discharged home with. The 
patient's temperature was closely watched for signs of 
infection. 
.
At the time of discharge on Hospital Day#2, the patient was 
doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a 
regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain 
was controlled by patient self report.  Patient will return to 
clinic for follow up.
 
Medications on Admission:
cefadroxil 500 mg po BID
Clonazepam 0.5mg po TID 
Sertraline 150 mg po QD
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q6H 
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg 2 tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) 
hours Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0
2. cefaDROXil 500 mg Oral Q12H Duration: 5 Days 
Finish the prescription you were given postoperatively 
3. ClonazePAM 0.5 mg PO TID 
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*0
5. Gabapentin 300 mg PO TID 
RX *gabapentin [Neurontin] 300 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth three 
times a day Disp #*42 Capsule Refills:*1
6. ketorolac 10 mg Oral Q6H Duration: 3 Days 
RX *ketorolac 10 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) hours 
Disp #*12 Tablet Refills:*0
7. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
Begin only after toradol/Ketorolac has finished. Max 2400mg per 
day.  
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) hours 
Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*1
8. Senna 1 TAB PO BID:PRN constipation 
9. Sertraline 150 mg PO DAILY 
10. Morphine Sulfate ___ ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *morphine 15 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*70 Tablet Refills:*0

Home

Acute pain RUE

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Bactrim
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
urinary retention after cerclage
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
cervical cerclage placement

 
History of Present Illness:
___ year G4P1021 with a history of PPROM/septic abortion in prior 
pregnancy, presenting at 17w0d weeks ___ ___ by 12 week 
ultrasound and LMP) for cervical cerclage placement. Patient was 
previously noted to have CL 19 mm and therefore sent to triage 
for ultrasound-indicated cerclage.
 
Past Medical History:
- G1 SAB after D&C PPY, had neg pregnancy test prior to 
procedure
but result showed pregnancy tissue
- G2 pLTCS for second stage arrest
- G3 septic abortion at 16w s/p D&E

GynHx:
- h/o fibroids
- denies abnormal Pap, STIs

PMH: 
- subclinical hyperthyroidism in pregnancy
- obesity

PSH: 
- D&C, D&E
- pLTCS           

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
denies bleeding/clotting disorders, no recurrent miscarriages. 
+fibroids, aunt breast cancer
 
Physical Exam:
 Physical Exam on Discharge:  
 CONSTITUTIONAL: normal  
 HEENT: normal, MMM  
 NEURO: alert, appropriate, oriented x 4  
 RESP: no increased WOB  
 HEART: extremities warm and well perfused  
 ABDOMEN: gravid, non-tender  
 EXTREMITIES: non-tender, no edema  
 FHR: present at a normal rate  
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:22PM   PLT COUNT-238
___ 06:22PM   WBC-10.7* RBC-4.02 HGB-11.2 HCT-34.6 MCV-86 
MCH-27.9 MCHC-32.4 RDW-13.9 RDWSD-43.3
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the Antepartum service after 
cervical cerclage placement, with failure to void after her 
procedure. A foley catheter was placed and she was observed 
overnight. In the morning, the foley catheter was removed and 
she voided without issues. She was discharged home in stable 
condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled. 
 
Medications on Admission:
prenatal vitamins
 
Discharge Medications:
prenatal vitamins
indomethacin
micronized progesterone
miralax
acetaminophen
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
post-operative from cerclage placement, failure to void

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear. Ms. ___,
  
You were admitted to the hospital after your procedure due to 
inability to urinate after the procedure. We kept the urinary 
catheter in overnight, and removed it in the morning. You were 
able to urinate normally. We think it is now safe for you to go 
home. 

Please follow the instructions below:  
 - Nothing in the vagina for the remainder of the pregnancy
 - Attend all appointments with your obstetrician and all fetal 
scans  
 - Monitor for the following danger signs:  
 - headache that is not responsive to medication  
 - abdominal pain  
 - increased swelling in your legs  
 - vision changes  
 - Worsening, painful or regular contractions  
 - Vaginal bleeding  
 - Leakage of water or concern that your water broke  
 - Nausea/vomiting  
 - Fever, chills  
 - Decreased fetal movement  
 - Other concerns  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the antepartum service for management of 
pre-eclampsia and collection of 24 hour urine protein.  Her 24 
hour urine protien was elevated at 325 mg.  She was induced for 
management of her confirmed pre-eclampsia.  Induction was 
attempted with cytotec, but she failed to make any cervical 
change or feel uncomfortable with her contractions.  She was 
taken for delivery via ___.  Please see opertive note for full 
details.

Post-operatively, she remained on labor and delivery for 24 
hours of magnesium.  She tolerated the treatment well and was 
subsequently transferred to the post-partum floor.  Her blood 
pressures were elevated in the post partum period, labetolol was 
titrated up to 300mg BID with good effect.  

During the course of her admission, patient noted a cold sore.  
The following day had several lesions on her lips and thus was 
started on PO valacyclovir and acyclovir ointment.

She was discharged home on POD 4 in stable condition.  She had 
adequate pain control, adequate blood pressure control, and was 
tolerating a po diet and ambulating with ease.

good

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted on ___ for abdominal pain, question 
stump appendicitis vs. epiploic appendagitis.  His WBC count was 
normal and he was afebrile with minimal tenderness. He was kept 
NPO overnight. Throughout the day of ___ his diet was 
advanced.  The patient remained afebrile and his pain lessened 
in nature.  

At the time of discharge he had minimal pain, was tolerating po, 
ambulating without assistance and voiding as normal.

None

Home

Epiploic Appendigitis

Good.
Tolerating PO
Ambulating without assistance
Neurologically intact

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the surgery service for abdominal pain 
concerning for epiploic appendagitis.  After a period of time we 
advanced your diet, which you tolerated well.  Your pain was 
controlled with oral medications, and your labwork was normal.  
After a period of observation you were deemed stable to go home. 
 No further intervention/treatment is needed unless you have 
increased pain or fever.

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
abdominal pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with UC s/p total abdominal 
colectomy, ileoanal pouch in ___ with Dr. ___.  She 
presents to the ED after being seen by Dr. ___ in clinic 
today. In clinic, she explained that she has about 6 pouch 
movements a day without the need for any motility agents.She has 
had intermittent bright red blood per rectum seen on the toilet
paper and occasionally in the toilet bowel. This has been 
ongoing for many years. 

She presented to clinic in the setting of decreased pouch 
movements and central abdominal pain that started on ___ 
after eating chili. Decreased PO intake on ___, ate lightly 
___ and ___, mild nausea, no vomiting. The symptoms feel 
similar to her SBO in ___, that resolved with conservative 
measures. On rectal exam, Dr. ___ that the 
anastamosis was normal
and required no dilation. He found her to have a normal 
abdominal exam in clinic, but with her history and symptoms sent 
her into the ED to obtain a CT scan and come into the hospital 
on his service. The patient unfortunately left the ED waiting 
room prior to being brought into a room after an over 4 hour 
wait. Patient tolerated eggs when she got home from ED wait, 
+flatus, +BM, no nausea.Her last bowel movement was this 
morning.

She returned to the hospital and was directly admitted to the 
floor on ___.

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: ulcerative colitis, depression, anemia treated with iron 
and B12, SBO in ___ resolved with conservative treatment

PSH:total abdominal colectomy with ileoanal J-pouch ___, 
ovarian cystectomies

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory

 
Physical Exam:
Vitals:98.2 70 115/68 18 100% RA
General:no acute distress
Cardiac: RRR
Pulmonary: CTAB
Abdomen: soft, non distended,non-tender, no palpable masses,no 
rebound or guarding.
Extremities:warm well perfused,no edema
Neuro:alert and oriented

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 04:20PM BLOOD WBC-5.8 RBC-3.60* Hgb-9.7* Hct-31.0* 
MCV-86 MCH-27.0 MCHC-31.3 RDW-13.4 Plt ___
___ 04:20PM BLOOD Neuts-67.1 ___ Monos-6.2 Eos-3.1 
Baso-0.4
___ 04:20PM BLOOD Glucose-108* UreaN-10 Creat-0.5 Na-141 
K-3.9 Cl-107 HCO3-29 AnGap-9
___ 04:20PM BLOOD Calcium-9.1 Phos-4.0 Mg-2.1
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the surgical floor for partial small 
bowel obstruction. She was treated conservatively with bowel 
rest and IV fluids.She did not require placement of a 
nasogastric tube. Serial abdominal exams were performed and were 
unremarkable and her abdominal pain was essentially gone. Per 
patient, she had a pouch movement and passed gas earlier this 
morning. 

Since her partial bowel obstruction was resolving a CT scan was 
not performed at this time. In the afternoon her diet was 
advanced to clears liquids which she tolerated well.By hospital 
2, she was able to tolerate a regular diet.Her abdominal exam 
was benign and she had no nausea or abdominal pain.

In regards to her anemia,GI was consulted and will follow her as 
an outpatient with plans to perform a scope to evaluate for any 
bleeding ulcers that may be a contributing source. Of note 
patient regularly takes Iron and Vitamin B12 supplements OTC.

The patient was discharged home in good condition with follow-up 
instructions and is amenable to plan.
 
Medications on Admission:
Fluoxetine 20 mg PO DAILY 
Ferrous Sulfate 2 tablets DAILY(OTC)
Vitamin B12 1 tablet PO DAILY (OTC)

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Fluoxetine 20 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
partial small bowel obstruction

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital for a partial small bowel 
obstruction and were treated conservatively with IV fluids and 
bowel rest. Once your symptoms resolved your diet was slowly 
advanced to regular which you tolerated well. You are being 
discharged home today and we have arranged for you to follow-up 
with  Gastroenterologist on ___ 8:00 AM as 
scheduled below. If you have any questions or concerns call Dr 
___ ___ or return to the emergency 
room if your abdominal pain returns. 
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___

Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics)

Chief Complaint:
abdominal pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with 4 days of abdominal pain. Pain described as colicky and 
crampy distribution. Diffusely located but centralized to 
epigastric. Pain briefly resolved x 1 day but returned with 
abdominal distention. Evaluated by PCP and was thought to be 
from GERD. Treated with Zantac to no improvement. Symptoms 
worsening today and now presents to ED for further evaluation. 
Per pt, had a similar episode 12 days ago but that was quickly 
resolved.

Denies fever, chills, dysuria, sob, cp. Last BM was 3 days ago. 
No flatus. Tolerating clears without N/V, minimal solid intake 
and occasional belching. Last colonoscopy was ___ yr ago and 
reports diverticulosis.

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: ADD 
PSH: tonsils

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
AVSS
GEN: AAOx3, NAD
HEART: RRR S1S2
PULM: CTAB, no respirtory distress
AB: soft, nontender, nondistened, normal bs
EXT: peripheral pulses intact bilaterally
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:15AM BLOOD WBC-5.4 RBC-4.53* Hgb-14.3 Hct-42.1 
MCV-93 MCH-31.6 MCHC-34.0 RDW-12.2 Plt ___
___ 09:50PM BLOOD WBC-7.9 RBC-5.39 Hgb-17.3 Hct-50.5 MCV-94 
MCH-32.2* MCHC-34.3 RDW-12.3 Plt ___
___ 06:15AM BLOOD Glucose-77 UreaN-18 Creat-1.3* Na-137 
K-4.4 Cl-105 HCO3-27 AnGap-9
___ 09:50PM BLOOD Glucose-135* UreaN-22* Creat-1.3* Na-136 
K-4.9 Cl-100 HCO3-28 AnGap-13

CT AB/PELVIS ___
IMPRESSION: Small bowel obstruction with transition point in the 
mid lower abdomen.  Small amount of ascites. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Acute Care Surgery Service on 
___ with a small bowel obstruction. He was treated with 
bowel rest, without an NG tube. His hospital course was 
uneventful, and he was discharged to home. 
 
Hospital Course by Systems:
Neuro: Pain was well controlled with PO meds. 

Cardiovascular: Remained hemodynamically stable.

Pulmonary: Ambulating independently without supplemental oxygen.

GI: Kept NPO on HD1 and HD2. Diet advanced on HD3, and tolerated 
well.  Passed flatus and had bowel movement prior to discharge.

GU: Patient was able to void independently.

Heme: Received heparin subcutaneously.

The patient was discharged to home in stable condition, 
ambulating, and voiding independently.  The patient was given 
instructions to follow-up in clinic in the ___ clinic in ___ 
weeks. He was also advised to follow-up with his PCP and GI.
 
Medications on Admission:
Aderol, zantac

 
Discharge Medications:
Aderol, zantac

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Partial small bowel obstruction

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with concern for a small bowel 
obstruction.  You were evaluated in our emergency department 
with a CT of your abdomen and a history/physical exam.   After a 
short period of time you began to feel better and did not 
require any intervention.  We considered doing some advanced 
imaging during this hospital stay, but in discussion with our 
radiologists it was deemed more appropriate to be done once this 
episode had resolved.  

You were initially not allowed to eat, but our diet was 
advanced, you had a bowel movement, and at the time of discharge 
were feeling well enough to go home.  Please follow the 
instructions below:

-You are advised to follow up in the Acute Care Surgery clinic 
in ___ weeks.  Please call ___ to schedule this 
appointment.

-You are advised to follow up with your primary care provider 
___ 1 week and with a GI specialist within ___ weeks.

-You may resume a normal diet as tolerated.  Please eat small 
portions slowly for at least 1 week.

-Please call the clinic, or go to the nearest emergency 
department, if you experience abdominal pain, nausea/vomiting, 
or for anything else that concerns you.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics)
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
vomiting, abdominal pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
___ with recent admission for pSBO (___) and was 
discharged home after tolerating PO's with normal BM and flatus. 
Pt returns home and after breakfast this AM, reports recurrence 
of this abdominal pain that is colicky with crampy distribution. 
He feels distended and abdomen as pain located to midline. Last 
BM and flatus was this AM. 

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: ADD 
PSH: tonsils

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Gen: NAD
HEENT: EOMI, PERRL, oropharynx clear
CV: RRR, no m/r/g
Pulm: CTAB
Abdomen: soft, NT, ND, no rebound or guarding
Skin: no rashes
Neuro: CN intact, no focal deficits
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:00AM BLOOD WBC-6.0 RBC-4.57* Hgb-14.3 Hct-42.6 
MCV-93 MCH-31.2 MCHC-33.5 RDW-12.2 Plt ___
___ 06:00AM BLOOD Glucose-86 UreaN-12 Creat-1.3* Na-140 
K-4.8 Cl-104 HCO3-30 AnGap-11
___ 06:00AM BLOOD Calcium-8.7 Phos-3.3 Mg-2.1
 
Brief Hospital Course:
HPI: ___ with presents with sudden onset abdominal pain and 
vomiting after eating. Pt was placed NPO, IVF, NG tube. Repeat 
CT again showed mild proximal small bowel dilation up to 3.3 cm, 
without clear lead point and normal distal small and large 
intestine. Patient unerwent magnetic resonance enterography 
which also showed "Multiple loops of distended small bowel with 
tapering at the distal ileum 
without clear transition point." Patient was transitioned to 
clear fluids and eventually ground diet, tolerated well without 
nausea or abdominal pain. Discharged on hospital day #4, advised 
follow up with PCP and GI for intermittent partial small bowel 
obsturction of unclear etiology. 
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
none
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Partial small bowel obstruction

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You came to the hospital for persistent vomiting and abdominal 
pain after being recently discharged from the hospital for the 
same symptoms. You had a repeat CT scan which again showed a 
narrowed area in your small intestines. You then had an MRI of 
the abdomen done, it showed some mild dilation of the intestines 
without any visible cause for narrowing or obstruction. You are 
tolerating solid foods with good symptom control. You will be 
sent home, please follow up with the gastroenterologists and 
your primary doctor to further evaluate this problem. Please 
return for worsening abdominal pain, vomitiing or fevers.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
radiating leg pain X 1 week.
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None.
 
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a ___ y/o man with a ___ year history of chronic back 
pain who presents with new onset radiating left buttock and leg 
pain that he currently rates as ___ in severity. He describes 
the pain as persistent, dull, throbbing pain that radiates from 
his left buttock through the laterl aspect of his leg the top of 
his left ankle; the pain is worse with movement and exacerbated 
by attempting to walk. He also notes that the bottom of his left 
foot is numb and that he had been experiencing some difficulty 
standing on the left leg.
. 
The patient had been experiencing low back pain for at least the 
past ___ years. He describes the back pain as sharp intense 
pain in the muscle of his lower back that tighten and spasm with 
exertion. He had been seeing a ___ regularly until 2 
months ago (which he notes was helping to alleviate the back 
spasms). He also had attempted physical therapy, injections, 
ice, and Medrol packs. About one year ago the patient began to 
notice dull pain behind his knee and perceived a loss of 
sensation in his foot; he saw a Neurosurgeon in ___, ___ 
year ago. This pain continued to increase in severity with 
ensuing left buttock and leg pain; he visited the Neurosurgeon 
again in ___. In ___, he received an epidural steroid 
injection which helped to relieve this new radicular pain. He 
then sought out a second opinion regarding his back pain from 
Dr. ___ recommended to continue with the epidural steroid 
injections at this time. He received the second epidural 
injection 10 days ago; 2 days later his radicular pain had begun 
to increase in intensity. Over the next four days, the pain 
magnified to ___ in intensity and became unbearable, at which 
point he presented to the ___ ED.  
. 
ROS: Denies chest pain, SOB, abdominal pain, dysuria, nausea, 
vomiting, fever, chills, weight loss, headache, dizziness, 
confusion, dysarthria, dysphagia. 

 
Past Medical History:
chronic low back pain with known L5/S1 disc disease.
dysthymia
bilateral ___ eye surgery
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Noncontributory.
 
Physical Exam:
VS: T 99.5 BP 134/90 HR 84 RR 18 97% 2L NC  
GEN- Middle-aged man resting comfortably in bed, wearing nasal 
canula. 
HEENT: Mucous membranes moist; oropharynx pink without lesions 
or exudates. PERRL. NO JVD. Neck supple. No lymphadenopathy. 
CV: RRR, normal S1, S2. No murmurs.
RESP: CTAB. No wheezes, rales, rhonchi. 
ABD: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, no hepatosplenomegaly. 
EXT: Pain to left leg raise test.  No tenderness to palpation, 
no swelling or edema.
SKIN: No rashes. 
NEURO: CN II-XII intact in detail. Muscle strength impaired in 
dorsiflexion of left foot (___), otherwise ___ throughout. 
Reflexes 2+ in quadriceps and ankles. Numbness of left foot 
sole; sensation to touch otherwise intact. Negative Romberg. 
Gait wide based, but steady; no pain with walking.
 
Pertinent Results:
LABS: 
7:10 am, ___
142  ___   AGap=11 
4.7  33  1.2  
.
9.3  14.3  301 
    40.4  
.
___ MRI L spine: Large posterior disk bulge at L5 with 
cranial extension, resulting in canal stenosis and severe left 
neuroforaminal narrowing. Fluid collection in left paraspinal 
muscles at L5 without enhancement, likely related to injection. 
No epidural bleed or abscess.  
.  
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On arrival to the ED he was in ___ pain; he was given morphine 
4mg IV x1, toradol 30mg IV x1 with decrease in pain to ___. He 
was given dialudid 1mg IV x 2 in quick succession as well as a 
second dose of toradol 30mg IV. Following that he was noted to 
be slightly somnolent with decrease in oxygen saturation to 88% 
on RA. He remained easily arousable although fell asleep when 
not stimulated. He was not given further narcotics and slowly 
woke up. He was evaluated by neurology in the ED who recommended 
MRI. Prior to admission he had MRI L spine which showed large 
posterior disc bulge at L5 with canal stenosis and severe left 
neuroforaminal narrowing. There was no evidence of epidural 
abscess. The patients neurosurgeon Dr. ___ was contacted by the 
ED who did not feel that the patient needed urgent surgery and 
recommended admission for pain control. In addition, he advised 
administration of PO steroids. Patient was transitioned from 
morphine 2 mg IV every 4 hrs to percocet (___). His pain 
abated to a manageable state and was discharged to follow up 
with his spinal surgeon after one week for further epidural 
steroid injections and/or consideration for spinal surgery. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Duloxetin 20mg PO QD 
Gabapentin 100mg PO TID (just started one day PTA)  
Percocet 1 tab PO Q4H PRN  
Naprosyn 500mg BID  
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Medrol (Pak) 4 mg Tablets, Dose Pack Sig: ASDIR Tablets, Dose 
Pack PO once a day for 6 days: ___ day: 2 tabs before breakfast, 
1 tablet after lunch and after supper, and 2 tablets at bedtime. 


___ day: 1 tablet before breakfast. 1 tablet after lunch and 
after supper, and 2 tablets at bedtime. 

___ day: 1 tablet before breakfast, after lunch, after supper 
and at bedtime. 

___ day: 1 tablet before breakfast, after lunch and at bedtime. 

___ day: 1 tablet before breakfast and at bedtime. 

___ day: 1 tablet before breakfast.
Disp:*1 pack* Refills:*0*
2. Gabapentin 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO TID (3 
times a day).  
3. Duloxetine 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).  
4. Naproxen 250 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q12H (every 12 
hours).  
5. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
6. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day) as needed.  
7. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).  
8. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
every four (4) hours as needed for pain for 5 days.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary: sciatica.
Secondary: L5 disk herniation. 

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable. 

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital for management of sciatic 
lower back and leg pain. This pain is most likely associated 
with a herniated disk at the L5 spinal cord level for which you 
are being followed as an outpatient by your orthopedic spine 
surgeon, Dr. ___. 

While in the hospital we treated your pain with intravenous 
morphine,  which was then transitioned to oral percocet. We 
continued naproxen and neurontin which you were taking at home. 
Per the recommendation of your spine surgeon, we started you on 
a steroid (medrol) taper which you will continue at home. 

No other changes were made to your home medication regimen. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Prednisone
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Fever, abdominal pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old gravida 2 para 1 status post Ultrasound guided 
Dilation and curettage on ___ presenting with fever to 101 at 
home today and abdominal cramps. Patient reports that she had 
some cramping post-procedure, which initially improved but got 
worse today. She denies any vaginal bleeding or passage of 
tissue but does endorse some foul-smelling vaginal discharge. 
Patient reports that she went grocery shopping today and by 7pm, 
was not feeling well. She checked her temperature at the time, 
which was 100.8. She had chills. She took 1g of tylenol and 
rechecked her temperature by 9pm, which was 101. She called Dr. 
___ at the time and was advised to come in for evaluation. 

 
Past Medical History:
Medical history: Anxiety, hypertension, Asthma

Surgical History: breast reduction, oral surgery, D&C as above, 
C-section x 1 

OB-GYN History: G2P1 Primary low transverse C-Section in ___ 
for failed induction of labor for preeclampsia. ___ missed 
abortion. Denies sexually transmitted infections. 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Physical exam on admission :
Afebrile, vital signs stable
General: No acute distress
Heart regular rate and rhythm 
Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally
ABD: soft, moderate bilateral lower abdominal tenderness. No 
distention. No
rebound/guarding.
EXT: non tender/non edematous 

Discharge physical exam: 
Afebrile, vital signs stable
General: No acute distress
Heart regular rate and rhythm 
Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally
ABD: soft, non distended, mild right lower quadrant tenderness 
to palpation, otherwise non tender, No rebound/guarding.
EXT: non tender/non edematous 

 
Pertinent Results:
Bedside Ultrasound on admission: 
Thin endometrial stripe. No evidence of retained products of 
conception

CBC:
___ 10:53PM BLOOD WBC-9.5 RBC-4.15* Hgb-12.9 Hct-35.3* 
MCV-85 MCH-31.1 MCHC-36.5* RDW-12.6 Plt ___
___ 10:53PM BLOOD Neuts-73.3* ___ Monos-4.7 Eos-1.8 
Baso-0.3
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the GYN service for observation of 
fever and abdominal pain presumably due to endometritis. She was 
given one dose of IV Ceftriaxone 1gm and was started on 
Doxycycline 100mg BID. She was given motrin which adequately 
conrolled her pain. Overnight, she was able to tolerate a 
regular diet and her pain improved significantly. She remained 
afebrile throughout her stay. She was discharged home the 
following morning in stable condition and was advised to 
continue doxycycline BID for 2 weeks. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Labetalol 200mg PO BID
Celexa 40mg PO daily

 
Discharge Medications:
1. doxycycline hyclate 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
Q12H (every 12 hours) for 14 days.
Disp:*28 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Endometritis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Ms. ___ you were admitted for observation of possible 
endometritis (uterine infection). You were given 1 dose of an IV 
antibiotic called Ceftriaxone. You will be taking another 
antibiotic by mouth for the next 2 weeks. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___.                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Labetalol
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
"menorrhagia"
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Exploratory laparotomy
Abdominal myomectomy 
Bilateral tubal ligation

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___, para 1 with a known fibroid uterus 
and complaints of menorrhagia. The patient desired permanent 
surgical management in the form of an abdominal myomectomy.  She 
was counseled about other options including medical management, 
as well as definitive management with a hysterectomy; but she 
desired to proceeding to proceed with an open abdominal 
myomectomy.  She also desired permanent sterilization in the 
form of bilateral tubal ligation.  Informed consent was obtained 
prior to proceeding to the operating room.

 
Past Medical History:
- Hypertension

Past Surgical History:
- Dilation and Curettage x 2
- Breast reduction

Gynecological History
- History of abbnormal paps
- IUD insertion and removal
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
None documented on file
 
Physical Exam:
Last documented physical examination by Dr. ___ in GYN triage 
___

Vitals - T:99.2  BP:155/97  HR:97  RR:18  O2sat:97% r/a
General: NAD
Abdomen: soft, non-distended, no TTP
Pelvic: on speculum exam, slow oozing of blood from the os, 
moderate amount of small clots/blood cleared from the vaginal 
vault, IUD strings visible and around 2cm in length, on bimanual 
exam mildly enlarged and slightly bulky  uterus at ___ wks 
size, mild discomfort with exam but no CMT, no palpable adnexal 
masses or TTP

 
Pertinent Results:
Pelvic Ultrasound ___

FINDINGS: The uterus measures 13.4 x 8.3 x 10.5 cm. There is an 
intramural 6.5 x 6.8 x 6.3 cm mid uterine fibroid causing 
distortion of the endometrium.  An IUD extends to the border of 
this fibroid and lies in the lower uterus or upper cervix. 
Multiple nabothian cysts are present. There is no free fluid. 
The ovaries are normal. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted into the gynecology service for routine 
post-operative care following her procedure. Her case was 
uncomplicated. Please refer to operative note for full details 
of her surgery. From a post-operative standpoint, she did well. 
Her foley was removed and she voided subsequently on 
post-operative day 1. She was discharged on post-operative day 1 
in good condition, adequate pain control, tolerating a regular 
diet, voiding and ambulating without difficulty. She will follow 
up outpatient for post-operative check within one week.
 
Medications on Admission:
- HCTZ 25mg daily
- Lisinopril 10mg daily
- Amlodipine 10mg daily

 
Discharge Medications:
1. oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Symptomatic fibroid uterus
Desires permanent sterilization

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Pelvic rest for 6 weeks, no exercise for two weeks. No lifting 
greater than 10 lbs. No driving for two weeks or if on 
narcotics.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Morphine / Iodine
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Recurrent Left forefoot infection s/p puncture wound
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo M transferred today, ___, for a L forefoot infection from 
___. His story begins a few months ago, 
when had a puncture-site infection at the base of his L ___ toe 
after stepping on a nail. This was debrided at that time and he 
was treated with a 4 week course of Vancomycin, finishing in 
early ___. By report, this was essentially healed. However, a 
few days after returning to work he noted progressively 
worsening swelling and tenderness. He was readmitted on ___ to 
the OSH, where he underwent additional debridement and was 
treated with IV Vancomycin and Zosyn. Wound cultures from the 
OSH were positive for Corynebacterium during his inital 
hospitalization and there is question of enterococcus from the 
recent wound debridement on ___, though I don't see the 
official report in the transfer documentation. He has had 2 
MRI's at the OSH during this infection, both of which were 
negative for osteomyelitis, the report from ___ is in the 
chart. A bone scan was also done on ___ at the OSH, which did 
not show uptake/osteo in the L forefoot. He has remained 
afebrile and denies subjective fevers or chills. He had a PICC 
placed on ___ at the OSH for anticipated long term antibiotics. 
Other than the foot infection, he has been feeling healthy and 
well.
 
Past Medical History:
None
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
On Discharge:
Afebrile, VSS
Gen: no distress
Chest: RRR, lungs clear
Abd: soft, nontender, nondistended
Ext: palpable pulses throughout, Left foot incision clean, no 
erythema or drainage
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 09:50PM BLOOD WBC-6.7 RBC-4.73 Hgb-14.7 Hct-41.3 MCV-87 
MCH-31.1 MCHC-35.7* RDW-13.5 Plt ___
___ 09:50PM BLOOD ___ PTT-24.5 ___
___ 09:50PM BLOOD Glucose-128* UreaN-13 Creat-1.1 Na-139 
K-3.8 Cl-101 HCO3-29 AnGap-13
___ 09:50PM BLOOD Calcium-10.0 Phos-3.2 Mg-2.1

Plain films of Left foot:
IMPRESSION:  Normal left foot.

MRI Left foot: result pending
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was transfered from a referring hospital with a 
recurrent left forefoot infection.  He was started on broad 
spectrum antibiotics and a wound culture was obtained.  The 
culture grew coag negative Staph, which is consistent with skin 
contamination so the antibiotics were stopped.  Podiatry was 
consulted.  Plain films of his left foot were normal.  A MRI of 
his left foot was obtained prior to discharge.  His foot does 
not seem to be currently infected.  He may be partial weight 
bearing on his left heel only.  If he needs to ambulate he may 
do so with crutches.  He will follow up in 2 weeks.  
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*20 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Weight Bearing Status
___ will be unable to perform any work activity that 
requires him to walk any considerable distance or stand for any 
extended period of time. He is limited to only partial weight 
bearing to the left heel and is to walk with cruthces at all 
times for at least 2 weeks from ___

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Recurrent left forefoot soft tissue infection

 
Discharge Condition:
Good

 
Discharge Instructions:
Call your physician or return to the Emergency Department if you 
develop:
- fever > 101.5
- chills
- purulent drainage from your foot incision
- increasing swelling or redness of your foot
- increasing pain that is not relieved by medication

You need to ambulate in your special boot to keep pressure off 
of your forefoot.  At your follow up appointment, you will 
receive further instructions. You should be partial weight 
bearing to the left heel. Use cruutches while ambulating.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: PODIATRY
 
Allergies: 
Morphine / Iodine / Shellfish Derived
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Abscess left foot
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Left ___ toe I&D with delayed primary closure

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ nondiabetic male, who presents to 
Dr. ___ a followup evaluation of an infected left foot.  
He is known to the service from his recent hospitalization.  The 
patient's history is that he stepped on a screw several weeks 
ago.  He had had two prior incision and drainage procedures at 
an outside hospital without resolution of his infection.  He was 
subsequently admitted to the ___ 
___ intravenous antibiotics.  During that course, he had 
daily dressing changes.  He also had an MRI of the left foot.  
The patient states that recently he has had no fevers or chills. 
 However, he continues to have pain in the foot.  He has noted
some slight increased redness at the base of the second toe with 
some drainage.  He is currently on no antibiotics.

 
Past Medical History:
None
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
VSS
Gen: NAD, AAO
HEENT: no LAD, EOMI
CV: RRR
Resp: CTAB
ABD: S, NT, ND, +BS
Ext: Reveals normal skin color, turgor, and temperature 
bilaterally.  Examination of the left foot shows an area of 
fluctuance and slight redness at the base of the second toe 
medially.  The plantar incisions themselves appear to be well 
healed.  strongly palpable pedal pulses bilaterally.
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 11:59AM BLOOD WBC-9.0# RBC-4.86 Hgb-15.6 Hct-42.3 
MCV-87 MCH-32.1* MCHC-36.8* RDW-13.2 Plt ___
___ 11:59AM BLOOD Neuts-67.3 ___ Monos-3.2 Eos-6.1* 
Baso-1.0
___ 11:59AM BLOOD Glucose-87 UreaN-17 Creat-1.0 Na-141 
K-4.2 Cl-102 HCO3-29 AnGap-14
___ 11:59AM BLOOD Calcium-9.5 Phos-4.0 Mg-2.1
.
___ 2:31 pm SWAB      SOFT TISSUE LEFT ___ DIGIT. 

                            **FINAL REPORT ___

   GRAM STAIN (Final ___: 
      NO POLYMORPHONUCLEAR LEUKOCYTES SEEN. 
      NO MICROORGANISMS SEEN. 

   WOUND CULTURE (Final ___: 
      STAPHYLOCOCCUS, COAGULASE NEGATIVE.    RARE GROWTH. 
      STAPHYLOCOCCUS, COAGULASE NEGATIVE.    RARE GROWTH. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Admitted through clinic.

Brought to the OR for an I&D of the left ___ digit and packed 
open.

Daily dressing changes/packing to encourage drainage.

Two days following I&D, the patient was closed at bedside.  
Ankle block and local v-block performed.  Prolene used to close 
the wound.  Betadine paint & DSD daily.

Cam walker & crutches dispensed for NWB on the left.

Given Rx for 2 weeks of Augmentin.

F/U with Dr. ___ in 1 week

Discharged in good condition
 
Medications on Admission:
Percocet ___ q4h
docusate sodium 100mg"
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
every ___ hours as needed.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Augmentin 875-125 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a 
day for 10 days.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
L ___ toe abscess

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted for an abscess in your left foot.  You were 
brought to the OR for an incision & drainage and the wound was 
packed open to drain.  You were closed at the bedside.  Please 
continue local wound care of daily: dilute betadine to incision 
site, dry sterile dressing and ACE.
.
Remain NONWEIGHT BEARING in the cam walker boot with crutches.  
.
You were given medication, please take as directed.  Please 
resume your home meds.
.
Please return to the ER or call the podiatry resident on call if 
you experience increased redness, swelling, increased pain, red 
streaks up the leg, fevers greater than 101.5 or any worsening 
symptoms.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___             ___ No:  ___

Admission Date: ___        Discharge Date: ___

Date of Birth:  ___        Sex:  F

Service:  OBS


ADMITTING DIAGNOSIS:  Urinary retention.

SECONDARY DIAGNOSES:
1. Multiple sclerosis flare.
2. Idiopathic thrombocytopenia.
3. Pregnancy.
4. Gestational diabetes.
5. Hypothyroidism.

DISCHARGE MEDICATION:  Prenatal vitamins.

DISCHARGE FOLLOWUP:  Is to follow up in ___ in
3 days for platelet count assessment.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:  Good.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is approximately 33
weeks pregnant and has noticed over the previous 48 hours
that she was unable to urinate with a lot of lower abdominal
pain, and still continued inability to urinate.  The patient
has a history of multiple sclerosis.  Has not had a flare in
___ years.  Was mainly optic involvement with the previous
flare.  The patient also is currently with IVF donor egg
pregnancy and was noted at approximately 26 weeks to have
severe idiopathic thrombocytopenia with platelet counts at
times getting as low as 18,000.  The patient was receiving
approximately every 2 weeks IgG therapy for 2 days which
would cause a temporary bump in her platelet count. The
patient also had some borderline insulin resistance from the
steroids that she was on for ITP.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  The patient had a catheter inserted which
was drained for 1.5 L of urine, and the catheter was left in
place.  An attempt the next day was made to do a voiding
trial.  The patient was continuing to have an inability to
urinate, so the catheter was replaced again for another L of
urine. Hematology consulted as well as Neurology.  MRI was
done, which had some new lesions in the thoracic part of the
spine that had not been on previous MRIs that had been done
at an outside institution.  Neurology was consulted, and
after urine culture was negative, and no other finding, the
decision was made that this was most likely due to an MS
flare, and different therapeutic options were considered.
The patient also had a low platelet count at the time of 20
k, and so was in need of her IgG therapy for her
thrombocytopenia.  After receiving 2 days of an IgG therapy
intravenous Neurology suggested that we continue the IgG for
another 3 days for a total 5 days to help treat her MS flare.
So she received 5 days of IgG therapy and her platelet count
went up to over 200,000, and a voiding trial on the ___ was successful, and the patient was able to successfully
void.  She also reported fewer restless leg movements and
twitching in her lower extremities from this.  After 24 hours
the patient was voiding well with no evidence of retained
urine or bladder dysfunction, and so the patient was
discharged to home.  At the time on ___ bedside
ultrasound showed good fetal well being.  With a good fetal
heart rate tracing that was reactive, and good amniotic
fluid, and an EFW that was the ___ percentile.  The patient
was to follow up in ___, as well as ___,
as well as general obstetrician's  clinic.  The patient will
follow up with her neurologist at ___ after discharge.



                        ___, MD

___ By:  ___, MD

MEDQUIST36
D:  ___ 15:49:41
T:  ___ 17:10:43
___:  ___

Service: OBS
ADMITTING DIAGNOSIS: Urinary retention.
SECONDARY DIAGNOSES:
1. Multiple sclerosis flare.
2. Idiopathic thrombocytopenia.
3. Pregnancy.
4. Gestational diabetes.
5. Hypothyroidism.
DISCHARGE MEDICATION: Prenatal vitamins.
DISCHARGE FOLLOWUP: Is to follow up in ___ in
3 days for platelet count assessment.
DISCHARGE CONDITION: Good.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is approximately 33
weeks pregnant and has noticed over the previous 48 hours
that she was unable to urinate with a lot of lower abdominal
pain, and still continued inability to urinate. The patient
has a history of multiple sclerosis. Has not had a flare in
___ years. Was mainly optic involvement with the previous
flare. The patient also is currently with IVF donor egg
pregnancy and was noted at approximately 26 weeks to have
severe idiopathic thrombocytopenia with platelet counts at
times getting as low as 18,000. The patient was receiving
approximately every 2 weeks IgG therapy for 2 days which
would cause a temporary bump in her platelet count. The
patient also had some borderline insulin resistance from the
steroids that she was on for ITP.
HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient had a catheter inserted which
was drained for 1.5 L of urine, and the catheter was left in
place. An attempt the next day was made to do a voiding
trial. The patient was continuing to have an inability to
urinate, so the catheter was replaced again for another L of
urine. Hematology consulted as well as Neurology. MRI was
done, which had some new lesions in the thoracic part of the
spine that had not been on previous MRIs that had been done
at an outside institution. Neurology was consulted, and
after urine culture was negative, and no other finding, the
decision was made that this was most likely due to an MS
flare, and different therapeutic options were considered.
The patient also had a low platelet count at the time of 20
k, and so was in need of her IgG therapy for her
thrombocytopenia. After receiving 2 days of an IgG therapy
intravenous Neurology suggested that we continue the IgG for
another 3 days for a total 5 days to help treat her MS flare.
So she received 5 days of IgG therapy and her platelet count
went up to over 200,000, and a voiding trial on the ___ was successful, and the patient was able to successfully
void. She also reported fewer restless leg movements and
twitching in her lower extremities from this. After 24 hours
the patient was voiding well with no evidence of retained
urine or bladder dysfunction, and so the patient was
discharged to home. At the time on ___ bedside
ultrasound showed good fetal well being. With a good fetal
heart rate tracing that was reactive, and good amniotic
fluid, and an EFW that was the ___ percentile. The patient
was to follow up in ___, as well as ___,
as well as general obstetrician's clinic. The patient will
follow up with her neurologist at ___ after discharge.
___, MD
___ By: ___, MD
MEDQUIST36
D: ___ 15:49:41
T: ___ 17:10:43
___: ___

Pertinent Results:

MCV-95 MCH-29.1 MCHC-30.5* RDW-17.0* Plt Ct-82*
___ 09:20AM BLOOD WBC-32.4*# RBC-3.07* Hgb-9.0* Hct-29.4* 
MCV-96 MCH-29.1 MCHC-30.4* RDW-16.5* Plt Ct-11*#
___ 01:45PM BLOOD WBC-29.1* RBC-2.80* Hgb-8.1* Hct-26.6* 
MCV-95 MCH-28.9 MCHC-30.4* RDW-16.5* Plt Ct-29*#
___ 05:40PM BLOOD WBC-28.7* RBC-2.66* Hgb-8.0* Hct-25.0* 
MCV-94 MCH-30.0 MCHC-31.9 RDW-16.6* Plt Ct-32*

___ 05:40PM BLOOD Creat-0.6
___ 05:40PM BLOOD ALT-18 AST-53* LD(LDH)-265* TotBili-0.1
___ 05:40PM BLOOD Hapto-121
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___, gravida 1, para 0, who presented to 
labor and delivery at 37 weeks' and 1 day gestation.  Of note, 
her pregnancy course had been complicated by multiple sclerosis 
and ITP.  For her ITP she had been followed by the Hematology 
service.  She was maintained on steroids and IVIG infusions.  
She presented at 3 cm of dilation.  She quickly progressed to 9 
cm, 100% effaced and a +1 station.  Her platelets were 82 on 
arrival. Given that she had a history of precipitous drops in 
her platelets after IVIG infusions, the Anesthesia service felt 
it would not be recommended to place an epidural catheter for 
her.  They recommended doing a fentanyl PCA and considering 
spinal.  When she progressed rapidly to 9 cm, decision was made 
to place a spinal for anesthesia during delivery.  A spinal was 
placed and she initially had good relief.  After the effect of 
the spinal had dissipated she was then switched to remifentanil 
PCA while pushing. She pushed for 3 hours with minimal descent 
of the fetal head.   After 3 hours in the ___ stage, she was 
counseled that she had made minimal progress, and a primary 
cesarean section was recommended for delivery. She agreed to 
proceed with a primary cesarean section.  She understood that 
the C-section would proceed under a general anesthetic due to 
her low platelet count.  Prior to the C- section her platelets 
were rechecked and were 77.  All consents were signed prior to 
the procedure. She delivered a liveborn male infant on 
___. Please see operative note for details. She was 
transferred to the postpartum floor in stable condition.

She was followed by hematology postpartum. She received stress 
dose steroids for her ITP followed by her home prednisone dose. 
Platelets were trended. She had nadir of 11K platelets PPD2 and 
received IVIG x 2 and platelet transfusion with appropriate rise 
in platelets to 105k. She had a recurrence of urinary retention 
of 1600cc on ___ consistent with history of multiple 
sclerosis flare. Urology was consulted and recommended foley for 
7 days with follow up trial of void at that time. Her primary 
neurologist was following her during her hospital stay and 
recommended IVIG for 5 days from ___. 

For her gestational hypertension, her blood pressures were in 
the non-severe range without symptoms of pre-clampsia and did 
not require antihypertensive medication. 

She was discharged home in stable condition on postpartum day 9

 
Medications on Admission:
1. 80mg prednisone
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain 
2. Levothyroxine Sodium 75 mcg PO DAILY 
3. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
4. PredniSONE 40 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Arrest of descent of labor
2. Multiple sclerosis
3. ITP
4. Hypothyroid

 
Discharge Condition:
good

 
Discharge Instructions:
rest. no heavy lifting, exercise, baths for 4 weeks
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
MVC, left ___ humerus fracture
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
left proximal humerus open reduction internal fixation

 
History of Present Illness:
___ s/p motorcycle vs auto accident tonight ___ w/ left
humeral head fracture, dislocation. Pt helmeted rider of
motorcycle at ~30miles per hour when car crossed into his ___
resulting in a collision. Pt denies any LOC, able to call ___ 
for
help. Found HD stable. He was BIBA to OSH where he was found to
have a left humeral head fracture, dislocation. CT head/c-spine
unremarkable. Pt denies any numbness/tingling/weakness in his
left upper extremity since the accident. He has sharp pain,
swelling localized to the left shoulder. No open wounds. 

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: 
HTN, high cholesterol, DM
 
PSH
appendectomy, umbilical hernia repair, hand surgery

 
Social History:
unemployed, worked as ___, lives with ___, denies smoking,
social drinker, no drugs

 
Physical Exam:
AFVSS
NAD, AAO X 3
RRR
CTAB
S/NT/ND
Left arm: In splint. Hand: SILT(ulnar,median/radial). Motor 
intact( wrist flexion/ext, finger 
flexion/extension/abduction/adduction)
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Hospital Course
Mr. ___ presented to the ___ on ___ after a MVC. He was 
evaluated by the orthopaedic surgery service and found to have a 
left proximal humerus fracture with significant dislocation  He 
was admitted,consented, and prepped for surgery.  On ___ he 
was taken to the operating room and underwent an ORIF of his 
left proximal humerus fracture.  He tolerated the procedure 
well, was extubated, 
transferred to the recovery room, and then to the floor.  On the 
floor he was seen by physical therapy to improve his strength 
and mobility.  

The rest of his hospital stay was uneventful with his lab data 
and vital signs within normal limits and his pain controlled.  
He is being discharged today in stable condition.

 
Discharge Medications:
1. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 hours) 
as needed for Pain.
Disp:*100 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
3. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO BID (2 times a day) 
as needed for Constipation.
Disp:*90 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. lisinopril 20 mg Tablet Sig: 1.5 Tablets PO DAILY (Daily).  
5. atorvastatin 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left proximal humerus fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory 

 
Discharge Instructions:
Continue to be non weight bearing on left upper extremity
Continue to be weight bearing as tolerated on your right upper 
extremity
Continue to be weight bearing as tolerated on your right leg
Continue to be weight bearing as tolerated on your left leg
 
Wound Care:
- Keep Incision clean and dry. Cover with dry streile gauze 
daily until completely dry. Then can shower and leave uncovered. 

- Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool.

Activity:
- Continue left upper extremity sling for comfort
- ___ start gentle left shoulder pendulum exercises in first 
week. Range of motion in left elbow, wrist as tolerated
- Continue to be full weight bearing on your right and left 
legs.
 
Other Instructions
- Resume your regular diet.
- Avoid nicotine products to optimize healing.
- Resume your home medications. Take all medications as 
instructed.
- If you have any increased redness, drainage, or swelling, or 
if you have a temperature greater than 101.5, please call the 
office or come to the emergency department.
- You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain. Please allow 72 hours ___ through ___, 9am to 
4pm) for refill of narcotic prescriptions, so plan ahead. There 
will be no prescription refils on ___, or 
holidays. You can either have them mailed to your home or pick 
them up at the clinic located on ___ 2. We are not allowed 
to call in narcotic (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) 
prescriptions to the pharmacy. In addition, we are only allowed 
to write for pain medications for 90 days from the date of 
surgery.
- Narcotic pain medication may cause drowsiness. Do not drink 
alcohol while taking narcotic medications. Do not operate any 
motor vehicle or machinery while taking narcotic pain 
medications. Taking more than recommended may cause serious 
breathing problems.
 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ right-hand dominant
gentleman who has had a difficult history with his left shoulder
on ___.  He sustained a left shoulder fracture 
dislocation
and underwent open reduction internal fixation of the left
proximal humerus fracture with Dr. ___ in my group 
here
at ___.  Unfortunately, the time following that he had
progressive pain and disability he had removal of the associated
hardware on ___.  At the time since then, he has had
persistent pain and persistent disability.  He was referred for
an MRI.  This was completed at the ___ at the ___ on the ___ on ___.  When his MRI confirmed
the presence of a subscapularis tendon tear and his radiographic
examination demonstrated progressive osteonecrosis, he was
referred to my attention for ongoing management of his shoulder
pain and disability.

extension, left and right bending, left and right rotation.  He
has no radiculopathy with axial compression.  He has no
tenderness in the posterior midline.

limitation
in range of motion, active forward elevation is 100 degrees,
active external rotation with his arm at side is 10 degrees,
passively is 10 degrees.  His strength examination is ___ on
internal rotation, ___ in external rotation, and ___ in the 
plane
of scapula.  He has a positive EPL, APB, and ADQ.  His fingers
are warm to touch with good capillary refill.

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:43PM   GLUCOSE-144* LACTATE-1.7 NA+-136 K+-4.2

POD#1 Transitioned from Pain Catheter to PO meds.

POD#___ontrolled. Discharged to home.
 
Medications on Admission:
1. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain.

(Daily).

day).

Home

Stable

ERCP
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo female with h/o cholelithiasis, obesity presenting with 
acute abd pain, nausea.  Patient has had these symptoms for ___ 
months with episodes of epigastric pain with nausea and vomiting 
which resolved in usually 30min - 1hour.  She states there was 
no association with po intake or time of day.  The episode last 
night lasted for ___ hours and she came to the ER.  Rated ___ 
sharp pain in the epigastric region, no radiation.  She noted 
nausea with no vomiting/diarrhea.  Previous work up by outpt 
gastroenterologist showed nothing on EGD and she was being 
treated for GERD with ppi.  It was noted she had gallstones, but 
the symptoms were not believed to be consistent with 
cholelithiasis.  She has no associated f/c/cp sob and no recent 
travel or changes in her diet(has lost 100# over the past yeasr 
with diet/exercise)

Pertinent ROS noted above, rest of 10 point ros wnl

obesity with 100# loss
GERD
depression

___

No family h/o biliary or liver disease

Admission exam
Vitals
98.1 51 122/81 18 100%

HEENT: mmm op clear
Neck: supple no jvd
CV: rrr no m/r/g
pulm: ctab no w/r/r
abd: soft nt nd bs+
ext no ___ edema good pedal pulses

Discharge exam
VSS

HEENT: mmm no oral ulcers or bleeding
Neck: supple no jvd
CV: rrr no m/r/g
pulm: ctab no w/r/r
abd: soft nontender, bs + 
ext no ___ edema good pedal pulses
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 10:50AM   ___ PTT-30.3 ___

___ 03:20AM   GLUCOSE-109* UREA N-15 CREAT-1.0 SODIUM-139 
POTASSIUM-5.9* CHLORIDE-103 TOTAL CO2-24 ANION GAP-18
___ 03:20AM   ALT(SGPT)-429* AST(SGOT)-624* ALK PHOS-101 
TOT BILI-1.2
___ 03:20AM   LIPASE-38
___ 03:20AM   ASA-NEG ETHANOL-NEG ACETMNPHN-NEG 
bnzodzpn-NEG barbitrt-NEG tricyclic-NEG
___ 03:20AM   WBC-6.9 RBC-4.93 HGB-13.6 HCT-40.3 MCV-82 
MCH-27.7 MCHC-33.8 RDW-13.8
___ 03:20AM   PLT COUNT-281

abd ultrasound: ___
IMPRESSION: 
1. Partially distended gallbladder, with multiple gallstones. No 
specific 
signs for acute cholecystitis. 
2. New CBD dilation to the level of the pancreatic head, 
suggesting 
obstructive choledocholithiasis. Recommend MRCP or ERCP to 
assess the distal 
CBD. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
A/P:
___ yo female with h/o obesity, GERD, cholelithiasis presenting 
with acute abd pain x 12 hours with associated nausea.  
Ultrasound showing cholelithiasis and dilated CBD consistent 
with choledocholithiasis.  No signs of cholecystitis and with no 
fevers or jaundice does not appear to have cholangitis.  
Transaminitis is noted.  Patient to be admitted for pain control 
and ERCP.
.
#?Choledocholithiasis
ERCP was performed, with no ductal dilation noted, small amount 
of sludge noted.  HIDA scan was performed and neg for 
cholecystitis.  Transaminitis persisted during hospitalization, 
but bili/alk phos were normal, viral hepatitis panel was neg, 
iron panel esr, crp and tsh normal.  Her symptoms resolved 
completely during hospitalization and she will plan to follow up 
with her pcp at which time lft can be repeated and, if still 
elevated may require further evaluation by hepatology.

Cholelithiasis:
Surgery evaluated the patient for possible cholecystectomy.  
HIDA scan was neg for cholecystitis.  She will f/u in surgery 
clinic in ___.
 
Medications on Admission:
Omeprazole 40 bid
 
Discharge Medications:
1. omeprazole 40 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO twice a day.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
biliary sludge
abnormal lft
cholelithiasis
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you.  You presented with 
abdominal pain and abnormal liver tests.  An ultrasound found 
stones in your gallbladder.  An ercp was performed and biliary 
sludge was removed.  Your symptoms resolved.  General surgery 
evaluated for possible cholecystectomy, but deferred for now and 
will be able to follow up in the general surgery clinic
 
Followup Instructions:
___

done on ___ which was stable (1.2-1.45 residual length). She

during this admission. On ___, ultrasound revealed breech, AFI

text:
Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
metastatic testicular cancer
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
robotic RPLND

 
History of Present Illness:
___ years old, is a
history of right orchiectomy ___.  He had new retroperitoneal
nodes ___ and underwent 3 cycles of BEP.  He had a residual 
mass
in the retroperitoneum which is been followed conservatively.  
In
particular there is a intra-aortocaval mass which was about 3 cm
back in ___ which is been slowly growing.  In ___ CT scan 
again
identified the lymph node which was measured at 2 cm and was
deemed stable.  He recently seen at ___ where imaging
again revealed a relatively stable intra-aortocaval region just
below the pancreas measuring 2.6 x 2.2 x 3.4 cm.  I reviewed 
this
image personally and concur.

Has seen Dr. ___ at ___ recently, who's team also
recommended RPLND and ___ wants to discuss surgery today.

Recent tumor markers at the ___ in ___ were as follows:
HCG less than 0.6
AFP 1.7
LDH 141

We discussed different surgical approaches including open or
robotic RPLND. He has agreed to proceed with a robotic RPLND. 
 
Past Medical History:
Right testicular mass: mixed germ cell tumor (70% seminoma and
30% embryonal carcinoma), appendicitis

PShx: Radical orchiectomy, open appendectomy ___ years ago)

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
No history of IBD
Aunt - ___ cancer
Dad - ___ clots and is on ___ thinners
Mother - ___ DM
___ - 5 brothers and 1 sister who are healthy

 
Physical Exam:
Gen: NAD, resting comfortably, AAO
 Pulm: nonlabored breathing, normal chest rise, acyanotic
 Abd: soft, NT, ND, incisions cdi
 Ext: WWP
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:20AM ___ WBC-14.9* RBC-4.89 Hgb-15.0 Hct-44.1 
MCV-90 MCH-30.7 MCHC-34.0 RDW-12.9 RDWSD-42.5 Plt ___
___ 05:20AM ___ Glucose-119* UreaN-8 Creat-1.0 Na-138 
K-4.2 Cl-98 HCO3-25 AnGap-15
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the urology service post-op. See op note 
for details of procedure.

Hospital course was unremarkable. Diet was advanced as tolerated 
and he was transitioned to PO pain meds. He passed a void trial 
on POD1.

He was deemed fit for discharge on POD1. 
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q4H:PRN fever  
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
3.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
testicular cancer

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental status: appropriate
Ambulatory

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Please also refer to the provided handout that details 
instructions and expectations for your post-operative phase as 
made available by your urologist. 

-Resume your pre-admission/home medications except as noted. 
ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication changes 
and your post-operative course with your primary care doctor.

-___ reduce the strain/pressure on your abdomen and incision 
sites; remember to log roll onto your side and then use your 
hands to push yourself upright while taking advantage of the 
momentum of putting your legs/feet to the ground.

--There may be bandage strips called steristrips which have 
been applied to reinforce wound closure.  Allow these bandage 
strips to fall off on their own over time but PLEASE REMOVE ANY 
REMAINING GAUZE DRESSINGS WITHIN 2 DAYS OF DISCHARGE. You may 
get the steristrips wet.

-UNLESS OTHERWISE NOTED; AVOID aspirin or aspirin containing 
products and supplements that may have ___ effects 
(like Fish Oil, Vitamin E, etc.).  This will be noted in your 
medication reconciliation. 

IF PRESCRIBED (see the MEDICATION RECONCILIATION):

-IBUPROFEN (the ingredient of Advil, Motrin, etc.) may be taken 
even though you may also be taking Tylenol/Acetaminophen. You 
may alternate these medications for pain control.  

For pain control, try TYLENOL (acetaminophen) FIRST, then 
ibuprofen, and then take the narcotic pain medication as 
prescribed if additional pain relief is needed.

-Ibuprofen should always be taken with food. Please discontinue 
taking and notify your doctor should you develop ___ in your 
stool (dark, tarry stools)

-Call your Urologist's office to schedule/confirm your follow-up 
appointment in 4 weeks AND if you have any questions.

-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until 
otherwise advised. Light household chores/activity and leisurely 
walking/activity is OK and should be continued. Do NOT be a 
couch potato

-Tylenol should be your first-line pain medication. A narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain ___.

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is THREE to FOUR grams 
from ALL sources

    AVOID lifting/pushing/pulling items heavier than 10 pounds 
(or 3 kilos; about a gallon of milk) or participate in high 
intensity physical activity (which includes intercourse) until 
you are cleared by your Urologist in follow-up.

-No DRIVING for THREE WEEKS or until you are cleared by your 
Urologist

-You may shower normally but do NOT immerse your incisions or 
bathe

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery

-You may be given prescriptions for a stool softener and/or a 
gentle laxative. These are  over-the-counter medications that 
may be health care spending account reimbursable. 

-Colace (docusate sodium) may have been prescribed to avoid 
post-surgical constipation or constipation related to use of 
narcotic pain medications. Discontinue if loose stool or 
diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool-softener, NOT a laxative.

-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
go to the nearest emergency room.

 
Followup Instructions:
___
