text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Morphine Sulfate / Ephedrine
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
nausea/vomitting
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
___ s/p lap gastric banding two days prior to presentation.  
She presents w nausea and vomitting x 4 associated with 
heartburn.  She states that she was tolerating liquids without 
difficulty until that evenning when she began to vomit.  She 
denies any shortness of breath, chest pain, palpitations, 
fevers, chills, or discomfort associated with the nausea besides 
the heartburn.
 
Past Medical History:
morbid obesity, "panic attacks" for which she takes prozac, h/o 
chest pain x1 last summer, reports h/o irregular HR/extra beats, 
s/p c-sections, TAH, appy, hernia repair 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
no CAD or sudden death
 
Physical Exam:
AVSS
Gen: NAD, A+Ox3
Lungs: CTAB
CV: RRR, -MRG
Abd: soft, approp tender, nondistended.  Inc=clean, dry, intact. 
 +BS.
Ext: no edema
 
Pertinent Results:
___ KUB
1. Lap band projecting in expected location just to the left of 
midline adjacent to T10.
2. Distended but not dilated loops of bowel suggestive of ileus.

___ 05:45AM BLOOD WBC-7.2 RBC-4.24 Hgb-12.9 Hct-37.9 MCV-89 
MCH-30.5 MCHC-34.1 RDW-13.4 Plt ___
___ 05:40AM BLOOD Glucose-67* UreaN-8 Creat-0.7 Na-139 
K-4.4 Cl-107 HCO3-19* AnGap-17
___ 05:45AM BLOOD Glucose-81 UreaN-7 Creat-0.7 Na-141 K-4.1 
Cl-105 HCO3-25 AnGap-15
___ 05:40AM BLOOD Calcium-8.6 Phos-2.5* Mg-1.8
___ 05:45AM BLOOD Calcium-8.7 Phos-3.6 Mg-2.0
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the surgical service for further 
evaluation and treatment.  EKG showed no evidence of myocardial 
ischemia.  She was made NPO and an NG tube was placed in the 
emergency department.  A KUB was done which showed likely ileus. 
 However, on the following day she began to pass flatus.  The NG 
tube was discontinued without any return of nausea/vomitting.  
Her diet was advanced to Stage 1 bariatric diet.  She was 
advanced to a Stage 2 diet without difficulty.  On the day of 
discharge she was advanced to a Stage 3 diet and was tolerating 
this without any nausea, vomitting, or pain.  She was discharged 
in good/stable condition.
 
Medications on Admission:
roxicet ___ Q4-6hrs PRN pain, prozac 40mg PO daily, 
metoprolol 25mg PO daily
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Prozac 40 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO once a day.  
2. Metoprolol Succinate 50 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr 
Sig: One (1) ___ Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO once a day.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
nausea/vomitting s/p lap gastric banding

 
Discharge Condition:
good/stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the 
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
* Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or 

back.

*Avoid lifting objects > 5lbs until your follow-up appointment 
with the surgeon.

*Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
as ordered. 
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.

Incision Care:
-Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
-You may shower, and wash surgical incisions.
-Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
-Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ KUB

midline adjacent to T10.
2. Distended but not dilated loops of bowel suggestive of ileus.
___ 05:45AM BLOOD WBC-7.2 RBC-4.24 Hgb-12.9 Hct-37.9 MCV-89
MCH-30.5 MCHC-34.1 RDW-13.4 Plt ___

___ 05:45AM BLOOD Calcium-8.7 Phos-3.6 Mg-2.0
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the surgical service for further
evaluation and treatment. EKG showed no evidence of myocardial
ischemia. She was made NPO and an NG tube was placed in the
emergency department. A KUB was done which showed likely ileus. However, on the following day she began to pass flatus. The NG
tube was discontinued without any return of nausea/vomitting.
Her diet was advanced to Stage 1 bariatric diet. She was
advanced to a Stage 2 diet without difficulty. On the day of
discharge she was advanced to a Stage 3 diet and was tolerating
this without any nausea, vomitting, or pain. She was discharged
in good/stable condition.
Medications on Admission:
roxicet ___ Q4-6hrs PRN pain, prozac 40mg PO daily,
metoprolol 25mg PO daily
Discharge Medications:
1. Prozac 40 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO once a day.
2. Metoprolol Succinate 50 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr
Sig: One (1) ___ Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO once a day.
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
nausea/vomitting s/p lap gastric banding
Discharge Condition:
good/stable
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or
tightness.
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting,
diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry
mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a
bowel movement.
* Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or not gone
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or
back.
*Avoid lifting objects > 5lbs until your follow-up appointment
with the surgeon.
*Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain
medications.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F)
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that
concern you.
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new
meds
as ordered.
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.
Incision Care:
-Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
-You may shower, and wash surgical incisions.
-Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
-Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling,
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service 
after undergoing total abdominal hysterectomy and left 
salpingectomy for menorrhagia. Please see the operative report 
for full details.

Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. Immediately 
post-op, her pain was controlled with an epidural managed by the 
acute pain service. On post-operative day 1 her pain was well 
controlled, and her epidural was removed. At that point, her 
urine output was adequate so her foley was removed and she 
voided spontaneously. Her diet was advanced without difficulty 
and she was transitioned to PO oxycodone, ibuprofen, and 
acetaminophen. 

By post-operative day 2, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was 
controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home 
in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

 
Medications on Admission:
amlodipine 5', lisinopril 20', MVI, zyrtec, mirena IUD

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Amlodipine 5 mg PO DAILY 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
3. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth q6h prn Disp #*50 
Tablet Refills:*1
4. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 
5. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
Do not exceed more than 4,000mg in 24 hrs 
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth q6h prn Disp 
#*50 Tablet Refills:*1
6. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  5 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone [Oxaydo] 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four 
(4) hours Disp #*45 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
menorrhagia

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecology service after your 
procedure. You have recovered well and the team believes you are 
ready to be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ office 
with any questions or concerns. Please follow the instructions 
below.

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 6 
weeks.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No tub baths for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the hospital and evaluated by the 
Acute Care service.  Her liver ultrasound showed a 1 cm stone at 
the gallbladder neck.  She was subsequently taken to the 
Operating Room where she underwent a laparoscopic 
cholecystectomy.  She tolerated the procedure well and returned 
to the PACU in stable condition.  She maintained stable 
hemodynamics and her pain was well controlled.

Following transfer to the Surgical floor she continued to make 
good progress.  She was able to tolerate a regular diet and she 
was up and walking without difficulty.  Her port sites were dry. 
 After an uncomplicated recovery she discharged to home on 
/___ and will follow up in the ___ in ___ weeks.
 
Medications on Admission:
OCP
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Resume your birth contol pills as directed.
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute cholecystitis.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain from 
your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and 
impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate 
machinery safely. You MUST  refrain from such activities while 
taking these medications.

 

 

Please call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you 
have any of the following:
 

 * You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
 tightness.
 
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
 medications.
 
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
 diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
 mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
 
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
 bowel movement.
 

* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
 degrees or 38(C) degrees.
 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
 concern you. 
 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
 as ordered.  

Activity:
No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may 
resume moderate
exercise at your discretion, no abdominal exercises.

Wound Care:
You may shower, no tub baths or swimming. 

If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with 
clean, dry gauze. 
Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ is a ___ year old female who presented to the ED c/ 
abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and fevers. She had a RUQ 
ultrasound which was unremarkable, mildly elevated amylase and 
lipase, and an unremarkable abdominal CT. She was admitted for 
pain control and inability to tolerate PO. She was started on IV 
fluids. During her hospitalization she had a dedicated rib x-ray 
due to point tenderness over her R rib which was negative for 
fracture. Her pain improved and she was able to tolerate clears. 
GI was consulted and performed a EGD which showed a small hiatal 
hernia and mild gastritis. Ms. ___ was started on a PPI. IVF 
were discontinued. She continued to have mild b/l lower quadrant 
abdominal pain, similar in nature to her chronic pain associated 
for her endometriosis. She was able to tolerate PO and was 
discharged home with prescription for Pantoprazole and 
instructions to follow up with her primary care physician and 
gynecologist.

Home

Abdominal pain

Stable. Tolerating PO.

You were admitted to the hospital for abdominal pain. You had a 
CT of your abdomen that was normal and an endoscopy that showed 
mild gastritis. You were started on a new medication for your 
stomach called pantoprazole. You should take this medication at 
home as directed. 

You should return to your physician or the ER for increasing 
pain, inability to keep down fluids, fevers, chills, blood in 
your bowel movements or any other concerning symptoms.

GI was consulted and performed a EGD which showed a small hiatal
hernia and mild gastritis. Ms. ___ was started on a PPI. IVF
were discontinued. She continued to have mild b/l lower quadrant
abdominal pain, similar in nature to her chronic pain associated
for her endometriosis. She was able to tolerate PO and was
discharged home with prescription for Pantoprazole and
instructions to follow up with her primary care physician and
gynecologist.
Medications on Admission:
Multivitamin
Discharge Medications:
___
2. Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One
(1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO twice a day for 1 months.
Disp:*30 Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.)(s)* Refills:*0*
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Abdominal pain
Discharge Condition:
Stable. Tolerating PO.
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital for abdominal pain. You had a
CT of your abdomen that was normal and an endoscopy that showed
mild gastritis. You were started on a new medication for your
stomach called pantoprazole. You should take this medication at
home as directed.
You should return to your physician or the ER for increasing
pain, inability to keep down fluids, fevers, chills, blood in
your bowel movements or any other concerning symptoms.
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to the Orthopedic service on ___ 
for a right tibia and fibula fracture.  On ___ he underwent 
open reduction internal fixation of the right tibia and fibula 
without complication.  On ___ he did well with physical 
therapy and had good pain management.  He was discharged to home 
on ___ in stable condition.
 
Medications on Admission:
NOne
 
Discharge Medications:
1. enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL Syringe Sig: One (1)  Subcutaneous 
DAILY (Daily) for 4 weeks.
Disp:*28 syringe* Refills:*0*
2. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 hours) 
as needed for Pain.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. multivitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Cap PO DAILY (Daily).

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right distal tib/fib fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Wound Care: 
-Keep Incision dry. 
-Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool.

Activity: 
-Continue to be touch down weight bearing on your Right leg.

Other Instructions
- Resume your regular diet. 
- Avoid nicotine products to optimize healing. 
- Resume your home medications. Take all medications as 
instructed. 

- Continue taking the Lovenox to prevent blood clots.

-You have also been given Additional Medications to control your 

pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so plan ahead. You can either have them mailed to 

your home or pick them up at the clinic located on ___. We 

are not allowed to call in narcotic (oxycontin, oxycodone, 
percocet) prescriptions to the pharmacy. In addition, we are 
only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days from the 
date of surgery.

- Narcotic pain medication may cause drowsiness. Do not drink 
alcohol while taking narcotic medications. Do not operate any 
motor vehicle or machinery while taking narcotic pain 
medications. Taking more than recommended may cause serious 
breathing problems.

If you have questions, concerns or experience any of the below 
danger signs then please call your doctor at ___ or go 
to your local emergency room.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Neuro: Speech fluent
Psych: Normal mood, Normal mentation

Pertinent Results:
___ 12:30AM   GLUCOSE-86 UREA N-8 CREAT-0.7 SODIUM-138 
POTASSIUM-4.0 CHLORIDE-104 TOTAL CO2-24 ANION GAP-14
___ 12:30AM   ALT(SGPT)-123* AST(SGOT)-58* ALK PHOS-53 TOT 
BILI-0.1
___ 12:30AM   WBC-8.9 RBC-4.68 HGB-12.1 HCT-36.6 MCV-78*

___ 12:30AM   NEUTS-62.1 ___ MONOS-5.4 EOS-1.9 
BASOS-0.5
___ 12:30AM   PLT COUNT-240

MRI Pelvis/Abd
IMPRESSION: 
1. Normal appearance of the appendix. 
2. Uterine contractions identified during the examination. 
3. Posterior location of the placenta, with inferior tip, is 
positioned 
approximately 1 cm from the internal cervical os. While this 
finding is 
unlikely to represent a placenta previa, this can be further 
assessed on the patient's next obstetric ultrasound. 
  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
She was admitted to the hospital with symptoms concerning for 
appendicitis. She was placed NPO and given IV fluids. Unasyn was 
started. She underwent gallbladder ultrasound showing no 
evidence of cholecystitis; an MRI of her pelvis and abdomen were 
also obtained which did not reveal appendicitis.

Over the course of the next ___ hours her symptoms completely 
resolved. She was given a diet for which she was able to 
tolerate. At time of discharge she was pain free and ambulating 
independently. Her antibiotics were switched to Augmentin. She 
will follow up with her primary providers as an outpatient.
 
Medications on Admission:
prenatal vitamins, iron pills 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. amoxicillin-pot clavulanate 500-125 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO Q8H (every 8 hours) for 7 days.
Disp:*qs Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Prenatal Plus ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a 
day.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
r/o Appendicitis
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with symptoms concerning for 
appendicitis. You were given bowel rest and your abdominal 
examination was followed very closely and within approx 24 hour 
period your sympotms resolved without any surgical intervention. 
You have also demonstrated that you are able to tolerate solids.

If the symptoms that brought you into the hopsital return plesea 
return to the Emergency room.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ had a normal spontaneous vaginal delivery with a 
second degree laceration repaired in the usual fashion.  Shortly 
thereafter she began to complain of rectal pressure.  
Examination revealed a vaginal hematoma.  She was taken the 
operating room for evacuation and repair.  Please see operative 
note for full details.

She was transferred to the post-partum floor in stable condition 
with serial hematocrits.  Her hematocrit trended down to 18.9%.  
Although she remained symptomatic and hemodynamically stable, 
she accepted a transfusion of 2u PRBCs for cardiovascular 
support.  Her post-transfusion hematocrit was 22.7.  Hematocrit 
the following day was stable at 23.1.  She had vaginal packing 
after the hematoma repair that was removed on POD1.  She 
remained on antibiotics until the packing was removed.  She had 
an otherwise unremarkable post-partum course.  She was 
discharged home in stable condition on post-partum day 3.
 
Medications on Admission:
ALBUTEROL SULFATE
FLONASE

times a day as needed for Constipation.

Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for Pain.

hours) as needed for Pain.

hours: infant separation & illness.  poor latch. hospital grade.

Home

term pregnancy delivered

blood loss anemia

good

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Do not smoke.
Keep your wound clean and dry /Keep incision dry until ___/ 
No tub baths or pool swimming until seen in follow up.
You have steri-strips in place, you must keep them dry for 72 
hours.  Do not pull them off. They will fall off on their own or 
be taken off in the office.  You may trim the edges if they 
begin to curl.
No pulling up, lifting more than 10 lbs., or excessive bending 
or twisting for 2 weeks then increase slowly as tolerated.
Limit your use of stairs to ___ times per day.
Check your incision daily for signs of infection.
Take your pain medication as instructed; you may find it best 
if taken in the morning when you wake-up for morning stiffness, 
and before bed for sleeping discomfort.
Do not take any anti-inflammatory medications such as Motrin, 
Advil, Aspirin, and Ibuprofen etc. for three months to increase 
chance of fusion.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as pain medicine 
(narcotics) can cause constipation. We recommend taking an over 
the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) while 
taking narcotic pain medication.
*  You shall be receiving a bone stimulator, use daily as 
directed. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Codeine
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
s/p MVC 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ s/p MVC v tree. Restrained driver. ?LOC, no airbag, +EtOH.  
Found ambulatory on scene.  Seen at ___. CT Head, C 
spine, Torso performed there - has C5  facet fracture extending 
into lamina. Also with L third and 
sixth rib fractures.

 
Past Medical History:
s/p appendectomy
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
nc
 
Physical Exam:
Temp:99.9 HR:82 BP:131/84 Resp:14 O(2)Sat:99% normal 
 
Constitutional: Boarded and collared
HEENT: head abrasion, no lacerations, no battles, no 
raccoon,
c-collar in place, no hemotympanum
Chest: Clear to auscultation. No crepitus, no flail. Focal 
TTP over lateral L rib cage
Cardiovascular: Regular Rate and Rhythm, Normal first and 
second heart sounds
Abdominal: Soft, Nontender. FAST negative
GU/Flank: TTP at T4, otherwise no midline TTP T/L/S
Extr/Back: ___ ___ bilaterally.
Skin: abrasion L hip
Neuro: mildly slurred speech, no focal deficits appreciated
Psych: cooperative, intoxicated
___: No petechiae
 

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 03:00AM   WBC-14.2* RBC-5.47 HGB-16.0 HCT-46.8 MCV-86 
MCH-29.2 MCHC-34.1 RDW-13.5
___ 03:00AM   ___ PTT-22.6 ___
___ 03:00AM   PLT COUNT-317
___ 03:00AM   ASA-NEG ___ ACETMNPHN-NEG 
bnzodzpn-NEG barbitrt-NEG tricyclic-NEG
___ 03:29AM   GLUCOSE-94 LACTATE-1.5 NA+-146 K+-4.7 CL--96* 
TCO2-25
___ 03:00AM   UREA N-13 CREAT-1.0

___ MR ___ spine : C4/5: Moderate sized disc-osteophyte 
complex/ extrusion, right paracentral in location deforming/ 
mildly compressing the cord with moderate canal stenosis and 
displacing the PLL; increased t2 signal in the C4 and C5 bodies 
- marrow edema/contusion. 
Increased T2 signal in the cervical cord at C5/6 level- edema/ 
contusion 
Assessment of facet joints is limited; mildly increased signal 
in the right facet at C5/6 levels. However, correlation with CT 
is necessary for better assesment. Prevertebral 
edema/fluid/hemorrhage from C4 to C6 levels. Multilevel 
degenerative changes. 

___ CT C spine : 1. Acute comminuted fracture of C5 right 
lamina with involvement of the superior and inferior articular 
facets. There is no extension into the foramen transversarium. 
There is a mild amount of neighboring soft tissue swelling. 
2. Multilevel degenerative changes, worst at C6/7 with disc 
space narrowing and mild canal stenosis. 
3. Mild apical paraseptal emphysema. 
4. Slight reversal of the normal cervical lordosis. 
  

  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was evaluated by the Trauma team in the Emergency 
Room as well as the Ortho spine service to assess his C 5 lamina 
fracture involving the inferior and superior articular facets.  
He had some tenderness to palpation but no neurologic sequela.

He was admitted to the hospital for pain management in light of 
his rib fractures, piulmonary toilet and neck immobilization.  
He was able to take a regular diet without any problems and was 
able to mobilize himself easily with his ___ j collar in 
place.  He was using his incentive spirometer and remained free 
of any pulmonary complications. His pain was adequately 
controlled with Oxycodone and Tylenol.

After an uncomplicated stay he was discharged to home on ___ 
and will follow up with Dr. ___ this week.
 
Medications on Admission:
Chantix
Albuteral prn
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain for 14 days.
Disp:*90 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Albuterol Sulfate 90 mcg/Actuation HFA Aerosol Inhaler Sig: 
___ Puffs Inhalation Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for SOB, 
wheezing for 14 days.
Disp:*1 1* Refills:*1*
3. Acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain for 7 days.
Disp:*14 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
C5 tranverse facet fx
L Rib fx x2

 
Discharge Condition:
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Wear your ___ J collar at all times.
Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you experience 
the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

NO heavy lifting for the next 8 weeks.
Continue to use your incentive

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Home

Knee Pain

Discharge Instructions:
MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.
ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take aspirin daily for 2 weeks
WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- No dressing is needed if wound continues to be non-draining.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Non Weight Bearing Left Lower Extremity. ___ locked in 5 
degrees of hyperextension

___

Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F

Allergies: 
Pertussis Vaccine,Fluid
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
neck pain 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
c5-6 ACDF

 
History of Present Illness:
___ is a ___ year old female with neck and right arm
pain. She failed conservative therapies and now presents for
elective surgical intervention. 
 
Past Medical History:
obesity with 100# loss
GERD
depression
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
No family h/o biliary or liver disease
 
Physical Exam:
gen: lying in hospital bed comfortably
resp: non labored
neuro:
- motor: ___ throughout ___ upper extremities. sensory intact in 
all distributions. 2+ triceps reflex. 
incision: anterior neck incision with dressing c/d/I. c-collar 
in place. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ year old female with neck and right arm
pain. She failed conservative therapies and now presents for
elective surgical intervention. She underwent c5-6 ACDF and 
recovered unremarkably. post op imaging showed stable construct. 
she was discharged home on post op day with c-collar in place, 
pain well controlled with oral pain meds, ambulating safely 
independently and voiding spontaneously. 
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H 
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg 2 tablet(s) by mouth every 8 hours Disp 
#*100 Tablet Refills:*0 
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice daily Disp 
#*100 Tablet Refills:*0 
3.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - Severe 
stop taking when pain improves  
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 6 hours Disp #*40 
Tablet Refills:*0 
4.  FLUoxetine 40 mg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
c5-6 disc herniation 

 
Discharge Condition:
avss 
aox3

 
Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions

ACDF

Surgery
Your dressing may come off on the second day after surgery. 
Your incision is closed with dissolvable sutures underneath 
the skin and steri strips. You do not need suture removal. Do 
not remove your steri strips, let them fall off.
Please keep your incision dry for 72 hours after surgery.
Please avoid swimming for two weeks.
Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
*** You must wear your hard cervical collar at all times. You 
may remove it briefly for skin care and showering. 
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 
Do NOT smoke. Smoking can affect your healing and fusion.

Medications
***Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
Do not take any anti-inflammatory medications such as Motrin, 
Advil, Aspirin, and Ibuprofen etc for 2 weeks.
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain 
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace. 
Pain medications can cause constipation. 

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Back and right leg pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ - L5/S1 ALIF 
___ - L5/S1 PSF
___ - Repositioning of ALIF cage.

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ returns to the
musculoskeletal medicine unit.  He continues with back pain now
of four months' duration with radiating right leg pain with
accompanying tingling and numbness today without any bowel or
bladder dysfunction.  The back pain is worse with standing for
any period of time.  It has not changed since he was seen on
___.  His back pain remains greater than his leg pain.  He
is continuing to work his full-time job at ___.

 
Past Medical History:
Lower back pain with bilateral L5 spondylolysis with
nerve root impingement at L5.

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
see admit H&P
 
Physical Exam:
AVSS
Well appearing, NAD, comfortable
BUE: SILT C5-T1 dermatomal distributions
BUE: ___ Del/Tri/Bic/WE/WF/FF/IO
BUE: tone normal, negative ___, 2+ symmetric DTR 
bic/bra/tri
All fingers WWP, brisk capillary refill, 2+ distal pulses
BLE: SILT L1-S1 dermatomal distributions
BLE: ___ ___
BLE: tone normal, no clonus, toes downgoing, 2+ DTR knee/ankle
All toes WWP, brisk capillary refill, 2+ distal pulses

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and 
taken to the Operating Room for the above procedures. Refer to 
the dictated operative note for further details.  The surgery 
was without complication and the patient was transferred to the 
PACU in a stable condition.  TEDs/pnemoboots were used for 
postoperative DVT prophylaxis.  Intravenous antibiotics were 
continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initial postop 
pain was controlled with a PCA.  Diet was advanced as tolerated. 
 The patient was transitioned to oral pain medication when 
tolerating PO diet.  Foley was removed on POD#2.  Physical 
therapy was consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate.  
Hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.  On the day of 
discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs, 
comfortable on oral pain control and tolerating a regular diet. 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
2. magnesium hydroxide 400 mg/5 mL Suspension Sig: Thirty (30) 
ML PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for constipation.  
3. hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 
hours) as needed for breakthrough pain .
Disp:*70 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for fever, pain.  
5. diazepam 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q8H (every 8 hours) 
as needed for spasm.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
6. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO QHS (once a day 
(at bedtime)) as needed for constipation.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Radicular pain and spondylolisthesis
Back Pain

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Lumbar decompression with fusion:
You have undergone the following operation: Anterior / Posterior 
Lumbar Decompression With Fusion

Immediately after the operation:

-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than ~45 minutes without getting up and walking around.

-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery.  You can walk as much as you can 
tolerate. 
oLimit any kind of lifting.

-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some 
constipation after surgery.  You have been given medication to 
help with this issue.

-Brace: You may have been given a brace. This brace is to be 
worn when you are walking. You may take it off when sitting in a 
chair or while lying in bed.

-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  If it is dry 
then you can leave the incision open to the air.  Once the 
incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile 
dressing.  Call the office. 

-You should resume taking your normal home medications.

-You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead.  You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___.  We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. 
 In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.

-Follow up:
oPlease Call the office and make an appointment for 2 weeks 
after the day of your operation if this has not been done 
already.
oAt the 2-week visit we will check your incision, take baseline 
X-rays and answer any questions. We may at that time start 
physical therapy.
oWe will then see you at 6 weeks from the day of the operation 
and at that time release you to full activity.

Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

(at bedtime)) as needed for constipation.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Radicular pain and spondylolisthesis
Back Pain
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Lumbar decompression with fusion:
You have undergone the following operation: Anterior / Posterior
Lumbar Decompression With Fusion
Immediately after the operation:
-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand
more than ~45 minutes without getting up and walking around.
-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy:
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as
part of your recovery. You can walk as much as you can
tolerate.
oLimit any kind of lifting.
-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some
constipation after surgery. You have been given medication to
help with this issue.
-Brace: You may have been given a brace. This brace is to be
worn when you are walking. You may take it off when sitting in a
chair or while lying in bed.
-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days. If the incision is
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing. If it is dry
then you can leave the incision open to the air. Once the
incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a
bath or pool. If the incision starts draining at anytime after
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile
dressing. Call the office.
-You should resume taking your normal home medications.
-You have also been given Additional Medications to control
your pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic
prescriptions, so please plan ahead. You can either have them
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on
___. We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications
for 90 days from the date of surgery.
-Follow up:
oPlease Call the office and make an appointment for 2 weeks
after the day of your operation if this has not been done
already.
oAt the 2-week visit we will check your incision, take baseline
X-rays and answer any questions. We may at that time start
physical therapy.
oWe will then see you at 6 weeks from the day of the operation
and at that time release you to full activity.
Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Aspirin / Nsaids / ibuprofen
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Lumbar back pain with left lower extremity radiculopathy
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ Left L4-5 Hemilaminectomy/Discectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with left leg pain in the L4 
or L5 distribution.  This has been going on for about five to 
six weeks now.  She also has weakness and she keeps tripping on 
the left foot.  The pins and needles.  The pain is so bad that 
she had to visit the local emergency room at one time. Her exam 
overall shows mild weakness of the left ___ 4+ to ___. Also, 
inversion of the left foot is slightly weak as well as TA on the 
left.  Rest is full.  Sensory is reduced on the left L4 and L5 
distribution to pinprick.  SLR is positive on the left for 
primarily L4 and also some L5 distribution pain.  Hip seems to 
be okay.  The MRI of her lumbar spine from a few weeks ago was 
reviewed.  It is significant for severe lateral recess stenosis 
at the left L4-L5 area, which is a result of disc bulging as 
well as ligamentous hypertrophy.  That is probably affecting the 
L5 nerve root causing the weakness an  probably the majority of 
the pain.  There is also a far lateral L4-L5 disc herniation, 
which is also contacting the left L4 nerve root after its exit 
from the canal and may also be responsible for the L4 type 
distribution. Reflexes on the other hand are 2+ in both knees 
and 1+ in both Achilles, which is indicating no severe L4 
compression.  However, the patient and her husband request to 
explore the L4 nerve root and we are going to proceed with an 
L4-L5 microdiscectomy sooner than later due to the weakness.  
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: HDL, thyroid disease, GERD

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non contributory
 
Physical Exam:
motor is ___ bilaterally, sensory to light touch intact
gait steady
babinski - flexor b/l
incision is c/d/i with steri strips
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to Neurosurgery on ___ and underwent 
the above stated procedure.  Please review dictated operative 
report for details.  Patient was extubated without incident and 
transferred to PACU then floor in stable condition.  Foley was 
removed in routine fashion and pt voided without incident. 
On ___ she was ambulating well and had no weakness. She has some 
mild residual discomfort in the left calf but there was no 
___ sign and she felt significantly better then her pre-op 
state. She was discharged to home.
 
Medications on Admission:
atorvastatin 40, ativan 2, neurontin, omeprazole 40, effexor, 
vicodin, fioricet, abilify 2

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain, ha, fever 
2. Aripiprazole 2 mg PO DAILY 
3. Atorvastatin 40 mg PO DAILY 
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
5. Gabapentin 300 mg PO TID 
6. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
7. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 
8. Tizanidine 4 mg PO TID 
9. Venlafaxine 225 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
left L4-5 lumbar stenosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Your large dressing may be removed the second day after 
surgery.
You have steri-strips in place, you must keep them dry for 72 
hours.  Do not pull them off. They will fall off on their own or 
be taken off in the office.  You may trim the edges if they 
begin to curl.
 No tub baths or pool swimming for two weeks from your date of 
surgery.
Do not smoke.
No pulling up, lifting more than 10 lbs., or excessive bending 
or twisting.
Limit your use of stairs to ___ times per day.
Have a friend or family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
Take your pain medication as instructed; you may find it best 
if taken in the morning when you wake-up for morning stiffness, 
and before bed for sleeping discomfort. Pain medication should 
be used as needed when you have pain. You do not need to take it 
if you do not have pain.
Do not take any anti-inflammatory medications such as Motrin, 
Advil, Aspirin, and Ibuprofen etc. for two weeks.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as pain medicine 
(narcotics) can cause constipation. We recommend taking an over 
the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) while 
taking narcotic pain medication.
Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING:

Pain that is continually increasing or not relieved by pain 
medicine.
Any weakness, numbness, tingling in your extremities.
Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, and drainage.
Fever greater than or equal to 101.5° F. 
Loss of control of bowel or bladder functioning

 
Followup Instructions:
___

History of Present Illness:
46 ___ s/p prior ___ and cystectomies for fibroids and 
endometriosis, presented with intermittent LLQ pain which 
started ___.  Since ___, she has had very severe, sharp, 
intermittent pain which has been accompanied by nausea and
vomiting and decreased appetite.  She had severe pain on morning 
of presentation, but has since had minimal pain s/p Toradol in 
the ED. No nausea now.  Denies fevers/chills, abnormal bleeding, 
dysuria, constipation, diarrhea.

- Sleep apnea

- Abdominal myomectomy, lysis of adhesions
- Hysteroscopy
- Abdominal SCH, bilateral cystectomies, lysis of adhesions

98.1, 110/84, 84, 20, 98%/RA
NAD

CTAB

Ext: no calf tenderness
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:00PM BLOOD WBC-10.2 RBC-4.30 Hgb-12.2 Hct-35.2* 
MCV-82 MCH-28.3 MCHC-34.6 RDW-13.7 Plt ___
___ 10:10AM BLOOD WBC-12.4*# RBC-4.86 Hgb-14.1 Hct-39.3 
MCV-81* MCH-29.0 MCHC-35.8* RDW-13.4 Plt ___
___ 10:10AM BLOOD Neuts-85.3* Lymphs-9.8* Monos-4.3 Eos-0.4 
Baso-0.2
___ 07:00PM BLOOD UreaN-12 Creat-1.1
___ 10:10AM BLOOD Glucose-99 UreaN-13 Creat-1.2* Na-139 
K-3.6 Cl-99 HCO3-27 AnGap-___ G0 with h/o MMY/LOA followed by ___/ovarian 
cystectomies/excision of peritonal inclusion cysts/LOA presented 
to the emergency department with LLQ pain likely due to left 
adnexal mass, which may represent hemorrhagic corpus luteal 
cyst, peritoneal inclusion cyst, or hydrosalpinx.  Most likely 
acute pain related to possible hemorrhagic corpus luteal cyst.  
Adnexal torsion could not be ruled out at time of presentation 
although less likely due to dense adhesion in pelvis. In 
addition, patient was noted to have left hydroureter and 
increased creatinine 1.1.  Pt was admitted for serial abdominal 
exams, kept NPO with IVF, and given IV Dilaudid for pain with 
the thought that patient my need to go to the operating room for 
evaluation on hospital day #2.  Pt did well overnight and 
required only minimal pain medication.  Cr increased to high of 
1.2 but on recheck came down to 1.1.  Cr was checked on hospital 
day #2 and found to be 0.9.  Pt was discharged to home on HD#2 
after being able to tolerate a regular diet and requiring only 
occasional pain medication.  Pt decided that she would in fact 
like to proceed with surgery to further evaluate and treat her 
pain.  Pt will call Dr. ___ office to make 
arrangements regarding operation scheduling.

 Eye drops for glaucoma

Home

hydrosalpinx vs. peritoneal inclusion cyst

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

Please call for fevers >100.4, chills, increased abdominal pain, 
nausea, vomiting, vaginal bleeding, or any other questions or 
concerns you may have.

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Left lower quadrant pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
1. Exam under anesthesia.
2. Exploratory laparotomy.
3. Extensive lysis of adhesions.
4. Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.
5. Repair of serosal bowel injury and bowel mesentery
    injury.

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ gravida 0 with a history of open 
abdominal myomectomy as well as open supracervical hysterectomy 
and ovarian cystectomies. She has had a prior severe pelvic 
adhesions noted on her prior surgeries. She has had a finding of 
10 cm pelvic mass thought to be a left hydrosalpinx as well as 
left hydroureter. She presented with worsening pelvic pain. The 
decision was made to proceed to the operating room for 
exploratory laparotomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.
 
Past Medical History:
GYN:
- Fibroids, endometriosis as above

OB: G0

MED: 
- Glaucoma
- Sleep apnea

SURG:
- Abdominal myomectomy, lysis of adhesions
- Hysteroscopy
- Abdominal SCH, bilateral cystectomies, lysis of adhesions

 
Social History:
Social: no T/E/D

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt underwent exploratory laparotomy, bilateral 
salpingo-oohporectomy for a large left adnexal mass, likely 
hydrosalpinx, and right endometrioma.  Her operation was 
complicated by bowel serosal tear and mesenteric tear which were 
easily repaired.  General Surgery was called in for intra-op 
consult to ensure that bowel look reassuring which it did. 
Post-operatively pt was kept on a clear liquid diet until she 
passed flatus secondary to manipulation of  bowel during the 
operation.  She tolerated clears without any difficulty and was 
easily transitioned to PO medication.  On post-operative day 
number 1 pt had some tachycardia with her heart rate up to 120 
but without any cardiac symptoms to suggest PE or arrhythmia.  
EKG demonstrated sinus tachycardia.  CBC and electrolytes were 
overall normal.  Tachycardia spontaneously resolved.  Pt passed 
flatus on post-operative day #2 and her diet was advanced to 
regular.  She tolerated the regular diet without difficulty and 
was dischaged to home on POD#3 in good condition.

 
Medications on Admission:
Alphagan drops  
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed: Do not exceed 4g tylenol in 
24hours.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left adnexal mass, likely hydrosalpinx, and right endometrioma 

 
Discharge Condition:
good

 
Discharge Instructions:
- Please call your doctor if you experience fever > 100.4,

chills, nausea and vomiting, worsening or severe abdominal pain,

heavy vaginal bleeding, chest pain, trouble breathing, or if you

have any other questions or concerns.

- Please call if you have

redness and warmth around the incision, if your incision is

draining pus-like or foul smelling discharge, or if your 
incision reopens.

- No driving while taking narcotic pain

medication as it can make you drowsy.

- No heavy lifting or strenuous exercise for 6 weeks to allow

your incision to heal adequately.

- Nothing per vagina (no tampons, intercourse, douching for 6

weeks.

- Please keep your follow-up appointments as outlined below.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

hours) as needed.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left adnexal mass, likely hydrosalpinx, and right endometrioma
Discharge Condition:
good
Discharge Instructions:
- Please call your doctor if you experience fever > 100.4,
chills, nausea and vomiting, worsening or severe abdominal pain,
heavy vaginal bleeding, chest pain, trouble breathing, or if you
have any other questions or concerns.
- Please call if you have
redness and warmth around the incision, if your incision is
draining pus-like or foul smelling discharge, or if your
incision reopens.
- No driving while taking narcotic pain
medication as it can make you drowsy.
- No heavy lifting or strenuous exercise for 6 weeks to allow
your incision to heal adequately.
- Nothing per vagina (no tampons, intercourse, douching for 6
weeks.
- Please keep your follow-up appointments as outlined below.
Followup Instructions:
___

Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: PLASTIC
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Macromastia
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Bilateral mammoplasty reduction

 
History of Present Illness:
___ woman with a history of bilateral breast 
hypertrophy.  She has back pain, neck pain, and shoulder 
grooving and  she was interested in a
breast reduction. 
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: denies  
PSH: lipoma removed from Left flank  
OB/GYN hx: G2 PO - 17 weeks gestation  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Noncontributory
 
Physical Exam:
GENERAL: Alert, oriented. Not in acute distress.
HEENT: Normocephalic atraumatic. Extraocular movements intact. 
Pupils equal and reactive to light bilaterally. 
CARDIOVASCULAR: Regular rate rhythm. 
CHEST: Clear to ausculatation. 
ABDOMEN: Soft nontender, nondistended. 
BREAST: Incision clean dry intact. Serosanguinous discharge in 
JP drains prior to being pulled on day of discharge. No 
swelling, erythema. No evidence of hematoma. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female admitted for observation post operatively for 
bilateral breast reduction secondary to pain control. There were 
no immediate complications and patient was feeling well, 
urinating/stooling adequately, ambulating, and tolerating POs 
prior to discharge. JP drains pulled prior to discharge. Will 
follow up with Dr. ___ in clinic. 
 
Medications on Admission:
1. Levothyroxine Sodium 125 mcg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
3. Levothyroxine Sodium 125 mcg PO DAILY 
4. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  5 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) hours 
Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Macromastia

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted on ___ for bilateral breast reduction. 
Please follow these discharge instructions.
.
Personal Care: 
1. Leave your surgical dressings in place for 48 hours after 
surgery and then they may be removed and the incisions left open 
to air. 
2. You should keep your surgibra or a zip up sports bra in place 
for 2 weeks after surgery. You may remove for showering.  Do not 
take a bath or swim for 2 weeks after surgery.
. 
Diet/Activity: 
1. You may resume your regular diet. 
2. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in 
strenuous activity for two weeks after surgery. 
. 
Medications: 
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered. 
2. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol 
for mild pain as directed on the packaging. Please note that 
Percocet and Vicodin have Tylenol as an active ingredient so do 
not take these meds with additional Tylenol. 
3. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol. 
4. Take your antibiotic as prescribed. 
5. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking 
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softerner if you wish. 
6. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber. 
. 
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following: 
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s). 
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s). 
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF 
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication. 
. 
Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications. 
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you. 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old female with severe worsening left leg 
pain. She presented on ___ for an elective L3-4 microdiscectomy. 
The patient tolerated the procedure well and recovered in the 
PACU. Imediately post op in the PACU, the patient became 
bradycardic to 30 transiently. She was otherwise stable. She had 
cardiac enzymes that were drawn and found to be negative. The 
patient remained stable and was transferred to the floor. On the 
floor, her pain was well-controlled, and she was tolerating a 
regular diet. On her post-op exam, she was completely neuro 
intact with ___ strength in bilateral lower extremities. She 
reported that she no longer experienced the left lower extremity 
radiculopathy that she had pre-op. She only had mild incisional 
back pain, that was well-controlled with pain meds. POD1, she 
continued to do well. Her pain was well-controlled, and her 
neuro exam remained stable and intact. She was discharged with 
follow-up with Dr. ___. 
 
Medications on Admission:
atenolol, HCTZ, neurontin, percocet, zocor

Refills:*0
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice daily 
Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*0
5. Gabapentin 600 mg PO AM 
6. Gabapentin 300 mg PO 1200 NOON 
7. Gabapentin 300 mg PO HS 
8. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY 
9. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every ___ hours Disp 
#*60 Tablet Refills:*0
10. Simvastatin 40 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
L3-L4 herniated disc

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Lumbar Laminectomy/Discectomy

Dr. ___

 

 

¨     Your large dressing may be removed the second day after 
surgery.

¨     You have steri-strips in place, you must keep them dry for 
72 hours.  Do not pull them off. They will fall off on their own 
or be taken off in the office.  You may trim the edges if they 
begin to curl.
 

¨      No tub baths or pool swimming for two weeks from your 
date of surgery.

¨     Do not smoke.

¨     No pulling up, lifting more than 10 lbs., or excessive 
bending or twisting.

¨     Limit your use of stairs to ___ times per day.

¨     Have a friend or family member check your incision daily 
for signs of infection.

¨     Take your pain medication as instructed; you may find it 
best if taken in the morning when you wake-up for morning 
stiffness, and before bed for sleeping discomfort. Pain 
medication should be used as needed when you have pain. You do 
not need to take it if you do not have pain.

¨     Do not take any anti-inflammatory medications such as 
Motrin, Advil, Aspirin, and Ibuprofen etc. for two weeks.

¨     Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as pain medicine 
(narcotics) can cause constipation. We recommend taking an over 
the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) while 
taking narcotic pain medication.

¨     Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.

 

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING:

 

¨     Pain that is continually increasing or not relieved by 
pain medicine.

¨     Any weakness, numbness, tingling in your extremities.

¨     Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, 
swelling, tenderness, and drainage.

¨     Fever greater than or equal to 101.5° F. 

¨     Loss of control of bowel or bladder functioning

 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy,

Past Medical History:
Endometriosis s/p surgery in ___ (R ovarian endometrioma) 
 
Ovarian cyst ___  
?___

Physical Exam:
Physical Examination on Discharge: 
VSS

CV: RRR
Pulm: CTAB
Abd: Soft, nondistended, nontender, incision C/D/I
Ext: warm well perfused, nontender
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service after 
undergoing exploratory laparotomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, 
bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, appendectomy, and extensive 
lysis of adhesions. Please see the operative report for full 
details.  

Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. Immediately 
post-op, her pain was controlled with epidural. On 
post-operative day 1, her urine output was adequate so her foley 
was removed and she voided spontaneously. Her diet was advanced 
without difficulty and she was transitioned to Dilaudid/PCA and 
toradol. On post op day 2 she was transitioned to po percocet 
and ibuprofen. 

By post-operative day 3, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was 
controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home 
in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth Twice daily

severe endometriosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the GYN service after undergoing the 
procedures listed below. The team feels that you have recovered 
well and are ready for discharge. Please follow the instructions 
below:

General instructions:  
* Take your medications as prescribed.  
* Do not drive while taking narcotics. 
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation. 
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.  
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.  
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.  
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 6 
weeks
* No heavy lifting of objects >10lbs for 6 weeks.    
* You may eat a regular diet.  
* Please take iron twice daily for your anemia.

Incision care:  
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.  
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.   
 
To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___

chest pressure and SOB

CABG x3 (LIMA-LAD, SVG-OM and PDA), AVR (___ 
___)with preop IABP 

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo M with CP and DOE preesnted to ___ and 
ruled in for AMI (anterior) with +troponin, transferred for 
cardiac cath which revealed LM and 3VD. IABP inserted and 
referred for surgery.
 
Past Medical History:
ASA, MVI 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
father deceased from ___ at age ___

 
Physical Exam:
HR 72 RR 18 
NAD
teeth in poor repair
Lungs CTAB anteriorly
Heart RRR, no M.R.G
Abdomen benign
Extrem warm, no edema

 
Pertinent Results:
___ Echo: Prebypass: Unable to pass TEE probe beyond 40 cms. 
Atraumatic placement. So only upper esophageal and midesophageal 
views obtained. Dr ___ part of study. 1.No atrial 
septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. 2.There is 
moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with 
severe hypokinesia of the anterior wall, septum and 
anteriorseptum. Overall left ventricular systolic function is 
moderately depressed (LVEF= 30 %). 3. There is mild global RV 
free wall hypokinesis. 4.The ascending aorta is moderately 
dilated. There are simple atheroma in the descending thoracic 
aorta. 5. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened. 
Moderate (2+) aortic regurgitation is seen. 6.The mitral valve 
leaflets are mildly thickened. Mild to moderate (___) mitral 
regurgitation is seen. 7. There is a small pericardial effusion 
8. Tip of intraaortic balloon pump in good position. 8. Dr. 
___ was notified in person of the results on ___ at ___. Patient is being AV paced and receving an 
infusion of phenylephrine and epinephrine. 2. Left ventricular 
ejection fraction 35% 3. Bioprosthetic valve seen in the aortic 
position. Valve appears well seated and the leaflets move well. 
Trace central aortic regurgitation present. Unable to calculate 
gradients across the aortic valve as no transgastric views. 4. 
Mild mitral regurgitation persists. 5. Aorta intact post 
decannulation.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
He was taken urgently to the operating room where he underwent a 
CABG x 3 and AVR. He was transferred to the ICU in stable 
condition on levophed, epinephrine and neosynephrine. He was 
placeed on flagyl prophylactically for his teeth given that he 
was unable to get dental clearance prior to his valve surgery. 
He was extubated on POD #1. IABP was dc'd on POD #2, and his 
vasoactive drips were weaned to off. He was pancultured for a 
fever, the cultures were negative. He was transferred to the 
floor  on POD #3. His epicardial wires were removed.  A dental 
consult was called and revealed the need from multiple 
extractions.  These were performed on post-operative day #6.  On 
the following day he was ready for discharge to rehab.
 
Medications on Admission:
aspirin
multivitamins
 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Coronary Artery Disease, Aortic Stenosis s/p Coronary Artery 
Bypass Graft x 3, Aortic Valve Replacement
PMH: Hypertension, s/p stent ___, Hyperlipidemia
 
Discharge Condition:
Good.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Call with fever, redness or drainage from incision or weight 
gain more than 2 pounds in one day or five in one week.
Shower, no baths, no lotions, creams or powders to incisions.
No lifting more 10 pounds for 10 weeks
No driving until follow up with surgeon.
You will need your ___ number for your appointment with 
your new PCP. It is ___.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

History of Present Illness:
___ F with known pancreatic divisum, h/o prior pancreatitis s/p 
CCY and sphincterotomy ___ for papillary stenosis, presents 
with acute pancreatitis for repeat ERCP. This was done today 
with sphincterotomy, cannulation of CBD and PD, and balloon 
sweep of CBD.  After procedure she received Dilaudid 0.125mg for 
abdominal pain.  Currently pain is gone, and she has no N / V.  
Last BM was today.

Pancreatitis

s/p C-section x ___

156/67, 63, 18, 97%RA

In NAD, well-nourished
OP clear, no ___, neck supple

COR - RRR no MRG, nl PMI
ABD - soft, (+) bs, non-tender, not distended
EXT - no c/c/e

NEURO - non-focal, nl sluent speech and cognition
PSYCH - appropriate

Husband at bedside and corroborates history/baseline condition
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 09:50AM   UREA N-12 CREAT-0.8 SODIUM-142 POTASSIUM-4.7 
CHLORIDE-107 TOTAL CO2-28 ANION GAP-12
___ 09:50AM   estGFR-Using this
___ 09:50AM   ALT(SGPT)-24 AST(SGOT)-28 ALK PHOS-60 
AMYLASE-94 TOT BILI-0.6 DIR BILI-0.2 INDIR BIL-0.4
___ 09:50AM   LIPASE-31

MCH-29.1 MCHC-32.6 RDW-13.6
___ 09:50AM   PLT COUNT-167
___ 09:50AM   ___ PTT-32.0 ___

ERCP ___:
Impression: The duodenum was mildly inflammed  
The major papilla was s/p sphincterotomy 
The papilla had stenosed considerably since the last ERCP 
Cannulation of the pancreatic duct was successful 
Cannulation of the bile duct was successful 
The CBD was mildly dilated at 8mm, the hilum and intra-hepatic 
ducts were also dilated but otherwise normal. 
The pancreatic duct measured 4mm and a partial pancreatic 
divisum was noted 
Because of the history of recurrent pancreatitis, endoscopic 
findings of sphincter re-stenosis and the previous excellent 
response to biliary sphincterotomy ___ years ago, a 
sphincterotomy was performed over the existing guidewire. 
A balloon sweep of the CBD was performed. 
The CBD was clear at end of the procedure
 
Recommendations: Admit to Hospital 
NPO overnight with aggressive IV hydration with LR at 200 cc/hr 
If no abdominal pain in the morning, advance diet to clear 
liquids and then advance as tolerated 
If any concerns please contact the ERCP fellow on-call
 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with recurrent pancreatitis and biliary papillary stenosis 
is now s/p repeat ERCP with sphincterotomy and no evidence of 
stone or sludge. She is admitted for observation given her risks 
for bleeding and post-ERCP pancreatitis.
.
Plan:
- IVNS at 200cc/hr x 3 L
- bowel regimen prn constipation
- Dilaudid 0.125mg IV q4hr prn pain
- NPO overnight
- if pain free in AM, advance diet
- restart levothyroxine in the AM
- low risk VTE
- husband ___ is ___

pain. Her diet was advanced the next morning successfully, and 
she was discharged to home.

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Left wrist pain 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Open reduction and internal fixation of left distal radius 
fracture

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ male presenting to ___ on ___ 
with left wrist pain. The patient was performing ___ work 
on his car and a heavy spring fell on the left wrist. Denies 
weakness, numbness or tingling. Denies
pain in the elbow or shoulder.
 
Past Medical History:
High Cholesterol

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
n/a
 
Physical Exam:
Afebrile 
Vital signs stable 
No apparent distress
Heart rate regular 
Respirations non-labored 
Abdomen soft, non-tender, nondistended 

Left wrist/forearm splinted 
Fires APL, FDS/FDP, DIO
Sensation intact to light touch M/U/R
Digits warm and well-perfused with brisk capillary refill 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have a left distal radius fracture and was admitted to the 
orthopedic surgery service. The patient was taken to the 
operating room on ___ for open reduction and internal 
fixation on his left distal radius, which the patient tolerated 
well. For full details of the procedure please see the 
separately dictated operative report. The patient was taken from 
the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory 
recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The 
patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, 
and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. 
The patient was given ___ antibiotics and 
anticoagulation per routine. The patient's home medications were 
continued throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked 
with ___ and OT who determined that discharge home was 
appropriate. The ___ hospital course was otherwise 
unremarkable.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
non-weight-bearing in the left upper extremity, and will be 
discharged on Aspirin for DVT prophylaxis. The patient will 
follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough discussion 
was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected 
post-discharge course including reasons to call the office or 
return to the hospital, and all questions were answered. The 
patient was also given written instructions concerning 
precautionary instructions and the appropriate follow-up care. 
The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H 
RX *acetaminophen 650 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Ever six (6) hours 
Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth Twice daily 
Disp #*28 Capsule Refills:*0
3. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 
4. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q3H:PRN Pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth Every three (3) hours 
Disp #*110 Tablet Refills:*0
5. Rosuvastatin Calcium 10 mg PO QPM 
6. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY 
RX *aspirin 325 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Daily Disp #*30 Tablet 
Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left distal radius fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___,

- ___ were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Please do not bear any weight through your left arm until ___ 
are permitted to do so by your surgeon. 

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so ___ should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take Aspirin 325 MG daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- ___ may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- No dressing is needed if wound continues to be non-draining.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed
- Do NOT get splint wet
Treatments Frequency:
General postoperative care 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Latex
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Small Bowel Obstruction
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
This patient is a ___ year old male with history of SBO from 
adhesions from a prior appendectomy who presents to the ED with 
abdominal pain.The patient reports symptoms are similar to prior 
SBO. The patient had episode of nausea and emesis. Last bowel 
movement and flatus was this morning but has not passed any 
since.Thus was admitted to the general surgery unit for further 
evaluation.
 
Past Medical History:
SBO
Hypercholesterolemia
Past Surgical History: Appendectomy, R achilles repair in ___

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals:98.7, 69, 112/75, 20,m 98 % room air
General: alert and oriented, no acute distress
HEENT: No scleral icterus, mucus membranes moist
Cardiovascular: regular rate rhythm
Pulmonary: Clear to auscultation
Abdomen: Soft, moderately distended, tender to palpation around 
umbilicus without rebound, guarding or evidence of 
peritonitis,appendectomy scar in RLQ well healed.
Extremities: No ___ edema, ___ warm and well perfused

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 11:28AM BLOOD WBC-10.2 RBC-5.21 Hgb-16.1 Hct-47.1 
MCV-91 MCH-31.0 MCHC-34.3 RDW-13.9 Plt ___
___ 11:28AM BLOOD Neuts-86.0* Lymphs-10.0* Monos-3.0 
Eos-0.7 Baso-0.3
___ 11:28AM BLOOD Glucose-91 UreaN-21* Creat-1.2 Na-141 
K-4.0 Cl-106 HCO3-27 AnGap-12
___ 11:28AM BLOOD ALT-26 AST-23 AlkPhos-53 TotBili-0.3
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On arrival to the inpatient general surgical unit, serial 
abdominal exams were performed and the patient was kept NPO with 
intravenous fluids and pain medication. The patient underwent an 
abdominal xray which revealed multiple air-fluid levels seen in 
the mid abdomen on the upright view with air and stool seen in 
the colon, raising concern for a mild partial or early small 
bowel obstruction versus a mild ileus. 
  
The patient remained NPO with hydration and bowel rest and had 
improvement of symptoms and did not require a nasogastric tube. 
By hospital day 2 had complete resolution of abdominal pain and 
was passing flatus and had a bowel movement.The diet was 
advanced to clears which was tolerated well.The patient was 
allowed to advance his diet to regular as tolerated. The patient 
was discharged home in good condition.
 
Medications on Admission:
Crestor 20 mg PO QD
 
Discharge Medications:
Crestor 20 mg PO QD
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Small Bowel Obstruction

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Dr. ___, 
___ was a pleasure participating in your care. You were admitted 
with a diagnosis of partial small bowel obstruction which 
resolved with bowel rest and hydration. You may resume your home 
medications.Please call Dr. ___ if you develop 
nausea, vomiting, increasing abdominal pain, distention, large 
decrease in bowel movements or flatus, or any other questions or 
concerns.

 

 
Followup Instructions:
___
