Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and 
taken to the Operating Room for an L2-S1 laminectomy.  Refer to 
the dictated operative note for further details.  The surgery 
was without complication and the patient was transferred to the 
PACU in a stable condition.  TEDs/pneumoboots were used for 
postoperative DVT prophylaxis.  Intravenous antibiotics were 
continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initial postop 
pain was controlled with a IV and PO pain medications.  Diet was 
advanced as tolerated.  The patient was transitioned to oral 
pain medication when tolerating PO diet.  Foley was removed 
postoperatively without issue.  On POD #1 she was ambulating 
under her own power without assistance.  Hospital course was 
otherwise unremarkable.  On the day of discharge the patient was 
afebrile with stable vital signs, comfortable on oral pain 
control and tolerating a regular diet.
 
Medications on Admission:

taking

Refills:*0 
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID

Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0 
3.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 2.5-5 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
Do not drive, drink alcohol or operate heavy machinery while 
taking 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every ___ hours Disp 
#*35 Tablet Refills:*0 
4.  Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Lumbar spinal stenosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have undergone the following operation: Lumbar Decompression 
Without Fusion

 

Immediately after the operation:

                Activity: You should not lift anything greater 
than 10 lbs for 2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do 
not sit or stand more than ~45 minutes without moving around.

 

                Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy:

___                ___ times a day you should go for a walk 
for ___ minutes as part of your recovery.  You can walk as 
much as you can tolerate.

___                Limit any kind of lifting.

 

                Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have 
some constipation after surgery.  You have been given medication 
to help with this issue.

 

                Brace: You may have been given a brace. This 
brace is to be worn when you are walking. You may take it off 
when sitting in a chair or lying in bed.

 

                Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If 
the incision is draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  
If it is dry then you can leave the incision open to the air.  
Once the incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile 
dressing and call the office.

 

                You should resume taking your normal home 
medications.

 

                You have also been given Additional Medications 
to control your pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of 
narcotic prescriptions, so please plan ahead.  You can either 
have them mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic 
located on ___.  We are not allowed to call in or fax 
narcotic prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your 
pharmacy.  In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain 
medications for 90 days from the date of surgery.

 

                Follow up:            

___                Please Call the office and make an 
appointment for 2 weeks after the day of your operation if this 
has not been done already.

___                At the 2-week visit we will check your 
incision, take baseline X-rays and answer any questions. We may 
at that time start physical therapy.

___                We will then see you at 6 weeks from the 
day of the operation and at that time release you to full 
activity.

 

 

Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Ms. ___ is a ___ with intentional OD of Ativan vs Ambien 
in suicide attempt. She was medically stabilized for transfer to 
inpatient psychiatric care.

#Intentional OD of Ativan 
#Major depression
Patient with intentional OD as noted above. After obtaining 
collateral from family and outpatient providers, this was found 
to be planned (suicide note written to husband) and 
out-of-character indicating a high ongoing safety risk. After 
initial monitoring the patient had no signs of CNS depression. 
She also had no signs of benzodiazepine withdrawal or 
intoxication.  She was seen by psychiatry who recommended 
involuntary inpatient psychiatric treatment given the 
aforementioned circumstances and risk. The patient was continued 
on venlafaxine (patient had not been taking regularly) and b 
vitamins. She is being transferred to ___ for ongoing 
treatment

#Anxiety
Held further Ativan in setting of overdose

#pre-DM
#HLD
- does not take any oral meds at home. Recommend follow up with 
PCP once stabilized

___ issues:
- Consider initiation of statin if clinically indicated once 
patient stabilized

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Venlafaxine 275 mg PO DAILY 
2. LORazepam 0.5 mg PO QHS:PRN anx 
3. L-Methyl-MC (levomefolate-B2-B6-B12) ___ mg oral Q24H

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: CARDIOTHORACIC
 
Allergies: 
Percocet
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Left lower lobe lung nodule
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___
Videoassisted thoracoscopic surgery, left lower lobe wedge 
resection

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the hospital and taken to the 
Operating Room where she underwent a left lower lobe wedge 
resction. She tolerated the procedure well and returned to the 
PACU in stable condition. She maintained stable hemodynamics and 
her main was minimal. Her chest tube drained a moderate amount 
of thin bloody fluid and had an intermittent air leak.

Following transfer to the Surgical floor she progressed well.  
She had a persistent air leak on POD 1. Her diet was advanced to 
a regular diet. repeat imaging showed a stable left apical 
pneumothorax. Her pain was well controlled with tramadol and 
acetaminophen. On POD 2, the air leak appeared to resolve. Her 
chest tube was removed and a follow up chest x ray revealed a 
smaller left sided apical pneumothorax. The decision was made to 
discharge the patient.

Her pain remained manageable with scheduled Tylenol. She was up 
and walking independently.  After an uneventful recovery she was 
discharged to home on ___. Follow up with Dr. ___ 
was scheduled in clinic in 2 weeks. 
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires 
futher investigation.
1. LORazepam 0.5 mg PO QHS:PRN insomnia 
2. levonorgestrel 20 mcg/24 hr ___ years) injection ___ yrs 
3. Vitamin D 1000 UNIT PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H 
Do not take more the 4000mg in one day 
RX *acetaminophen 650 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 8 hours as 
needed Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0 
2.  Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q8H:PRN Pain - Mild 
Alternate with acetaminophen 
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 8 hours as 
needed Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0 
3.  levonorgestrel 20 mcg/24 hr ___ years) injection ___ yrs  
4.  LORazepam 0.5 mg PO QHS:PRN insomnia  
5.  Vitamin D 1000 UNIT PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left lung nodule

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
* You were admitted to the hospital for lung surgery and you've 
recovered well. You are now ready for discharge. 

* Continue to use your incentive spirometer 10 times an hour 
while awake.

* Check your incisions daily and report any increased redness or 
drainage.   Cover the area with a gauze pad if it is draining.

* Your chest tube dressing may be removed in 48 hours.  If it 
starts to drain, cover it with a clean dry dressing and change 
it  as needed to keep site clean and dry.

 * You may need pain medication once you are home but you can 
wean it over the next week as the discomfort resolves.  Make 
sure that you have regular bowel movements while on narcotic 
pain medications as they are constipating which can cause more 
problems.  Use a stool softener or gentle laxative to stay 
regular.

* No driving while taking narcotic pain medication.

* Take Tylenol for pain.  

* Continue to stay well hydrated and eat well to heal your 
incisions

* Shower daily. Wash incision with mild soap & water, rinse, pat 
dry
 * No tub bathing, swimming or hot tubs until incision healed
 * No lotions or creams to incision site

* Walk ___ times a day and gradually increase your activity as 
you can tolerate.

Call Dr. ___  ___ ___ if you experience:
 -Fevers > 101 or chills
 -Increased shortness of breath, chest pain or any other 
symptoms that concern you.

 

** If pathology specimens were sent at the time of surgery, the 
reports will be reviewed with you in detail at your follow up 
appointment. This will give both you and your doctor time to 
understand the pathology, its implications and discuss options 
going forward.**

 

 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
renal laceration
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
embolization of left sided small renal arteries
 
History of Present Illness:
___ F with PCKD presents with hematuria, L flank and abdominal 
pain
after a fall yesterday evening.  She was being carried by a
friend when he tripped and fell on her, with her falling on her 
L
side.  She developed increasing pain and nausea about half an
hour later.  Nausea quickly resolved.  She presented to ___ where a catheter was placed for bloody urine.  A CT
I+/I- was obtained ___ shows left sided perinephric and
retroperitoneal hemmorhage.  There is some question as to
possible vascular extravasation in the arterial phase.  She is
then transferred to ___ ED.

In the ED she was hemodynamically stable without tachycardia or
hypotension.  HCT was 23.8.  She is being admitted to the TICU
for recussitation with ___ consultation for posible embolization
of bleeding vessel.

In the ED a CXR was obtained which showed excretion of contrast
into both collecting systems.  A follow up KUB sowed drainage
from both ureters with retained contrast and probable urinary
leak from the left.

 
 
Past Medical History:
PSKD
 
Social History:
denies smoking
 
Physical Exam:
T99.1 P93 BP 98/59 rr 18 99% on RA
Gen: NAD
CAD: RRR
Resp: no distress
Abd: tender on left flank, no peritoneal signs
Ext: no edema
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 03:50PM BLOOD Hct-25.3*
___ 10:25AM BLOOD Hct-24.2*
___ 05:00AM BLOOD Hct-23.3*
___ 09:10PM BLOOD Hct-25.0*
___ 05:05PM BLOOD Hct-28.4*
___ 02:59AM BLOOD WBC-6.2 RBC-2.10* Hgb-6.0* Hct-17.4* 
MCV-83 MCH-28.5 MCHC-34.4 RDW-12.7 Plt ___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient admitted ___ with left renal laceration and two small 
vessels off inferior branch coil embolized ___ . Patient 
transfused two units of blood ___ for and discharged ___ with 
improving Hct. 
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
iron
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left kidney laceration
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Patient may resume activity as tolerated and normal bathing. 
Please call primary care provider or return to emergency 
department if blood in urine.  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Hematuria, fever and flank pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ FEMORAL VASCULAR US RIGHT
 
History of Present Illness:
___ with PCKD who was recently discharged after L kidney rupture 
s/p coil embolization now presents with abdominal pain, fever 
and recurrent hematuria. The patients initial injury occured on 
___ when a friend was carrying her, tripped, and she hit her 
left side ont he ground. Imaging showed an anterial 
extravasation and the patient underwent embolization of 2 small 
inferior L renal arteries. She was discharged to home on ___ 
and returned on ___ because she developed gross hematuria again 
and abdominal pain. She was always hemodynamically stable and 
has not required any blood transfusions during this admission. A 
CTA was performed which did not show any evidence of active 
vascular extravasation or significant change in the size of her 
hematoma. The CT also showed a moderate left sided pleural 
effusion. 
 
Past Medical History:
PCKD, kidney stones
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
PCKD in father 
 
Physical ___:
VS: AVSS, no fever or tachycardia 
General: pleasant, nad  
HEENT: PERRL, sclerae anicteric  
OP: MMM, no ulcers/lesions/thrush  
Neck: supple, no LAD  
Cardiovascular: RRR, normal S1, S2, ___ systolic flow murmur 
over precordium  
Respiratory: decreased breath sounds in the bases L>R  
Back: no focal tenderness, no CVAT  
Gastrointestinal: +bs, soft, non-distended, tender left flank
Musculoskeletal: moving all extremities, normal ROM
Ext: Warm and well perfused, no edema. 2+ DP pulses palpable 
bilaterally  
Skin: no rashes, no jaundice  
Neurological: aaox3  
Psychiatric: non-anxious, normal affect  

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 04:25PM   GLUCOSE-99 UREA N-9 CREAT-0.7 SODIUM-141 
POTASSIUM-4.1 CHLORIDE-105 TOTAL CO2-24 ANION GAP-16
___ 04:25PM   WBC-10.5# RBC-3.53*# HGB-10.0*# HCT-28.5* 
MCV-81* MCH-28.3 MCHC-35.1* RDW-14.3
___ 04:25PM   NEUTS-82.7* LYMPHS-13.1* MONOS-3.5 EOS-0.5 
BASOS-0.3
___ 04:25PM   PLT COUNT-293

IMAGING:  
US kidneys ___. Polycystic kidneys.  
2. Left perinephric hematoma and small hematoma in the left 
renal pelvis.  
3. Small left pleural effusion and ascites.  
CTA abdomen ___:  
1. Stable appearance of enlarged, polycystic left kidney, with 
extensive parenchymal and subcapsular hematoma encompassing the 
lower pole. Embolization coil material is in place at the 
inferior renal artery. There has been no increase in hematoma 
compared to the ___ study. There is no evidence of 
superimposed acute bleeding.  
2. New bilateral pleural effusions, moderate on the left and 
small on the right.  
CXR ___: Left lower retrocardiac opacity with trace effusion may 
represent pneumonia in the right clinical setting.  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
She was admitted to surgery service. On admission she was 
started on Vanco and Ciprofloxacin for a positive urine culture 
from the ___. This culture subsequently grew Klebsiella 
sensitive to Cipro. On ___ she developed a temperature of 102.6. 
and was cultured. A CXR showed a possible retrocardiac opacity 
and her blood cultures were negative. As she continued to have a 
fever to 103 on the ___ she was changed to Vanco and 
Pip/Tazo. Over the following days her Tmax was 101.6 and 101. 
Vanco was increased subsequently and her fevers defervesced. She 
was changed to oral Cipro and discharged home on this. Urology 
was consulted and recommended bedrest until resolution of 
hematuria. Over the course of her stay the hematuria improved 
but did not totally resolve; she is being discharged with Foley 
in place and will follow up with Urology as an outpatient.
 
She was also noted to complain of pain in her right groin and 
mild discomfort in her lower abdomen. A femoral ultrasound was 
done which showed no sonographic findings of pseudoaneurysm or 
abnormal collection. She was evaluated by Physical therapy and 
given crutches and was cleared for home.
 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) as needed for constipation.  
2. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain/fever.  
3. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every four (4) 
hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*90 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Ciprofloxacin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q12H 
(every 12 hours) for 10 days.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. Milk of Magnesia 800 mg/5 mL Suspension Sig: Thirty (30) ML's 
PO twice a day as needed for constipation.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Polycystic kidney disease
Left kidney rupture w/ hematuria
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).
 
Discharge Instructions:
You were hospitalized after sustaining an injury to your kidney 
which has caused bleeding in your urine. You were monitored in 
the hospital for further bleeding and was placed on bedrest to 
allow for the bleeding to stop. Your blood counts have remained 
stable but you are still having some blood in your urine that 
appears to be old as the clot in your kidney dissolves. You are 
being recommended to take an antibiotic for a total of 14 days 
and follow up in the Infectious disease clinic in 2 weeks. You 
will also need to follow up in ___ clinic.

AVOID any contact sports or activities that may cause an injury 
to your torso region for at least the next 6 weeks.

Drink plenty of fluids and allow for adequate periods of rest 
during the day. Do not return to work unless you are clearedto 
do so by the Urologist.

You have indicated that you would like to get your care at 
___ if you call ___ Health care Associates they will 
be able to tell you is taking on new patients.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

preoperatively in consultation for desired breast reconstruction 
to follow a planned 
mastectomy for breast cancer. The patient, however, needed to 
undergo neoadjuvant chemotherapy and also had a planned need for 
irradiation therapy following her mastectomy. Because of this, a 
decision was made to pursue delayed breast reconstruction 
approximately ___ months following her
irradiation treatment. The patient has done well following her 
previously described treatment course and now presents for the 
delayed breast reconstruction.

breast camcer
dyslipidemia
cva (___)

s/p tubal ligation

___

nc

AFAVSS JP 105, 30, 65
NAD
excellent signals flap 
abd soft, nt, nd
incisions c/d/i w/o surrounding erythema/warmth
jps w/ serosanguinous dc

na

Pt underwent R delayed ___ flap reconstruction  on ___. Pt 
followed the ___ flap pathway without complication throughout 
her post-operative course. Her flap maintained good perfusion 
throughout with excellent pulses by doppler.

The pt was started on ASA per ___ pathway and was told to hold 
her aggrenox for three weeks. She will restart her aggrenox for 
hx of idiopathic stroke in three weeks which will allow for 1 
week of overlap with ASA and aggrenox before discontinuing her 
ASA.

She was told to hold any estrogen until follow-up with Dr.

fluticasone
aggrenox
femara
simvastatin

for 2 weeks.
Disp:*qs Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

PO every ___ hours as needed: Please do not take tylenol while 
taking this medicine. .

Home With Service

breast cancer

good

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Back pain, perineal numbness
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ - Right L5-S1 Discectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
This is a young female with right lower extremity radicular 
pains that are severe with perineal numbness but no frank 
incontinence. Due to the size of the
disk herniation as well as her perineal numbness as well as 
persistent S1 radicular symptoms and severity of stenosis, she 
presents for surgical intervention.
 
Past Medical History:
retinal detachment
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
n/c
 
Physical Exam:
AVSS
Well appearing, NAD, comfortable
BUE: SILT C5-T1 dermatomal distributions
BUE: ___ Del/Tri/Bic/WE/WF/FF/IO
BUE: tone normal, negative ___, 2+ symmetric DTR 
bic/bra/tri
All fingers WWP, brisk capillary refill, 2+ distal pulses
BLE: SILT L1-S1 dermatomal distributions
BLE: ___ ___
BLE: tone normal, no clonus, toes downgoing, 2+ DTR knee/ankle
All toes WWP, brisk capillary refill, 2+ distal pulses

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and 
taken to the Operating Room for the above procedure.  Refer to 
the dictated operative note for further details.  The surgery 
was without complication and the patient was transferred to the 
PACU in a stable condition.  TEDs/pnemoboots were used for 
postoperative DVT prophylaxis.  Intravenous antibiotics were 
continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initial postop 
pain was controlled with a PCA.  Diet was advanced as tolerated. 
 The patient was transitioned to oral pain medication when 
tolerating PO diet.  Foley was removed on POD#2.  Physical 
therapy was consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate.  
Hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.  On the day of 
discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs, 
comfortable on oral pain control and tolerating a regular diet. 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain, fever.  
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 hours) 
as needed for pain: Do not drink alcohol or drive while taking 
this medication.
Disp:*120 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Diclofenac Sodium 50 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: 
One (1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO BID (2 times a day).  
5. Magnesium Oxide 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
L5-S1 Herniated Disc

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable, A+O, Ambulatory

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than ~45 minutes without moving around.  Try to avoid any 
twisting motion above the knees.

-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery.  You can walk as much as you can 
tolerate. 
oLimit any kind of lifting.

-Brace: You do not need a brace.

-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  If it is dry 
then you can leave the incision open to the air.  Once the 
incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile 
dressing.  Call the office. 

-You should resume taking your normal home medications.

-You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead.  You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___ 2.  We are not allowed to call in narcotic prescriptions 
(oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to the pharmacy.  In addition, 
we are only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days 
from the date of surgery.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

post-operative headache.  Given apparent positional nature, MRI 
was obtained, revealing small fluid collection not consistent 
with CSF.

Work-up was complicated by patient h/o migraines.  Resolution of 
headaches was achieved with change of medication including 
discontinuation of narcotic meds.

Once dural leak was ruled out, patient activity was advanced.  
She tolerated the new regimen well and was discharged with good 
resolution of symptoms.

see admit H&P

needed for pain for 4 weeks.

# Code Status: Full, presumed
# Emergency Contact: Husband, ___ (___)

PATIENT SUMMARY:
================
Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old female with uterine fibroids, now 
s/p UAE and admitted for observation and pain control. Was 
briefly on PCA and transitioned to oral medications for pain 
control before discharge. 

ACUTE ISSUES
============
# Uterine Fibroids s/p UAE: Underwent procedure w/o 
complications. Started on PCA
post-operatively and transitioned to PO before discharge. 
Discharged on: oxycodone 5mg q4h, Tylenol 1g q8h, Zofran prn, 
and bowel regimen. PMP was checked, was last Rx tramadol in 
___. 

# Anemia: Admission Hb 9.9, baseline of 11. MCV low-normal, and 
iron panel with low ferritin. Most likely c/w iron deficiency 
i/s/o known heavy & painful periods. Was given IV iron. 

# Systolic murmur: Noted to have II/VI systolic murmur. No chest 
pain or concerning symptoms, so no role for acute TTE but not 
previously noted to have murmur per outpatient records. Likely 
flow murmur from anemia. 

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Tranexamic Acid Oral Solution 1300 mg PO TID 
2. norethindrone (contraceptive) 0.35 mg oral DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H  
2.  Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg PO EVERY OTHER DAY  
3.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate  
4.  Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY  
5.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN Constipation - First Line  
6.  norethindrone (contraceptive) 0.35 mg oral DAILY  
7. HELD- Tranexamic Acid Oral Solution 1300 mg PO TID  This 
medication was held. Do not restart Tranexamic Acid Oral 
Solution until discussing with your OB/GYN

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
PRIMARY DIAGNOSES: 
Uterine fibroids
Anemia 
Systolic murmur 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,  

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___!  

WHY WAS I IN THE HOSPITAL?  
==========================  
- You were admitted because you had a procedure to help with the 
pain and increased vaginal bleeding caused by uterine fibroids 

WHAT HAPPENED IN THE HOSPITAL?  
==============================  
- You were given medication to control your pain after the 
procedure 
- Your blood counts were monitored and were stable

WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME?  
================================  
- Be sure to take all your medications and attend all of your 
appointments listed below. 

We wish you the best! 

Sincerely, 
Your ___ Team 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
L hand pain and swelling
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
I&D L flexor tenosynovitis

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ M prisoner transferred from ___
with ___ day h/o left hand pain and swelling after he developed/
lysed a blister while doing pull-ups. Hand swelling gradually
worsened. He has pain with motion of digits. He has known h/o
MRSA infection s/p R leg I & D and prolonged course of 
antibiotic
treatment.

 
Past Medical History:
None
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
GEN: Well appearing, NAD
AVSS

LUE:
Sutures in place, incision c/d/i without erythema or induration
SLT m/r/u
+EPL/FDS/FDP/DIO
2+ radial pulse, fingers WWP
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:

******

Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by 
a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1.  The surgical 
dressing was changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision was 
found to be clean and intact without erythema or abnormal 
drainage.  Patient was started on empiric Pip/Tazo pending 
culture results.  After sensitivities revealed MSSA, the patient 
was transitioned to PO keflex for discharge.  Labs were checked 
throughout the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the 
time of discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and 
feeling well.  The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs. 
 The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately 
controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was 
neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is non weight bearing LUE in 
orthoplast splint

Mr ___ is discharged to home in stable condition.
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q6H 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
3. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
4. Cephalexin 500 mg PO Q6H Duration: 2 Weeks 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left flexor tenosynovitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.

2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills.  
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.
6. Please keep your wounds clean. You may shower after 
discharge, but no tub baths or swimming for at least four (4) 
weeks. No dressing is needed if wound continues to be 
non-draining. Any stitches or staples that need to be removed 
will be taken out at first follow up appointment two weeks after 
your surgery.
7. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in two (2) weeks.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___

Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
vaginal bleeding
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none
 
History of Present Illness:
___ G1P0 at 33wks3d with known marginal previa presents after 
waking up and noting to have a steady stream of bright red 
vaginal bleeding. No abdominal pain. Reports active fetal 
movement. No leaking of fluid or contractions. Pt denies any 
dizziness or LOC. Pt denies any intercourse or recent 
falls/trauma.
 
Past Medical History:
PRENATAL COURSE
___ ___, scheduled c/s ___
*)O+/Ab-
*)Per pt her last u/s was with Dr. ___ on ___ and she still 
had a marginal previa

PAST OBSTETRIC HISTORY
nullip

PAST GYNECOLOGIC HISTORY
denies

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
anxiety and depression

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY
LSC ?R salpingectomy and oopherectomy
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
(on admission)
VITALS: T 98.6, HR 113, BP 125/83
GENERAL: NAD
ABDOMEN: soft, gravid, NT
EXTREMITIES: no calf tenderness

SSE: plum sized clot removed from vaginal vault, slow steady 
stream of blood from cervical os which appears closed on visual 
inspection

FHT: 140s/mod var/+A/no decels
TOCO: Q8-10min
SVE: deferred
TAUS: BPP ___, AFI 16, VTX
 
Pertinent Results:
___ WBC-7.7 RBC-3.57 Hgb-11.5 Hct-31.7 MCV-89 Plt-229
___ Hct-31.2
___ BLOOD ___ PTT-22.8 ___ ___ G1 with known marginal previa admitted at 33+3 weeks with 
first episode of vaginal bleeding.
.
Ms ___ was hemodynamically stable on arrival to labor and 
delivery. Sterile speculum exam revealed a plum size clot in the 
vagina with a small amount of blood oozing from the cervix. Her 
cervix appeared closed visually. CBC was stable at 31 and coags 
were normal. She was contracting irregularly, however, was not 
feeling them. Fetal testing was reassuring and she was given a 
course of betamethasone for fetal lung maturity. She was closely 
monitored on labor and delivery and her contractions spaced out 
significantly. She was transferred to the antepartum floor for 
further observation. Ultrasound on ___ revealed a vertex fetus 
with BPP ___, normal AFI (14.3), and EFW 2353g(40%). 
Transvaginal ultrasound revealed a normal cervical length (4.5) 
with no funneling. There was a persistent marginal previa noted. 
She had no further vaginal bleeding, only a small amount of 
brown discharge over the next 2 days. She was betamethasone 
complete on ___. She was discharged home at 34+0 weeks in 
stable condition. She will continue bedrest and have close 
outpatient followup.
 
Medications on Admission:
prenatal vitamins
iron supplement
 
Discharge Medications:
prenatal vitamins
iron supplement
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Marginal placenta previa
Vaginal bleeding
 
Discharge Condition:
Stable. No recent bleeding. Occassional dark brown streaks when 
wiping genitals.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call if you have any vaginal bleeding or spotting. 
Call if you notice any decrease in fetal activity, leakage or 
gushes of fluid, contractions. 
You may also call for anything else that concerns you. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Mucinex Mini-Melts
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Substernal goiter, left.

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Removal of substernal goiter, cervical approach.

 
History of Present Illness:
This patient presented with deviation of the trachea to the 
right significantly and needle biopsy of substernal mass was 
consistent with a benign goiter.However, the connection between 
the left lobe and the goiter
was unclear on CT scan.

 
Past Medical History:
migraines
Substernal goiter, left.

PSH: 
Removal of substernal goiter, cervical approach.
tubal ligation

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
VS:97.8,90, 151/95,20,99% RA
General:well appearing, NAD, clear phonation
HEENT:neck incision C/D/I, no neck fullness,no hematoma
Cardiac:regular rate rhythm,S1 S2 normal 
Pulmonary: clear, no stridor
Abdomen:soft,nontender, nondistended, normoactive bowel sounds
Extremities:WWP, no CCE

 
 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is status post removal of substernal goiter, cervical 
approach. Refer to the operative notes for further details of 
surgery. Patient was transferred to the recovery room and 
admitted to the inpatient general surgery unit overnight.
Patient postoperative course was stable. 
She had good pain control and was transition to oral pain 
medication. Patient had intermittent nausea and received 
antiemetics as needed. Her diet was advanced as tolerated.POD 1 
patient was able to tolerate a regular diet. Patient was voiding 
without difficulty and ambulating independently. Patient was 
discharged home in good condition and will follow-up with Dr. 
___.
 
Medications on Admission:
Famotidine Dosage uncertain
Meclizine 25 mg PO TID 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. meclizine 12.5 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO TID (3 times 
a day).  
2. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day.  
3. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for headache.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Substernal goiter, left.
  

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the inpatient general surgery unit after 
removal of substernal goiter.You have adequate pain control and 
have tolerated a regular diet and may return home to continue 
your recovery. Please resume all regular home medications, 
unless specifically advised not to take a particular medication 
and take any new medications as prescribed. You will be given a 
prescription for narcotic pain medication, take as prescribed. 
It is recommended that you take a stool softner such as Colace 
while taking oral narcotic pain medication to prevent 
constipation. You may also take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as 
directed, but do not exceed 4000 mg in one day. Please get 
plenty of rest, continue to walk several times per day, and 
drink adequate amounts of fluids. 

Please call your surgeon or go to the emergency department if 
you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the 
incision site.You may shower and wash incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water.Avoid swimming and baths until cleared by your 
surgeon.Gently pat the area dry.You have a neck incision with 
steri-strips in place, do not remove, they will fall off on 
their own.

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope 
is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual 
activities. Good luck!

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Chief Complaint:

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:

History of Present Illness:
___ w/ hx of fibroids who presented with 12 hrs of acute on
chronic lower abdominal pain. The pain began ~ 1month ago and
describes it as initially LLQ but transforming into bilateral
groin pain that radiates to the back. Walking exacerbates the
pain, but no single position improves it. Pain is also not
affected by food. She was evaluated by her PCP ___ ___ who was
unable to identify the etiology of the pain. Abdominal and 
rectal
exams were normal then. At 5pm on the day of presentation, the
pain suddenly worsened to ___. She was still able to continue
taking fluids and food and continues to urinate. She had a bowel
movement earlier today and is passing flatus.  She denies 
fevers,
chills, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, loose stools, melena, BRBPR,
dysuria, sexual activity.
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: Fibroids, Menorrhagia, Stress incontinence, Obesity,
Multinodular goiter, Asthma, Migraines, GERD

PSH: Partial thyroidectomy, Bilateral tubal ligation

non-contributory

guarding,
+bowel sounds, no CVA tenderness 
Pain in groin region bilaterally on hip flexion
Ext: WWP, +DP bilaterally, no edema

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 11:55PM BLOOD WBC-10.7 RBC-4.59 Hgb-12.9 Hct-39.9 
MCV-87 MCH-28.1 MCHC-32.4 RDW-12.7 Plt ___
___ 11:55PM BLOOD Glucose-102* UreaN-13 Creat-0.8 Na-138 
K-3.9 Cl-104 HCO3-25 AnGap-13
___ 11:55PM BLOOD ALT-17 AST-24 AlkPhos-85 TotBili-0.2
___ 11:55PM BLOOD Lipase-42
___ 11:55PM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the ___ service on ___ with acute 
abdominal pain for overnight observation to rule out 
appendicitis.  Her CT scan showed a normal sized appendix 
without inflammation.  Her WBC count was normal.  On the morning 
of ___, her pain had resolved, she was able to tolerate a 
regular diet, and she was deemed appropriate for discharge.
 
Medications on Admission:
Fluticasone, Amlodipine, Pepcid prn, Albuterol prn

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
2. Amlodipine 5 mg PO DAILY 
3. Fluticasone Propionate NASAL 2 SPRY NU DAILY 
4. Albuterol Inhaler 2 PUFF IH Q6H:PRN SOB 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Abdominal pain

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the ___ surgery service with abdominal pain 
concerning for appendicitis.  You had a CT scan which 
demonstrated a normal sized, non-imflammed appendix.  You were 
monitored overnight, and remained afebrile.  Your pain improved 
in the morning, and you were able to tolerate a regular diet.  
You are now ready to return home.
 
Please call your doctor or go to the emergency department if:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*You develop new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or 
wheeze.
*You are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons.  Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience an unusual discharge.
*Your pain is not improving within 12 hours or is not under 
control within 24 hours.
*Your pain worsens or changes location.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*You develop any concerning symptoms.
 
General Discharge Instructions:
Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication.  Please take any 
new medications as prescribed.
Please take the prescribed analgesic medications as needed.  You 
may not drive or heavy machinery while taking narcotic analgesic 
medications.  You may also take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as 
directed, but do not exceed 4000 mg in one day.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk several times per 
day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.  Please also 
follow-up with your primary care physician.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___               ___ No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Latex / Epinephrine Hcl
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
liver lesion
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___- left lateral segmentectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___- old female with an incidental finding of 
a hypointense
lesion in the left lobe of the liver on MRI for a breast lesion 
in ___.  An abdominal ultrasound on ___ demonstrated a 
space-occupying
lesion in the left lobe of the liver. An MRI on ___ 
demonstrated a T1 and
T2-hyperintense lesion measuring 6.6 cm x 6.5 cm in the left 
lateral segment of the liver.  Postcontrast images demonstrated 
peripheral centripetal enhancement, findings consistent with a 
large cavernous hemangioma.  Over the past several months she 
developed midepigastric abdominal pain described as sharp, 
sometimes severe, to the point of doubling her over. She was 
quite concerned about the severity of the pain, especially as it 
occurs every ___ days and interrupts her normal functioning. 
Risks and benefits of surgical intervention were discussed with 
the patient in clinic, and after informed consent was obtained 
she was brought to the operating room for enucleation versus 
left lateral segmentectomy. 
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: anemia, s/p endometrial ablation, uterine fibroids, 
mastitis, and right breast calcifications.

PSH: none

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM
VS: 97.5 81 ___ 99%ra
Gen: alert and oriented, pleasant appearing woman in no acute 
distress
CV: regular rate/rhythm
Pulm: clear to auscultation, easy work of breathing
GI: soft, nondistended, appropriately tender to palpation. Right 
subcostal incision with steri strips in place, clean/dry/intact
Ext: warm, well perfused
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:00AM BLOOD WBC-8.3 RBC-4.81 Hgb-9.6* Hct-31.2* 
MCV-65* MCH-19.9* MCHC-30.8* RDW-18.2* Plt ___
___ 06:00AM BLOOD Glucose-92 UreaN-8 Creat-0.7 Na-139 K-4.1 
Cl-106 HCO3-25 AnGap-12
___ 06:00AM BLOOD ALT-32 AST-27 AlkPhos-48 TotBili-0.6
___ 06:00AM BLOOD Calcium-8.3* Phos-3.7 Mg-1.8
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, she underwent exploratory laparotomy and left 
lateral segmentectomy. Surgeon was Dr. ___. Please 
refer to operative note for details. Postop, vital signs were 
stable. She experienced a lot of back pain postop. Pain was 
controlled initially with IV Morphine, Toradol and warm packs. 
IV Morphine was switched to IV Dilaudid due to pruritus. This 
was later switched back to Morphine due to better pain control 
with Morphine. She had a low grade temp on postop day 1 
attributed to respiratory source. Incentive spirometry and 
ambulation were encouraged with temperature decrease. Zofran was 
given for nausea.

Diet was slowly advanced and tolerated. IV Morphine was switched 
to Oxycodone with decreased pain. Abdomen was mildly distended. 
She was passing flatus and had a small BM x2 by postop day 5. 
Back pain was improved. LFTs were notable for initial slight 
increase in alt/ast. These trended back down to normal. Hct 
decreased to 31 (from 36)and stabilized at 31. Incision remained 
intact, dry and without redness. She felt well enough to go home 
on postop day 6 and was ambulating independently at time of 
discharge to home on postop day 6. 

Of note, path report was finalized as follows: 
Liver, left lateral segment mass, resection (A-F):

hyalinization.

Additional evaluation with trichrome stain will be reported in 
an addendum.

___. You underwent a liver resection for cavernous

text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
left sided trigeminal nerve pain 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ MICROVASCULAR DECOMPRESSION OF TRIGEMINAL NERVE / LEFT 
SIDE 

 
History of Present Illness:
 had the pleasure of seeing ___ in the ___
clinic.  As you will recall, she is a ___ right-handed
female who complains of left facial pain since ___.  She has 
had
a longstanding history of trigeminal neuralgia, essentially in
the left V3 distribution.  The pain increased in ___.  She
was initially managed with Trileptal and she had good relief;
however, the dose of Trileptal has been raised to 900 mg b.i.d. 
The pain does not cross the midline and occasionally affects the
V2 distribution also.  Anything such as cold air, brushing 
teeth,
or eating can aggravate it.

 
Past Medical History:
Past medical history is significant for cholecystectomy and 
tubal
ligation.

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Family history is negative for stroke and hypertension.

 
Physical Exam:
On examination, she is awake, alert, oriented x3.  Her speech is
fluent.  She is oriented to person, place, and date.  Her pupils
are equal and reacting to light.  Extraocular movements are 
full.
 Facial sensation is intact.  Face is symmetric.  Hearing is
intact bilaterally.  Palate elevation is symmetric.  Shoulder
shrug is symmetric.  Tongue is in the midline.  Motor strength 
is
___ in all four extremities.  There is no pronator drift.  Gait
is within normal limits.

Exam on Discharge:
Neurologically intact. Incision on the left side of head closed 
with nyelon sutures.

 
Pertinent Results:
CT head ___:

Postoperative changes related to left occipital craniectomy with 
numerous 
locules of gas and opacification of the left mastoid air cells, 
presumably 
post-surgical. 
  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted through the same day admission department for 
elective left sided microvascular decompression of the 
trigeminal nerve.  She underwent the procedure without 
complication and was recovered in the ICU overnight.  

Her pain was well controlled and her diet advanced.  She was 
started on steroids to assist in control of her nausea.  Her 
postoperative imaging was stable and she was later transfered to 
the floor.  

She had some continued problems with nausea, we added a 
scoplamine patch for nausea control and her symptoms improved.  
She was discharged home on ___.
 
Medications on Admission:
She is on aspirin, not on Coumadin or Plavix.

Current medications are Trileptal, calcium and vitamin D,
oxycodone.  No allergies.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain for 1 weeks.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. dexamethasone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO q8-12hours for 
3 days: Steroid taper:
1 day 4mg Q8hours
1 day 4mg Q12hours
1 day 2mg Q12 horus.
Disp:*13 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. famotidine 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day) for 1 weeks: While on steroids.
Disp:*14 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
TRIGEMINAL NEURALGIA

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital for elective left sided 
microvascular decompression of your trigeminal nerve.  You 
underwent the procedure without incident and were recovered in 
the ICU. Your post operative imaging was as expected.  Your 
hospitalization was otherwise uneventful.

General Instructions

Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
--You may wash your hair ___ days after your surgery with mild 
shampoo, do not scrub the area.
You may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover 
your head.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc. 
Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.
Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while 
at home, unless you have been instructed not to. 

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

New onset of tremors or seizures.
Any confusion or change in mental status. 
Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, or drainage.
Fever greater than or equal to 101° F.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right thyroid nodule with indeterminate cytology.

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Right hemithyroidectomy, parathyroid autotransplantation, 
intraoperative nerve monitoring.

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ woman with a previous medical 
history significant for a stroke in ___ of unknown 
etiology.Since then,she has been on Aggrenox,and being followed 
by primary care physician,and also by Neurology at ___ 
___ underwent a right mastectomy for cancer in 
___ by immediate breast reconstruction.The patient now 
presents with a newly-diagnosed right-sided 1.1-cm thyroid 
nodule where recent ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration 
biopsy yielded cytology that was indeterminate for 
malignancy,and consistent with a microfollicular neoplasm.The 
patient now presents for right hemithyroidectomy.
 
Past Medical History:
Thyroid nodule
Right breast cancer (ER positive, HER-2/neu positive 
CVA without sequalae
Hyperlipidemia
Low vitamin D levels,
Obesity
Allergic rhinitis

PSH:
Right hemithyroidectomy
s/p right total mastectomy with reconstruction

 

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Maternal grand mother died of throat cancer, no thyroid cancer, 
liver cancer, no renal stones.

 
Physical Exam:
VS:98.6,78,125/88, 16, 100% room air
Gen: well appearing, NAD, clear phonation, no stridor
HEENT:no hematoma, dressing C/D/I, no neck fullness, 
Cardiac:regular rate rhythm,no murmur, gallop,rubs 
Pulmonary:clear, no stridor
Abdomen:soft,nontender, nondistended, normoactive bowel sounds
Ext: WWP, no CCE

 
 
Pertinent Results:
none
 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old female with history of right thyroid 
nodule with indeterminate cytology.The patient is status post 
right hemithyroidectomy, parathyroid autotransplantation, 
intraoperative nerve monitoring.

The procedure went well without complication (reader referred to 
the Operative Notes for details). After a brief, uneventful stay 
in the PACU, the patient was transferred to the inpatient 
general surgery unit and was hemodynamically stable.
 
HEENT: The neck monitored for signs of hematoma of which there 
were none. There was no voice hoarseness,no stridor,no dyspnea 
and demonstrated excellent phonation, .
 
Gastrointestinal: The diet was advanced from clears to regular 
which was tolerated well without any nausea or emesis.

Genitourinary: The patient voided spontaneously without any 
difficulty.
 
Endocrine: The patient denied perioral or lower extremity 
numbness or tingling.   
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

 
Medications on Admission:
Aggrenox
estadiol
flonase
femara
leuprolide
nasonex
calcium/VitD

 
Discharge Medications:
1. fluticasone 50 mcg/Actuation Spray, Suspension Sig: Two (2) 
Spray Nasal DAILY (Daily).  
2. hydrocodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right thyroid nodule with indeterminate cytology.

  

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
It was a pleasure to take care of you after your surgery. You 
have adequate pain control,tolerated a regular diet and may 
return home to continue your recovery. Please notify office or 
go to emergency room if you develop fever, 
chills,redness,increase pain, neck swelling or drainage at 
incision site.You have steri strips on your neck incision, 
please keep clean and dry. These steri-strips will fall off on 
their own, please do not remove them. You may shower but avoid 
swimming or bathing. You will be given a prescription for 
vicodin for pain, take as directed. For mild pain you may take 
acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Motrin) as directed. Do 
not take more than 4000 mg of acetaminophen daily. We recommend 
that you take a stool softner (Colace)while taking oral narcotic 
medication. If you have any questions or concerns please call 
the office ___.

 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___.                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Cipro
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Left flank pain, Nausea
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female who is 6 weeks status post
dismembered pyeloplasty for left kidney for chronic 
ureteropelvic
junction obstruction. She underwent attempted removal of her
ureteral stent in the office on ___ which was not able 
to
be completed due to migration of the tip of the stent into the
very distal ureter just past the ureteral orifice. ___ confirmed
this finding. She presented ___ for removal of the stent
under anesthesia via ureteroscopy which was performed along with
balloon dilation of the left ureteral orifice.  She presented to
the emergency department late this evening with nausea and
vomiting (which she has experienced before after anesthesia) and
worsening left flank pain.  She denies having hematuria, but has
noted that she has not passed much urine since the procedure.

text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Pain and protrusion of mesh from prior cranioplasty
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ - Dr ___ - revision cranioplasty
 
History of Present Illness:
___ who underwent a cranioplasty for L trigeminal neuralgia in 
___ and then p/w pain and protrusion of mesh behind 
left ear. This was causing pt distress and she decided to 
undergo revision cranioplasty. No fevers/chills or other signs 
of infection. No neurologic symptoms.
 
Past Medical History:
Past medical history is significant for cholecystectomy and 
tubal
ligation.

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Family history is negative for stroke and hypertension.

 
Physical Exam:
Alert and oriented x3
No apparent distress
Cranial Nerves intact (specifically CN 5)
Wound c/d/i, no erythema.
EOMI
PERRL
lungs CTAB
abd soft/NT/ND
Moving all 4 extremities spontaneously and purposefully
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ was admitted to the neurosurgery service at ___ 
postoperatively on ___ following a revision cranioplasty. 
She was initially followed in the PACU with PO pain meds and IV 
pain meds for breakthrough pain. She remained stable in the PACU 
and was transferred to the floor in the usual fashion. On the 
floor she advanced her diet, was out of bed, was encouraged to 
deep breath and use incentive spirometry and progressed without 
complication. Her vital signs remained stable and she was 
neurologically intact. Her wound was clean and dry without 
erythema or induration. On POD 1 she was deemed stable and ready 
for discharge to home with the appropriate medication 
prescription and instructions for follow-up.
 
Medications on Admission:
Aspirin, Calcium, MVI
 
Discharge Medications:
1. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
2. oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain : do not drive, drink 
alcohol or operate machinery/appliances while taking this 
medication.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
revision cranioplasty

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
You may wash your hair only after sutures and/or staples have 
been removed. 
You may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover 
your head.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc.   
Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.
Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while 
at home.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Pt admitted from the ED with the above history on ___. She

Discharge Condition:

difficulty, having regular bowel movements and passing flatus.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the 
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
diarrhea or other reasons. 
* Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid heartbeat or 
feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
* Your skin, or the whites of your eyes become yellow.
* Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or 

back.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
* Please resume all regular home medications 
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

following:

medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting,
diarrhea or other reasons.
* Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid heartbeat or
feeling dizzy or faint when standing.

bowel movement.

within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or
back.

degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that
concern you.
* Please resume all regular home medications
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.

text:
Name:  ___.              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Magnesium Sulfate Heptahydrate
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Recurrent small bowel obstruction
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Lysis of adhesions

 
History of Present Illness:
___ had undergone surgery within a few
days of her birth for necrotizing enterocolitis.  Over the 
succeeding years
about once a year and sometimes more frequently she would
present to the hospital with a bowel obstruction. On the last
occasion when I looked after her for the first time, this
bowel obstruction with severe, quite prolonged and there was
a question of ischemia raised at one point. I therefore
discussed the situation with her and we decided to perform an
elective operation to try and solve this problem.

 
Past Medical History:
SBR and appendectomy for NEC as a baby
Disc herniation
recurrent SBO

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
Physical Exam:
96.8 58 128/68 18 100%RA
Gen: AA&O x3, NAD
___: RRR, no m/r/g
Resp: CTAB
Abd: soft, ND
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:20AM BLOOD Hct-31.1*
___ 07:50AM BLOOD Glucose-101 UreaN-12 Creat-0.7 Na-138 
K-4.5 Cl-106 HCO3-26 AnGap-11
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ underwent an elective lysis of adhesions on ___. 
 No bowel resections were necessary.  She had a fairly 
unremarkable post-operative course.  Pain was controlled with a 
pca. POD # 1 her diet was advanced to clears.  By POD #2 she was 
passing gas and tolerating a regular diet.  She was discharged 
later that day with instructions to follow up in clinic.  
 
Medications on Admission:
vicodin prn

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain: Do not exceed 4000mg of 
acetaminophen in 24hrs.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) as needed for constipation.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary:
Recurrent Small bowel obstruction
.
Secondary:
prematurity, NEC, s/p jejunal plication & TI resection, 
appendectomy, L4-5 L5-S1 herniated disc, recurrent SBO 

 
Discharge Condition:
hemodynamically stable, tolerating oral intake, voiding without 
difficulty, pain well controlled on an oral regimen. 

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the 
following:
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
* Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or 

back.
*Avoid lifting objects > 5lbs until your follow-up appointment 
with the surgeon.
*Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
as ordered. 
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.
.
Incision Care:
-You may shower, and gently wash surgical incisions.
-Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
-Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.
- Your staples will be removed at your follow-up appointment.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
___ Complaint:
fundal fibroid
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
open abdominal myomectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ G0, with enlarged fibroid uterus, menorrhagia, right side 
abodminal discomfort with menses.
 
Past Medical History:
No prior surgery
No h/o heart, lung, liver, kidney disease
No h/o clotting disorders
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
noncontributory
 
Physical Exam:
Post-op ___

Tm 99.2, Tc 97.9, 94/54, 78, 18, 100%RA
Gen: NAD, AxO
Cv: RRR
Resp: CTAB, no crackles
Abd: normoactive BS, soft, nontender, appropriately tender to 
palpation, no rebound or guarding, incision covered and dry
Ext: pboots on, calves nontender
 
Pertinent Results:
none for this admission
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted after undergoing an open 
abdominal myomectomy for a large fundal fibroid. Please refer to 
operative report for details of the procedure. Her 
post-operative course was uncomplicated. By the afternoon of 
POD1, she was tolerating PO, voiding spontaneously, passed 
flatus, pain was controlled with oral medications, and she was 
ambulating independently without difficulty. She was then 
discharged home in good condition.
 
Medications on Admission:
MVI
 
Discharge Medications:
1. oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet 
PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*1*
3. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
uterine fibroid

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted after undergoing an open abdominal myomectomy 
for uterine fibroid.

General instructions:  
* Take your medications as prescribed.  
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.  
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol  
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs  
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex), no 
heavy lifting of objects >10lbs for 6 weeks.  
* You may eat a regular diet.  

Call your doctor for:  
* fever > 100.4  
* severe abdominal pain  
* difficulty urinating  
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr  
* abnormal vaginal discharge  
* redness or drainage from incision  
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication  

Incision care:  
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.  
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.  
 
To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.  

 
Followup Instructions:
___

for a L dorsal hand abscess after injecting himself with 
cocaine. He underwent operative I&D on ___. The patient 
tolerated the procedure well. He remained in house awaiting Cx 
results, which speciated on ___ with coag+ Staph. aureus. He 
had another bedside I&D on ___ of a separate R arm abscess, 
uneventful. He was discharged on ___ with Bactrim. He will 
follow up in Hand Fellows clinic on ___, but may be seen 
earlier.

L dorsal hand abscess

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
- RUQ pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
- none

 
History of Present Illness:
On admission:
___ presents complaining of 24 hours of severe RUQ pain. States 
that pain awoke her last evening at midnight, ___ constant 
sharp pain. Never had anything like it before. No associated 
nausea or vomiting or fever or chills. Went to ___ 
where she had normal labs and scheduled an U/S for later in the 
day. Went home and had some toast, returned and had to delay U/S 
secondary to eating. Labs returned with positive pregnancy test 
and an U/S that showed a viable fetus. RUQ U/S was normal, but 
she was transferred to BID due to the pregnancy. On arrival 
here, still uncomfortable but improving, no nausea or vomiting. 
Pain on U/S, but otherwise mostly resolved. Last BM this AM, 
normal, no blood, no diarrhea. No chest pain or shortness of 
breath. No dysuria.

 
Past Medical History:
- none
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
- non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Day of Discharge:
Vitals -  T:96.0  BP:102/69  HR:62  RR:16  O2sat:100% r/a
Gen: NAD, A&O
CV: RRR, no M/R/G
Resp: CTAB
Abd: soft, + BS, not distended, no TTP
Ext: no C/C/E
 
Pertinent Results:
___ WBC-9.3 Hgb-12.6 Hct-35.9 Plt ___
___ Neuts-72.4 ___ Monos-2.2 Eos-0.9 Baso-0.2
.
___ Lipase-26
___ Lipase-28
___ Lipase-40
.
___ ALT-383 AST-283 AlkPhos-94 TotBili-0.5
___ ALT-295 AST-158 AlkPhos-89 Amylase-49 TotBili-0.5
___ ALT-192 AST-63 AlkPhos-83 Amylase-54 TotBili-0.7
.
___ RUQ ULTRASOUND:
IMPRESSION: Intraluminal echogenic contents within the 
gallbladder, which may reflect sludge and/or small gallstones, 
with tenderness over this area. However, no additional findings 
to suggest acute cholecystitis such as gallbladder wall 
thickening, pericholecystic fluid, or distention. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
*)Biliary Colic
She was admitted and made NPO; ultrasound was significant for 
biliary sludge and some small gallstones. However, she remained 
afebrile and with no signs of infection. Her pain gradually 
improved and her diet was advanced. On discharge her pain had 
resolved and she was tolerating a regular diet. Follow up was to 
be arranged for likely cholecystectomy during the second 
trimester. 
.
*)Early Pregnancy
Follow up was arranged with Obstetrics for ___ care. 
 
Medications on Admission:
- multi-vitamin
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Prenatal ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.
Disp:30 Tablet(s) Refills:2
2. Augmentin 500-125 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a 
day for 1 weeks.
Disp:14 Tablet(s) Refills:0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
- biliary colic
- early pregnancy

 
Discharge Condition:
- stable
- tolerating oral intake

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the 
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea 
or other reasons. 
* Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid heartbeat or 
feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
* Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*Avoid lifting objects > 5lbs until your follow-up appointment 
with the surgeon.
*Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
as ordered. 
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.
* Abdominal pain/cramping or vaginal bleeding. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right ankle pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Right ankle ORIF 

 
History of Present Illness:
___ presents with Right ankle pain s/p mechanical fall. She was 
walking over a small ledge and rolled her ankle, landed on her 
backside. Immediate pain and inability to bear weight. Presented 
to ___ where x-rays revealed Right ankle fracture. Orthopedics 
 was consulted, and the patient was taken for ORIF of her right 
ankle fracture on ___.  

 
Past Medical History:
anxiety, depression, chronic low back pain 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM
General: NAD, A&Ox3, pleasant  
Psych: appropriate mood and affect  
Musculoskeletal:  
Right Lower Extremity:  
Skin clean and intact, splint in place to right foot and ankle 
Thigh and leg compartments soft and compressible  
Sensation intact to light touch sural, saphenous, tibial, 
superficial and deep peroneal nerve distributions
Fires ___
1+ dorsal pedis and posterior tibial pulses  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have right ankle fracture, and was admitted to the orthopedic 
surgery service. The patient was taken to the operating room on 
___ for ORIF right ankle fracture, which the patient 
tolerated well (for full details please see the separately 
dictated operative report). The patient was taken from the OR to 
the PACU in stable condition and after recovery from anesthesia 
was transferred to the floor. The patient was initially given IV 
fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet 
and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was given 
perioperative antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine. The 
patient worked with ___ who determined that discharge to home was 
appropriate. The ___ hospital course was otherwise 
unremarkable.  

At the time of discharge the patient was afebrile with stable 
vital signs that were within normal limits, pain was well 
controlled with oral medications, incisions were 
clean/dry/intact, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels 
spontaneously. The patient is NWB in the right lower extremity, 
and will be discharged on ASA 325 for DVT prophylaxis. The 
patient will follow up in two weeks per routine. A thorough 
discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and 
expected post-discharge course, and all questions were answered 
prior to discharge.  

 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 to 2 tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) 
hours Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Lorazepam 0.5-1 mg IV Q4H:PRN anxiety/agitation 
RX *lorazepam [Ativan] 0.5 mg 1 to 2 tablet(s) by mouth every 
four (4) hours Disp #*20 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right ankle fracture 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires crutches 

 
Discharge Instructions:
MEDICATIONS
You will be given a prescription for pain medicine. The pain 
medication is a codeine derivative and should be taken as 
directed.  
Please take one full strength aspirin (325 mg) each day for six 
weeks to decrease the risk of having a complication related to a 
blood clot.  
Please take a stool softener, like Colace (Docusate Sodium 
100mg), twice a day while taking narcotics to prevent 
constipation.  
Dressing  
Leave your dressing in place for 48 hours after your surgery. 
After 48 hours, you may remove your dressing. LEAVE THE TAPE 
STRIPS OVER YOUR INCISIONS. These will stay on for 1.5 to 2 
weeks and will slowly peel off.  

SHOWERING
You may shower 48 hours after your surgery and get your 
incisions wet. DO NOT soak in a tub or pool for 2 weeks to avoid 
excessive scarring and risk of infection.  
 
ACTIVITY
-Take it easy.
-DO NOT BEAR WEIGHT on your right ankle until you have been seen 
for follow up and been instructed that it is safe to bear weight 
  

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
