Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
right ankle injury
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Right ankle external fixator placement on ___

 
History of Present Illness:
___ otherwise healthy self-employed ___ who was
standing on a ___ forklift that was carrying a heavy package
when the package slipped off causing one of the forks to spring
upward striking the heel of his right foot. He noted immediate
right ankle pain but did not fall. He was initially evaluated at
___ and transferred to ___ ED here for
evaluation of R ankle fx. He denies injury elsewhere. He denies
numbness or tinling.

 
Past Medical History:
None
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
n/c
 
Physical Exam:
Vital signs: 98, 111, 116/72, 16, 100% RA 
Gen: NAD, calm & comfortable 
 
RLE:
Old abrasion over medial mal
Minimal deformity and edema over R ankle 
Thigh & leg compartments soft
Sensation intact to light touch in saphenous, sural, deep
peroneal & superficial peroneal distributions
Motor intact for ___, FHL, GSC, TA
Dorsalis pedis palpable, toes warm & well perfused

 
Pertinent Results:
Xrays/CT: comminuted right pilon fracture with posterior talar 
head
fracture, subluxation of talus anteriorly
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the hospital after a closed reduction 
and splinting of his right pilon fracture in the ED. He was 
taken to the OR on ___ for external fixation of his 
fracture given significant swelling. Post-operatively he will be 
non weight bearing of the right lower extremity with elevation. 
Pain was controlled with a postoperative block and PO pain 
medications. He will be discharged on Lovenox for DVT 
prophylaxis.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. This patient is not taking any preadmission medications

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID:PRN constipation 
3. Enoxaparin Sodium 40 mg SC QPM 
Start: Today - ___, First Dose: Next Routine Administration 
Time 
RX *enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL 40 mg SC daily Disp #*14 Syringe 
Refills:*0
4. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q3H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*80 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right distal tibia pilon fracture
Right talus fracture
Right fifth metatarsal fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take lovenox 40mg daily for 2 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You should keep the right leg and external fixator dry.  You 
should remove the dressing and clean the pin sites daily 
starting the ___ day from surgery with ___ strength hydrogen 
peroxide. 
- No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- No dressing is needed if wound continues to be non-draining.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Non weight bearing right leg, strict elevation
Physical Therapy:
Right lower extremity elevation, non weight bearing
Treatments Frequency:
Right lower extremity pin site care daily with ___ strength 
hydrogen peroxide
 
Followup Instructions:
___

RLE: Splint in place, toes WWP, SILT sp/dp, fires ___. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented for planned surgery on his right ankle. 
The patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for 
removal right ankle external fixator and ORIF pilon fracture, 
which the patient tolerated well. For full details of the 
procedure please see the separately dictated operative report. 
The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable 
condition and after satisfactory recovery from anesthesia was 
transferred to the floor. The patient was initially given IV 
fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet 
and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was given 
___ antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine. The 
patient's home medications were continued throughout this 
hospitalization. The patient worked with ___ who determined that 
discharge to home with services was appropriate. The ___ 
hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
NWB in a splint in the right lower extremity, and will be 
discharged on lovenox for DVT prophylaxis. The patient will 
follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough discussion 
was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected 
post-discharge course including reasons to call the office or 
return to the hospital, and all questions were answered. The 
patient was also given written instructions concerning 
precautionary instructions and the appropriate follow-up care. 
The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
3. Enoxaparin Sodium 40 mg SC QPM 
Start: ___, First Dose: Next Routine Administration Time 
RX *enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL 40 mg sc at bedtime Disp #*28 
Syringe Refills:*0
4. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
5. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q3H:PRN Pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth Q3H Disp #*80 Tablet 
Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right tibial plafond fracture
Right talar dome fracture
Right fifth metatarsal fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___, 

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Right lower extremity non-weight-bearing in splint. 
- Elevate on pillows to reduce swelling. 
 

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take Lovenox 40mg daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- No dressing is needed if wound continues to be non-draining.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed
- Do NOT get splint wet
Physical Therapy:
Right lower extremity non-weight-bearing in splint 
Range of motion as tolerated at knee  
Treatments Frequency:
General postoperative care 
Splint to remain in place until 2 week follow up appointment
Elevate right lower extremity 
Lovenox education 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

no organomegaly,

Pertinent Results:
RUQ US
TECHNIQUE: The liver demonstrates no focal or textural 
abnormalities. There is no intra- or extra-hepatic biliary 
ductal dilatation. The gallbladder is normal in appearance 
without stones or wall edema. The common bile duct is normal in 
caliber measuring 3 mm. The body and head of the pancreas appear 
unremarkable. The tail of the pancreas is slightly obscured by 
overlying bowel gas. There is no perihepatic ascites. The main 
portal vein is patent with hepatopetal flow.

IMPRESSION:
1. Normal sonographic appearance of the liver and gallbladder 
with no evidence for cholelithiasis, ascites or biliary ductal 
dilatation.
2. Slightly limited view of the distal pancreas due to overlying 
bowel gas. The head and body of the pancreas appear 
unremarkable.

heavy ETOH use. No gallstones on RUQ U/S, no meds, Unclear 
etiology, minimal evidence of UTI/pyelonephritis, min evidence 
for ovarian process, treated for pancreatitis. LFTs peaked and 
declined, her diet was advanced to regular without difficulty, 
she was administered IVF, and percocet for pain once tolerating 
POs. Diagnostics were with normal calcium and triglyericides.

OCP

Home

Good, tolerating PO diet, afebrile

symptomatically with IV hydration and pain medications and bowel 
rest.  

If you experience increased fevers chills, nausea, vomitting or 
any other concerning symptom, please call your primary care 
doctor or go to the nearest hospital

text:
Name:  ___                      Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Healthy kidney donor
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
donor nephrectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ y.o. healthy male who successfully underwent renal donor 
workup to donate to friend. He has been in good healthy and 
presents for donor nephrectomy. 
 
Past Medical History:
throat surgery for OSA, rotator cuff surgery
___ left laparascopic donor nephrectomy
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
father had cad and died from alcoholism
mother is healthy
 
Physical ___:
98.3  72  120/74 14  95% wt 86.15  height 167.64cm
NAD
neck no LAD, no TM, neck supple
lungs clear
cor rrr
abd non-tender
ext no edema

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 04:40AM BLOOD WBC-13.3*# RBC-4.60 Hgb-13.9* Hct-41.1 
MCV-89 MCH-30.1 MCHC-33.8 RDW-13.7 Plt ___
___ 04:40AM BLOOD Glucose-103* UreaN-24* Creat-1.9* Na-137 
K-4.4 Cl-97 HCO3-28 AnGap-16
___ 04:40AM BLOOD Calcium-8.8 Phos-4.1 Mg-2.0
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, he underwent left laparoscopic donor nephrectomy. 
Postop, he did well with appropriate urine output. Pain was 
controlled with pca morphine. Vital signs were stable. 

On postop day 1, creatinine increased as expected (1.9 from 
baseline of 1.0). Foley was removed and he voided without 
incident.Hematocrit was stable. Diet was advanced and tolerated. 
Incisions remained intact with small amount of bruising. He was 
ambulatory. sLate in the day, he had a temperature of 101. 
Incision were without redness/drainage. Lungs were diminished in 
bases, but clear. He denied dysuria. He had a temperature of 
100.8 on postop day 2 and was pan cultured. CXR revealed low 
lung volumes w/ bibasilar atelectasis,no acute process and 
moderate postop pneumoperitoneum. Bowel loops were prominent 
with air-fluid levels, suggesting ileus. 

He did experience some abdominal fullness and was given a 
dulcolax suppository without results. Given fever and KUB 
findings, an abdominal CT with po contrast only was performed 
noting air in the colon, air under the diaphragm and no fluid 
collections. 

He was afebrile x 24hour and was discharged to home in stable 
condition. 
 
Medications on Admission:
pravastatin
 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO prn; every 
8 hours as needed for pain: no more than 4 grams per day.  
2. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day): stool softner
may obtain over the counter.  
3. pravastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
4. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
healthy renal donor
ileus

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call the Transplant Office ___ if you have any 
of the following: 
fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, increased abdominal pain, 
abdominal distension, incision redness/bleeding/drainage
You may shower. Do not apply lotion/powder/ointment to incision
No heavy lifting/straining 
no driving while taking pain medication
 
Followup Instructions:
___

History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a new patient to
this clinic, but was previously being treated by Dr. ___. On ___, the patient underwent an ORIF of 
her
right ankle fracture dislocation that she sustained when she
slipped down some stairs.  The patient was doing well
postoperatively.  She did two courses of physical therapy, but
unfortunately she has not regained full function of her ankle. 
She says it does feel better, but she has pain on a daily basis
and this pain is a ___.  She says that if she walks for more
than two hours, she is in a great deal of pain.  Going up and
down steps is especially difficult for her.  She did try wearing
a lace-up ankle support, but it did not provide her with any
significant relief.  She has not had any cortisone injections,
but she does take diclofenac when needed.  She presents today 
for
evaluation and to discuss treatment.

 
Past Medical History:
anxiety, depression, chronic low back pain 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
Gen: NAD
RLE: Splint c/d/I.  Toes wwp. Wiggles toes with minimal 
sensation ___ block
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was taken to OR to undergo R ankle ___, syndesmotic and 
deltoid ligament reconstructions. Please see operative report 
for full details. Post-procedure, patient was transferred to 
PACU then floor.  Her pain was initially controlled with iv pain 
meds and transitioned to oral pain meds. She tolerated a diet 
and worked with ___.  Patient received lovenox for DVT 
prophylaxis and was encouraged to ambulate within her activity 
limitations.  At time of discharge, pain controlled, her splint 
was c/d/I, and patient expressed readiness for discharge.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. BuPROPion (Sustained Release) 100 mg PO QAM 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. BuPROPion (Sustained Release) 100 mg PO QAM 
2. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H 
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO TID 
4. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
5. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY Duration: 14 Days 
6. Ondansetron 4 mg PO Q8H:PRN nausea 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___

R ankle instability

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

See separate Dr. ___ sheet

Name:  ___                       Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
re-admission for pre-eclampsia severe by headache and BPs
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
Physical Exam:
Physical Exam on Discharge: 

VS: Afebrile, Vital signs stable 
Neuro/Psych: no acute distress, Oriented x3, Affect Normal 
Heart: regular rate and rhythm
Lungs: clear to auscultation bilaterally
Abdomen: soft, appropriately tender, fundus firm, incision 
clean/dry/intact
Pelvis: minimal bleeding 
Extremities: warm and well perfused, no calf tenderness, no 
edema 

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:00PM   CREAT-0.7
___ 05:00PM   estGFR-Using this
___ 05:00PM   estGFR-Using this
___ 05:00PM   URIC ACID-6.4*
___ 05:00PM   WBC-6.7 RBC-3.87* HGB-12.4 HCT-37.5 MCV-97 
MCH-32.0 MCHC-33.1 RDW-12.8 RDWSD-45.1
___ 05:00PM   PLT COUNT-311
___ 04:58PM URINE  HOURS-RANDOM CREAT-15 TOT PROT-4 
PROT/CREA-0.3*
___ 04:58PM URINE  COLOR-Straw APPEAR-Clear SP ___
___ 04:58PM URINE  BLOOD-MOD* NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG 
GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-6.0 
LEUK-NEG
___ 04:58PM URINE  RBC-1 WBC-1 BACTERIA-FEW* YEAST-NONE 
EPI-<1 TRANS EPI-1
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Her postpartum course was complicated by a readmission for 
pre-eclampsia severe by headaches and BPs. She received 24 hours 
of magnesium postpartum. PIH labs were ordered and showed 
elevated ALT to 46 and Uric Acid of 6.4. Labs were otherwise 
normal. Neurology was consulted for her headache. They felt 
there was low suspicion for an acute intracranial process but 
recommended a MRA/MRV. Her MRA/MRV was unremarkable. She 
received two doses of IV Hydralazine for severe range BPs and 
required no further anti-hypertensives agents. Her pain was 
treated with oral pain medications. She ambulated and her foley 
was discontinued and she voided spontaneously. Her diet was 
advanced without incident. 

By postpartum day #10, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

 
Medications on Admission:
PNV, Insulin Humalog (4 units at breakfast, 3 units at
lunch, 3 units at dinner)
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
headache

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
pelvic rest until 6 week postpartum visit
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                       Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Multiple right-sided thyroid nodules with an indeterminate 
right-sided thyroid nodule.

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
right thyroid lobectomy and isthmusectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a pleasant ___ female who presented to 
the Endocrine Surgery Service for the evaluation of a 
right-sided thyroid nodule. 
As the nodule was causing symptoms as well as the fact that she 
had an indeterminate biopsy,  she was consented to a right 
thyroid lobectomy and isthmusectomy and brought to the operating 
room for the above-stated procedure.

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: 
gestational diabetes
Benign ovarian cyst

PSH: 
C- section x2
laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
FH:Possible thyroid problem in her mother but she is unsure of 
the details. Father had throat cancer. Paternal uncle had 
stomach cancer.  Paternal grandmother had a cerebral blood clot.

 
Physical Exam:
General- NAD, AOx3. Clear phonation, similar projection to 
pre-op speech. 
HEENT- neck incision c/d/i with steri-strips and dermabond, neck
is soft/flat with no evidence of hematoma. 
CV- RRR
Pulmonary- breathing unlabored on RA, no stridor or accessory
muscle use
Abdomen- SNTND
Extremities- wwp

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ F with history of multiple right sided thyroid nodules, 
exhibit atypia of indeterminate significance on FNA now s/p 
right thyroid lobectomy and isthmusectomy. She tolerated the 
procedure well without complication. Please refer to operative 
report for full details of surgery; dictated separately. She was 
brought to the PACU for close monitoring before being 
transferred to the floor for continued observation. 
Postoperatively, she reported sore throat and incisonal neck 
pain which improved with pain meds. She also had nausea and 
emesis which and improved with antiemetics prn. She tolerated 
clear liquids and diet was advanced to regular by POD #1. At no 
point did she experience symptoms of hypocalcemia, such as 
___ numbness or tingling. Similarly, she did not 
experience any difficulty breathing or sensation of swelling in 
the neck. 
At time of discharge, her pain was well controlled, she was 
tolerating a diet, voiding independently, and ambulating without 
concern.  She was discharged home with follow-up instructions 
and verbalized good understanding.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Ibuprofen 400 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild/Fever  
2.  Ondansetron 4 mg PO Q6H:PRN Nausea/Vomiting - First Line 
Duration: 3 Days 
RX *ondansetron 4 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) hours 
Disp #*10 Tablet Refills:*0 
3.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*15 Tablet Refills:*0 
4.  Ibuprofen 400 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right thyroid lobectomy, isthmusectomy

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Ms. ___,
You were admitted to ___ overnight for observation following 
your surgery. You did well postoperatively and were discharged 
home once you were eating, on oral medications, walking, and 
completing daily activities as normal. 
Medications: For pain medication you may take acetaminophen 
(Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Motrin). Additionally you were also 
prescribed a limited amount of narcotic pain medication that you 
may take over the next 3 days as needed. You may restart all 
your usual home medications.
Symptoms of low calcium: If you develop tingling or numbness 
around your mouth, fingertips or toes this may be a sign of a 
low calcium and you should call our office. 
Wound care: You may shower normally. Allow warm soapy water to 
run over the wound, rinse and pat dry gently. There is no need 
to keep a dressing over the wound. Do not apply creams or 
ointments. Do not submerge the wound in a swimming pool or bath 
until cleared at your follow up visit. Do  not pull off the 
steri strip tapes--these will fall off by themselves over the 
next ___ weeks.

Diet:You may resume your regular home diet without restriction. 
You should use stick to foods that do not upset your stomach. 
You may need to start with small meals first and may not feel 
very hungry at first. This will improve over time. You may 
supplement your diet with protein shakes as needed if you do not 
feel you are taking in enough nutrition.

Activity:You may resume all of your normal home activities, 
except for straining or lifting heavy weight. We recommend you 
resume walking, exercise, bathing, per your normal regimen. 

Warning signs:
You should contact our clinic or return to the ED immediately if 
you experience any of the following signs or symptoms:
Fever above 101.5
Worsening pain
Worsening GI upset, nausea/vomiting, diarrhea
Change in the appearance of your incision, or redness, swelling, 
or change in drainage from your incision
Any other symptoms that concern you

You can contact our clinic at any time with questions or 
concerns. You should be seen in our clinic for follow up 
following your discharge from the hospital. 

Best wishes,
Your ___ Care Team

 
Followup Instructions:
___

You may need to start with small meals first and may not feel
very hungry at first. This will improve over time. You may
supplement your diet with protein shakes as needed if you do not
feel you are taking in enough nutrition.
Activity:You may resume all of your normal home activities,
except for straining or lifting heavy weight. We recommend you
resume walking, exercise, bathing, per your normal regimen.
Warning signs:
You should contact our clinic or return to the ED immediately if
you experience any of the following signs or symptoms:
Fever above 101.5
Worsening pain
Worsening GI upset, nausea/vomiting, diarrhea
Change in the appearance of your incision, or redness, swelling,
or change in drainage from your incision
Any other symptoms that concern you
You can contact our clinic at any time with questions or
concerns. You should be seen in our clinic for follow up
following your discharge from the hospital.
Best wishes,
Your ___ Care Team
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to the service of Dr. ___ for a 
lumbar laminectomy.  He was informed and consented and elected 
to proceed.  Please see Operative Note for procedure in detail.  

Post-operatively he was given antibiotics and pain medication.  
A hemovac drain was placed intra-operatively and this was 
removed POD 1.  His bladder catheter was removed POD 1 and his 
diet was advanced without difficulty.  He was able to work with 
physical therapy for strength and balance.  He was discharged in 
good condition and will follow up in the Orthopaedic Spine

synthroid

2. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
3. hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*100 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. simvastatin 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
5. levothyroxine 100 mcg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Lumbar disc herniation and stenosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Good

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have undergone the following operation: Lumbar 
laminectomy/discectomy 

 
Immediately after the operation:
 

 
-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than ~45 minutes without getting up and walking around.
 

 
-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
 
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery. You can walk as much as you can tolerate. 

 
oLimit any kind of lifting.
 

 
-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some constipation 
after surgery. You have been given medication to help with this 
issue.
 

 
-Brace: You have been given a brace. This brace is to be worn 
for comfort when you are walking. You may take it off when 
sitting in a chair or while lying in bed.
 

 
-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days. If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing. If it is dry then 
you can leave the incision open to the air. Once the incision is 
completely dry (usually ___ days after the operation) you may 
take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool. If 
the incision starts draining at anytime after surgery, do not 
get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile dressing. Call the 
office. 
 

 
-You should resume taking your normal home medications. No 
NSAIDs.
 

 
-You have also been given Additional Medications to control your 
pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead. You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___ 2. We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. 
In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.
 

 
Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.
 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:

from orthopaedic surgery clinic with a left talonavicular 
dislocation.  He was consented and prepped for surgery.  On 
___ he was taken to the operating room and underwent a left 
navicular ORIF and a right fibular ORIF.  He tolerated the 
procedure well, was extubated, transferred to the recovery room, 
and then to the floor.  On the floor he was seen by physical 
therapy to improve his function.  The rest of his hospital stay 
was uneventful with his lab data and vital signs within normal

- Resume your home medications. Take all medications as

pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so plan ahead.  You can either have them mailed 
to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on ___ 2. 
 We are not allowed to call in narcotic (oxycontin, oxycodone, 
percocet) prescriptions to the pharmacy.   In addition, we are 
only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days from the 
date of surgery.

 

- Narcotic pain medication may cause drowsiness.  Do not drink 
alcohol while taking narcotic medications.  Do not operate any 
motor vehicle or machinery while taking narcotic pain 
medications.  Taking more than recommended may cause serious 
breathing problems.

danger signs then please call your doctor at ___ or go 
to your local emergency room.

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Papillary thyroid carcinoma
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
completion right thyroidectomy 

 
Past Medical History:
Left thyroidectomy ___

 
Physical Exam:
VS:97.4,62,106/62, 20, 100% room air
General: well appearing, NAD, clear phonation, no stridor
HEENT:no hematoma, incision C/D/I, no erythema, no hematoma
Cardiac:regular rate rhythm,S1 S2 normal,nomurmur,gallop,rubs 
Pulmonary:clear,no stridor
Abdomen:soft,nontender, nondistended, normoactive bowel sounds
Extremities: WWP, no CCE

 
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:05AM BLOOD Calcium-7.9*
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is status post completion right thyroidectomy for 
papillary thyroid carcinoma. The patient tolerated the procedure 
well and was transferred to the recovery room in good condition 
and admitted to the inpatient general surgery unit overnight. 
Neurological: The patient received oral pain medications with 
good effect and had adequate pain control.
HEENT: The neck was monitored for signs of hematoma of which 
there were none. The patient had no voice hoarseness, no 
dyspnea,no stridor and demonstrated excellent phonation. 
Gastrointestinal: The diet was advanced from clears to regular 
which was tolerated well.
Genitourinary:Postoperatively had urinary retention and was 
bladder scanned for 600 cc. She was strait catheterized once and 
she voided had without any further difficulty. 
Endocrine: On postoperative day 1 she was mildly hypocalcemic 
however was asymptomatic and had no perioral or lower extremity 
paresthesia. She received oral calcium supplementation 
accordingly and was discharged home on thyroid replacement 
medication and calcium supplementation.
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.The patient received discharge teaching 
and follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

 
Medications on Admission:
pantoprazole 40 mg daily 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. liothyronine 25 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
2. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours).  
4. calcitriol 0.25 mcg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO DAILY 
(Daily) for 10 days.
Disp:*10 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
5. calcium carbonate 200 mg calcium (500 mg) Tablet, Chewable 
Sig: Two (2) Tablet, Chewable PO TID (3 times a day).
Disp:*180 Tablet, Chewable(s)* Refills:*2*
6. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
papillary thyroid carcinoma.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have adequate pain control and have tolerated a regular diet 
and may return home to continue your recovery. You will be 
discharged home on thyroid medication,take Cytomel 25 mcg once a 
day.Your Calcium level was slighty low after your thyroid 
surgery and you were started on calcium supplement. Please take 
Tums(Calcium Carbonate)1000 mg three times a day and take 
Calcitriol 0.25 mcg once a day for 10 days. We would like for 
you to follow-up with your endocrinologist to have your Calcium 
level checked. Please monitor for signs and symptoms of low 
Calcium such as numbness or tingling around mouth or fingetips. 
If you experience any of these signs or symptoms you may take an 
extra dose of Tums, however if symptoms continue please call the 
office for advice or go to emergency room.
Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication and take any new 
medications as prescribed. You will be given a prescription for 
narcotic pain medication, take as prescribed.It is recommended 
that you take a stool softner such as Colace while taking oral 
narcotic pain medication to prevent constipation. You may also 
take acetaminophen(Tylenol) as directed, but do not exceed 4000 
mg in one day. Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk 
several times per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. 
Incision Care:
Please call your surgeon or go to the emergency department if 
you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the 
incision site.You may shower and wash incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water.Avoid swimming and baths until cleared by your 
surgeon.Gently pat the area dry.You have a neck incision with 
steri-strips in place, do not remove, they will fall off on 
their own. 
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope 
is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual 
activities. Good luck!

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Mrs ___ had stable blood pressures on arrival to triage. 
She had no preeclampsia symptoms and labs were overall stable, 
with the exception of the elevated urine protein/creatinine 
ratio (0.6). Fetal testing was reassuring and the NICU was 
consulted. She was admitted for bedrest, close blood pressure 
monitoring, and a repeat 24 hour urine. Her hypertension was 
well controlled on Nifedipine and Labetolol, however, on 
hospital day #2, Twin A had a non-reactive NST and the decision 
was made to proceed with delivery. Repeat cesarean section was 
performed on ___ at 34+0 weeks gestation. Please see operative 
report for details. She was not treated with magnesium.
.
Postoperatively, her hypertension was managed with labetolol 
200mg bid. She had no further complications and was discharged 
home on POD#4. She will have close outpatient followup.

PNV
Labetalol 200 mg TID
Nifedipine 30CR BID

day).

Home

Stable

Given
See below

Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
___ Complaint:
- elevated BP
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
- none
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo ___ s/p C/S (twins) on ___, p/w elevated BP. Has cHTN
and had been taking labetalol 100mg BID since discharge. On the 
night prior to admission checked her BP at home and found it to 
be elevated to 150/90; the afternoon of admission was feeling 
poorly and checked it again - 210/110. C/o eye "heaviness" but 
o/w no other sx. Denied numbness, weakness, LOC. No CP/SOB/N/V. 
Per her report, urination had been normal. She took an extra 
100mg of labetalol and 30mg of nifedipine CR (left over from 
antepartum regimen) and presented to Gyn Triage for evaluation. 
 
 
Past Medical History:
- MCTD (mixed connective tissue d/o) 
- cHTN 

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
- non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals - BP: 170/100 L, 160/95 R  HR: 64  RR: 18
Gen: NAD, anxious
Neuro: A&O, PERRLA, CN II-XII grossly intact, sensation to light
touch intact, motor strength ___ all extremities
Resp: lungs CTAB
CV: RRR, soft ___ systolic murmur
Back: no CVAT
Ext: no edema, no calf TTP

 
Pertinent Results:
- none
 
Brief Hospital Course:
1. Elevated BP
In triage BP was 160-170/90-100. There were no s/sx of 
hypertensive emergency (no neurological changes, CP/SOB). Was 
given nifedipine 10mg po x 1 with some response. She was 
admitted for o/n observation and started on a new regimen of 
labetalol 100mg po BID and nifedipine CR 30mg BID. After being 
given short-acting nifedipine she developed a h/a, which 
resolved over the course of the night. She did not develop any 
other sx of PEC and did not have any stroke range BP, with BP 
ranging 140-150s/80-90s o/n (with one or two elevations to SBP 
160-170 before her AM meds were given). BP was stable and below 
stroke range on discharge. She was discharged in good condition 
with rx for labetalol 100mg po BID and nifedipine CR 30mg po 
BID.
 
Medications on Admission:
- labetalol 100mg po BID
 
Discharge Medications:
- Nifedipine 30 mg Tablet Sustained Release Sig: One (1) Tablet 
Sustained Release PO BID (2 times a day)
Disp:60 Tablet Sustained Release(s) Refills:2
.
- Labetalol 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day)
Disp:60 Tablet(s) Refills:2

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
- chronic hypertension

 
Discharge Condition:
- stable 

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please take all medication as instructed.  Please follow up with 
Dr. ___ week. Please call or return to the hospital if 
you have BP >160/90, headache that will not go away, new chest 
pain, new shortness of breath, or increased pain.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Giant liver cyst.

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___:  Laparoscopic fenestration of liver cyst

 
History of Present Illness:
___ woman who saw Dr ___ in clinic for increasing 
fullness, bloating and discomfort in the abdomen since ___ of 
this year.  She has also developed acid reflux symptoms at this 
time.  She has had ultrasounds, CTs and MRs ___ her abdomen that 
were reviewed in clinic and show a large, slightly
over 20 cm cyst in the left lobe of the liver, creating mass 
effect on the stomach and other abdominal viscera.  Distally, it 
extends to below her umbilicus.  She also has some cavernous 
hemangiomas in the liver.
She is taken to the OR with Dr ___ for laparoscopic 
fenestration of the cyst.

 
Past Medical History:
Cavernous Hemangiomas
.
No Past surgical history
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
No Family history of liver disease
 
Physical Exam:
VS: 98.6, 54, 120/69, 18, 100% RA
General: Resting comfortably, pain ___
Card: RRR, no M/R/G
Lungs: CTA bilaterally, no acute distress
Abd: Appropriately tender, non-distended, soft, JP drain with 
sero-sanguinous drainage. Dressings in place, sero-sanguinous 
staining
Extremities: 2+ bilateral pulses, warm/well perfused

 
Pertinent Results:
POD 1: ___
WBC-7.1 RBC-4.43 Hgb-12.7 Hct-38.9 MCV-88 MCH-28.6 MCHC-32.5 
RDW-18.2* Plt ___
Glucose-93 UreaN-9 Creat-0.6 Na-138 K-4.2 Cl-103 HCO3-27 
AnGap-12
ALT-45* AST-43* AlkPhos-110* TotBili-0.9
Calcium-9.6 Phos-2.4* Mg-1.___ y/o female taken to the OR with symptomatic, large liver 
cyst.
At the time of surgery, 2.5 L of clear serous fluid was drained 
from the cyst, which
decompressed the cyst. The redundant portion of cyst wall was 
removed and submitted to pathology. The inside of the cyst wall 
was cauterized with an argon beam. And a strand of omentum was 
brought up into the cyst area. A JP drain was placed.
She tolerated the procedure without complication. She was 
extubated and transferred to PACU in stable condition. 

Overnight the patient did quite well. She was tolerating a 
regular diet, and pain was managed with Tylenol.  The dressings 
were heavily stained with serosanguinous drainage, but there was 
no leakage.
The JP drain was sero-sanguinous in nature, and was removed on 
post op day 1. She was looking well, ambulatory, and so it was 
determined it was safe for discharge to home.
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H 
Maximum 8 of the 325 mg tablets daily 
2. OxycoDONE Liquid 5 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
No driving if using this medication 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg/5 mL 5 mg by mouth q 4 hours Disp #*100 
Milliliter Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left lobe giant liver cyst

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call Dr. ___ office at ___ for fever > 101, 
chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, increased 
abdominal pain, pain not controlled by your pain medication, 
swelling of the abdomen or ankles, yellowing of the skin or 
eyes, inability to tolerate food, fluids or medications, or any 
other concerning symptoms.

You may shower. Allow water to run over the drain site. Do not 
apply lotions or powders to the drain insertion area. 
The dressings may be removed on ___, and the incision 
sites left open to the air.

No lifting more than 10 pounds
No Driving if taking narcotic pain medication

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___ Ms. ___ was admitted to the GYN service for blood 
transfusion given vaginal bleeding in the context of known 
fibroid uterus and menorrhagia.  She reported dizziness, AND her 
hematocrit was found to be 25.7.

She received 2 units of packed red blood cells, was found to be 
hemodynamically stable.  her hematocrit was trended and resulted 
as 24.4 post-transfusion.  She remained inpatient, and received 
an additional 2 units of packed red blood cells.  Her 
post-transfusion hematocrit resulted 31.6.  She was started on a 
course of medroxyprogesterone.  On ___ she was ambulating 
without dizziness, denied shortness of breath or 
lightheadedness, and was discharged home in stable condition 
with a course of medroxyprogesterone.  At the time of discharge 
she was recommended to follow-up with the minimally invasive 
surgical group for discussion of surgical management of her 
menorrhagia.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Larissia (levonorgestrel-ethinyl estrad) 0.1-20 mg-mcg oral 
DAILY 
2. Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg PO DAILY

1.  MedroxyPROGESTERone Acetate 20 mg PO DAILY 
RX *medroxyprogesterone [Provera] 10 mg 2 tablet(s) by mouth 
daily Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*1 
2.  Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg PO DAILY  
3.  Larissia (levonorgestrel-ethinyl estrad) 0.1-20 mg-mcg oral 
DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
vaginal bleeding, anemia

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecology service for vaginal bleeding 
and anemia. You were given a blood transfusion. You were started 
on Provera medication to help decrease your vaginal bleeding. 
You have recovered well and the team believes you are ready to 
be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ office with any 
questions or concerns. Please follow the instructions below.

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

 
Followup Instructions:
___

MCV-90 MCH-29.6 MCHC-32.9 RDW-14.5 RDWSD-46.7* Plt ___
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___ Ms. ___ was admitted to the GYN service for blood
transfusion given vaginal bleeding in the context of known
fibroid uterus and menorrhagia. She reported dizziness, AND her
hematocrit was found to be 25.7.
She received 2 units of packed red blood cells, was found to be
hemodynamically stable. her hematocrit was trended and resulted
as 24.4 post-transfusion. She remained inpatient, and received
an additional 2 units of packed red blood cells. Her
post-transfusion hematocrit resulted 31.6. She was started on a
course of medroxyprogesterone. On ___ she was ambulating
without dizziness, denied shortness of breath or
lightheadedness, and was discharged home in stable condition
with a course of medroxyprogesterone. At the time of discharge
she was recommended to follow-up with the minimally invasive
surgical group for discussion of surgical management of her
menorrhagia.
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Larissia (levonorgestrel-ethinyl estrad) 0.1-20 mg-mcg oral
DAILY
2. Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg PO DAILY
Discharge Medications:
1. MedroxyPROGESTERone Acetate 20 mg PO DAILY
RX *medroxyprogesterone [Provera] 10 mg 2 tablet(s) by mouth
daily Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*1
2. Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg PO DAILY
3. Larissia (levonorgestrel-ethinyl estrad) 0.1-20 mg-mcg oral
DAILY
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
vaginal bleeding, anemia
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You were admitted to the gynecology service for vaginal bleeding
and anemia. You were given a blood transfusion. You were started
on Provera medication to help decrease your vaginal bleeding.
You have recovered well and the team believes you are ready to
be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ office with any
questions or concerns. Please follow the instructions below.
General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.
Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food
or your medication
Followup Instructions:
___

Extr: No edema

Pertinent Results:
POD 1 Labs: ___
WBC-9.8# RBC-3.89* Hgb-11.3 Hct-35.1 MCV-90 MCH-29.0 MCHC-32.2 
RDW-13.9 RDWSD-45.1 Plt ___
Glucose-96 UreaN-8 Creat-0.6 Na-137 K-3.8 Cl-101 HCO3-26 
AnGap-14
ALT-23 AST-35 AlkPhos-51 TotBili-0.8
Calcium-9.1 Phos-3.4 Mg-1.___ y/o with history of previous fenestration of hepatic cyst who 
returns now for another cyst unroofing due to symptomatic 
recurrence.
Patient is taken to the OR with Dr. ___. At the time 
of the surgery,  the  cyst was punctured anteriorly and 2 L of 
clear serous fluid was drained out of it. Cyst wall and portion 
of liver were submitted for pathology. JP drain was placed in 
surgical resection bed, she was extubated and transferred to 
PACU in stable condition.

Post op the patient was started on clears and advanced to 
regular diet which was well tolerated. Pain was managed with 
oral oxycodone and Tylenol. She was ambulating without 
difficulty and voiding.
The JP drain was sero-sanguinous in nature with less than 50 cc 
drained overnight.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain/fever 
___ purchase over the counter 
2. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
No driving if taking narcotic pain medication 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth q 4 hours Disp #*40 
Tablet Refills:*0
3. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
___ purchase over the counter 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Recurrrent Hepatic Cyst

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call Dr. ___ office at ___ for fever > 101, 
chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, increased 
abdominal pain, pain not controlled by your pain medication, 
swelling of the abdomen or ankles, yellowing of the skin or 
eyes, inability to tolerate food, fluids or medications, the 
incision sites have redness, drainage or bleeding, or any other 
concerning symptoms.

You may shower. Allow water to run over the incision sites. Do 
not apply lotions or powders to the incision areas. Leave 
incisions open to the air.

No lifting more than 10 pounds
No driving if taking narcotic pain medication

Drain and record the JP drain output twice daily and as needed 
so that the drain is never more than ½ full. 

Call the office if the drain output increases by more than 100 
cc from the previous day, turns greenish in color, becomes 
bloody or develops a foul odor.

Change the drain dressing once daily or after your shower. Do 
not allow the drain to hang freely at any time. Inspect the site 
for redness, drainage or bleeding. Make sure there is a stitch 
at the drain site.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Percocet / Milk / Tape
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Chronic pelvic pain, endometriosis
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Exploratory laparotomy, lysis of adhesions, total abdominal 
hysterectomy, right salpingo-oophorectomy 

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ sent with a right ovarian cyst 
and a history of endometriosis.  The patient has a long history 
of endometriosis dating back to ___.  She has undergone 
multiple surgeries for this condition.  She had a laparoscopic 
leftovarian cystectomy in ___ for a left ovarian endometrioma.  
In
___, she underwent a laparotomy with left 
salpingo-oophorectomy.  She was told that there were severe 
adhesions and that a portion of the left ovary may have been 
left behind.  In ___, she underwent laparoscopy with lysis of 
adhesions for chronic pelvic pain attributed to endometriosis.  
In ___, she underwent
laparoscopy for a right ovarian endometrioma.  In ___, she 
underwent laparotomy with drainage of a right ovarian 
endometrioma.  At the time of this laparotomy, there were severe 
pelvic adhesions, precluding right salpingo-oophorectomy.

Since ___, the patient has experienced chronic back and
pelvic pain.  She has a history of lumbar disk disease, and it
has therefore been difficult to know how much of her back pain 
is
from this condition versus endometriosis.  However, over the 
past
several months, her pelvic pain has increased, and her back pain
has decreased.  She has been on medical therapy with
norethindrone in an attempt to suppress her endometriosis, but
this has not resulted in satisfactory relief of the pelvic pain. 

In addition, she reports some intermittent mild numbness and
tingling in her right knee and ankle region.  She has had no
definite weakness in her lower extremities.  She denies any
sciatica.  Concurrent with the symptoms, she has had some
constipation, sometimes alternating with diarrhea, and urinary
frequency.  Prior to initiating the norethindrone, she had been
having regular menses, but has been oligomenorrheic.  Her last
menstrual period was ___.

She had a followup pelvic ultrasound at ___ Ultrasound
___ on ___.  This study revealed a normal uterus. 

The endometrium was 6-7 mm.  The left ovary was not identified. 
The right ovary had a complex cyst measuring 3.5 cm in largest
dimension with diffuse low-level echoes consistent with
endometrioma.

 
Past Medical History:
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Significant for lumbar disk disease,
endometriosis, recent onset asthma, hyperprolactinemia 
attributed
to a small but unidentified pituitary adenoma, migraine
headaches.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:  L5-S1 disk surgery for ruptured disk in
___, other surgeries for endometriosis as above.
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Significant for a paternal grandmother with unspecified cancer.

 
Physical Exam:
GENERAL:  Well developed and obese.
HEENT:  Sclerae anicteric.
LYMPHATICS:  Lymph node survey was negative.
LUNGS:  Clear to auscultation.
HEART:  Regular without murmurs.
ABDOMEN:  Soft and nondistended and without palpable masses. 
There was no tenderness.  There was a well-healed transverse
lower abdominal incision.
EXTREMITIES:  Without edema.
PELVIC:  The vulva and vagina were normal.  The cervix was
normal.  Bimanual and rectovaginal examination was limited by
body habitus.  The uterus and adnexa were not palpable.  There
was no cul-de-sac nodularity, and the rectum was intrinsically
normal.  There was no adnexal tenderness on palpation.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman admitted after exploratory 
laparotomy, extensive pelvic
adhesiolysis, total abdominal hysterectomy, right 
salpingo-oophorectomy for chronic pelvic pain and endometriosis. 
Please see operative note for details.

Postoperative course was uncomplicated. Pt was discharged home 
on POD#2 in stable condition.
 
Medications on Admission:
Bromocriptine, norethindrone, albuterol, Imitrex, Tylenol No. 3, 
lidocaine patches.

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
q3h as needed for pain.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
4. Bromocriptine 2.5 mg Tablet Sig: 1.5 Tablets PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
5. Albuterol 90 mcg/Actuation Aerosol Sig: ___ Puffs Inhalation 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Chronic pelvic pain, endometriosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call or return to the hospital if you have increased 
pain, fevers, chills, inability to tolerate food or drink, chest 
pain, shortness of breath, or any other questions or concerns.
.
You may resume your regular diet and home medications upon 
discharge. No driving, heavy lifting, or strenuous activity for 
6 weeks. You may shower, but avoid perfumed soaps and lotions 
near your incision. You will return to the office for staple 
removal.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.

*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.

*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.

*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.

*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.

*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.

*Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.

*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.

*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.

Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

The pa tient is a ___ s/p pedestrian struck by ___ with

You were admitted to the hospital after being struck by an auto 
where you suatined some significant bruising on your scalp 
called a subgaleal hematoma and a contusion to your brain. These 
injuries did not require any operations. Youwere monitored 
closley in the hospital and were seen by the Occupational 
therapists to test your memory due to the loss of consciousness 
reported after you were struck.

You should resume your prescribed medications.

Avoid drinking alcohol and/or taking illicit drugs.

Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right knee pain.
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ - Open reduction internal fixation of right tibial 
plateau fracture.

 
History of Present Illness:
___, intoxicated, ped struck by car. +headtsrike and LOC.
BIBEMS. C/o RLE pain. Ortho consulted for R tib plateau fx.
Non-ortho injuries - SDH with neurosurg c/s

 
Past Medical History:
HTN
Alcohol abuse
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Noncontributory
 
Physical Exam:
EXAM ON DISCHARGE:
VS - AVSS
GEN - NAD
RLE - Knee immobilizer in place, incision c/d/i, no discharge or 
erythema. ___, SILT in S/S/SP/DP/T, DP 1+, WWP.
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 08:18PM BLOOD WBC-3.9* RBC-4.15* Hgb-13.4* Hct-40.8 
MCV-98 MCH-32.3* MCHC-32.8 RDW-14.8 Plt ___
___ 06:00AM BLOOD WBC-7.0 RBC-3.52* Hgb-11.2* Hct-36.0* 
MCV-102* MCH-31.9 MCHC-31.2 RDW-15.0 Plt ___
___ 05:08AM BLOOD WBC-6.5 RBC-3.61* Hgb-11.6* Hct-36.4* 
MCV-101* MCH-32.1* MCHC-31.7 RDW-14.7 Plt ___

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service on 
___ with a right tibial plateau fracture. The patient was 
taken to the operating room and underwent  ORIF of his right 
tibial plateau fracture. Patient tolerated the procedure without 
difficulty and was transferred to the PACU, then the floor in 
stable condition. Please see operative report for full details.

Musculoskeletal:  After procedure, patient's weight-bearing 
status was transitioned to non-weight bearing, then he was 
liberalized to touchdown weight bearing. Throughout the 
hospitalization, patient worked with physical therapy and was 
given detailed instructions regarding post-discharge exercise 
and the appropriate weight-bearing progression.

Neuro: post-operatively, patient's pain was controlled by IV 
pain medications and was subsequently transitioned to oxycodone 
with good effect and adequate pain control. Early in his 
hospitalization (___) he was actively withdrawing from 
alcohol with hallucinations, agitation, and hemodynamic changes. 
 The medicine team was consulted, and he was given ativan, 
haldol, and hydralazine per their recommendations, with good 
effect.

CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.  He was initially 
hypertensive in the setting of alcohol withdrawal, but good 
blood pressure control was maintained when he was restarted on 
his home medications per medical consult recommendation.

Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.

GI/GU:  A po diet was tolerated well. Patient was also started 
on a bowel regimen to encourage bowel movement. Intake and 
output were closely monitored.

ID: The patient received perioperative antibiotics.  The 
patient's temperature was closely watched for signs of 
infection.  He had no signs of active infection throughout the 
hospital stay.

Prophylaxis:  The patient received enoxaparin during this stay, 
and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible.

Heme:  The patient had an elevated platelet count approximately 
12 days into his hospitalization, so the hematology oncology 
service was consulted. Further laboratory evaluation did not 
reveal a cause for his elevated platelets, but they were 
starting to trend down prior to discharge and the patient is 
scheduled to follow up with hematology/oncology as an 
outpatient.

At the time of discharge on ___ POD #16, the patient was 
doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a 
regular diet, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The incision was clean, dry, and intact without 
evidence of erythema or drainage; the extremity was NVI distally 
throughout.  The patient was given written instructions 
concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate 
follow-up care.  The patient will be continued on chemical DVT 
prophylaxis for 6 weeks post-discharge (aspirin).  All questions 
were answered prior to discharge and the patient expressed 
readiness for discharge.  He was given a plan for ___ progression 
(1) Touch down weight bearing right lower extremity until 
___.  Unlocked ___ with full range of motion and 
quadricep strengthening.
2) Advance to partial (50%) weight bearing 8 weeks 
post-operatively (___).  ___ discontinue knee immobilizer at 
that time), and will follow up in 8 weeks.

 
Medications on Admission:
Lisinopril
Verapamil
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Cyanocobalamin 100 mcg PO DAILY 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID hold for loose bm  
3. FoLIC Acid 1 mg PO DAILY 
4. Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY 
5. Milk of Magnesia 30 mL PO Q6H:PRN constipation  
6. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
7. Thiamine 100 mg PO DAILY 
8. Verapamil SR 180 mg PO Q24H 
9. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY 
RX *aspirin 325 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Daily Disp #*42 Tablet 
Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right tibial plateau fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take Aspirin 325mg daily for 6 weeks.

WOUND CARE:
- You can get the wound wet/take a shower starting 3 days after 
your surgery.  No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- No dressing is needed if wound continues to be non-draining.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- You may be touchdown weight bearing on your right lower 
extremity with the unlocked ___ brace on at all times.
- Range of motion as tolerated right knee with unlocked ___ 
brace on.
- Please continue to do the range of motion exercises you were 
shown by the physical therapists.
- Please follow this plan for weight bearing progression: 1) 
Touch down weight bearing right lower extremity until ___.  
Unlocked ___ with full range of motion and quadricep 
strengthening.
2) Advance to partial (50%) weight bearing 8 weeks 
post-operatively (___).  ___ discontinue knee immobilizer at 
that time.
Physical Therapy:
___ PLAN FOR PROGRESSION
1) Touch down weight bearing right lower extremity until 
___.  Unlocked ___ with full range of motion and 
quadricep strengthening.
2) Advance to partial (50%) weight bearing 8 weeks 
post-operatively (___).  ___ discontinue knee immobilizer at 
that time.
Treatments Frequency:
Monitor right knee wound for signs of infection/breakdown.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service on
___ with a right tibial plateau fracture. The patient was
taken to the operating room and underwent ORIF of his right
tibial plateau fracture. Patient tolerated the procedure without
difficulty and was transferred to the PACU, then the floor in
stable condition. Please see operative report for full details.
Musculoskeletal: After procedure, patient's weight-bearing
status was transitioned to non-weight bearing, then he was
liberalized to touchdown weight bearing. Throughout the
hospitalization, patient worked with physical therapy and was
given detailed instructions regarding post-discharge exercise
and the appropriate weight-bearing progression.
Neuro: post-operatively, patient's pain was controlled by IV
pain medications and was subsequently transitioned to oxycodone
with good effect and adequate pain control. Early in his
hospitalization (___) he was actively withdrawing from
alcohol with hallucinations, agitation, and hemodynamic changes. The medicine team was consulted, and he was given ativan,
haldol, and hydralazine per their recommendations, with good
effect.
CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint;
vital signs were routinely monitored. He was initially
hypertensive in the setting of alcohol withdrawal, but good
blood pressure control was maintained when he was restarted on
his home medications per medical consult recommendation.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint;
vital signs were routinely monitored.
GI/GU: A po diet was tolerated well. Patient was also started
on a bowel regimen to encourage bowel movement. Intake and
output were closely monitored.
ID: The patient received perioperative antibiotics. The
patient's temperature was closely watched for signs of
infection. He had no signs of active infection throughout the
hospital stay.
Prophylaxis: The patient received enoxaparin during this stay,
and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible.
Heme: The patient had an elevated platelet count approximately
12 days into his hospitalization, so the hematology oncology
service was consulted. Further laboratory evaluation did not
reveal a cause for his elevated platelets, but they were
starting to trend down prior to discharge and the patient is
scheduled to follow up with hematology/oncology as an
outpatient.
At the time of discharge on ___ POD #16, the patient was
doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a
regular diet, voiding without assistance, and pain was well
controlled. The incision was clean, dry, and intact without
evidence of erythema or drainage; the extremity was NVI distally
throughout. The patient was given written instructions
concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate
follow-up care. The patient will be continued on chemical DVT
prophylaxis for 6 weeks post-discharge (aspirin). All questions
were answered prior to discharge and the patient expressed
readiness for discharge. He was given a plan for ___ progression
(1) Touch down weight bearing right lower extremity until
___. Unlocked ___ with full range of motion and
quadricep strengthening.
2) Advance to partial (50%) weight bearing 8 weeks
post-operatively (___). ___ discontinue knee immobilizer at
that time), and will follow up in 8 weeks.
Medications on Admission:
Lisinopril
Verapamil
Discharge Medications:
1. Cyanocobalamin 100 mcg PO DAILY
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID hold for loose bm
3. FoLIC Acid 1 mg PO DAILY
4. Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY

6. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY
7. Thiamine 100 mg PO DAILY
8. Verapamil SR 180 mg PO Q24H
9. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY

none

physical exam at discharge
==========================
T 98.9  HR 91 lying, 94 sitting and 99 standing
BP 120/69 lying, 116/73 sitting, 111/78 standing
Pad examined and has a 6x4cm spot of dark blood.
No flow from between labia.
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 02:14PM   PLT COUNT-267
___ 02:14PM   WBC-5.5 RBC-1.97* HGB-6.0* HCT-19.8* MCV-101* 
MCH-30.5 MCHC-30.3* RDW-19.5* RDWSD-70.0*

===============

INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with heavy perimenopausal 
bleeding. Recent EMB 
negative.// Size of fibroids? Etiology of heavy bleeding. 
  
TECHNIQUE:  PELVIS, NON-OBSTETRIC 
  
COMPARISON:  Pelvic ultrasound ___ and ___ 
  
FINDINGS:  
  
Both transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound were performed. 
  
An anteverted uterus is present that measures 11.4 x 6.0 x 7.6 
cm.  A fibroid 
is present with a significant sub mucosal component.  This 
arises from the 
anterior uterine wall.  It is been present on the prior scans.  
Within the 
endometrial cavity blood is seen which extends down to the 
internal os.  The 
endometrium is hard to evaluate some echogenic mid areas are 
present which may 
represent blood clot or may represent abnormal endometrium. 
The right ovary is normal.  The left ovary is not identified. 
  
IMPRESSION:  
  
1.  Hematometrium 
2.  Anterior fibroid with significant sub mucosal component. 
3.  Echogenic material superior to fibroid which may represent 
debris or 
abnormal endometrium. 
  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted for observation for vaginal bleeding due 
to fibroids. She underwent a pelvic ultrasound which showed 
fibroids and hematometra.  She was found to be anemic and was 
given 2 units of blood and an injection of Lupron. She was 
observed for several hours and her vaginal bleeding stabilized.  
She was discharged home in stable condition with outpatient 
follow up scheduled. 
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
fibroid uterus, bleeding

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted the Gynecology service due to management of 
vaginal bleeding from your fibroids. You were found to be anemic 
and were given 2 units of blood and an injection of a medication 
called Lupron to manage the bleeding. Your bleeding was stable 
and minimal as well while you were here. The team feels you are 
stable for discharge as you would like to go home. 

Please follow the instructions below:
Call if
- heavy vaginal bleeding soaking >1 pad an hour for two hours
- lightheadedness, dizziness, heart racing
- nausea, vomiting
- fever >100.4, chills, chest pain, difficulty breathing 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___ Ms. ___ was admitted to the hospital after 
undergoing TOTAL LAPAROSCOPIC HYSTERECTOMY; BILATERAL 
SALPINGECTOMIES, lysis of adhesions. Please see operative report 
for complete details.

Patient was extubated slowly given the CO2 issues intra-op and 
patient's response to CO2 insufflation observed during surgery.  
Post-operatively, the decision was made to admit the patient 
overnight for observation-- she had difficulty opening her right 
eye due to a corneal abrasion and the patient had emphysema 
related to the CO2 gas. She was monitored on telemetry without 
any issues. Her pain was controlled with PO 
oxycodone/ibuprofen/acetaminophen. Her diet was advanced to 
regular. She was given erythromycin ointment by the anesthesia 
team.  We also presecribed artificial tears given the patient's 
right eye discomfort.  

She remained stable overnight without desaturation on telemetry. 
A CBC and chemistry were checked the morning of POD1, and found 
to be within normal limits. She was ambulating without 
difficulty, tolerating a regular diet, voiding urine without 
difficulty. She was discharged home in stable condition with 
outpatient follow up scheduled. 
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild 
  Reason for PRN duplicate override: Alternating agents for 
similar severity
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 6 hours as 
needed Disp #*50 Tablet Refills:*1 
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID:PRN Constipation - First Line 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice per day 
Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*1 
3.  Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain 
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 6 hours as 
needed Disp #*50 Tablet Refills:*1 
4.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
  Reason for PRN duplicate override: Alternating agents for 
similar severity
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ or 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 4 hours as 
needed Disp #*15 Tablet Refills:*0 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
ABNORMAL UTERINE BLEEDING, fibroids

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___:

You were admitted to the gynecology service after your 
procedure. You have recovered well and the team believes you are 
ready to be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ office 
with any questions or concerns. Please follow the instructions 
below.

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for  6 
weeks 
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No tub baths for 6 weeks.
* Since you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off 
on their own or be removed during your followup visit.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

Constipation:
* Drink ___ liters of water every day.
* Incorporate 20 to 35 grams of fiber into your daily diet to 
maintain normal bowel function. Examples of high fiber foods 
include:
Whole grain breads, Bran cereal, Prune juice, Fresh fruits and 
vegetables, Dried fruits such as dried apricots and prunes, 
Legumes, Nuts/seeds. 
* Take Colace stool softener ___ times daily.
* Use Dulcolax suppository daily as needed.
* Take Miralax laxative powder daily as needed. 
* Stop constipation medications if you are having loose stools 
or diarrhea.
To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ s/p rescue cerclage on ___ 
admitted to the ___ service postoperatively with urinary 
retention and abdominal pain. In the PACU, she failed to void 
within the appropriate window and was straight catheterized for 
1L. She endorsed significant abdominal pain in the setting of 
urinary retention. Following decompression of her bladder, her 
pain improved. She remained stable overnight and was continued 
on a course of indomethacin. She was also treated with 
metronidazole for bacterial vaginosis. She voided spontaneously 
overnight without issue. On hospital day 1, she noted some 
increased pain in the morning, improved with oxycodone. Her pain 
had improved by the afternoon, she was voiding independently, 
tolerating a regular diet and was appropriate for discharge home 
with outpatient follow up.

Levothyroxine 75mcg QD

shortened cervix

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ s/p rescue cerclage on ___
admitted to the ___ service postoperatively with urinary
retention and abdominal pain. In the PACU, she failed to void
within the appropriate window and was straight catheterized for
1L. She endorsed significant abdominal pain in the setting of
urinary retention. Following decompression of her bladder, her
pain improved. She remained stable overnight and was continued
on a course of indomethacin. She was also treated with
metronidazole for bacterial vaginosis. She voided spontaneously
overnight without issue. On hospital day 1, she noted some
increased pain in the morning, improved with oxycodone. Her pain
had improved by the afternoon, she was voiding independently,
tolerating a regular diet and was appropriate for discharge home
with outpatient follow up.

Levothyroxine 75mcg QD

Home

shortened cervix

stable

after a rescue cerclage was placed for cervical shortening. You
were stable without any evidence of preterm labor. Please

R/O GROUP B BETA STREP (Final ___: 
  POSITIVE FOR GROUP B BETA STREP
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ G6___ admitted at 32+1 weeks gestation with preterm 
contractions.
.
Ms ___ was contracting every ___ minutes on arrival to labor 
and delivery. Her cervix was FT/50/high. She was afebrile and 
without any evidence of infection or abruption. She po hydrated 
and received one dose of sc terbutaline, however, continued to 
contract frequently. In addition, her fetal fibronectin was 
positive. She was then started on magnesium tocolysis and given 
a course of betamethasone for fetal lung maturity. Her 
contractions spaced out and her cervix made no further cervical 
change. Fetal testing was reassuring and the NICU was consulted. 
Once betamethasone complete (___), the magnesium was 
discontinued and she was closely monitored. She had no 
contractions off tocolysis. She was discharged home at 32+4 
weeks gestation and she will have close outpatient followup. Of 
note, there were mild variables noted during her NST prior to 
discharge. Ultrasound was reassuring with a normal AFI (13). A 
GBS swab collected during this admission was positive.
 
Medications on Admission:
Levoxyl 112mcg daily
prenatal vitamin
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) as needed for Constipation.  
2. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for Pain.  
3. B Complex-Vitamin C-Folic Acid 1 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Cap 
PO DAILY 
4. Levothyroxine 112 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
preterm contractions
breech presentation
 
Discharge Condition:
good.
 
Discharge Instructions:
per instruction sheets
call with any decreased fetal movement
 
Followup Instructions:
___
