text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Erectile Dysfunction
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Implantation of Penile Prosthesis

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yom with a hx of ED following RRP in ___.  First prosthesis 
lasted ___ years and current ___ years - both were mechanical 
failures. 

PMH: gout, htn, rrp
Meds: colchicine, lipitor, lisinopril
nkda
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to Dr. ___ Urology service 
for insertion of penile prosthesis. No concerning intraoperative 
events occurred; please see dictated operative note for details. 
He patient received vancomycin and gentamycin post-operatively 
for antibiotic prophylaxis. Post-op course also uncomplicated. 
The patient voided without difficulty. At discharge, patient's 
pain well controlled with oral pain medications, tolerating 
regular diet, ambulating without assistance, and voiding without 
difficulty. Incision at discharge without erythema or hematoma. 
Specific instructions about prosthesis care given, and also 
included in this discharge summary.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*35 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) for 15 days.
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Atorvastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
4. Colchicine 0.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
5. Levofloxacin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day 
for 7 days.
Disp:*7 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Erectile Dysfunction

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Take off dressing over penis on post-operative day two, no 
further wound care is needed

-Do not use prosthesis for 6 weeks

-Complete a 7 day course of levofloxicin (antibiotic)

-You may shower, but do not bathe, swim or otherwise immerse 
your incision. 

-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book.  

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotic pain 
medication.  

-Resume all of your home medications.  

-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
go to the nearest emergency room.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o G3P0 with IUI triplets admitted at 30+1wks gestation due 
to Triplet C with IUGR, oligohydramnios, and absent EDF.
.
Ms ___ was admitted for close fetal surveillance and 
betamethasone for fetal lung maturity. She was seen by 
Neonatology during her admission. On her second hospital day, 
she underwent fetal testing in the antepartum testing unit and 
was found to have intermittend reversed end diastolic flow in 
triplet C. As a result, the patient was recommended for Cesarean 
delivery. She had received two doses of betamethasone but was 
not yet 24 hours since her second dose. Please see operative 
note for full details of the delivery. 
.
Postpartum, she recovered well and was discharged home on 
post-op day #___ontrolled, tolerating a regular 
diet and ambulating and voiding without difficulty.
.

prenatal vitamins
singulair
pulmicort
levothyroxine

text:
Name:  ___          Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Cephalexin / E-Mycin / Doxycycline / Zithromax / Ginger
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
recurrent mastitis
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo ___ s/p c-s on ___ for triplets.  Post partum 
course sig for wound seroma managed w/packing wet to dry.
 
She was evaluated and treated for mastitis on ___ with 
Dicloxacillin 500qid x 7d.  At the time, she reported R breast 
redness, pain and fever.  She was pumping at the time and 
continued to do so.

Her condition improved with antibiotics and after her course, 
she was symptom free for about ten days.  Three days ago; 
however, she again developed R breast redness, pain and fever to 
103.0 intermittently.  In addition, the breast redness was noted 
on the L breast as well, also associated with pain.

She was restarted on Dicloxacillin.  She continued to spike 
temps after resuming abx as high as 101.  She continues to pump, 
but has noted lower volumes from her right breast, despite 
massage. She denies productive cough, diarrhea, dysuria.

The infants are presently in the NICU doing well.  As part of 
their w/u, they have been screened for viral and bacterial 
infection and these studies have been negative.

 
Past Medical History:
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY 
asthma 
hypothyroid 
 
PAST SURGICAL HISTORY 
___ molars

___
Family History:
non-contributory

avss, afebrile
Breast: right breast non-erythematous, non-edematous, non-tender
        left breast: small amount of dependent erythema, 
non-tender, non-edematous
Abd: soft, NT, ND
Ext: no calf tenderness
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:31PM BLOOD WBC-14.0* RBC-3.89* Hgb-11.5* Hct-33.7* 
MCV-87 MCH-29.5 MCHC-34.1 RDW-14.6 Plt ___
___ 06:31PM BLOOD Neuts-88.6* Lymphs-6.2* Monos-2.8 Eos-2.2 
Baso-0.2
___ 06:31PM BLOOD Glucose-110* UreaN-12 Creat-0.9 Na-139 
K-3.7 Cl-101 HCO3-28 AnGap-14
___ 06:57PM BLOOD Lactate-0.9
CDiff neg x2
Blood Cx NGTD x4 as of ___
Left breast/milk cx STAPHYLOCOCCUS, COAGULASE NEGATIVE
Right breast/milk cx NGTD

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Briefly this is a ___ s/p cs ___ triplets readmitted for 
bilateral mastitis s/p 7d diclox w resolution, recurrence ___ w 
fever (103) while on ___ course of diclox.  Patient underwent 
bilateral breast ultrasound which was negative for fluid 
collections.  Blood cultures, urine cultures, and breast/milk 
cultures were collected and patient was started on IV 
vancomycin.  Urine cultures grew gram negative rods and patient 
was started on macrobid for her UTI.  Her left breast milk 
culture grew gram positive cocci which was eventually determined 
to be coag negative staph.  Patient was discharged home on HD#6 
on Bactrim in good condition.
.
Patient also complained of several watery daily bowel movement.  
Her stool was tested for c.diff toxin which was negative.  

 
Medications on Admission:
Dicloxacillin 500mg QID
Levoxyl 25mcg qd
Pulmicort 180mcg MDI 2 puff bid
Singulair 10mg qd
Flonase
PNV

hours) as needed for Pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

6 hours) as needed for fever.  
4. Montelukast 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
5. Fluticasone 110 mcg/Actuation Aerosol Sig: Two (2) Puff 
Inhalation BID (2 times a day).  
6. Albuterol Sulfate  Inhalation
7. Levothyroxine 25 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
8. Bactrim DS 160-800 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO twice a 
day for 2 days.
Disp:*8 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
9. Bactrim DS 160-800 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a 
day for 8 days: start after 2 days of bactrim ds ___isp:*16 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

Home

change in histological diagnosis and need for additional
surgery.

Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
right flank pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
ureteroscopy- Dr. ___- ___, followed placement of right 
PCNT placement by Interventional Radiology

 
History of Present Illness:
___ is ___ y/o male with history of obstructing 11-mm mid 
right ureteral stone with severe hydroureteronephrosis. A  right 
ureteroscopy with laser
lithotripsy failed on ___  secondary to blockage by ureteral 
stone and
subsequent inability to pass a wire up the ureter. Patient was
then sent to interventional radiology and a right nephrostomy
tube was placed as an outpatient.
 
Past Medical History:
Kidney stones
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:45AM BLOOD Hct-44.8
___ 10:30AM BLOOD ___ PTT-22.4 ___
___ 06:45AM BLOOD Glucose-109* UreaN-15 Creat-1.2 Na-138 
K-4.0 Cl-103 HCO3-27 AnGap-12
___ 06:45AM BLOOD estGFR-Using this
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to Dr. ___ service for a 
scheduled ureteroscopy and ___ lithotripsy of ___ ureteral 
stone.  Due to the the size of the stone difficulty was 
encountered in the passage of the wire up the ureter. see 
dictated operative note for details Subsequently the patient was 
then sent to interventional radiology and a right nephrostomy 
tube was placed. The patient tolderated the procedure well with 
no complications.  He remained afebrile following the procedure. 
 At discharge, the patient's pain was well controlled with oral 
pain medications, tolerating regular diet, ambulating without 
assistance, and voiding without difficulty. He is given oral 
pain medications on discharge, without antibiotics. He is given 
explicit instructions to call Dr. ___ follow-up to 
arrange for removal as stone as well as PCNT. ___ services were 
arranged to assist the patient with care of his nephrostomy 
tube. 

 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain, fever.  
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___ 
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
nephrolithiasis

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Expect significant drainage (bloody drainage is expected) from 
your back.  
 
-Please change your dressings as often as needed to keep your 
skin as dry as possible.

 -Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4.  
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.  Max daily 
Tylenol dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain medication also 
contains Tylenol (acetaminophen)

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, 
discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops.

-Resume all of your home medications, except hold NSAID 
(aspirin,  and ibuprofen containing products such as advil & 
motrin,) for 1 week.

-Please call if you experience fevers > 101.5
 
-Call Dr. ___ office to schedule a follow-up appointment 
AND if you have any urological questions, ___.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
HPI: Ms. ___ is a ___ G3P1 at 8w6d by LMP presents to the ED
with persistent nausea/vomiting. She had presented to ___ 
urgent
care given poor PO intake over three days and concern for 
minimal
urination over two days. She last voided this morning. 

She reports that she vomits countless times per day. She had Rx
for Compazine PR and Zofran PO. The Compazine PR had not 
improved
her symptoms and she was unable to keep the Zofran PO down. Her
emesis appeared dark ___ over the last two days and she has
passed dark tarry stools over the last two days. She also 
reports
dizziness, heart palpitations, chest pain and diffuse abdominal
pain. She recalls hyperemesis in a prior pregnancy but cannot
remember medications that worked for her in the past. 

She also reports that she had vomited so severely this morning
that she felt some wetness in her underwear and was concerned
that she had a gush of amniotic fluid. Denies any continued
leaking. 

Of note, she was admitted for about 1 week at ___ for 
hyperemesis
around New ___. She reports that her nausea has been
persistent since. 

ROS: Negative except for pertinent positives and negatives
mentioned above.

 
Past Medical History:
OBHx: G3P1
- pLTCS ___ at term
- TAB x 1

GYNHx
- laparoscopy for ruptured ovarian cyst/benign ___ (complicated
by 1L EBL)
- denies hx of abnormal pap
- denies hx of STDs

PMH: hirsutism

PSH: pLTCS, lsc for ruptured ovarian cyst in ___

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
sister PCOS

 
Physical ___:
PHYSICAL EXAM
Vitals: Temp 97.4 HR 69 BP 105/51 SpO2 97%tile on RA
General: NAD, patient appears tired and weak
Cardiorespiratory: normal work of breathing
Abd: soft, nondistended, patient is diffusely mildly tender to
palpation, no peritoneal signs
Pelvis: no moisture on patient's perineum, normal appearing
vaginal mucosa, no evidence of blood, normal appearing and 
closed
cervix, normal physiologic discharge
Extrem: nontender to palpation

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:27PM   WBC-8.5 RBC-3.70* HGB-11.2 HCT-33.4* MCV-90 
MCH-30.3 MCHC-33.5 RDW-13.2 RDWSD-43.6
___ 07:27PM   TSH-0.08*  Free T4 1.0
___ 07:27PM   ALT(SGPT)-19 AST(SGOT)-21 ALK PHOS-41 TOT 
BILI-0.3
___ 07:27PM   GLUCOSE-84 UREA N-8 CREAT-0.6 SODIUM-133* 
POTASSIUM-4.1 CHLORIDE-101 TOTAL CO2-20* ANION GAP-12
___ 05:00PM   HBsAg-NEG
___ 05:00PM   HIV Ab-NEG

u/s FINDINGS: 
 
An intrauterine gestational sac is seen and a single living 
embryo is
identified with a crown rump length of 23 mmrepresenting a 
gestational age of
9 weeks, 0 days. This corresponds satisfactorily with the 
menstrual dates of 9
weeks, 0 days.   The uterus contains multiple masses consistent 
with fibroids,
the largest is an exophytic fibroid on the left measuring 5.2 x 
4.7 x 4.8 cm.
 
The ovaries are normal.  Due to acute, localized pain symptoms, 
spectral and
color Doppler of the ovaries was performed.  There was normal 
arterial and
venous flow demonstrated within the ovaries.  There is a small 
amount of
debris within the bladder.
 
CXR normal

Carotid artery
IMPRESSION: 
 
Elevated CCA and proximal ICA velocities likely normal for age.  
No
atherosclerosis.
Antegrade vertebral flow with slightly more resistive waveform 
on the left may
represent distal vertebral stenosis vs congenitally small artery 
on the left. 
If there are no correlatable symptoms then this does not need 
dedicated
imaging.
 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted and treated with antiemetics, IV hyratiion.  She 
improved and was able to tolerate po.

GI consult decided to defer endoscopy.

There was discussion of feeding tube but that was deferred 
because of p's ability to eat.

1. Ranitidine 75 mg PO BID 
2. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
3. Prochlorperazine 25 mg PR Q12H

2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID:PRN Constipation  
3.  Famotidine 20 mg PO BID  
4.  Metoclopramide 10 mg PO QIDACHS  
5.  Metoclopramide 10 mg PO Q6H:PRN nausea  
6.  Ondansetron ODT ___ mg PO ONCE Duration: 1 Dose  
7.  Pyridoxine 25 mg PO Q8H  
8.  Unisom (doxylamine) (doxylamine succinate) 25 mg oral QHS 
take additional ___ tab in morning or afternoon PRN  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Hyperemesis gravidarum
Pregnancy 9 weeks
Hirsutism
Fibroids

 
Discharge Condition:
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
See handout about hyperemesis
Medications as suggested

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Fevers and back pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with hx of 11 mm R ureteral stone s/p several attempts at 
treatment, most recently on ___ when he underwent 
cystoscopy, R ureteroscopy, laser lithotripsy, and stent change. 
 The case was uncomplicated, however, the patient states he 
started feeling unwell and spiking high fevers as high as 104.3 
beginning yesterday around 1pm.  He hoped these would improve 
without seeking treatment, but finally came to the ED this 
evening with decreased oral intake, muscle aches, and persistent 
high fevers and profuse sweating.  He feels like all of his 
muscles ache and has felt lightheaded since this AM.  He denies 
any nausea or vomiting, SOB, CP, leg pain.  He has mild 
abdominal pain which has been improving since his operation.  He 
states he has not been able to drink much due to generalized 
malaise.  He denies any gross hematuria or dysuria, but has 
noted some urinary incontinence since the procedure after he 
voids.

 
Past Medical History:
Kidney stones
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non contributory
 
Physical Exam:
on admission:
Vitals: 102.2, 125, 154/81, 16, 100% RA
Gen: Somnolent but arousable, uncomfortable appearing male 
drenched in sweat
Resp: Unlabored, CTA
CV: Sinus tachy
Abd: Soft, NT, ND, no guarding or RT. No CVAT on left or right 
side.  
Legs: NT, No edema

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 10:10AM BLOOD WBC-12.1* RBC-4.20* Hgb-13.3* Hct-38.5* 
MCV-92 MCH-31.7 MCHC-34.6 RDW-13.5 Plt ___
___ 10:10AM BLOOD Glucose-107* UreaN-11 Creat-1.0 Na-138 
K-3.7 Cl-104 HCO3-24 AnGap-14
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient admitted to Dr. ___ service for urosepsis 
following ureteroscopy and laser lithotripsy on ___. On 
admission patient had fever of 105.2.  He was placed empirically 
on amp/gent. A renal U/S performed showed moderate right 
hydronephrosis slightly increased since previous, the left side 
was normal. Blood and urine cultures were obtained, urine 
culture was positive for enterococcus and the gentamycin was 
changed to Ceftriaxone the ampicillin was continued. On HD 5 
blood cultures were still negative. He was noted to have 
intermittent spikes in temperature and he was held in hospital 
until he had been afebrile for 24 hours.  The patient was 
discharged to home on HD 5 in stable condition, having been 
afebrile (below 101.5) for greater than 24 hours, ambulating 
independently and tolerating a regular diet.  He was discharged 
with a 7 day course of oral antibiotics and instructed to 
contact Dr. ___ upon discharge to arrange follow up.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours).  
2. Tamsulosin 0.4 mg Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr PO HS.
Disp:*30 Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Ampicillin 250 mg Capsule Sig: Two (2) Capsule PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) for 7 days.
Disp:*56 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Urosepsis s/p ureteroscopy and laser lithotripsy

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Tylenol and Motrin can be used for pain and fevers. Max daily 
Tylenol dose is 4gm. Ibuprofen should always be taken with food.

-Continue to take Flomax as prescribed until your follow up with 
Dr. ___

-___ contact Dr. ___ upon discharge to arrange 
follow up appointment. ___
 
- If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, 
or inability to urinate, call your doctor or go to the nearest 
emergency room

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
Bactrim Ds
 
Attending: ___
 
___ Complaint:
Progressive left knee pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
L TKA

 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old female with a history of osteoarthritis and left 
knee pain presents for definitive treatment.
 
Past Medical History:
Healthy
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
On discharge: 
Afebrile, All vital signs stable
General: Alert and oriented, No acute distress
Extremities: left lower
Weight bearing: partial weight bearing
Incision: intact, no swelling/erythema/drainage
Dressing: clean/dry/intact
  Extensor/flexor hallicus longus intact
  Sensation intact to light touch
  Neurovascular intact distally
  Capillary refill brisk
  2+ pulses 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to ___ on ___ for an elective left 
total knee replacement. Pre-operatively, she was consented, 
prepped, and brought to the operating room. Intra-operatively, 
she was closely monitored and remained hemodynamically stable. 
She tolerated the procedure well without any complication. 
Post-operatively, she was transferred to the PACU and floor for 
further recovery. On the floor, she was transfused 1 unit of 
PRBC for postoperative anemia on POD #3. She then remained 
hemodynamically stable with her pain controlled. She progressed 
with physical therapy to improve her strength and mobility. She 
was discharged in stable condition. 

 
Medications on Admission:
Tylenol
MVI
Vitamin E
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL Syringe Sig: One (1)  Subcutaneous 
DAILY (Daily) for 3 weeks.
Disp:*qs * Refills:*0*
2. Percocet ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*90 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home with Service
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
left knee osteoarthritis
postoperative anemia

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
-you may shower on POD 5
-call your MD or return to the Emergency room if you notice 
fevers > 101, if you notice redness of your wound, drainage, 
increasing warmth and pain
-return to emergency room if you have chest pain, shortness of 
breath, or any other concerning symptoms. 
-wean your pain medication as you are able
-you may drive once you have been cleared to do so by your 
physician
-___ your coumadin as shots daily for three weeks. One shot 
daily. Once you have completed your coumadin shots, you need to 
start taking a 325mg Aspirin twice a day.
-weight bearing as tolerated, ROM as tolerated, advance CPM as 
tolerated.
-call Dr. ___ office to confirm/schedule your follow-up 
appointment. 
Physical Therapy:
ROM as tolerated, weight bearing as tolerated. 
Treatments Frequency:
.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Phenergan Plain
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Abdominal pain with weight loss and nausea
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Exploratory laparoscopy, retroperitoneal pericaval 
lymph node removal, laparoscopic appendectomy, extensive lysis 
of adhesions, and pelvic inflammatory process culture and 
biopsy.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ presenting with crampy abdominal and flank pain since 
running the ___ Marathon in ___. She had minimal PO 
intake prior to running and felt dehydrated after the marathon. 
Since that time, she has had persistent abdominal and right 
flank pain requiring narcotic pain medication.  

Outpatient workup including, CTU, abdominal CT and MRI were 
unremarkable. She is therefore admitted to the hospital for PICC 
placement and TPN for bowel rest.  We feel this pain may be from 
hypoperfusion during a low-flow state when she was dehydrated 
during and after the marathon causing ischemia of the
right colon. 

 
Past Medical History:
___:  osteopenia, hyperparathyroidism, acalculous cholecystisis 
(s/p LCCY)  
SH:  LCCY, wrist surgery, knee arthroscopy, L RFA ablation of 
the GSV  

 
Physical Exam:
Alert and oriented x 3 
VS:BP  106/63      HR   72       RR  16
CV: HR reg
Resp: Lungs clear
Abd: Soft, non tender. Incisions steristripped and clean

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:40AM BLOOD WBC-8.7 RBC-3.52* Hgb-10.8* Hct-33.3* 
MCV-95 MCH-30.7 MCHC-32.4 RDW-13.1 RDWSD-44.9 Plt ___
___ 05:40AM BLOOD Glucose-90 UreaN-12 Creat-0.6 Na-141 
K-4.1 Cl-108 HCO3-27 AnGap-10
___ 05:40AM BLOOD Calcium-8.8 Phos-3.1 Mg-1.9
___ 05:29AM BLOOD CRP-0.___ presents with persistent abdominal and right flank pain with 
associated nausea and weight loss.  The described pain started 
shortly after completing a marathon about a month ago. Extensive 
outpatient workup including CTU, abdominal CT and MRI revealed 
no structural etiology of the pain.  We felt the pain was from 
hypoperfusion during a low-flow state when she was dehydrated 
during and after a marathon causing ischemia of the right colon. 
 

She is admitted to the hospital for further evaluation including 
PICC line placement and TPN secondary to severe malnutrition.  
She has had a > 5% loss in body weight over 1 month and  < 50% 
energy intake compared to estimated energy needs for > 5days.   

By hospital day 3, the pain and nausea had not improved despite 
being NPO so she was taken for an  exploratory laparoscopy, 
retroperitoneal pericaval lymph node removal, laparoscopic 
appendectomy, extensive lysis of adhesions, and pelvic 
inflammatory process culture and biopsy.  After the procedure, 
her pain level substantially improved.  She started to slowly 
take small amounts of po liquids without an increase in pain so 
that by hospital day 7, she was ready to be discharged to home. 

Given her malnutrition, we plan to continue TPN at home for the 
next 2 weeks. She wil follow up with Dr. ___ as 
needed. 

 
Medications on Admission:
Zofran, pantoprazole 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q6H 
2. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H 
3. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 2.5-5 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 4 hours as 
needed. Disp #*12 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Abdominal Pain 
Malnutrition

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dr ___,

___ was a pleasure taking care of you at ___.  You were 
admitted to with a one month history of crampy abdominal and 
flank pain with weight loss.  Outpatient workup including CTU, 
abdominal CT and MRI were negative. We felt the pain was 
secondary to hypoperfusion during a low-flow state from 
dehydrated during and after a marathon which caused ischemia of 
the right colon.  We placed a PICC line and started TPN.  

Despite bowel rest, your abdominal pain persisted.  You then 
underwent a laparoscopy abdominal exploration.   During the 
procedure, we removed adhesions, a lymph node and your appendix. 
 We also sent multiple samples to the lab for further analysis.  
  

You tolerated the procedure well and are now ready to be 
discharge to home.  We will keep your PICC in place and continue 
TPN at home on a nightly basis.  You are now being discharged 
home with the following instructions:

Please follow up at the appointment in clinic listed below. We 
also generally recommend that patients follow up with their 
primary care provider after having surgery. 

ACTIVITY:
Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs.
You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you 
see your surgeon at your next visit.
Don't lift more than ___ lbs for ___ weeks. (This is about the 
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to 
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.

HOW YOU MAY FEEL:
You may feel weak or "washed out" a couple weeks. You might want 
to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
You could have a poor appetite for a couple days. Food may seem 
unappealing.
All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.

YOUR INCISION:
You may shower and remove the gauzes over your incisions. Under 
these dressings you have small plastic bandages called 
steristrips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. (These are 
the thin paper strips that might be on your incision.) But if 
they fall off before that that's okay.
Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This is 
normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining 
your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call 
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.

YOUR BOWELS:
Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving 
the bowels, call your surgeon.

PAIN MANAGEMENT:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness".
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is 
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. Do not 
take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed. Do not drink alcohol or 
drive while taking narcotic pain medication.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.

surgeon has said its okay.

or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.

Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Exploratory laparoscopy, retroperitoneal pericaval
lymph node removal, laparoscopic appendectomy, extensive lysis
of adhesions, and pelvic inflammatory process culture and

History of Present Illness:
___ presenting with crampy abdominal and flank pain since
running the ___ Marathon in ___. She had minimal PO
intake prior to running and felt dehydrated after the marathon.
Since that time, she has had persistent abdominal and right
flank pain requiring narcotic pain medication.
Outpatient workup including, CTU, abdominal CT and MRI were
unremarkable. She is therefore admitted to the hospital for PICC
placement and TPN for bowel rest. We feel this pain may be from

during and after the marathon causing ischemia of the
right colon.

(s/p LCCY)

the GSV
Physical Exam:

Abd: Soft, non tender. Incisions steristripped and clean
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:40AM BLOOD WBC-8.7 RBC-3.52* Hgb-10.8* Hct-33.3*
MCV-95 MCH-30.7 MCHC-32.4 RDW-13.1 RDWSD-44.9 Plt ___

K-4.1 Cl-108 HCO3-27 AnGap-10
___ 05:40AM BLOOD Calcium-8.8 Phos-3.1 Mg-1.9
___ 05:29AM BLOOD CRP-0.___ presents with persistent abdominal and right flank pain with
associated nausea and weight loss. The described pain started
shortly after completing a marathon about a month ago. Extensive
outpatient workup including CTU, abdominal CT and MRI revealed
no structural etiology of the pain. We felt the pain was from
hypoperfusion during a low-flow state when she was dehydrated
during and after a marathon causing ischemia of the right colon.
She is admitted to the hospital for further evaluation including
PICC line placement and TPN secondary to severe malnutrition.
She has had a > 5% loss in body weight over 1 month and < 50%
energy intake compared to estimated energy needs for > 5days.
By hospital day 3, the pain and nausea had not improved despite
being NPO so she was taken for an exploratory laparoscopy,
retroperitoneal pericaval lymph node removal, laparoscopic
appendectomy, extensive lysis of adhesions, and pelvic
inflammatory process culture and biopsy. After the procedure,
her pain level substantially improved. She started to slowly
take small amounts of po liquids without an increase in pain so
that by hospital day 7, she was ready to be discharged to home.
Given her malnutrition, we plan to continue TPN at home for the
next 2 weeks. She wil follow up with Dr. ___ as
needed.
Medications on Admission:
Zofran, pantoprazole
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q6H
2. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H
3. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 2.5-5 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 4 hours as
needed. Disp #*12 Tablet Refills:*0
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Abdominal Pain
Malnutrition
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Dr ___,
___ was a pleasure taking care of you at ___. You were
admitted to with a one month history of crampy abdominal and
flank pain with weight loss. Outpatient workup including CTU,
abdominal CT and MRI were negative. We felt the pain was
secondary to hypoperfusion during a low-flow state from
dehydrated during and after a marathon which caused ischemia of
the right colon. We placed a PICC line and started TPN.
Despite bowel rest, your abdominal pain persisted. You then
underwent a laparoscopy abdominal exploration. During the
procedure, we removed adhesions, a lymph node and your appendix. We also sent multiple samples to the lab for further analysis.
You tolerated the procedure well and are now ready to be
discharge to home. We will keep your PICC in place and continue
TPN at home on a nightly basis. You are now being discharged
home with the following instructions:
Please follow up at the appointment in clinic listed below. We
also generally recommend that patients follow up with their
primary care provider after having surgery.
ACTIVITY:
Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and
feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs.
You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you
see your surgeon at your next visit.
Don't lift more than ___ lbs for ___ weeks. (This is about the
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you
can resume tub baths or swimming.
HOW YOU MAY FEEL:
You may feel weak or "washed out" a couple weeks. You might want
to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your
throat during surgery.
You could have a poor appetite for a couple days. Food may seem
unappealing.
All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go
away in a short time. If they do not, tell your surgeon.
YOUR INCISION:
You may shower and remove the gauzes over your incisions. Under
these dressings you have small plastic bandages called
steristrips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. (These are
the thin paper strips that might be on your incision.) But if
they fall off before that that's okay.
Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This is
normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining
your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may
resume tub baths or swimming.
YOUR BOWELS:
Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain
medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these
medicines without a prescription.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving
the bowels, call your surgeon.
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness".
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. Do not
take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more
medicine at one time than prescribed. Do not drink alcohol or
drive while taking narcotic pain medication.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your
pain gets too severe.
Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your
surgeon has said its okay.
If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of
pain medicine.
Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough
or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to
take, please call your surgeon.
Followup Instructions:
___

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Significant for lumbar disk disease,
endometriosis, recent onset asthma, hyperprolactinemia 
attributed
to a small but unidentified pituitary adenoma, migraine

___, other surgeries for endometriosis as above.

___
Family History:
Significant for a paternal grandmother with unspecified cancer.

see admission record
 
Pertinent Results:
n/a
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted as described above and underwent closed 
manipulation under anesthesia.  Please see operative note for 
full details.  Her ROM was significantly improved.  
Postoperatively CPM and aggressive ROM was performed under the 
direction of physical therapy.  Her postop course was otherwise 
unremarkable.  She was discharged in stable condition.  
 
Medications on Admission:
see admission record
 
Discharge Medications:
1. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
2. albuterol sulfate 90 mcg/Actuation HFA Aerosol Inhaler Sig: 
___ Puffs Inhalation Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for wheeze, 
sob, chest tightness.  
3. sumatriptan succinate 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H 
(every 6 hours) as needed for migraine headache.  
4. Dilaudid 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours.
Disp:*80 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Decreased range of motion right knee

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.  
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills.  
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.  
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool  
softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent this side effect. 
 
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon or your primary physician.  
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in four weeks.   
7. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue ambulate frequently to help 
prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots). 
8. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated. No strenuous exercise 
or heavy lifting until follow up appointment. Continue to 
participate in ___ and aggressive range of motion exercises.
Treatments Frequency:
Physical therapy, CPM

Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Sore throat, Hoarseness
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Laryngoscopy
 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old female with a history of an episode of sore throat, 
hoarseness, and respiratory distress requiring ICU admission for 
steroids/abx, also with a known vallecular cyst who now presents 
with acute onset throat pain and dysphonia.  Patient was in her 
usual state of health until the day of admission when she woke 
up with sore throat. It became progressively worse throughout 
the day and by the afternoon of admission developed hoarseness. 
She denied any other associated symptoms, in particular fever, 
chills, shortness of breath, cough, sick contacts. In ___, 
she developed sore throat and hoarseness that progressed over 
the course of several days to the point that she had difficulty 
breathing (she notes that episode was much worse than symptoms 
she is experiencing today). At that time, she was admitted to 
___ ICU for for airway monitoring and was 
given antibiotics and steroids for presumed bacterial 
pharyngitis causing laryngeal edema. She was evaluated by ___ 
where she was noted to have a vallecular cyst although its 
contribution to airway obstruction was not clear. She was 
eventually discharged on a steroid taper and completed a course 
of flagyl and vantin. She notes no difficulty swallowing or 
subacute voice changes at baseline. She has been evaluated at 
___ (Dr. ___ for vallecular cyst removal in the 
past. 
.
In the ED, initial vs 98.2 90 136/87 24 100%RA.  On initial 
evaluation, patient noted to have marked stridor.  Was treated 
with racemic EPI and 10mg of IV decadron.  ENT was urgently 
consulted.  By time of ENT evaluation stridor had resolved.  ENT 
eval in ED demonstrated normal vocal cords, unchanged vallecular 
cyst, and unremarkable glottis.  Recommended discharge home but 
ED requesting ICU observation given marked stridor on 
presentation.  Given clindamycin and 1L NS prior to transfer. 
.
On the floor, she reported ___ sore throat and stable 
hoarseness since presenting to the ED. She reported worsening 
sore throat with deep inspiration but denies SOB. 

 
Past Medical History:
(1) vallecular cyst 
(2) gestational DM 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
- No family
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: 98.2  123/72  73 15 98%RA 
General: dysphonia, Alert, oriented, no acute distress 
HEENT: MMM, uvula visualized and midline, oropharynx clear
LYMPH: no cervical, axillary, inguinal LAD
Neck: supple, JVP not elevated
Lungs: poor inspiratory effort, CTA bilaterally, no wheezes
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, 
gallops
Abdomen:  soft, NTND, positive bowel sounds 
GU: no foley
Ext: warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or 
edema

ENT Evaluation/Exam: 
After  decongestion with Afrin, the scope was easily
passed through the right nasal cavity.  No 
edema, erythema or masses noted in the NP.  There is a ~1cm
vallecular cyst just right of midline.  The epiglottis is
minimally displaced posteriorly, but the tip sharp.  False vocal
folds crisp and wnl.  B/L true vocal folds are mobile and normal
appearing.  Airway is widely patent.  No pooling of secretions 
in
the piriform sinuses or vallecula.

Brief Hospital Course:
#Sore Throat/Hoarseness: 
The presentation was similar to the initial phase of her prior 
episode, which was hypothesized to be due to acute pharyngitis 
(although no documented infection) with associated laryngeal 
edema resulting in partial airway obstruction and respiratory 
distress. On admission, she felt that her respiratory status was 
at baseline and fiberoptic exam by ENT demonstrated widely 
patent airway. No additional symptomatology to suggest 
influenza, mononucleosis or primary HIV. No known caustic 
ingestions on inhalant abuse. No history of symptoms consistent 
with GERD. Paroxysmal vocal cord movement considered although 
atypical to present with prominent sore throat rather than 
respiratory distress, throat tightening. 
Contribution of the vallecular cyst to symptoms not clear 
although potentially exacerbating factor in the setting acute 
process. 

A throat culture was sent from the emergency department, though 
was not complete at the time of discharge.

The patient was started on Decadrom 10mg IV q 8 hours x 2 doses 
and then switched to an oral Medrol dose pack.  She was started 
on IV clindamycin, and will be discharged on PO clindamycin for 
a 10 day course.

She will follow up with Dr. ___ as an ___ at 
the conclusion of her antibiotic course.

#Microcytic Anemia: 
Unclear baseline hematocrit but reports history of anemia, 
intermittently takes iron, never transfused, no hx acute blood 
loss. 

Her hematocrit was trended throughout her admission and was 
noted to be stable.  Iron studies were completed and she had a 
normal iron, transferrin, total iron binding capacity, and 
ferritin levels.
 
Medications on Admission:
None

6 hours) as needed for pain.

times a day for 10 days.

Disp:*1 Tablets, Dose Pack(s)* Refills:*0*

Home

Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Bladder Tumor
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
TURBT

 
History of Present Illness:
___ smoker with bladder tumor found on cystoscopy
PMH: none
MEDS: none
ALL: none
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Admitted to Urology from the PACU in stable consition. Op note 
dictated separately. O/N received IVF hydration and IV pain 
control. Discharged tolerating regular diet, foley in place and 
draining, pain controlled with oral analgesics. Will remove 
Foley ___ with antibiotic prophylaxis and he will follow up 
in clinic.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxybutynin Chloride 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO TID (3 
times a day).  
2. Phenazopyridine 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO TID (3 
times a day) for 3 days.  
3. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain: do not exceed 4g acetaminophen/24hr 
.  
5. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
6. Cipro 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day for 3 
days: Take first tomorrow, then take until gone.
Disp:*6 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Bladder tumor

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
-You may take motrin and narcotic together for pain control

-You may shower 2 days after surgery, but do not tub bathe, 
swim, or soak for 2 weeks. 

-No heavy lifting for 4 weeks (no more than 10 pounds)

-___ medical attention for fevers (temp>101.5), chills, 
worsening pain, chest pain or shortness of breath.

-Remove your Foley catheter on ___ morning. Take your 
antibiotic starting tomorrow and then for next 2 days. If you 
are unable to void within 7 hours, call your Urologist or go to 
the ER.

-Please do not drive or consume alcohol while taking pain 
medications.

-Take first dose of Ciprofloxacin 1 day prior to foley catheter 
removal (___) and for next 2 days.

- Wear Large foley bag for majority of time, leg bag is only for 
short-term when leaving house.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

TURBT who was admitted for pain control overnight, now back with 
abd pain.  Has h/o colitis, CT cystogram in ED confirmed no 
leak, but did show dilated loops of bowel.  Back with likely 
ileus.  His foley was removed and he voided clear urine in the

Mild distress
RRR

GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-5.0 
LEUK-SM 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to urology after undergoing a TURBT 3days 
prior.  He had left flank pain and a CT cystogram in the ED 
conformed no leak.  It did, however, show an ileus, so he was 
admitted for presumed ileus.  Later the day of admission, the 
patients pain had not subsided and became ___.  We therefore 
then obtained a CTU which showed a left ureteral leak 
promximally.  Presumably the etiology was edema at the left UO 
from the resection and this soon resolved over the next 2 days 
as the patients pain improved.  He was treated with Levo/Vaco 
while in house, but urine cx were negative, therefore he was not 
sent on abx.  Diet advanced as tolerated. At discharge patient's 
pain was well controlled with PO pain medications, ambulating 
without assistance, and passing urine in the foley.  Patient was 
given instructions to follow up with Dr. ___ in ___ days for 
foley removal. 

 
Medications on Admission:
1. Oxybutynin Chloride 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO TID (3 

times a day).

times a day) for 3 days.

Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.

4. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 

6 hours) as needed for pain: do not exceed 4g acetaminophen/24hr 

5. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 

times a day).  
6. Cipro 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day for 3 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Dilaudid 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours as 
needed for pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left renal colic, ileus

 
Discharge Condition:
Good

 
Discharge Instructions:
-You may shower and bathe normally.  
-Do not drive or drink alcohol if taking narcotic pain 
medication.    
-Call your Urologist's office (___) to schedule a 
follow-up appointment in 1 week AND if you have any questions. 
 -If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, 
or inability to urinate, call your doctor or go to the nearest 
emergency room.

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: PLASTIC
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Facial pain, swelling
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
bedside drainage of nasal abscess

 
History of Present Illness:
___ is a ___ year-old male S/P rhinoplasty at 
___ with Dr. ___, by report, spreader 
grafts and bilateral conchal cartilage grafts who presented with 
increasing pain over the nasal dorsum and maxillary sinuses. His 
post-op course was notable for increasing pain. He was initially 
unable to tolerate Clindamycin but later finished his 3 day 
supply.  He presented to the emergency department ___ with 
increasing pain which was well-controlled with morphine.  He was 
discharged home with Vicodin but returned the ED the same day 
with refractory nasal and sinus pain. 

 
Past Medical History:
Rhinoplasty X 2.
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
Physical Exam on Admission:

VS: Tm97.7 ___ BP146/80  RR16 100%RA 
HEENT Mild swelling and ecchymosis over infraorbital region
bilaterally L>R, no significant erythema, EOMI, PERRL, nasal
septum intact without hematoma, nares clear wihtout packing,
dorsal splint intact, throat with minimal erythema and mild 
white
exudate, tender to percussion over frontal and maxillary sinuses

 
Pertinent Results:
CT head- IMPRESSION:
1. Edema and a small amount of fluid of the soft tissues of the 
nose anterior to the nasal bone could simply represent 
post-surgical change or abscess. Correlation with physical 
examination is suggested.
2. Mild mucosal thickening of the maxillary and sphenoid sinuses 
and a sphenoid Onodi cell on the ___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to the plastic surgery service.  He 
was started on vancomycin and zosyn.  He underwent a bedside 
drainage of a nasal abscess a fluid was sent for culture.  
Culture revealed mixed oropharyngeal flora including coagulase 
negative staph.  Infectious disease was consulted and 
recommended  a head CT which revealed the expected post-surgical 
and post-drainage changes but no extension of infection.  His 
facial cellulitis and swelling markedly improved after IV 
antibiotics.  He was discharged on hospital day ___ with  a PICC 
line for IV vancomycin in addition to PO ciprofloxacin and 
metronidazole.  He will follow-up with Dr. ___ 
infectious disease specialists in clinic.
 
Medications on Admission:
Vicodin
Dilaudid
Augmentin
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Sodium Chloride 0.65 % Aerosol, Spray Sig: ___ Sprays Nasal 
QID (4 times a day).
Disp:*2 bottles* Refills:*2*
3. Heparin Lock Flush (Porcine) 100 unit/mL Syringe Sig: ___ MLs 
Intravenous SASH and PRN as needed for 10 days.
Disp:*200 ML(s)* Refills:*1*
4. Saline Flush 0.9 % Syringe Sig: ___ ml Injection SASH and 
PRN for 10 days.
Disp:*200 ml* Refills:*1*
5. Ciprofloxacin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q12H 
(every 12 hours) for 10 days.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
6. Metronidazole 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO TID (3 
times a day) for 10 days.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
7. Line care
___ line care per protocol
8. Outpatient Lab Work
VANCOMYCIN TROUGH BEFORE ___ DOSING AM OR ___
9. Vancomycin 500 mg Recon Soln Sig: One (1) Recon Soln 
Intravenous Q 12H (Every 12 Hours).
Disp:*60 Recon Soln(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
postoperative nasal abscess

 
Discharge Condition:
good

 
Discharge Instructions:
If you develop fever >101.5, chills, increasing pain or redness, 
or any other symptom concerning to you, please call ___ or 
return to the emergency department.  

Take all medications as prescribed by your doctor. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right tibia ___
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___:  Repair of right tibia nonunion with plating and iliac 
crest bone grafting
 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female who suffered a right tibial 
shaft stress fracture approximately 15 months ago.  
Unfortunately this went on not to heal.  She presents today for 
definitive treatment.
 
Past Medical History:
hypothyriodism  
hx of DVT
Right Tibial Tubercal Osteotomy in ___, 
ORIF Right tibia ___
Removal of hardware right tibia ___.

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
n/a
 
Physical Exam:
Upon admission

Alert and oriented
Cardiac:  Regular rate rhythm
Chest:  Lungs clear biaterally
Abdomen:  Soft non-tender
Extremities:  RLE:  incisions well approximated, 
+pulses/sensation.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female who presents to the ___ 
on ___ for elective repair of her right tibia ___.  
Prior to surgery she was prepped and consented.  She tolerated 
the procedure well, was extubated, transferred to the recovery 
room, and then to the floor.  On the floor she was seen by 
physical therapy to improve her strength and mobility. The rest 
of her hospital stay was uneventful with her lab data and vital 
signs within normal limits and her pain controlled.  She is 
being discharged today in stable condition.
 
Medications on Admission:
Levothyroxine
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL Syringe Sig: One (1) 40mg syringe 
Subcutaneous DAILY (Daily) for 2 weeks.
Disp:*14 syringes* Refills:*0*
2. Levothyroxine 50 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
3. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
every four (4) hours as needed for pain: Do NOT drive while on 
this medication.
Disp:*80 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Senokot-S 8.6-50 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO once a day as 
needed for constipation.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right tibia fracture ___
 
Discharge Condition:
Afebrile with stable vital signs. Awake alert and oriented x 3. 
Tolerating regular diet, pain controlled on oral medications, 
voiding bowels and bladder independently. 
 
Discharge Instructions:
You are touch-down weight bearing on your Right Lower extremity. 
You should keep your leg elevated as much as possible to prevent 
swelling and discomfort.
 
Please take your lovenox injections for a total of  2 weeks 
after surgery

Please take your medication as prescribed

If you have any increased redness, drainage, or swelling, or if 
you have a temperature greater than 101.5, please call the 
office or come to the emergency department.
 
Followup Instructions:

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
Latex / Aspirin
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Back pain and L buttock pain radiating down LLE
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: L L5-S1 microdiscectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
Mrs. ___ is a pleasant ___ with a one year history of back 
pain and LLE symptoms including pain in the L buttock and 
weakness in plantarflexion.  Denies bowel and bladder symptoms.  
Given her neurologic symptoms, she elected to proceed with 
surgical management. 
 
Past Medical History:
s/p hysterectomy
s/p cholecystectomy
s/p tonsillectomy
Hypotension
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
AVSS
Well appearing, NAD, comfortable
BUE: SILT C5-T1 dermatomal distributions
BUE: ___ Del/Tri/Bic/WE/WF/FF/IO
BUE: tone normal, negative ___, 2+ symmetric DTR 
bic/bra/tri
All fingers WWP, brisk capillary refill, 2+ distal pulses
BLE: SILT L1-S1 dermatomal distributions
LLE: ___ HF/Q/H, ___ ___
RLE: ___ throughout
BLE: tone normal, no clonus, toes downgoing, 2+ DTR knee/ankle
All toes WWP, brisk capillary refill, 2+ distal pulses
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service on 
___ and taken to the Operating Room for the above procedure 
performed by Dr. ___.  Please refer to the dictated 
operative note for further details. The surgery was without 
complication and the patient was transferred to the PACU in a 
stable condition. TEDs/pnemoboots were used for postoperative 
DVT prophylaxis. Intravenous antibiotics were continued for 
24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initial postop pain was 
controlled with a PCA then she was transitioned to a PO regimen 
the evening of surgery.   Diet was advanced as tolerated.  
Hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. On the day of 
discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs, 
comfortable on oral pain control and tolerating a regular diet.
 
Medications on Admission:
1. Midodrine 5 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO TID (3 times a 
day).  
2. Fludrocortisone 0.1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 
times a day).
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Midodrine 5 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO TID (3 times a 
day).  
2. Fludrocortisone 0.1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 
times a day).  
3. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg/5 mL Solution Sig: Five (5) 
ML PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*200 ML(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
L L5-S1 disc herniation

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have undergone the following operation: Minimally Invasive 
Microdiscectomy

Immediately after the operation:

-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than ~45 minutes without moving around.

-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery.  You can walk as much as you can 
tolerate. 
oLimit any kind of lifting.

-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some 
constipation after surgery. 

-Brace: You do not need a brace.

-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  If it is dry 
then you can leave the incision open to the air.  Once the 
incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile 
dressing.  Call the office. 

-You should resume taking your normal home medications.

-You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead.  You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___ 2.  We are not allowed to call in narcotic prescriptions 
(oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to the pharmacy.  In addition, 
we are only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days 
from the date of surgery.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to Antepartum service for 
pre-term labor and placental abruption. She underwent a low 
transverse cesarean section, with an estimated blood loss and 
her hematocrit was monitored closely. 

Post-operatively her pain was controlled with Dilaudid PCA, 
which was transitioned to oral Dilaudid, acetaminophen and 
ibuprofen. She was also seen by the chronic pain service during 
her hospitalization. She was continued on her home levothyroxine 
during her hospitalization. She was offered her home Subutex but 
declined. 

By postpartum day 4, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Buprenorphine 4 mg SL DAILY 
2. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
3. Levothyroxine Sodium 100 mcg PO DAILY

pain

oAt the 2-week visit we will check your incision, take baseline 
X-rays and answer any questions. We may at that time start 
physical therapy.
oWe will then see you at 6 weeks from the day of the operation 
and at that time release you to full activity.

Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound

Hypotension

AVSS
Well appearing, NAD, comfortable

BUE: ___ Del/Tri/Bic/WE/WF/FF/IO
BUE: tone normal, negative ___, 2+ symmetric DTR
bic/bra/tri
All fingers WWP, brisk capillary refill, 2+ distal pulses
BLE: SILT L1-S1 dermatomal distributions
LLE: ___ HF/Q/H, ___ ___
RLE: ___ throughout
BLE: tone normal, no clonus, toes downgoing, 2+ DTR knee/ankle
All toes WWP, brisk capillary refill, 2+ distal pulses
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service on
___ and taken to the Operating Room for the above procedure
performed by Dr. ___. Please refer to the dictated
operative note for further details. The surgery was without
complication and the patient was transferred to the PACU in a
stable condition. TEDs/pnemoboots were used for postoperative
DVT prophylaxis. Intravenous antibiotics were continued for
24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initial postop pain was
controlled with a PCA then she was transitioned to a PO regimen
the evening of surgery. Diet was advanced as tolerated.
Hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. On the day of
discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs,
comfortable on oral pain control and tolerating a regular diet.
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone 5 mg/5 mL Solution Sig: One (1) PO Q4H (every 4
hours).
Disp:*80 * Refills:*0*
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2
times a day).
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
L5-S1 herniated nuleus pulposus.
Discharge Condition:
Stable
Discharge Instructions:
Immediately after the operation: Minimally invasive Discectomy.
-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand
more than ~45 minutes without moving around.
-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy:
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as
part of your recovery. You can walk as much as you can
tolerate.
oLimit any kind of lifting.
-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some
constipation after surgery.
-Brace: You do not need a brace.
-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days. If the incision is
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing. If it is dry
then you can leave the incision open to the air. Once the
incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a
bath or pool. If the incision starts draining at anytime after
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile
dressing. Call the office.
-You should resume taking your normal home medications.
-You have also been given Additional Medications to control
your pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic
prescriptions, so please plan ahead. You can either have them
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on
___. We are not allowed to call in narcotic prescriptions
(oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to the pharmacy. In addition,
we are only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days
from the date of surgery.
-Follow up:
oPlease Call the office and make an appointment for 2 weeks
after the day of your operation if this has not been done
already.
oAt the 2-week visit we will check your incision, take baseline
X-rays and answer any questions. We may at that time start
physical therapy.
oWe will then see you at 6 weeks from the day of the operation
and at that time release you to full activity.
Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
neck pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
C3-C7 laminectomy, PSIF, C5-C6 foraminotomy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ gentleman who presents with right neck and shoulder 
pain.  This has been going on for the last ___ years.  There is 
no traumatic precipitant.  His condition has proceeded more or 
less unchanged over that time interval.  He has
been involved with physical therapy, but this has not been 
helpful.  He denies any difficulty with bowel, bladder, or 
gait.He does not smoke.  He continues to work as a ___.

 
Past Medical History:
HTN, Twave Depressions on Stress test ___, high Cholesterol 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
noncontrib
 
Physical Exam:
PRE-OP:
His motor strength is ___ in the deltoid, biceps,
triceps, and hand intrinsics bilaterally.  There is no clonus. 
There is evidence of Lhermitte's phenomenon.

DISCHARGE:
motor full, sensation intact, wound with staples and minimal 
amount staining on dressings, no active drainage
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 11:59AM   GLUCOSE-148* UREA N-17 CREAT-1.1 SODIUM-141 
POTASSIUM-4.3 CHLORIDE-107 TOTAL CO2-25 ANION GAP-13
___ 11:59AM   CALCIUM-8.3* MAGNESIUM-1.7
___ 11:59AM   WBC-9.1# RBC-4.45* HGB-13.2* HCT-40.8 MCV-92 
MCH-29.7 MCHC-32.4 RDW-14.2
___ 11:59AM   PLT COUNT-221
___ 11:59AM   ___ PTT-20.3* ___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___ he presented electively and went to OR where under 
general anesthesia he underwent a C3-7 laminectomy and C5-6 
foraminotomy.  He tolerated the procedure well, was extubated, 
transferred to PACU and then floor. Diet and actvity were 
advanced.  Pain medication was transitioned to PO. He had soft 
cervical collar for comfort. 

On the morning of POD #2, the patient was found to be quite 
diaphoretic, and he spiked a fever of 101.6. His incision began 
to drain significant amounts of serosanguenous fluid, and it 
appeared erythematous.  He was placed on antibiotic therapy and 
was pan cultured. Cultures were negative with exception of wound 
swab which had expected skin flora contamination.  The drainage 
from wound slowed appreciably.  CT of the neck showed normal 
postop appearance without evidence for infection. He did not 
spike another fever.  His pain medication was titrated.  His 
foley was removed and he voided without difficulty. ___ worked 
with patient and he was ambulating in halls.  
 
Medications on Admission:
lovastatin 40 mg daily, atenolol 100 mg daily, and aspirin 81 mg 
daily.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Atenolol 50 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. Atorvastatin 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*1*
4. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day).
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*1*
5. Diazepam 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q 8H (Every 8 
Hours) as needed for muscle spasm.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
6. Gabapentin 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO TID (3 
times a day).
Disp:*90 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
7. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*120 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Cervical Stenosis, C5 foramenal Stenosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Do not smoke.
Keep your wound clean/ No tub baths or pool swimming for two 
weeks from your date of surgery. You may remove your dressing on 
___ and begin daily showers on ___
No pulling up, lifting more than 10 lbs., or excessive bending 
or twisting.
Limit your use of stairs to ___ times per day.
Have a friend or family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
Take your pain medication as instructed; you may find it best 
if taken in the morning when you wake-up for morning stiffness, 
and before bed for sleeping discomfort.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as pain medicine 
(narcotics) can cause constipation. We recommend taking an over 
the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) while 
taking narcotic pain medication.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

BP monitoring

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms ___ is a ___ G4P3 who is postpartum day 8 from an
uncomplicated LTCS. She presents today after elevated BPs of
155/100 and 154/98 on repeat in clinic today. Patient had normal
BPs in the 110s-120s systolically prenatally, but had some
elevated BPs postpartum, while in the hospital. She was told to
follow up in clinic and was found to have elevated pressures in
clinic today. She was then sent to gyn triage. 

Patient's BP upon arrival was 158/93 then 170/96 and 160/101 on
repeat checks. She states she has some swelling in her feet that
has worsened since discharge but feels fine otherwise. She 
denies
any headaches, vision changes, chest pain, shortness of breath,
abdominal pain, or nausea/vomiting. She has been feeling well at
home aside from getting minimal sleep with baby. 
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: None
PSH: C/s x3

___

Father with high BP and CAD

.

___ 02:15PM URINE Hours-RANDOM Creat-107 TotProt-18 
Prot/Cr-0.2
___ 12:17PM URINE Hours-RANDOM Creat-76 TotProt-30 
Prot/Cr-0.4*
 
Brief Hospital Course:
In triage she was given 3 doses of IV Labetalol 20mg-40mg-80mg 
respectively.  She was then started on oral antihypertensives. 
She had no symptoms of PEC and her laboratory workup for PEC was 
negative.  The decision was then made to admit the patient for 
BP monitoring and titration of anti-hypertnesives.  
.
Her blood pressures were well controlled on nifedipine 30mg CR 
daily and remained asymptomatic. She was discahrged on hospital 
day 2 with nifedipine 30mg CR daily and outpatient follow up.

Motrin, Oxycodone

the neonate to the NICU for prematurity. Please see operative

___ URINE Hours-RANDOM Creat-26 TotProt-<___ y/o G1P0 admitted at 30w3d for close surveillance due to a
vasa previa. She underwent close surveillance with daily NSTs.
On admission, she received a course of betamethasone for fetal
lung maturity and the NICU was consulted. She was noted to have
intermittently elevated blood pressures (systolic BP in 140s),
however, preeclampsia labs were normal and she had no
proteinuria. At approximately 33 weeks, she developed some
intermittent variable decels on routine NSTs and often underwent
prolonged monitoring. These decels promted a rescue course of
betamethasone (complete on ___. She remained clinically stable
until 34w5d when ___ recommended delivery due to the variable
decelerations. She underwent a primary LTCS on ___ (at 34w5d)
and delivered a liveborn male infant weighing 2275g with apgars
of 8 and 9. NICU staff was present for delivery and transferred
the neonate to the NICU for prematurity. Please see operative
report for details.
.

discharged home in stable condition on POD#4.

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
headache
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None 

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old right-handed female who
presents to ED with reports of headache x3 weeks. She states her
headaches were initially throbbing and severe during the first
week. She was taking Ibuprofen without relief so went to her PCP
who gave her Toradol with relief x1 day only.  She started 
taking
extra strength Tylenol yesterday without good effect and her PCP
ordered an MRI which showed an 11mm hemorrhagic anterosuperior
pituitary mass with suprasellar extension and compression of the
chiasm, concerning for a pituitary adenoma with hemorrhage so 
she
was sent to ___ ED. She denies visual changes. Her menstrual
cycle was reportedly normal prior to her recent pregnancy, she 
is
s/p C-section 4 months ago. She denies being on anticoagulants. 

 
Past Medical History:
Hypertension
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Father with high BP and CAD

 
Physical Exam:
Upon admission: 
Gen: WD/WN, comfortable, NAD.
HEENT: Pupils:  ___ reactive bilaterally       
EOMs: intact
Visual acuity: intact bilaterally and independently of each
other. 
Extrem: Warm and well-perfused.
Neuro:
Mental status: Awake and alert, cooperative with exam, normal
affect, teary-eyed. 
Orientation: Oriented to person, place, and date.
Language: Speech fluent with good comprehension. No dysarthria.

Cranial Nerves:
I: Not tested
II: Pupils equally round and reactive to light, to
mm bilaterally. Visual fields are full to confrontation.
III, IV, VI: Extraocular movements intact bilaterally without
nystagmus.
V, VII: Facial strength and sensation intact and symmetric.
VIII: Hearing intact to voice.
IX, X: Palatal elevation symmetrical.
XI: Sternocleidomastoid and trapezius normal bilaterally.
XII: Tongue midline without fasciculations.

Motor: Normal bulk and tone bilaterally. No abnormal movements,
tremors. Strength full power ___ throughout. No pronator drift

Sensation: Intact to light touch.

Coordination: normal on finger-nose-finger, rapid alternating
movements, heel to shin

Handedness: Right

Upon discharge: 
alert and oriented x3 
PERRL 
EOM intact 
Face symmetric 
Visual fields intact 
___ Strength 
No pronator drift 
 
Pertinent Results:
___ CXR
No acute cardiopulmonary process.

___ MRI pituitary 
Midline cystic superior sellar lesion extending into the 
suprasellar 
cistern which demonstrates a mural nonenhancing nodule.  This 
lesion contacts the optic chiasm which is superiorly displaced 
and mildly deforms the posterior infundibulum.  Finding may 
represent a Rathke's cleft cyst versus a cystic pituitary 
adenoma.  Craniopharyngioma is less likely in the absence of 
calcification which could be better characterized with dedicated 
CT. 
  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was sent to ED by her PCP for MRI findings of 11mm 
hemorrhagic anterosuperior pituitary mass with suprasellar 
extension and compression of the chiasm, likely pituitary 
adenoma with hemorrhage in the setting of labile blood pressure. 
 Admitted for blood pressure control and pending pituitary panel 
lab results. 

On ___ Patient was neurologically stable. Endocrine consult was 
placed. Prolactin, Cortisol, LH, FSH, TSH, Free T4 were ordered 
and were all within normal limits 

On ___ Patient was neurologically intact. A dedicated MRI of 
the pituitary was completed. Concern for compression of optic 
chiasm. Optho was consulted. 

On ___ Patient was neurologically intact. She underwent formal 
visual field testing with ophthalmology.

On ___ Patient was neurologically intact. She was discharged 
home in good condition with instructions for follow up. 

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain 
2. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Hemorrhagic Pituitary Lesion 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after work up for headaches 
revealed a Pituitary tumor. 

You were seen by Endocrinology and Neurosurgery for workup of 
this lesion. 

At this time we feel it is safe for you to be monitored as an 
outpatient for this lesion and we will see you in follow up in 1 
month. 

CALL YOUR DOCTOR IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

¨New onset of tremors or seizures.
¨Any confusion or change in mental status. 
¨Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
¨Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
¨If you notice your urine output to be increasing, and/or 
excessive, and you are unable to quench your thirst, please call 
your endocrinologist. 
-      Any change in your vision 

 
Followup Instructions:
___
