text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
RUE pain following posterior fusion
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Removal of right C6 lateral mass screw

 
History of Present Illness:
Pt underwent a previous posterior cervical instrumented fusion 
in ___.  He has had some right-sided symptoms for some 
number of months now.  He recently
underwent repair of right-sided rotator cuff.  That has led to
some improvement in his shoulder, but he has persistent symptoms
in his right upper extremity that seem to be radicular.  A CT
scan has demonstrated malposition of the right C6 lateral mass
screw.

 
Past Medical History:
HTN, Twave Depressions on Stress test ___, high Cholesterol 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
noncontrib
 
Physical Exam:
On examination, his motor strength is graded ___ in the deltoid,
biceps, triceps, and hand intrinsics bilaterally.  His sensory
examination did not show dermatomal deficit.  His reflexes were
1+ throughout.  His incision is well healed.  There is some
atrophy in the right triceps.

 
Pertinent Results:
CT scan demonstrates malposistioning of R C6 lateral mass screw. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted to neurosurgery service for elective removal of 
previously placed cervical hardware. He tolerated this procedure 
very well with no complications. He was transferred to floor in 
stable condtion.  Pt had issues incomplete voiding requiring 
straight cath.  But was able to urinate spontaneously in the AM.

Now DOD, patient is afebrile, VSS, and neurologically stable.  
Patient's pain is well-controlled and the patient is tolerating 
a good oral diet.  Pt's incision is clean, dry and inctact 
without evidence of infection.  He is set for discharge home in 
stable condition and will follow-up accordingly. 
 
Medications on Admission:
MORPHINE SUL TAB 15MG ER as needed for pain
OXYCODONE TAB 5MG as needed for pain
LOVASTATIN TAB 40MG daily 
Lisinopril 20mg daily
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Malposistioned cervical hardware

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
        Do not smoke
        Keep wound clean / No tub baths or pools until seen in 
follow up/ remove dressing POD#2   / begin daily showers POD#4
        If you have steri-strips in place  keep dry x 72 
hours.  Do not pull them off. They will fall off on their own or 
be taken off in the office
        No pulling up, lifting> 10 lbs., excessive bending or 
twisting for two weeks.
        Limit your use of stairs to ___ times per day
        Have a family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection
        If you are required to wear one, wear cervical collar 
or back brace as instructed
        You may shower briefly without the collar / back brace 
unless instructed otherwise
        Take pain medication as instructed; you may find it 
best if taken in the a.m. when you wake for morning stiffness 
and before bed for sleeping discomfort
        Do not take any anti-inflammatory medications such as 
Motrin, Advil, aspirin, Ibuprofen etc. for 3 months.
        Increase your intake of fluids and fiber as pain 
medicine (narcotics) can cause constipation
        Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed 
at your post-operative office visit
 
CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING:
 
        Pain that is continually increasing or not relieved by 
pain medicine
        Any weakness, numbness, tingling in your extremities
        Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, 
swelling, tenderness, drainage
        Fever greater than or equal to 101° F 
        Any change in your bowel or bladder habits 
 
 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Codeine / Percocet
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
bladder cancer
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
retropubic radical prostatectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
pmh: colon ca s/p subtotal colectomy; bladd ca hg pap s/p 
bcg/interferon
meds: herbals
 
Brief Hospital Course:
He was admitted to Dr. ___ Urology service after undergoing 
open radical prostatectomy. No concerning intraoperative events 
occurred; please see dictated operative note for details. He 
received ancef for perioperative prophylaxis and coumadin for 
deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis. He was transferred to the 
urology floor from the PACU in stable condition. His pain was 
initially controlled with PCA. Diet was advanced with passage of 
flatus. JP was removed without difficulty. The remainder of the 
hospital course was relatively unremarkable. He was discharged 
in stable condition, ambulating independently, eating well, and 
with pain control on oral analgesics. On exam, his incision was 
clean, dry, and intact, with no evidence of hematoma collection 
or infection. He was given explicit instructions to follow-up in 
clinic with Dr. ___ in 1 week, and that the urethral catheter 
(foley) would be removed during the follow-up appointment.  He 
was instructed to start 1 week course of ciprofloxacin as 
antibiotic prophylaxis for foley removal. 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed.  
2. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain>4.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Cipro 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day for 5 
days: Start the morning of appointment.
Disp:*10 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
s/p prostatectomy

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
-You may take motrin and narcotic together for pain control

-You may shower 2 days after surgery, but do not tub bathe, 
swim, soak, or scrub incision for 2 weeks.  

-Allow bandage strips to fall off over time

-No heavy lifting for 4 weeks (no more than 10 pounds)

-___ medical attention for fevers (temp>101.5), worsening pain, 
drainage or excessive bleeding from incision, chest pain or 
shortness of breath.

-Follow up in 1 week for wound check/foley removal

-Please do not drive or consume alcohol while taking pain 
medications.

bladder cancer

retropubic radical prostatectomy
History of Present Illness:
pmh: colon ca s/p subtotal colectomy; bladd ca hg pap s/p
bcg/interferon
meds: herbals
Brief Hospital Course:
He was admitted to Dr. ___ Urology service after undergoing
open radical prostatectomy. No concerning intraoperative events
occurred; please see dictated operative note for details. He
received ancef for perioperative prophylaxis and coumadin for
deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis. He was transferred to the
urology floor from the PACU in stable condition. His pain was
initially controlled with PCA. Diet was advanced with passage of
flatus. JP was removed without difficulty. The remainder of the
hospital course was relatively unremarkable. He was discharged
in stable condition, ambulating independently, eating well, and
with pain control on oral analgesics. On exam, his incision was
clean, dry, and intact, with no evidence of hematoma collection
or infection. He was given explicit instructions to follow-up in
clinic with Dr. ___ in 1 week, and that the urethral catheter
(foley) would be removed during the follow-up appointment. He
was instructed to start 1 week course of ciprofloxacin as
antibiotic prophylaxis for foley removal.
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6
hours) as needed.
2. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain>4.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Cipro 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day for 5
days: Start the morning of appointment.
Disp:*10 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
Facility:
___
Discharge Diagnosis:
s/p prostatectomy
Discharge Condition:
stable
Discharge Instructions:
-You may take motrin and narcotic together for pain control
-You may shower 2 days after surgery, but do not tub bathe,
swim, soak, or scrub incision for 2 weeks.
-Allow bandage strips to fall off over time
-No heavy lifting for 4 weeks (no more than 10 pounds)
-___ medical attention for fevers (temp>101.5), worsening pain,
drainage or excessive bleeding from incision, chest pain or
shortness of breath.
-Follow up in 1 week for wound check/foley removal
-Please do not drive or consume alcohol while taking pain
medications.
-Take ciproflaoxacin for 1 week as protection against infection
with foley catheter - Wear Large foley bag for majority of time,
leg bag is only for short-term when leaving house.

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Codeine / Percocet
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Dizziness, Fall
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
___ healthy male w/ PMH of multiple malignancies, extensive 
cervical and lumbar spondylosis presented to the ED today after 
a fall associated with lightheadedness but without LOC, 
numbness, weakness or vision changes. He has h/o multiple falls 
as he is very predisoposed to falls due to his spondylosis with 
known weakness and impaired proprioceptive deficits ___ distal 
neuropathy. He has ___ month history of episodes of 
lightheadedness and unsteadiness for which he has been seeing 
neurology as an outpatient. He reports that he has these 
episodes of dizziness intermittently when he gets up from 
sitting position and walks. However the dizzines was not as bad 
as it was today. He also denied any symptoms of vertigo, 
palpatations, CP or SOB. Of note, he had a colonoscopy yesterday 
with 3 enemas and decreased PO intake. 
.
ED: Neuro was consulted who did not think that his dizziness was 
related to any acute neurological issues and that the episodes 
of lightheadedness and gait instability were multifactorial. His 
CT Pelvis showed comminuted fracture of left greater trochanter 
and Ortho recommended non-operative management. He was admitted 
for ___ eval and rehab placement.
 
Past Medical History:
-Cervical spondylosis
-Lumbar stenosis
-Prostate cancer status post recent prostatectomy on ___
-Bladder cancer, reports that he is to start BCG and interferon
next week
-Colon cancer status post multiple resections
-Severe osteoarthritis
-DISH
-status post lumbar laminectomy in ___
-Bilateral cataracts status post surgeries in ___ and ___
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Not contributory
 
Physical Exam:
98.2  120/72  71  20  97RA
Orthostatics negative
.
HEENT: NC/AT, no scleral icterus noted, MMM
Neck: Supple, no carotid bruits appreciated.
Pulmonary: Lungs CTA bilaterally without R/R/W  
Cardiac: RRR, nl. S1S2, no M/R/G noted  
Abdomen: soft, NT/ND, normoactive bowel sounds.
Extremities: mildly swollen L hand (pt states chronic). Pt able 
to ambulate with walker with modest discomfort.
Neurologic:  AOx3. CN ___ intact. 
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 10:55AM BLOOD WBC-8.0# RBC-4.30* Hgb-12.9* Hct-37.2* 
MCV-87# MCH-30.1 MCHC-34.7 RDW-13.9 Plt ___
___ 10:55AM BLOOD Neuts-79.9* Lymphs-12.7* Monos-5.1 
Eos-1.1 Baso-1.2
___ 10:55AM BLOOD ___ PTT-24.9 ___
___ 10:55AM BLOOD Glucose-101 UreaN-18 Creat-0.9 Na-137 
K-4.0 Cl-102 HCO3-29 AnGap-10
___ 10:55AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-149
___ 10:55AM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01
___ 10:55AM BLOOD Calcium-9.1 Phos-2.4* Mg-1.9
.
Chest Xray
No acute intrathoracic process. Hyperinflated lungs, stable.
.
Left Hand Xray
No fracture or dislocation identified. Degenerative changes.
.
Left Hip Xray
No definitive acute fracture or dislocation is seen. However, an 
occult left femoral fracture of the greater trochanter was 
subsequently identified on CT pelvis performed the same day.
.
CT Pelvis
1. Comminuted fracture of the left greater trochanter. 
2. 7.5-cm left pelvic collection which may represent hematoma or 
lymphocele containing hemorrhagic debris and is likely related 
to recent prostatectomy.
.
CT Head
No acute intracranial process. No fractures.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ M w/ multiple previous episodes of dizzines now with severe 
episode of dizziness causing fall and comminuted fracture of the 
left greater trochanter.  Pt has a known hx of chronic dizziness 
for which he has been evaluated by neurology in the past.  Pt 
was evaluated by Neurology in the ED, and thought to be 
multifactorial and similar to previous episodes.  
.  
# Dizziness: multifactorial
Pt was unable to have orthostatics performed on admission due to 
severe L hip pain, so pt empirically rec'd 2 L IVF on admission. 
 Later, when hip pain was improved, pt's orthostatics were 
negative, however this was after receiving IVF. Pt was monitored 
on telemetry, with no events.  Pt remained neurologically 
stable. 
.  
# Comminuted fracture of the left greater trochanter:  
Ortho was consulted in the ED, and continued to follow pt on the 
floor.  They recommended weight bearing as tolerated, no active 
abduction of left hip.  Pt received physical therapy and 
tylenol/Ibuprofen for pain control with good effect.  Over 
subsequent days, pt's pain dramatically improved, and pt was 
able to bear weight (previously unable), and able to ambulate 
with a walker.  Pt was provided DVT prophylaxis with Lovenox, 
however he often refused injection. 

.  
# L hand swelling  
Pt was noted to have signif L hand swelling, but pt stated that 
this is chronic in the mornings.  Pt injured his hand in fall, 
but no fx on Xray.  
.  
# Osteoarthritis  
- continued Ibuprofen with benefit
.  
# Dispo: to rehab today  

 
Medications on Admission:
- Ibuprofen 200 mg prn pain
- Vitamin, including B12
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain.  
2. Ibuprofen 400 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 8 
hours) as needed for pain.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
# Comminuted fracture of Left greater trochanter
# Dizziness, multifactorial
# Osteoarthritis

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
Continue to work with physical therapy and follow up with 
orthopedics and your neurologist.  Please seek medical attention 
if you develop worsened pain or inability to bear weight.  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

history of chronic hypertension she was continued on her home
dose of metoprolol 75mg daily. She continued levothyroxine
112mcg for her history of hypothyroidism. She had improvement in
her contractions and was discharged home on ___ with planned
outpatient follow up. Of note, her cervical exam at time of
discharge was unchanged at 2cm externally and closed internally,
long and posterior.

2. Metoprolol Succinate XL 75 mg PO DAILY

preterm contractions
chronic hypertension

stable

to preterm contractions and concern for preterm labor. Your
contractions improved significantly and you had no evidence of
preterm labor. Fetal testing was reassuring. You received a
course of betamethasone (steroid) for fetal lung maturity.
Please maintain pelvic rest (nothing in the vagina) and avoid
strenuous exercise. Stay well hydrated.

polypectomy. This appears to be slowing and your blood counts 
and vital signs have been stable, which are reassuring. You may 
have some mild, light bleeding for a several days, and this is 
safe if you feel well and the amount of blood is not increasing. 
Please hold your aspirin at present and attempt to limit your 
ibuprofen, as discussed. Your primary care doctor ___ discuss 
restarting the Aspirin with you.

Chief Complaint:
erectile dysfunction; failed penile prosthesis
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
 Removal and replacement of inflatable penile prosthesis.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo male with history of prostate CA s/p radical 
prostatectomy, with post-operative ED. Patient has 2 previous 
IPP placement, now here for replacement again.
 
Past Medical History:
PMHx:
PCa
HLD
HTN
Arthritis/Gout
CKD

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
WdWn male, NAD, AVSS
Interactive, cooperative
Abdomen soft, Nt/Nd
Hemiscrotum Incision c/d/i w/out evidence hematoma or infection
Lower extremities w/out edema or pitting and no report of calf 
pain
 
Pertinent Results:
None for this admission
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to Dr. ___ service for 
removal and replacement of penile prosthesis. No concerning 
intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated operative 
note for details.  Vancomycin and Gentamicin were administered 
for ___ infection prophylaxis.  Mr. ___ tolerated 
the procedure well and was recovered in the PACU before transfer 
to the general surgical floor.  The post-op course was 
uncomplicated.  His foley catheter was removed immediately 
postoperatively and Mr. ___ voided without difficulty. At 
discharge, patient's pain was well controlled with oral pain 
medications, tolerating regular diet, ambulating without 
assistance, and voiding without difficulty. Incision at 
discharge without erythema or hematoma.  He will follow-up with 
his urologist as directed and complete a one week course of 
antibiotics.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
2. Losartan Potassium 100 mg PO DAILY 
3. amLODIPine 10 mg PO DAILY 
4. Colchicine 0.6 mg PO ASDIR 
5. Allopurinol ___ mg PO DAILY 
6. Gemfibrozil 600 mg PO BID 
7. Calcitriol 0.25 mcg PO DAILY 
8. flaxseed oil 1,000 mg oral DAILY 
9. Fish Oil (Omega 3) 1000 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild/Fever  
2.  Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H Duration: 7 Days 
RX *ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg ONE tablet(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*14 Tablet Refills:*0 
3.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg one capsule(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0 
4.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ONE tablet(s) by mouth Q6HRS Disp #*25 Tablet 
Refills:*0 
5.  Allopurinol ___ mg PO DAILY  
6.  amLODIPine 10 mg PO DAILY  
7.  Calcitriol 0.25 mcg PO DAILY  
8.  Colchicine 0.6 mg PO DAILY  
9.  Fish Oil (Omega 3) 1000 mg PO DAILY  
10.  flaxseed oil 1,000 mg oral DAILY  
11.  Gemfibrozil 600 mg PO BID  
12.  Losartan Potassium 100 mg PO DAILY  
13. HELD- Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY  This medication was held. Do 
not restart Aspirin until ___.

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Erectile dysfunction with failed penile prosthesis.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Please also refer to the instructions provided to you by the 
manufacturer of this prosthesis

-Do not Manipulate the pump in your scrotum. Remove the 
bandage-dressing on ___. 

-ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication 
changes and your post-operative course with your primary care 
doctor.

-over the next several days you may experience some increased 
swelling of your phallus (and scrotum) resembling a semi-rigid 
phallus (semi-erect); this is "normal" from the prosthesis and 
related surgery/edema. This may be accompanied by discoloration 
(ecchymosis) involving the phallus and the scrotum; this too is 
normal and will gradually resolve.

-Please remove the surgical dressing over penis and/or under 
scrotum on post-operative day two: no further wound care is 
needed and you may leave the wound open to air. 

-Please keep your phallus at midline, pointed toward your 
umbilicus, taped in place with protective gauze/pads (if 
necessary) for the next ___ days. Of course you may point it 
downward for voiding.

-Use a jock-supporter/strap or jockey-type briefs or tight, 
tighty-whities to facilitate this; Subsequently you may 
transition to loose fitting briefs or boxer-briefs for 
support--they should be cotton and/or breathable.

-Do NOT use prosthesis for 6 weeks and until explicitly advised 
by your urologist

-Complete a 7 day course of antibiotics as directed 
(Ciprofloxacin)

-You may shower, but do NOT bathe, swim or otherwise immerse 
your incision.

-Do NOT lift anything heavier than a phone book and no sports, 
vigorous physical activity (including sexual).

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4. 
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication. Max daily Tylenol 
dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol (acetaminophen)

-Do NOT drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do NOT 
operate dangerous machinery. For your safety, please do NOT 
DRIVE FOR ONE WEEK AFTER SURGERY or unless otherwise advised. 

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post-surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, 
discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool "softener"- it is NOT a laxative

-Resume your home medications, EXCEPT HOLD NSAIDs (aspirin, and 
ibuprofen containing products such as Advil & Motrin, Excedrin) 
for ONE week or until you see your urologist in follow-up OR you 
are explicitly advised to resume sooner by your PCP, ___ 
or Cardiologist.  DO NOT RESUME medications like VIAGRA, LEVITRA 
or CIALIS.

-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
go to the nearest emergency room.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

transition to loose fitting briefs or boxer-briefs for
support--they should be cotton and/or breathable.
-Do NOT use prosthesis for 6 weeks and until explicitly advised
by your urologist
-Complete a 7 day course of antibiotics as directed
(Ciprofloxacin)
-You may shower, but do NOT bathe, swim or otherwise immerse
your incision.
-Do NOT lift anything heavier than a phone book and no sports,
vigorous physical activity (including sexual).
-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4.
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication. Max daily Tylenol
dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain medication also contains
Tylenol (acetaminophen)
-Do NOT drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do NOT
operate dangerous machinery. For your safety, please do NOT
DRIVE FOR ONE WEEK AFTER SURGERY or unless otherwise advised.
-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post-surgical constipation
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication,
discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a
stool "softener"- it is NOT a laxative
-Resume your home medications, EXCEPT HOLD NSAIDs (aspirin, and
ibuprofen containing products such as Advil & Motrin, Excedrin)
for ONE week or until you see your urologist in follow-up OR you
are explicitly advised to resume sooner by your PCP, ___
or Cardiologist. DO NOT RESUME medications like VIAGRA, LEVITRA
or CIALIS.
-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness,
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or
go to the nearest emergency room.
Followup Instructions:
___

6 hours).

Home With Service
 
Facility:
___

Right distal tibia fracture

Good

you have a temperature greater than 101.5, please call the

___ ORIF Right distal tibia fracture with removal of

History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man who sustained a fall off a 
ladder while at work ___ suffering a right distal tibia 
frature.  He was placed in an external fixator to wait for 
swelling to go down and skin to heal.  He now presents for 
operative fixation.
 
Past Medical History:
Denies
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
n/a
 
Physical Exam:
Upon admission

Alert and oriented
Cardiac:  Regular rate rhythm
Chest:  Lungs clear
Abdomen:  Soft non-tender non-distended
Extremities:  RLE in ex-fix pin sites intact, +edema, skin 
intact
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 12:01PM BLOOD WBC-8.7 RBC-4.34* Hgb-12.7* Hct-39.4* 
MCV-91 MCH-29.4 MCHC-32.4 RDW-13.1 Plt ___
___ 09:30AM BLOOD Glucose-100 UreaN-10 Creat-0.6 Na-137 
K-4.0 Cl-99 HCO3-24 AnGap-18
___ 12:01PM BLOOD Glucose-111* UreaN-14 Creat-0.8 Na-140 
K-4.1 Cl-104 HCO3-27 AnGap-13
___ 09:30AM BLOOD Calcium-9.2 Phos-4.0 Mg-1.9
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ presented to the ___ on ___ for a elective ORIF 
of his right distal tibia fracture and removal of the external 
fixator.  Prior to surgery he was prepped and consented.  He was 
taken to the operating room an underwent the procedure an 
incisional VAC was placed over the wound.  He was extubated, 
transferred to the recovery room and then to the floor.  On the 
floor he was seen by physical therapy to improve his strength 
and mobility.  His incisional VAC was removed on ___ and he 
was placed in a short leg cast.  The rest of his hospital stay 
was uneventful with his lab data and vital signs within normal 
limits and his pain controlled.  He is being discharged today in 
stable condition.
 
Medications on Admission:
dilaudid
lovenox
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain.  
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL Syringe Sig: One (1) syringe 
Subcutaneous once a day for 4 weeks.
Disp:*28 syringe* Refills:*0*
4. Hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right pilon fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
Call or come back if increasing pain, fevers, chills, or any 
other concerns.  

Keep your right leg elevated and keep you cast clean and dry.

Follow up this week for cast removal and wound check.

Take pain medications as directed.  Take a stool softener daily. 
 Use lovenox as directed.  Resume any home medications.  Do not 
drive until cleared by you physician.
Physical Therapy:
Non weight bearing RLE.  Crutches. Cast clean and dry and 
elevated at rest. Home safety evaluation.
Treatments Frequency:
Lovenox teaching
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Service: SURGERY

No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
abdominal pain / fevers
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
___ w no significant PMH p/w RLQ x 16days and OSH CT ___
showing possible appendicitis.  Patient was in usual state of
good health until 16 days ago when he noted onset of
RLQ/epigastric pain.  Describes pain as ___ in severity,
constant and located in epigastrium/RLQ.  As pain persisted
patient sought evaluation by his PMD who performed UA
demonstrating microscopic hematuria.  CT Urogram ___ was 
obtained
that was negative for GU pathology but showed ruptured
appendicitis with associated phlegmon.  Was seen by Dr.
___ as an outpatient who recommended po antibiotics
given benign appearance of patient.  In last day patient noted 
to
be febrile at home to 102.0 and was instructed by Dr. ___ to
report to ___ ED for further evaluation/admission.  

At present, patient notes ___ RLQ/suprapubic pain that is
constant in nature.  Associated symptoms include fevers at home
as above, decreased appettite, mild nausea, and generalized
fatigue.  Tolerating minimal po, passing flatus/BMs normally. 
Denies headache, chest pain, shortness of breath, vomiting,
dysuria.  

 
Past Medical History:
neck lipoma (not interested in surgery)

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother: no major medical issues; Father: prostate CA in
___

 
Physical Exam:
T 99.1  HR 90  BP 124/80  RR 18  O2sat 97% RA
GEN: WD, WN in NAD
HEENT: NCAT, EOMI, anicteric
CV: RRR
PULM: CTA B/L w no W/R/R, no respiratory distress
ABD: soft, +mild RLQ/suprapubic tenderness to palpation, ND,
no mass, no hernia
PELVIS: rectal tone normal, no gross blood, no masses, prostate
WNL, guaiac negative
EXT: WWP, no edema, 2+ B/L DP
NEURO: A&Ox3, no focal neurologic deficits

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 08:00AM BLOOD WBC-9.4 RBC-3.61* Hgb-11.0* Hct-30.6* 
MCV-85 MCH-30.4 MCHC-35.8* RDW-12.1 Plt ___
___ 08:00AM BLOOD Glucose-86 UreaN-9 Creat-0.8 Na-137 K-4.1 
Cl-99 HCO3-25 AnGap-17
___ 08:00AM BLOOD Calcium-8.6 Phos-3.3 Mg-2.2
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt is a ___ who was admitted on ___ for IV antibiotics and 
observation after experiencing worsening abdominal pain and 
fevers with known perforated appendicitis.  He received IV cipro 
and flagyl, and his WBC count improved from admission through 
hospital day 3.  He was initially made NPO and given IV fluids 
and morphine for pain control.  On HD2, he was advanced to a 
regular diet but had poor PO intake.  On HD3, his appetite 
improved, and his pain and white blood count both normalized.  
He was discharged home on HD3 tolerating a regular diet, no 
longer requiring any pain medications, and ambulating 
independently.  He will follow up with Dr. ___ as an outpatient 
for surgical planning.
 
Medications on Admission:
Cipro 500'' (started ___, Flagyl 500''' (started ___
 
Discharge Medications:
1. ciprofloxacin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q12H 
(every 12 hours).  
2. metronidazole 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 
8 hours).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
ruptured appendicitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure seeing you during your admission to ___. You 
were admitted for abdominal pain due to your appendicitis. You 
were given IV fluids, pain medication and your symptoms and lab 
values showed improvement.   You are being discharged home on a 
regular diet, and you should continue to take your antibiotics 
as prescribed.

Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication.  Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.  

Please call your doctor or return to the ED if you experience 
fevers, increasing abdominal pain, nausea/vomiting, blood in 
vomit or stool, increasing abdominal distention, or stop passing 
flatus or stool.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Abdominal pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Laparoscopic appendectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with history of perforated appendicitis treated 
conservatively presents for interval laparoscopic appendectomy. 
Patient was treated at the time of his appendicitis with 
antibiotics and bowel rest due to perforation. He responded well 
to treatment and was seen in the clinic twice in the interim to 
confirm resolution of symptoms. He presents now 2 months after 
initial appendicitis for interval appendectomy.
 
Past Medical History:
Neck lipoma 

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother: no major medical issues; Father: prostate CA in ___

 
Physical Exam:
On Discharge:
Gen: Appears well, NAD
CV: RRR
Resp: CTAB
Abd: Soft, nontender, nondistended, incisions c/d/i
Ext: Warm, no edema
 
Pertinent Results:
None
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ underwent laparoscopic appendectomy on ___ 
without complications. He was extubated in the OR and brought to 
the PACU in good condition. While in PACU, he complained of 
nausea and weakness. He was treated with zofran with good 
effect, however the patient did not feel comfortable returning 
home. He was admitted overnight for observation. His pain was 
well controlled and his nausea did not recur. He tolerated a 
regular diet and was discharged home on POD#1.
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain.  
3. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Ruptured appendicitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___,

You were admitted for observation after your sppendix was 
removed. You're now ready to continue your recovery at home.

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.

Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower tomorrow, and wash surgical incisions with a 
mild soap and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.
*You may remove your dressings on ___
*You have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. Please 
remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
open left ankle fx
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
I&D, ex-fix, ORIF, posterior tib tendon repair ___, ___

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo M presents as transfer for ankle fracture. Patient states 
that he was on a ladder at work and slipped getting his ankle 
caught through a rung a felt a pop. Patient had XRays done at 
___ with exam revealing open ankle fracture. Denies weakness 
or numbness

 
Past Medical History:
GERD, HLD, s/p L rotator cuff repair, hernia surgery

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
LLE:
NVI distally
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have open left ankle fx and was admitted to the orthopedic 
surgery service. The patient was taken to the operating room on 
___ for I&D, ORIF left ankle fx, posterior tibialis tendon 
repair, which the patient tolerated well. For full details of 
the procedure please see the separately dictated operative 
report. The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable 
condition and after satisfactory recovery from anesthesia was 
transferred to the floor. The patient was initially given IV 
fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet 
and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was given 
___ antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine. The 
patient's home medications were continued throughout this 
hospitalization. The patient worked with ___ who determined that 
discharge to home with services was appropriate. The ___ 
hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
NVI distally in the left lower extremity, and will be discharged 
on lovenox for DVT prophylaxis. The patient will follow up with 
Dr. ___ routine. A thorough discussion was had with the 
patient regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge 
course including reasons to call the office or return to the 
hospital, and all questions were answered. The patient was also 
given written instructions concerning precautionary instructions 
and the appropriate follow-up care. The patient expressed 
readiness for discharge.
 
Medications on Admission:
simvastatin, omeprazole
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H  
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
3.  Enoxaparin Sodium 40 mg SC QPM 
Start: Today - ___, First Dose: Next Routine Administration 
Time 
RX *enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL 40 mg SC QPM Disp #*21 Syringe 
Refills:*0 
4.  Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY  
5.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth Q4H: PRN Disp #*70 
Tablet Refills:*0 
6.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID  
7.  Calcium Carbonate 500 mg PO QID:PRN stomach sx  
8.  LORazepam 0.5 mg PO Q8H:PRN Anxiety  
9.  Omeprazole 20 mg PO BID  
10.  Simvastatin 20 mg PO QPM  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
open left ankle fx s/p I&D, ex-fix, ORIF, posterior tib tendon 
repair ___, ___

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- NWB LLE in ex-fix

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take lovenox daily for 3 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.

Physical Therapy:
Activity:   Activity:  Activity as tolerated
 Left lower extremity:  Non weight bearing
Treatments Frequency:
  Wound care: 
 Site: External Fixator 
 Comment: Gently clean each pin site daily beginning POD2. 
Please use a seperate sterile cotton tipped applicator for each 
pin with ___ strength hydrogen peroxide. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Vaginal bleeding
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
Pt is a ___ G2P0010 at 22+1 weeks gestation who presents
to triage with vaginal bleeding. States the bleeding started at
approximately 4:00am today, bleeding was bright red and passed
some small clots. Reports some cramping earlier which
spontaneously resolved. No pain or cramping now. Denies back
pain, dysuria, fevers. Pt feels well otherwise. No dizzyness. 
Has
been out of work for the past few weeks. Pt has had multiple
episodes of vaginal bleeding since approximately 10 weeks.

 
Past Medical History:
PRENATAL COURSE
___ ___
(2)Labs: O neg, RPRNR, RI, HepB neg, VZV immune, HIV neg, CF 
neg,
+PPD ___, pap WNL ___
(3)Screening:
- quad: T21=1:10K, T18 not increased, AFP=1.12 MoM
- FFS as above + 2 fibroids
(4)Transfer of care at 21+6wks from ___
- diagnosed with short cervix, CL 2.2cm, at FFS; seen by Dr
___ pt declined cerclage
- U/S by Dr ___ on ___: breech, nl AFI, anterior placenta 
with
no previa, CL 4.4cm, EFW 407g
ISSUES
*)vaginal bleeding: multiple episodes since ~10wks, likely
chronic abruption
*)possible fetal cardiac anomaly; pericardial effusion at time 
of
FFS; nl cardiac views at ___ on ___
*) SS trait: fob not tested
*) +ppd; needs CXR, referral to ID
*) Rh negative, s/p rhogam ___

OBHX: G2P0
G1 SAB at 10wks, no D&C

GYNHX: denies hx STDs, abn paps
PMH: none
SurgHx: none

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Noncontributory
 
Physical Exam:
PE: Gen: appears well, NAD
VS: T 98.0, BP 98/64, HR 97, RR 18
LUNGS: CTAB
HEART: RRR
ABD: soft, gravid, nontender
SSE: (by Dr ___ cervix appears closed; not friable; no active
bleeding from os. ping-pong ball size clot removed
FH: spot check 140s

Ms. ___ is a ___ G2P0 who was admitted at ___ with vaginal

transferred to the antepartum unit for further monitoring and 
evaluation. On HD#2, she complained of significant cramping and 
increased vaginal bleeding. She was transferred back to L&D,

She and her husband did wish to end the pregnancy, but while

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Compazine
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
symptomatic fibroid uterus and gender affirmation
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Total laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral 
salpingo-oophorectomy, cystoscopy

 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ gravida 0
transgendered man who initially saw me for preoperative
consultation on ___.  At that time, we discussed his
chronic pelvic pain/uterine cramping in the face of a small
fibroid uterus.  In addition, he would like to align his 
physical
with his gender identification.  We once again discussed the
operative procedure including risks.  We discussed the 
anesthetic
that will be used, which will be general anesthesia.  The 
patient
voiced concern about nausea after the anesthetic because of his
history of nausea and GI issues.  I encouraged him to discuss
this with the anesthesia team.

The patient is known as ___, prefers to be called MJ. 
He brought in a letter of support from primary care physician,
___ who noted that "MJ has been on the 
male
spectrum both socially and psychologically.  It is my opinion
that Merdith meets the criteria for gender identity disorder. 
The only effective treatment for this condition is a combination
of psychotherapeutic and medical intervention to enable ___
to live as a person on the male spectrum - the role in which he
must comfortably and effectively function.  Merdith presents 
full
time as a person on the male spectrum and has had good initial
masculinization through testosterone treatment.  Merdith has
expressed a strong desire to have a TAH/BSO to enhance the
successful transformation to a more male role.  Merdith's 
support
system ___, therapist) are aware of the gender condition and 
are
supportive of the gender transition."  This letter will be
scanned into OMR.
 
Past Medical History:
breast cysts, depression, anxiety, hemorrhoids, heart murmur 
(aortic insufficiency), h/o suicide attempts, esophagitis
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
VSS
Gen: NAD
CV: RRR
Lungs: CTA
Abd: soft, NT, ND
Ext: no edema or tenderness
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Mr. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service 
after undergoing total laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral 
salpingo-oophorectomy, cystoscopy. Please see the operative 
report for full details.
His post-operative course was uncomplicated. Immediately 
post-op, his pain was controlled with IV dilaudid/toradol.
On post-operative day 1, his urine output was adequate so his 
foley was removed and he voided spontaneously. His diet was 
advanced without difficulty and he was transitioned to PO 
oxycodone/ibuprofen/acetaminophen. 
By post-operative day 1, he was tolerating a regular diet, 
voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was 
controlled with oral medications. He was then discharged home in 
stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.
 
Medications on Admission:
clonazepam, Ativan, Zofran, testosterone, trazodone, fluticasone
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q6H pain 
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 6 hours 
Disp #*50 Tablet Refills:*0
2. ClonazePAM 1 mg PO BID 
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a day Disp 
#*50 Tablet Refills:*1
4. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H pain 
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 6 hours Disp 
#*50 Tablet Refills:*1
5. Lorazepam 1 mg PO BID:PRN anxiety 
6. Senna 17.2 mg PO QHS 
RX *sennosides [senna] 8.6 mg 2 tab by mouth at bedtime Disp 
#*50 Tablet Refills:*0
7. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
Do not drive while taking. 
RX *hydromorphone 2 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 4 hours Disp 
#*30 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Fibroid uterus
Gender affirmation surgery

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecology service after your 
procedure. You have recovered well and the team believes you are 
ready to be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ 
office with any questions or concerns. Please follow the 
instructions below.

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 3 
months.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No tub baths for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Ms. ___ is a ___ G1 @ ___ with di-di twins and history of 
chronic hypertension who presented for induction of labor due to 
exacerbation of chronic hypertension leading to a diagnosis of 
gestational hypertension at term. Evaluations for preeclampsia 
were negative. As her blood pressure was not responsive to 
antihypertensive medication and she was at term the decision was 
made to proceed with delivery. The patient started as an 
induction of labor but this progressed slowly and the patient 
elected for a cesarean section. She was extensively counseled 
regarding this decision. She underwent a primary cesarean 
section on ___. For full details of the procedure please see 
___ report. 

Post-partum, Ms. ___ antihypertensive medication was 
initially held, but was restarted post-op day #4 due to rising 
blood pressure. Post-partum, the patient developed epigastric 
pain and nausea. Her pre-eclampsia labs were wnl. Her alk phos 
was found to be elevated. She underwent a right upper quadrant 
ultrasound which showed gallstones but no evidence of 
cholecystitis. General surgery was consulted who recommended 
outpatient follow-up with Dr. ___. The patient had been 
diagnosed with GDMA1 and fingersticks were in good range 
postpartum. She will have 6 wk follow up regarding her 
diabetes.The patient was discharged home in stable condition 
with her pain and nausea much improved on post-operative day #5.

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
L calcaneus fracture
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Splint application ___

 
History of Present Illness:
___ male presents with the above fracture s/p mechanical
fall. Pt states he was changing a light bulb this morning and
fell off of the ladder and landing onto his left foot with
immediate pain and swelling. He denies head strike or LOC. He 
was
unable to ambulate afterwards and called ambulance who brought
him to ___ where he was found to have a left
comminuted calcaneal fracture.
 
Past Medical History:
None
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
GEN: NAD, Well-aopearing

LLE:
- Splint clean and dry
- Thigh soft and compressible
- Fires ___
- SILT S/S/SP/DP/T distributions
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 04:54PM BLOOD WBC-16.3* RBC-5.06 Hgb-15.2 Hct-43.9 
MCV-87 MCH-30.0 MCHC-34.6 RDW-12.9 RDWSD-40.0 Plt ___
___ 04:54PM BLOOD UreaN-16 Creat-1.1
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have left calcaneus fracture and was admitted to the 
orthopedic surgery service. The patient was splinted in the ED 
and discussed potential surgical options with the Trauma team. 
After discussion with the Foot and Ankle Service, the patient 
and team decided that the best course of option would be to 
follow up with Dr. ___ of the Foot and Ankle Service. 

The ___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels 
spontaneously. The patient is non-weight bearing in the left 
lower extremity, and will be discharged on aspirin 325 for DVT 
prophylaxis. The patient will follow up with Dr. ___ 
for further evaluation and surgical treatment planning. A 
thorough discussion was had with the patient regarding the 
diagnosis and expected post-discharge course including reasons 
to call the office or return to the hospital, and all questions 
were answered. The patient was also given written instructions 
concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate 
follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H  
2.  Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY 
RX *aspirin 325 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*14 
Tablet Refills:*0 
3.  HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) ___ mg PO Q3H:PRN Pain - Moderate 
RX *hydromorphone [Dilaudid] 2 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 
four (4) hours PRN Disp #*25 Tablet Refills:*0 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
L Calcaneus Fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
AVSS
NAD
LLE: Splint clean and dry. Fires FHL, ___. SILT ___ n 
distributions. Toes WWP distally.

 
Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
-Non-weight bearing of the left lower extremity

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take aspirin 325 daily until your follow-up appointment

WOUND CARE:
- You are in a splint. It must be left on until follow up 
appointment unless otherwise instructed. Please DO NOT get the 
splint wet.
- You may shower but keep the splint dry.

Physical Therapy:
Activity:   Left lower extremity:  Non weight bearing

Treatments Frequency:
None
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Left calcaneal wound

Left calcaneal wound irrigation & debridement

 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old male with hx. left
calcaneus fracture s/p ORIF ___ who presents with drainage 
from
left foot surgical wound concerning for surgical site infection.

The patient reports falling from a ladder in a warehouse on
___.  He sustained an injury to his left foot and was
diagnosed with comminuted left calcaneal fracture s/p splinting. 

He then presented on ___ and underwent ORIF of left calcaneal
fracture which was reportedly uncomplicated.

The patient reports he developed a foul odor from his surgical
incision about ___ weeks after suture removal.  He was evaluated
in surgery clinic with incisional erythema noted in f/u visit
___ for which he was started on clindamycin 300mg PO TID x7d 
->
___.

He reports a day prior to presentation he felt fatigued and 
noted
new drainage from his incision.  He was directed to the ED where
a CT of his LLE showed extensive fat stranding and edema
surrounding his left calcaneous.  He has been treated with
Vancomycin and is currently NPO for I and D of his surgical 
wound
tomorrow.    

Upon evaluation on the floor, the patient reports feeling better
since admission.  Denies fevers, chills, or other systemic
complaints.

None

___ ___ for formal I&D of the calcaneal wound. ID 
was consulted. PICC was placed. Otherwise, ___ 
hospital course, discharged with PICC, home antibiotics regimen 
with ID follow up, and home nursing services for wound care 
including negative pressure therapy.

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right hand infection
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ - Right hand I&D with Dr. ___

 
___ of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ presents today
approximately 15 days postop.  He was last seen in hand clinic 
on
___.  He reports that over the past couple of days, he 
has
developed significant pain and swelling in his right fourth
digit.  He has also developed some numbness in his thumb of the
right hand and pain in the hand when he takes a deep breath.  He
has been seen by occupational therapy close to his home, who 
have
become concerned that he may have developed an infection.  He
reports that over the past couple of days, he has also had a
low-grade temperature of around 99 degrees, which he has managed
with Tylenol.  He also reports that last night he was able to
express what he refers to as pus from his incision site.

 
Past Medical History:
Anxiety
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-Contributory
 
Physical Exam:
MUSCULOSKELETAL:  Right upper extremity, the patient's sutures
are intact.  There is warmth and redness around the incision 
site
and throughout the fourth digit, which extends into his small
finger as well as his third digit and into the palm of his hand. 

The redness is mild-to-moderate.  There is significant swelling
of the fourth digit and some edema also noted in the fifth 
digit.
 With pressure, serosanguineous fluid is expressed from the
incision site.  No pus is appreciated.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Orthopaedic Hand Service 
post-operatively. Please see operative report for full details. 
The patient tolerated the procedure without difficulty and was 
transferred to the PACU in stable condition, and then 
transferred to the floor in the usual fashion. Postoperatively, 
pain was controlled with parenteral narcotics, with transition 
PO pain meds as tolerated. Perioperative antibiotics and 
TEDS/SCDs for DVT prophylaxis were given as per routine. Diet 
was advanced without complication. The hospitalization has 
otherwise been uneventful and the patient has done well. 

At discharge, vital signs are stable, the patient is afebrile, 
tolerating a regular diet, voiding spontaneously every shift and 
pain is well controlled. The extremities are neurovascularly 
intact distally throughout. All incisions are clean, dry and 
intact without evidence of infection, hematoma or seroma. 

The patient is discharged home in stable condition.  Patient 
given detailed precautionary instructions and instructions for 
the appropriate follow up care.  

 
Medications on Admission:
Percocet, Keflex
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Bactrim DS 800-160 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every 
twelve (12) hours for 10 days.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a ___.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Motrin 800 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every ___ hours 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*100 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Dilaudid 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours as 
needed for pain.
Disp:*80 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right hand infection

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify MD if you 
should experience: severe pain not relieved by medication, 
increased swelling, decreased sensation, difficulty with 
movement, fevers >101.5, shaking chills, redness or drainage at 
the incision site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other 
concerns.
2. Please follow up with your PCP regarding this admission and 
any new medications and refills.
3. Please follow-up in hand clinic as directed.
4. Resume your ___ hospital medications unless otherwise 
instructed.
5. You have been given medications for your pain control. Please 
do not operate heavy machinery, drive, or drink alcohol when 
taking this medication. As your pain improves, please decrease 
the amount of pain medication (by taking fewer tablets and/or 
increasing the time interval between doses). This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink 8 glasses of water daily 
and take a stool softener as needed to prevent this side effect.
6. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon or your primary MD.
7. Please keep your wounds clean. Place dry sterile dressings 
over your wounds and wrap with coban.  Change as needed.
8. Antibiotics: Take antibiotics as directed.
9. Activity: Nonweightbearing right upper extremity.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

had a bowel movement and +flatus, diet was slowly advanced.

was deemed stable for discharge home.

hours) as needed for spasm.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

(Daily).

Home

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
L4-5 disc herniation
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
revision L4-5 decompression / discectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ s/p L4-5 lami ___, now with recurrence and left ___ sx

 
Past Medical History:
HTN, hyperchol, obesity
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and 
taken to the Operating Room for the above procedure without 
complication. For details please refer to the dictated operative 
note. TEDs / pnemoboots were used for postoperative DVT 
prophylaxis. Intravenous antibiotics were continued for 24hrs 
postoperatively per standard protocol. The patient's pain was 
controlled with IV pain medications followed by oral analgesics 
once tolerating POs. The patient's diet was advanced as 
tolerated. The foley was removed on POD#1. Physical therapy was 
consulted for mobilization. The ___ hospital course was 
otherwise unremarkable. On the day of discharge the patient was 
afebrile with stable vital signs, comfortable on oral pain 
control and tolerating a regular diet. The patient was 
discharged with instructions to follow up in clinic as directed.
 
Medications on Admission:
Oxycodone 15 q3 PRN, valium 5 q6 PRN, lipitor 20, hctz 25, 
lisinopril 20, asa

 
Discharge Medications:
1. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*100 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 
hours) as needed for pain, headache, fever.  
3. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
4. diazepam 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for spasm.  
5. atorvastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
6. hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: Two (2) Capsule PO 
DAILY (Daily).  
7. lisinopril 10 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
L4-5 disc herniation

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable
A&O x3
Ambulatory without assist

 
Discharge Instructions:
Immediately after the operation:  
- Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than ~45 minutes without moving around.  
- ___/ Physical Therapy:  
o ___ times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery. You can walk as much as you can tolerate. 
 
o Limit any kind of lifting.  
- Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some 
constipation after surgery. You have been given medication to 
help with this issue.  
- Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days. If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing. If it is dry then 
you can leave the incision open to the air. Once the incision is 
completely dry (usually ___ days after the operation) you may 
take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool. If 
the incision starts draining at anytime after surgery, do not 
get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile dressing and call 
the office.  
- You should resume taking your normal home medications.  
- You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead. You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___. We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. 
In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.  
- Follow up:  
o Please Call the office and make an appointment for 2 weeks 
after the day of your operation if this has not been done 
already.  
o At the 2-week visit we will check your incision, take baseline 
X-rays and answer any questions. We may at that time start 
physical therapy.  
o We will then see you at 6 weeks from the day of the operation 
and at that time release you to full activity.  
Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
Fentanyl / Percocet / Morphine
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right shoulder pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Curettage and allograft packing right proximal humerus 
lesion

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ man who had been treated for a giant cell 
tumor of his proximal humerus in the past. He did well initially 
but slowly over time, he was having more symptoms of pain. MRI 
revealed a likely recurrence. We talked about the risks, 
benefits, and alternatives of this surgical approach with him 
and he wished to proceed.
 
Past Medical History:
Giant cell tumor, right proximal humerus
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted after the above procedure which he tolerated 
well. His pain was well controlled with nerve block and then 
oral analgesics. He tolerated POs and was voiding spontaneously. 
On POD#1, he worked with OT on passive ROM exercises of his 
right shoulder. He was medically ready for safe d/c home on 
POD#1.
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 
hours) as needed for pain for 2 doses.
Disp:*35 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Recurrent giant cell tumor right proximal humerus

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Activity: No weight bearing with your right arm. Wear your sling 
for comfort. You may do passive range of motion exercises as 
shown to you by the occupational therapist. No active range of 
motion until cleared by Dr. ___.

Driving: Do not drive while taking narcotic pain medication. DO 
not drive until cleared by your Orhtoaedic Surgeon.

Medications: Dilaudid. Take as needed for pain. You will need 
less of this as time passes. You may also take Tylenol. Do not 
take Ibuprofen.

Shower: You may shower starting tomorrow. Let water run over 
your incision/wound and pat dry. Do not rub or vigorously scrub 
incision. Do not soak incision until cleared by your Orthopaedic 
Surgeon.

Wound care: Keep the dressing in place for 5 days unless it gets 
soiled. After 5 days, remove the dressing and do dry dressing 
changes as needed. The steri-strips will come off on their own 
with showering.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
Allergies:
Fentanyl / Percocet / Morphine
Attending: ___.
Chief Complaint:
Right shoulder pain
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Curettage and allograft packing right proximal humerus
lesion
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ man who had been treated for a giant cell
tumor of his proximal humerus in the past. He did well initially
but slowly over time, he was having more symptoms of pain. MRI
revealed a likely recurrence. We talked about the risks,
benefits, and alternatives of this surgical approach with him
and he wished to proceed.
Past Medical History:
Giant cell tumor, right proximal humerus
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted after the above procedure which he tolerated
well. His pain was well controlled with nerve block and then
oral analgesics. He tolerated POs and was voiding spontaneously.
On POD#1, he worked with OT on passive ROM exercises of his
right shoulder. He was medically ready for safe d/c home on
POD#1.
Medications on Admission:
None
Discharge Medications:
1. hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4
hours) as needed for pain for 2 doses.
Disp:*35 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Recurrent giant cell tumor right proximal humerus
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Activity: No weight bearing with your right arm. Wear your sling
for comfort. You may do passive range of motion exercises as
shown to you by the occupational therapist. No active range of
motion until cleared by Dr. ___.
Driving: Do not drive while taking narcotic pain medication. DO
not drive until cleared by your Orhtoaedic Surgeon.
Medications: Dilaudid. Take as needed for pain. You will need
less of this as time passes. You may also take Tylenol. Do not
take Ibuprofen.
Shower: You may shower starting tomorrow. Let water run over
your incision/wound and pat dry. Do not rub or vigorously scrub
incision. Do not soak incision until cleared by your Orthopaedic
Surgeon.
Wound care: Keep the dressing in place for 5 days unless it gets
soiled. After 5 days, remove the dressing and do dry dressing
changes as needed. The steri-strips will come off on their own
with showering.
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ presented to the ___ on ___ with left leg pain. 
 He was evaluated by the orthopaedic surgery service and he was 
noted to have tense compartments of his left thigh.  He was then 
admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and taken to the OR 
for fasciotomy of his left thigh. A VAC dressing was placed in 
the OR and he recovered in the PACU without acute events and 
transferred to the floor.  He was taken back to the OR on ___ 
for an I&D with VAC change.  He tolerated the procedure well, 
was extubated, transferred to the recovery room and then to the 
floor.  On ___ he returned to the operating room and 
underwent another I&D with fasciotomy closure.  He tolerated the 
procedure well, was extubated, transferred to the recovery room, 
and then to the floor.  His pain was well controlled with IV and 
then PO pain medications. He was tolerating a regular a diet 
throughout his hospital course.  He was seen by physical therapy 
to improve his strength and mobility.  The rest of his hospital 
stay was uneventful with his lab data and vital signs within 
normal limits and his pain controlled.  He is being discharged 
today in stable condition.

times a day).

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left thigh compartment syndrome
 
Discharge Condition:
Stable
 
Discharge Instructions:
You may bear weight as tolerated on your leg.

Please take all your medication as prescribed

If you have any increased redness, draiange, or swelling, or if 
you have a temperature greater than 101.5, please call the 
office or come to the emergency department

You have been prescribed a narcotic pain medication.  Please 
take only as directed and do not drive or operate any machinery 
while taking this medication.  There is a 72 hour ___ 
through ___, 9am to 4pm) response time for prescription refil 
requests.  There will be no prescription refils on ___, 
___, or holidays.  Please plan accordingly.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ presented to the ___ on ___ for an elective 
quadricepsplasty.  Prior to surgery he was prepped and 
consented.  He was taken to the operating room and underwent the 
procedure.  He was able to flex to 130 in the operating room.  
He was extubated, transferred to the recovery room, and then to 
the floor.  On the floor he was seen by physical therapy to 
improve his strength and mobility.  The rest of his hospital 
stay was uneventful with his lab data and vital signs within 
normal limits and his pain controlled.  He is being discharged 
today in stable condition.

None.

WBAT/AROM Agressive

hours) as needed for Pain.

Capsule, Sustained Release PO DAILY (Daily) for 2 weeks.
Disp:*QS Capsule, Sustained Release(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL Syringe Sig: One (1) 40mg syringe 
Subcutaneous DAILY (Daily) for 2 weeks.

times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left knee arthrofibrosis
 
Discharge Condition:
Stable
 
Discharge Instructions:
Continue to be weight bearing as tolerated on your left leg

Continue your lovenox injections for a total of 2 weeks after 
surgery

Please take all your medication as prescribed

If you have any increased redness, drainage, or swelling, or if 
you have a temperature greater than 101.5, please call the 
office or come to the emergency department.

Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: PLASTIC
 
Allergies: 
Compazine / Ambien
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
gender dysphoria
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
double incision top surgery mastectomies with free 
nipple/alveolar complex grafting

 
History of Present Illness:
MJ is a ___ Caucasian
transgender male who has been on cross sex hormone therapy for ___
years and is now interested in "top surgery" as part of his
gender transition process.  MJ reports that a mammogram 
performed
approximately one year ago was benign.  He presents today to
discuss surgical options for top surgery.
 
Past Medical History:
breast cysts, depression, anxiety, hemorrhoids, heart murmur 
(aortic insufficiency), h/o suicide attempts, esophagitis
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
___ ___ Temp: 98.7 PO BP: 115/74 HR: 106 RR: 18 O2 sat: 
95%
O2 delivery: RA 
Gen: Well-appearing M in no acute distress.
HEENT: Normocephalic. Sclerae anicteric. 
CV: Tachycardic. No murmur. 
R: Breathing comfortably on room air. No wheezing.
Chest: Bilateral mastectomy flaps soft and without palpable 
fluid
collection. Nipple grafts with Xeroform bolsters in place
bilaterally. JP drains to bulb suction draining minimal
serosanguinous fluid. 
Ext: WWP. No calf swelling or tenderness. 

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 03:50PM   CK-MB-1 cTropnT-<0.01
___ 03:50PM   CK(CPK)-232
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital after double incision 
top surgery and free nipple alveolar complex grafts due to 
prolonged tachycardia in the PACU. Typically this is day 
surgery. troponins and CKMB were checked and negative and EKG 
did not show signs of cardiac ischemia. He was admitted for 
observation and his tachycardia improved to low 100s and he 
denied cardiopulmonary complaints. He was able to void and 
tolerate oral intake. Pain was controlled with oral medications. 
After 24 hours of monitoring the patient was discharged home 
with close follow up in plastic surgery clinic. 
 
Medications on Admission:
see OMR
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild  
2.  cefaDROXil 500 mg oral Q12H Duration: 7 Days  
3.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
4.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain  
5.  Scopolamine Patch 1 PTCH TD ONCE Duration: 72 Hours 
remove after 72 hours. do not touch eyes.   
6.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN constipation  
7.  Albuterol Inhaler ___ PUFF IH Q4H:PRN asthma  
8.  Fluticasone Propionate NASAL 1 SPRY NU BID  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
gender dysphoria

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
- Antibiotic: Continue prescribed antibiotics for 1 week after 
discharge. 
- Showering: You may shower 48 hours after surgery from the 
waist down. Do not get yellow nipple dressings wet. ___ sponge 
bathe from waist up. 
- Pain medication: You may take Tylenol and prescribed narcotic 
medication. Avoid NSAIDs such as ibuprofen/Aleve/Motrin/Advil. 
- Activity: Take it easy and do not do any heavy lifting (>5 
lbs) or vigorous activities until cleared by your surgeon. You 
should walk frequently. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / Statins-Hmg-Coa Reductase Inhibitors
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
endometrial intraepthielial neoplasia
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophrectomy

 
Physical Exam:
Discharge physical exam
Vitals: VSS
Gen: NAD, A&O x 3
CV: RRR
Resp: no acute respiratory distress
Abd: soft, appropriately tender, no rebound/guarding, incision 
c/d/i
Ext: no TTP
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service 
after undergoing laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral 
salpingo-oophrectomy. Please see the operative report for full 
details.

Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. Immediately 
post-op, her pain was controlled with IV dilaudid/toradol. She 
had decreased urine output, and was given IV fluids with 
improvement in urine output. 

On post-operative day 1, her urine output was adequate so her 
foley was removed and she voided spontaneously. Her diet was 
advanced without difficulty and she was transitioned to 
oxycodone/acetaminophen/ibuprofen(pain meds).

By post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was 
controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home 
in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.
 
Medications on Admission:
QVAR 80'', albuterol 90mcg prn, lispro ___/ 5, glargine 68 
'

 
Discharge Medications:
(post-op pain medications given pre-operatively by Dr. ___
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___ ,

You were admitted to the gynecology service after your 
procedure. You have recovered well and the team believes you are 
ready to be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ office with 
any questions or concerns. Please follow the instructions below.

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 3 
months.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No tub baths for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

 
Followup Instructions:
___
