text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Left flank pain - Left ureteral stone
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
___ @ 20 weeks gestation presented to outside hospital 3 days 
prior to admission with flank pain and dysuria, empirically 
started on Macrobid. Flank pain worsened over the next few days 
and she presented to the ER. Initially she had a temperature to 
100.9. Renal ultrasound demonstrated a distal left ureteral 
stone with mild hydronephrosis. There was a ureteral jet seen. 
Due to the low grade fever and concern for obstructing stone she 
was admitted to the urology service and placed on IV 
ceftriaxone.
 
Past Medical History:
PCOS
 
Physical Exam:
Gen: Alert, NAD
Chest: nonlabored breathing on room air
Abd: Gravid, soft, no CVA tenderness
Ext: WWP, no edema
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:57AM BLOOD WBC-9.9 RBC-3.76* Hgb-11.0* Hct-33.9* 
MCV-90 MCH-29.3 MCHC-32.4 RDW-14.1 RDWSD-46.7* Plt ___
___ 06:57AM BLOOD Glucose-79 UreaN-6 Creat-0.6 Na-139 K-3.9 
Cl-107 HCO3-20* AnGap-12
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the urology service and started on 
IV ceftriaxone. Initially she was planend to undergo L PCNL 
placement in ___. However, her fever curve improved over the next 
several hours and she had no fevers throughout the remainder of 
her hospitalization. Leukocytosis improved from 14 on admission 
to 11 to 9 by day of discharge. serial ultrasounds were 
performed showing stable position of the ureteral stone but with 
good ureteral jets. OB service followed the patient throughout 
her hospitalization. She was started on nifedipine to facilitate 
stone passage. She was advanced to a regular diet and tolerated 
it without nausea or vomiting. On Hospital day #2 she was 
afebrile with stable vital signs. She had no flank pain or 
nausea and was stable for discharge home.

Urine culture results were pending at the time of discharge.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild  
2.  NIFEdipine (Extended Release) 30 mg PO DAILY 
RX *nifedipine 30 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet 
Refills:*3 
3.  Nitrofurantoin Monohyd (MacroBID) 100 mg PO Q12H Duration: 5 
Days 
RX *nitrofurantoin monohyd/m-cryst [Macrobid] 100 mg 1 
capsule(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*10 Capsule Refills:*0 
4.  Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
left ureteral stone

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-You can expect to see occasional blood in your urine and to 
possibly experience some urgency and frequency

-Strain all urine for stones

-Resume your pre-admission/home medications EXCEPT as noted. You 
should ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication 
changes and your post-operative course with your primary care 
doctor.  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Thyroid isthmic lesion.
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Total thyroidectomy with central node sampling.

 
History of Present Illness:
This patient presented with an isthmic lesion, aspiration of 
which was suspicious for papillary carcinoma. She was 
consequently recommended to undergo total thyroidectomy.

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: Anxiety
PSH: wisdom teeth
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
nc
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: T 98.2 HR 84  BP 97/61  RR 18  O2 sats 100% RA
General: NAD, A&Ox3
Heart: RRR
Lungs: CTAB
Abd: soft, NT/ND, normal bowel sounds
Incision: c/d/i, no hematoma
Ext: c/c/e 
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 
Calcium-8.2*
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted on ___ and taken to the operating 
room for total thyroidectomy with central node sampling. She 
tolerated the procedure. Her diet was slowly advanced to regular 
without any nausea. Her pain was well controlled. 

On the day of discharge, there is no voice hoarseness, no 
perioral or lower extremity paresthesia. The neck is 
soft,incision is intact with steri strips, no erythema, no 
hematoma. She has no nausea and tolerated a regular diet. She is 
voiding and ambulating independently. She had adequate pain 
control and was discharged home in good condition and will 
follow-up with Dr. ___ in 1 month.

 
Medications on Admission:
ativan 1 mg bid

 
Discharge Medications:
1. levothyroxine 100 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
2. calcium carbonate 200 mg (500 mg) Tablet, Chewable Sig: Two 
(2) Tablet, Chewable PO TID (3 times a day).
Disp:*180 Tablet, Chewable(s)* Refills:*2*
3. lorazepam 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q12H (every 12 
hours) as needed for anxiety.  
4. oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet 
PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain: Do not take more than 
4000 mg of tylenol/day.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 8 
hours) as needed for pain.  
6. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day as 
needed for constipation.
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Papillary thyroid carcinoma.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the General Surgery inpatient unit after 
your 
total thyroidectomy. Your tissue was sent to pathology and you 
should have your results in 1 week. Please monitor your neck 
incision for any drainage, swelling or redness. You have steri 
strips on your neck incision, please keep clean and dry. These 
steri-strips will fall off on their own, please do not remove 
them. You may shower but avoid swimming or bathing. You will be 
given a prescription for Percocet for pain. Each Percocet tablet 

contains 5mg oxycodone and 325 mg acetaminophen (Tylenol). 
Please do not drink alcohol or drive while taking this 
medication as it may cause drowsiness. Do not take more than 
4000 mg of acetaminophen in a 24 hour period. Continue to take 
Levothyroxine 100 mcg, take once a day. We have increased your 
Calcium Carbonate, take 1000 mg three times a day. Please 
monitor for signs and symptoms of Hypothyroidism: watch for 
numbness or tingling 
around mouth or legs, confusion, muscle spasm, or changes in 
level of conciousness, these could be signs of low calcium which 

can happen after thyroid surgery. Please monitor for signs and 
symptoms of Hyperthyroidism: anxiety, irritability, trouble 
sleeping, weakness (in particular of the upper arms and thighs, 
making it difficult to lift heavy items or climb stairs), 
tremors (of the hands, perspiring more than normal, difficulty 
tolerating hot weather, rapid or irregular heartbeats, 
fatigue,weight loss in spite of a normal or increased appetite,

Pertinent Results:
___
Calcium-8.2*
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted on ___ and taken to the operating
room for total thyroidectomy with central node sampling. She
tolerated the procedure. Her diet was slowly advanced to regular
without any nausea. Her pain was well controlled.
On the day of discharge, there is no voice hoarseness, no
perioral or lower extremity paresthesia. The neck is
soft,incision is intact with steri strips, no erythema, no
hematoma. She has no nausea and tolerated a regular diet. She is
voiding and ambulating independently. She had adequate pain
control and was discharged home in good condition and will
follow-up with Dr. ___ in 1 month.
Medications on Admission:
ativan 1 mg bid
Discharge Medications:
1. levothyroxine 100 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY
(Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
2. calcium carbonate 200 mg (500 mg) Tablet, Chewable Sig: Two
(2) Tablet, Chewable PO TID (3 times a day).
Disp:*180 Tablet, Chewable(s)* Refills:*2*
3. lorazepam 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q12H (every 12
hours) as needed for anxiety.
4. oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet
PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain: Do not take more than
4000 mg of tylenol/day.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 8
hours) as needed for pain.
6. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day as
needed for constipation.
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Papillary thyroid carcinoma.
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the General Surgery inpatient unit after
your
total thyroidectomy. Your tissue was sent to pathology and you
should have your results in 1 week. Please monitor your neck
incision for any drainage, swelling or redness. You have steri
strips on your neck incision, please keep clean and dry. These
steri-strips will fall off on their own, please do not remove
them. You may shower but avoid swimming or bathing. You will be
given a prescription for Percocet for pain. Each Percocet tablet
contains 5mg oxycodone and 325 mg acetaminophen (Tylenol).
Please do not drink alcohol or drive while taking this
medication as it may cause drowsiness. Do not take more than
4000 mg of acetaminophen in a 24 hour period. Continue to take
Levothyroxine 100 mcg, take once a day. We have increased your
Calcium Carbonate, take 1000 mg three times a day. Please
monitor for signs and symptoms of Hypothyroidism: watch for
numbness or tingling
around mouth or legs, confusion, muscle spasm, or changes in
level of conciousness, these could be signs of low calcium which
can happen after thyroid surgery. Please monitor for signs and
symptoms of Hyperthyroidism: anxiety, irritability, trouble
sleeping, weakness (in particular of the upper arms and thighs,
making it difficult to lift heavy items or climb stairs),
tremors (of the hands, perspiring more than normal, difficulty
tolerating hot weather, rapid or irregular heartbeats,
fatigue,weight loss in spite of a normal or increased appetite,
frequent bowel movements. If you experience any of these signs
or symptoms please contact Dr. ___. You should
scheduled a follow-up appointment with Dr. ___ 1
month after your surgery and with your endocrinologist in ___
weeks.
Followup Instructions:
___

nc

no acute distress

 -dressing-c/d/i
 -NVI distally

___ 06:50AM BLOOD WBC-6.8 RBC-3.83* Hgb-11.6*# Hct-32.4* 
MCV-85 MCH-30.2 MCHC-35.7* RDW-14.6 Plt ___
___ 06:50AM BLOOD Glucose-101* UreaN-14 Creat-0.9 Na-138 
K-3.9 Cl-102 HCO3-28 AnGap-12
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:

1. APS consult to manage indwelling pain catheter

Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with an interscalene 
catheter followed by a transition to oral pain medications on 
POD#1.  The patient received aspirin for DVT prophylaxis 
starting on the morning of POD#1.  The patient was voiding 
independently. Labs were checked throughout the hospital course 
and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient 
was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well.  The patient was 
afebrile with stable vital signs.  The patient's hematocrit was 
acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on an oral 
regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly intact and 
the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is NONweight bearing on the 
operative extremity in a sling at all times. 
 
Mr ___ is discharged to home in stable condition.

 
Medications on Admission:
This patient is not taking any preadmission medications

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
3. Senna 1 TAB PO BID 
4. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-500mg) ___ TAB PO Q6H:PRN pain 

Max 8 tabs/day 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home

1. giant cell tumor
2. osteonecrosis R humeral head

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

please see attached instructions

Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___

Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
pelvic pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Vaginal delivery

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo G1P0 at 39+ weeks presented for induction of labor due 
worsening severe pubic symphysis pain thought to be secondary to 
pubic symphysis separation. The pain started the week prior to 
presentation. She was seen by the ___ service and counseled that 
there is no benefit for c-section versus vaginal delivery as 
there is no evidence it would change outcomes in her condition. 
She was counseled about the risks of induction of labor and 
opted for induction as her pain was severe and worsening. 

 
Past Medical History:
PMHx: some scitica, no mri done

PSHx: denies

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
On admission:
98, 118/78, 85, 16
General: Well-nourished, well-developed woman in NAD
Neck: Supple, no thyromegaly
Cardiac: RRR, no murmurs, rubs or gallops
Chest: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, crackles 
or
rubs
Abdominal exam: S=D, no masses appreciated, no pain, rebound or
guarding EFW by ___ 7 pounds
Extremities: No skin changes and 1+ symmetric pain

Pelvic: ___
pain on pubic symphysis, 
neuro: equal to sensation to motor and reflexes

On discharge:
pain in the symphysis area
BP normal
 
Pertinent Results:
Pelvic X-ray ___
INDICATION:  ___ woman with presumed separation of pubic 
symphysis, 
continued severe pain post-vaginal delivery. 
  
COMPARISON:  None. 
  
TECHNIQUE:  Single supine AP view of the pelvis was acquired. 
  
FINDINGS:  Pubic symphysis is diastatic to about 4.9 cm.  There 
is no 
fracture.  The hip joints and sacroiliac joints are 
unremarkable.  There are 
no concerning bony lesions.  There is a non-obstructive bowel 
gas pattern. 
  
IMPRESSION:  Diastasis of the pubic symphysis. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ underwent an induction of labor and had an uncomplicated 
vaginal delivery on ___. Post-partum, she reported severe 
pubic symphysis pain and difficulty with ambulation. A pelvic 
x-ray showed a separation of the pubic symphysis of 4.9 cm. ___ 
evaluted the patient to assist her with ambulation with a walker 
and recommendations for continued physical therapy for 
rehabilation. She remained in the hospital as her pain control 
regimen was titrated and discharged home on postpartum day 4 
with home physical therapy planned. 

SHe was in a lot of pain that was well controlled by dilaudid 
and then flexeril was added for muscular spasm.  She also had a 
consult with Ortho while in the hospital.

The patient was cleared by ___ from a safety point of view to go 
home via ambulance with home ___ and home ___ arranged as she 
could not walk up and down stairs.

 

 
Medications on Admission:
pre-natal vitamins
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q6H Pain 
2. Cyclobenzaprine 10 mg PO TID:PRN muscle spasm 
RX *cyclobenzaprine 10 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth q8 hours Disp 
#*60 Tablet Refills:*0
3. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) ___ mg PO Q3H:PRN pain 
RX *hydromorphone 2 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth q3-4 hours Disp 
#*60 Tablet Refills:*0
4. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
take with food 
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth q6 hours as needed 
Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*2
5. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID:PRN Constipation 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Pregnancy delivered
Separation of pubic symphysis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Given
 
Followup Instructions:

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:  ___

Admission Date: ___        Discharge Date: ___

Date of Birth:  ___        Sex:  F

Service:  OBS


HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  This ___ para 1 had a
normal delivery on ___ complicated by a severe
separation of the pubic symphysis requiring a walker and
physical therapy.  She was discharged home on the ___.  She
spiked a temperature to 105 degrees, was sent to the
emergency room where she was found to have a pyelonephritis.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  She was begun on intravenous antibiotics.
The remainder of her labs were normal.  Pelvic ultrasound
revealed no other abnormalities.  She remained on intravenous
antibiotics from admission, became afebrile within 24 hours
except for 1 small spike on the ___ to 100.  On the day of
the ___, she had been afebrile for 48 hours.  Urine cultures
revealed 100,000  Escherichia coli pansensitive.  She was
therefore switched to oral ampicillin and to be discharged
home with continued physical therapy, ampicillin, Dilaudid
and Motrin for pain, and Pyridium as needed for her bladder
function.

FINAL DIAGNOSES:
1. Two weeks postpartum.
2. Acute pyelonephritis.
3. Acute symphysis pubis separation.



                        ___, M.D. ___

Dictated By:  ___, M.D.

MEDQUIST36
D:  ___ 08:55:47
T:  ___ 12:14:00
___:  ___

___ hx of bladder, prostate Ca s/p XRT presents with

His past medical history is significant for cancer of the kidney 
s/p radio frequency ablation and prostate s/p XRT and hormone 
therapy is noted.  

Past surgical history is significant for the radiofrequency
ablation of his right kidney, cancer, and radiation therapy and
expiration for the prostate cancer, those are managed by Dr.
___ at ___ and by Dr. ___ at ___ respectively.

___
Family History:
His family history is significant and his mother died at age ___
of breast cancer.  His father died at age ___ from bladder 
cancer.

NAD
Abdomen soft, NT, ND
Voiding orange-tinged urine
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Urology service after TURP. No 
concerning intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated 
operative note for details. The patient received ___ 
antibiotic prophylaxis. Patient's postoperative course was 
uncomplicated. He received intravenous antibiotics and pyridium, 
and continous bladder irrigation overnight. On POD1, the CBI and 
foley catheter were discontinued, and he passed a voiding trial. 
 His urine was orange tingedwithout clots with post-void 
residual less than voided volumes. He remained afebrile 
throughout his hospital stay.  At discharge, patient's pain well 
controlled with oral pain medications, tolerating regular diet, 
ambulating without assistance, and voiding without difficulty.

 tamsulosin [Flomax]

as needed for pain

colace 100mg po bid

Satisfacotry.
Ambulatory.
A/Ox3.

admitted to gyn with right sided persistent flank attributed
most likely secondary to right hemorrhage cyst. On arrival, in

cyst. As pt was requiring IV narcotics she was admitted for
serial abdominal exams and IV pain control overnight. Pt's Hct
remained stable, and her pain improved. She was able to
tolerate PO regular diet and PO narcotic for adequate pain
control. She was discharged on HD#2 and will follow up with

while in house pt was seen by ___ attending, ___, for
consultation regarding quad gestation.

Name:  ___            Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Urinary Retention (obstructive lower urinary tract symptoms)
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
TRANSURETHRAL RESECTION OF THE PROSTATE

 
History of Present Illness:
___ hx of bladder, prostate Ca s/p XRT presents with 
obstructive lower urinary tract symptoms. This is a gentleman 
who had a
previous radiation for his prostate cancer and had undergone a 
previous channel TURP with inability to urinate.  He reports 
today with decision given that he was originally able to urinate 
and had a good urinary control for complete TURP.

 
 
Past Medical History:
His past medical history is significant for cancer of the kidney 
s/p radio frequency ablation and prostate s/p XRT and hormone 
therapy is noted.  

Past surgical history is significant for the radiofrequency
ablation of his right kidney, cancer, and radiation therapy and
expiration for the prostate cancer, those are managed by Dr.
___ at ___ and by Dr. ___ at ___ respectively.

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
His family history is significant and his mother died at age ___
of breast cancer.  His father died at age ___ from bladder 
cancer.

 
Physical Exam:
NAD
Abdomen soft, NT, ND
Voiding orange-tinged urine
Lower extremities w/out edema, pitting, calf pain
 
Pertinent Results:
None for this admission
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to the Urology service after 
transurethral resection of the prostate. No concerning 
intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated operative 
note for details. The patient received ___ antibiotic 
prophylaxis. Patient's postoperative course was uncomplicated. 
He received intravenous antibiotics and pyridium, and continous 
bladder irrigation overnight. On POD1, the CBI and foley 
catheter were discontinued, and he passed a voiding trial.  His 
urine was orange tingedwithout clots with post-void residual 
less than voided volumes. He remained afebrile throughout his 
hospital stay.  At discharge, patient's pain well controlled 
with oral pain medications, tolerating regular diet, ambulating 
without assistance, and voiding without difficulty.
 
Medications on Admission:
tamsulosin [Flomax] 0.4 mg Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr 1 
Capsule(s) PO QDAY  Tylenol Oral 1000 mg every 4 to 6 hours as 
needed for pain  

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg ONE capsule(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*2
3. Influenza Virus Vaccine 0.5 mL IM NOW X1 
Follow Influenza Protocol
4. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q6H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone-acetaminophen 5 mg-325 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth 
Q6hrs Disp #*20 Tablet Refills:*0
5. Pneumococcal Vac Polyvalent 0.5 ml IM NOW ___. Tamsulosin 0.4 mg PO HS 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
BENIGN PROSTATIC HYPERTROPHY with obstructive lower urinary 
tract symptoms

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-You may continue to periodically see small amounts of blood in 
your urine--this is normal and will gradually improve

-Resume all of your pre-admission medications, except HOLD 
aspirin until you see your urologist in followup or you are 
otherwise explicitly advised

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. 
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool softener, NOT a laxative

-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until 
otherwise advised

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain >4. 
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.

-___ daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL 
sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
- leakage of fluid at 18 wks gestational age
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
- vaginal delivery x 4

 
History of Present Illness:
On admission:
Ms. ___ is ___ yo G1P0 at 18.0 weeks with tetra-tetra 
quadruplet pregnancy who presents by ambulance with leakage of 
blood-tinged fluid at 8pm this evening. Patient notes large gush 
of fluid that "kept coming." No fetal movement yet. No abdominal 
cramping/CTX. No abdominal pain. No fevers/dysuria.

 
Past Medical History:
- none
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
- non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
On admission:
Vitals -  T:98.6  BP:108/57  HR:104,93  RR:18
Gen: well, NAD
Abd: soft, gravid, non-tender
Ext: soft, non-tender
Perineum: small bleeding at perineum, no active bleeding
Speculum: +small amount of pooling, umbilical cord visualized, 
hand seen with movement, 30 cc blood clot in vault

 
Pertinent Results:
___ WBC-11.3 Hgb-11.3 Hct-31.5 Plt ___
___ Neuts-73.2 ___ Monos-5.6 Eos-1.8 Baso-0.3
___ WBC-11.3 Hgb-11.3 Hct-31.5 Plt ___
___ Neuts-76.7 ___ Monos-5.3 Eos-1.4 Baso-0.3
.
___ ___ PTT-30.9 ___
___ ___ PTT-30.8 ___
.
___ ___
.
___ FetlHgb-0
 
Brief Hospital Course:
*)PPROM/IUFD
On admission, rupture of membranes and imminent delivery of 
quadruplet A was confirmed by exam and ultrasound. Intra-uterine 
fetal demise of quadruplet A was also noted at that time. There 
was no evidence of infection or abruption on presentation. After 
counseling regarding her options for management, she elected to 
initially proceed with expectant management. However, given the 
poor prognosis for carrying the remaining fetuses to viability, 
and the imminent delivery of quadruplet A, the decision was made 
to give cytotec to facilitate delivery. She subsequently 
delivered all four quadruplets via vaginal delivery, with 
spontaneous delivery of the placenta afterward. Rhogam was 
administered for Rh negative blood type, and she was seen by 
both the chaplain and social work during her hospitalization. 
Prophylactic antibiotics were administered for 24 hours 
postpartum; she was never febrile. Postpartum course was 
uneventful, with stable hematocrit and coagulation panel. She 
was discharged home in stable condition. 
 
Medications on Admission:
- none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed.
Disp:90 Tablet(s) Refills:1

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
- quadruplet pregnancy; delivered at 18 weeks of gestation
- premature rupture of membranes
- intraamniotic infection

 
Discharge Condition:
- good

 
Discharge Instructions:
- take temperature twice per day; call with temp > 100.4
- call with increased vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain or 
malaise
- nothing in the vagina and no tub bathing for 2 weeks
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ presented to the ___ On ___ after being 
involved in a motor vehicle crash.  She was evaluated by the 
orthopaedic and trauma surgery service.  She was found to have a 
right open tib/fib fracture and a left ankle fracture 
dislocation.  She was admitted, consented, and prepped for 
surgery.  She was then taken to the operating room and underwent 
a right tibia IM nail and an ORIF of her left ankle 
fracture/dislocation.  She tolerated the procedure well, was 
extubated, transferred to the recovery room, and then to the 
floor.  On the floor she was seen by physical therapy to improve 
her strength and mobility.  On the inpatient floor, she was 
noted to be mildly tachycardic with normal blood pressures and 
oxygen saturation levels that were stable throughout her 
inpatient stay.  She had significant pain control issues related 
to movement of her lower extremities.  The remainder of her 
inpatient admission was uneventful.  She is being discharged to 
a rehabilitation facility in stable condition.

 
Medications on Admission:
denies
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Famotidine 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day).  
2. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain.  
3. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain, fever > 100.4.  
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
5. Bisacodyl 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day as 
needed for constipation.  
6. Enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL Syringe Sig: One (1) syringe 
Subcutaneous DAILY (Daily) for 4 weeks.  
7. Hydromorphone (PF) 1 mg/mL Syringe Sig: 0.25 mg Injection 
every ___ hours as needed for breakthrough pain.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
left distal tibia and fibula fracture
right tibial fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: clear and coherent
Level of Consciousness: alert and interactive
Activity Status: ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane)

 
Discharge Instructions:
- Wound Care: Keep Incision dry. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.

-Activity: Continue to be full weight bearing on your right leg 
and touch down weight bearing on your left leg.  

    -You should not lift anything greater than 5 pounds. 

    -Elevate both legs to reduce swelling and pain.

    -Keep air cast boots on as much as possible

- Resume your regular diet. 
- Avoid nicotine products to optimize healing. 
- Resume your home medications. Take all medications as 
instructed. 
- Continue taking the Lovenox to prevent blood clots.

- You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so plan ahead.  You can either have them mailed 
to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on ___. 
 We are not allowed to call in narcotic (oxycontin, oxycodone, 
percocet) prescriptions to the pharmacy.   In addition, we are 
only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days from the 
date of surgery.

- Narcotic pain medication may cause drowsiness.  Do not drink 
alcohol while taking narcotic medications.  Do not operate any 
motor vehicle or machinery while taking narcotic pain 
medications.  Taking more than recommended may cause serious 
breathing problems.
 
If you have questions, concerns or experience any of the below 
danger signs then please call your doctor at ___ or go 
to your local emergency room.
Physical Therapy:
Activity:  as tolerated
 Right lower extremity:  full weight bearing
 Left lower extremity:  touch-down weight bearing

Treatments Frequency:
Staples/sutures out 14 days after surgery

Boot may come off for daily care, dry dressing changes, and for 
evaluation of wound
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Diverticulitis
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ Laparoscopic Sigmoid colectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
This gentleman has had recurrent episodes of diverticulitis. He 
has been given his options and wished to have surgical 
treatment.

 
Past Medical History:
hypercholesterolemia, fatty liver, GERD, radial/ulnar fracture
 
Family History:
Father with ___ syndrome, Mother with endometrial cancer, 
maternalGF with hodgkins disease, maternal uncle with colon 
cancer diagnosed at age ___
 
Physical Exam:
On discharge:
Temp 98.0, HR 89, BP 120/80, RR 16, O2 96% on RA
Gen: well, nad, Alert and oriented
CV: RRR, No R/G/M
RESP: CTAB
ABD: Soft, ND, Appropriately Tender, surgical wounds c/d/i with 
steri-strips in place

 
Pertinent Results:
___ Pathology DIAGNOSIS: 
 I.  Sigmoid colon, segment (A-F):
Multiple diverticula with rupture and chronic pericolic abscess.
II.  Colon, rectal donuts (G-H):
Colon fragments; within normal limits.
Clinical:  Sigmoid diverticulitis. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt admitted to ___ on ___ and underwent a laparoscopic 
sigmoid colectomy for diverticulitis. Please see operative note 
for details. Pt had an uncomplicated post-operative course and 
was discharged home on POD#3. ___ pain was 
controlled with a PCA as well as a bupivicane pain pump. On 
POD#1 a diet of sips was initiated. On POD#2 the pt was started 
on clear liquids and placed on his home medications. The pt had 
a bowel movement on POD#2, was advanced to a regular diet and 
was transitioned to PO pain medications. On POD#3 the pain pump 
was removed, the pt was ambulating without assistance, 
tolerating a regular diet and pain was well controlled with oral 
pain medication.
 
Medications on Admission:
lipitor 10', flonase, ambien prn, prilosec
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Percocet ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every four (4) 
hours as needed for pain for 1 weeks.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day for 
2 weeks.
Disp:*28 Capsule(s)* Refills:*1*
Continue Home Medications

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Diverticulitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Excellent

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Pertinent Results:

MCV-89 MCH-29.0 MCHC-32.6 RDW-13.0 Plt ___
___ 10:20AM BLOOD Plt ___
___ 10:20AM BLOOD Glucose-100 UreaN-8 Creat-0.8 Na-136 
K-3.9 Cl-106 HCO3-22 AnGap-12
___ 10:20AM BLOOD Calcium-8.2* Phos-2.4* Mg-2.1
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ was admitted to general surgery from the pacu. She was 
maintained as NPO with IVF/PCA/Foley. With the return of bowel 
function and flatus her diet was advanced from sips to regular. 
She tolerated this well and her medications were changed to 
oral. ___ was removed without issues. ___ had an 
uncomplicated post-op course. She will follow up with Dr. ___ 
in ___ weeks.
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain for 2 weeks.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left hemicolectomy for colon cancer

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable, tolerating a po diet, adeqaute po pain control.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the 
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
* Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or 

back.
*Avoid lifting objects > 5lbs until your follow-up appointment 
with the surgeon.
*Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
as ordered. 
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.
.
Incision Care:
-Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
-You may shower, and wash surgical incisions.
-Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
-Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ presented to the ___ on ___ after an 
approximately 15 foot fall off a ladder while at work.  He was 
evaulated by the orthopaedic and trauma surgery departments.  He 
was found to have a right distal tibia fracture on XRAY.  He was 
admitted to orthopaedics, prepped, and consented for surgery.  
Later that day he was taken to the operating room and underwent 
an external fixator placement to his right distal tibia 
fracture.  He tolerated the procedure well, was extubated, 
transferred to the recovery room, and then to the floor.  On the 
floor he was seen by physical therapy to improve his strength 
and mobility. On ___, he was cleared by ___ for home. 
The rest of his hospital stay was uneventful with his lab data 
and vital signs within normal limits and his pain controlled.  
He is being discharged today in stable condition, with a 
visiting nurse for care of his ex fix and for lovenox. The plan 
will be to take him to the OR next week for ORIF.

6 hours).

Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
6. Multivitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Cap PO DAILY (Daily).

Home With Service

___

s/p fall
Right distal tibia fracture

Stable

Continue your lovenox injections for a total of 4 weeks after 
surgery

Continue your medications as prescribed

If you have any increased redness, drainge, or swelling, or if 
you have a temeprature greater than 101.5, please call the 
office or come to the emergency department.

Activity:  As tolerated
 Right lower extremity:  Non weight bearing
 Left lower extremity:  Full weight bearing
 Keep right leg elevated as much as possible, above your heart.

hydrogen peroxide and normal saline

Montior wound for signs/symptoms of infection

Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man who had a fall off a ladder of
approximately 15 feet, presenting with R ankle pain and
deformity. He was taken to the ___ for further evaluation.
Past Medical History:
Denies
Social History:
___
Family History:
n/a
Physical Exam:
Upon admission
Alert and oriented
Cardiac: Regular rate rhythm
Chest: Lungs clear bilaterally
Abdomen: Soft non-tender non-distended
Extremities: RLE diffuse edema, +TTP over distal tibia and
lateral malleolus. Warm with cap refill <2 seconds. Normal
sensation, + pulses, skin intact.
Pertinent Results:
___ 10:41AM GLUCOSE-103 NA+-143 K+-3.8 CL--101 TCO2-23
___ 10:16AM WBC-9.8 RBC-4.86 HGB-14.3 HCT-40.9 MCV-84
MCH-29.5 MCHC-35.0 RDW-12.6
___ 10:16AM UREA N-17 CREAT-0.9
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ presented to the ___ on ___ after an
approximately 15 foot fall off a ladder while at work. He was
evaulated by the orthopaedic and trauma surgery departments. He
was found to have a right distal tibia fracture on XRAY. He was
admitted to orthopaedics, prepped, and consented for surgery.
Later that day he was taken to the operating room and underwent
an external fixator placement to his right distal tibia
fracture. He tolerated the procedure well, was extubated,
transferred to the recovery room, and then to the floor. On the
floor he was seen by physical therapy to improve his strength
and mobility. On ___, he was cleared by ___ for home.
The rest of his hospital stay was uneventful with his lab data
and vital signs within normal limits and his pain controlled.
He is being discharged today in stable condition, with a
visiting nurse for care of his ex fix and for lovenox. The plan
will be to take him to the OR next week for ORIF.

denies

Subcutaneous DAILY (Daily) for 4 weeks.

as needed for pain.

times a day).

6 hours).
5. Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3) 400 unit Tablet Sig: One (1)
Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
6. Multivitamin Tablet Sig: One (1) Cap PO DAILY (Daily).

Home With Service
Facility:
___
Discharge Diagnosis:
s/p fall
Right distal tibia fracture
Discharge Condition:
Stable
Discharge Instructions:
Continue to be non-weight bearing on your right leg
Continue your lovenox injections for a total of 4 weeks after
surgery
Continue your medications as prescribed
If you have any increased redness, drainge, or swelling, or if
you have a temeprature greater than 101.5, please call the
office or come to the emergency department.
Physical Therapy:
Activity: As tolerated
Right lower extremity: Non weight bearing
Left lower extremity: Full weight bearing
Keep right leg elevated as much as possible, above your heart.

Daily pin care to right external fixator with ___ strength
hydrogen peroxide and normal saline
Montior wound for signs/symptoms of infection

Percocet
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Left ankle pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Removal of left ankle hardware

 
History of Present Illness:
___ is a female who had an ankle fracture repaired in the 
distant past.  She appeared in clinic last week, and noted that 
one of the syndesmotic screws had migrated into the joint and 
was causing some discomfort.  Therefore, we are electing to 
proceed with
hardware removal.
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: Denies  
PSH: Knee surgery  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Physical Exam:
General: NAD
Abdomen: soft, NT
Extremities: LLE with dressing in place, c/d/i.  Distally n/v
intact

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the Orthopedic service on 
___ for removal of left ankle hardware.  She underwent 
removal of hardware without complication on ___. She was 
extubated without difficulty and transferred to the recovery 
room in stable condition.  In the early post-operative course 
Ms. ___ had increased post operative pain and was 
transferred to the floor in stable condition for pain control.

She had adequate pain management. The remainder of her hospital 
course was uneventful and Ms. ___ is being discharged 
to home on ___ in stable condition

 
Discharge Medications:
1. hydrocodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain.  
2. ibuprofen 800 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every eight 
(8) hours as needed for pain for 1 weeks.  
3. acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO every 
eight (8) hours as needed for pain for 2 weeks.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Removal of left ankle hardware
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

Wound Care: 
-Dressings may come down ___ afternoon. ___ take shower on 
___
-Keep Incision dry.  
-Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool.  
-Sutures will be removed at your first post-operative visit.

Activity: 
-Continue to be weight bearing as tolerated on your left leg.  
-Elevate left leg to reduce swelling and pain.

Other Instructions
- Resume your regular diet. 
- Avoid nicotine products to optimize healing. 
- Resume your home medications. Take all medications as 
instructed. 
- Continue taking the Asparin to prevent blood clots.
- You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so plan ahead.  You can either have them mailed 
to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on ___ 2. 
 We are not allowed to call in narcotic (oxycontin, oxycodone, 
percocet) prescriptions to the pharmacy.   In addition, we are 
only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days from the 
date of surgery.
- Narcotic pain medication may cause drowsiness.  Do not drink 
alcohol while taking narcotic medications.  Do not operate any 
motor vehicle or machinery while taking narcotic pain 
medications.  Taking more than recommended may cause serious 
breathing problems.
- If you have questions, concerns or experience any of the below 
danger signs then please call your doctor at ___ or go 
to your local emergency room.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Diplopia, headache
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
LP
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo man with PMH significant only for B 12 deficiency
who presents with three days of R facial and retroorbital pain.
He states having difficulty keeping his eyes open as well as
significant horizontal diplopia when looking to the right. He
presented to ___ where brain MRI was initially
read as R cavernous sinus mass with no thrombosis and 
transferred
here for neurosurgical evaluation.

Significant findings on exam include: decreased sensation to PP
and LT in the Right V1 and V2 distribution as well as a marked
___ nerve palsy on the Right.

I reviewed his MRI which seems to show a uniformly enhancing 
mass
in the right cavernous sinus extensing into the superior orbital
fissure. It looks somewhat suspicious for a meningioma given its
robust enhancement (although a dural tail is not evident).

The official radiology read is as follows: 
Mass lesion in the right cavernous sinus extending to the right 
foramen ovale region. The differential diagnosis includes
meningioma or hemangioma of the cavernous sinus, inflammatory
lesion such as ___ syndrome or neoplastic lesion such as
metastasis or lymphoma. The enhancement pattern and signal
characteristics favor inflammatory lesion versus metastasis 
or lymphoma. Clinical correlation is recommended with any
nasopharyngeal or oropharyngeal lesion, which could produce
perineural spread and metastatic disease. Correlation with
patient's onset of symptoms and other findings would also be
helpful in differential diagnosis.  

 
Past Medical History:
B12 deficiency
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
___: non-contributory for mass

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the neurology service and found to 
have R cavernous sinus mass. MRI/V negative for thrombosis. 
Workup for inflammatory causes negative.

Scheduled for biopsy on ___ by neurosurgery, as 
elective procedure.

He was started on lyrica 100mg BID and MS contin for pain.
 
Medications on Admission:
B12
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Cyanocobalamin 1,000 mcg/mL Solution Sig: One (1)  Injection 
QTHUR (every ___.  
2. Morphine 30 mg Tablet Sustained Release Sig: One (1) Tablet 
Sustained Release PO Q12H (every 12 hours).
Disp:*14 Tablet Sustained Release(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Pregabalin 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
4. Outpatient Lab Work
For ___ at the ___ outpatient lab:
Type and screen; CBC; ___ chem 7

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
R cavernous sinus mass
 
Discharge Condition:
R VIth nerve palsy, decreased pinprick over R V1-V3

Mass lesion in the right cavernous sinus extending to the right
foramen ovale region. The differential diagnosis includes
meningioma or hemangioma of the cavernous sinus, inflammatory
lesion such as ___ syndrome or neoplastic lesion such as
metastasis or lymphoma. The enhancement pattern and signal
characteristics favor inflammatory lesion versus metastasis
or lymphoma. Clinical correlation is recommended with any
nasopharyngeal or oropharyngeal lesion, which could produce

right cavernous sinus mass, cranial nerve 3,4,6

neurologically stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
General Instructions

Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
Exercise should be limited to walking; no driving,lifting, 
straining, or excessive bending.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc. 
If you have been prescribed an anti-seizure medicine, take it 
as prescribed and follow up with laboratory blood drawing in one 
week.  Please have results faxed to ___.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

New onset of tremors or seizures.
Any confusion, lethargy or change in mental status. 
Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Vaginal Bleeding
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ s/p cold knife cone x 2 ___ and ___ for 
adenocarcinoma in situ of the cervix, presents to the ED via 
ambulance due to heavy vaginal bleeding.  Patient notes an 
uneventful postoperative course until last night at 6pm, at 
which time she passed three large blood clots and started 
bleeding heavily.  She notes soaking through several pads, her 
clothes, and the sheets in the ambulance.  Denies recent sexual 
intercourse or tampon use.

She denies abdominal pain or cramping.  Denies F/C.  Denies N/V. 
 Denies dizziness or weakness.  Denies chest pain or shortness 
of breath. 

She complains of urinary retention, however no dysuria.  Denies 
GI symptoms. 

 
Past Medical History:
OBHx:
SVD x 2, full term, no complications

GynHx:
LMP ___
Regular menses, lasting 5 days, moderate flow
Contraception: tubal ligation
Denies STIs
Abnl pap smear, s/p cold knife cone x 2 
 - ___ adenocarcinoma in situ, extending to margins 
 - ___ benign

PMH:
Mild mitral regurg
Labile HTN, no meds

PSH:
___ Tubal ligation thru small mini lap
___ excision breast fibroma x 2
Cold knife cone x 2

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
nc
 
Physical Exam:
VS: T 99.8  BP 156/89  HR 86  RR 16  O2Sat 100% RA
NAD, pale (bedsheets and patient's clothes soaked with blood)
RRR
CTAB
Abd soft, nontender, nondistended
Ext NTNE

Spec (per ED resident) ~ 100cc dark red blood evacuated from
vaginal vault, slow active bleeding
Spec (per myself) nl vagina mucosa, ~ 50cc dark red blood
evacuated from vaginal vault, no active pooling of blood in the
vagina with valsalva, dark red clot across surgical site,
difficult to assess however slow active bleeding from approx
0.5cm up cervical canal noted, ___'s solution applied to
surgical site.

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:10AM   WBC-9.6 RBC-3.60* HGB-10.2* HCT-31.7* MCV-88 
MCH-28.3 MCHC-32.2 RDW-13.6
___ 07:10AM   PLT COUNT-322
___ 07:10AM   ___ PTT-29.8 ___
___ 07:10AM   ___ 11:50PM   WBC-8.2 RBC-3.43* HGB-9.6* HCT-29.3* MCV-85 
MCH-28.0 MCHC-32.8 RDW-13.9
___ 09:45PM   HCG-<5
___ 09:45PM   WBC-9.8 RBC-4.12* HGB-11.7* HCT-35.1* MCV-85 
MCH-28.3 MCHC-33.2 RDW-13.9
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted from the emergency department with 
significant vaginal bleeding 2 weeks following a cold knife 
cone.

The patient was observed for 24 hours. Her hematocrit was noted 
to decreased from her preoperative hematocrit and continued to 
drop from 35% to 29%. The patient's bleeding subsided with 
treatment of ___'s solution at the bleeding area on the 
postoperative site. The patient was monitored closely with 
serial hematocrit and pad counts.  Her bleeding was minimal 
following admission. She was discharged in stable condition with 
close outpatient followup.  
 
Medications on Admission:
-
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain.  
2. Calcium Carbonate 500 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) 
Tablet, Chewable PO QID (4 times a day) as needed for heartburn. 
 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Postoperative cervical bleeding
Adenocarcinoma in situ cervical cancer

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status:Clear and coherent
Level of Consciousness:Alert and interactive
Activity Status:Ambulatory - Independent

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted following bleeding from your cervix that can 
occasionally happen after a cold knife cone biopsy.  We do not 
expect you to have further bleeding other than mild brown/black 
discharge. 
.
Call Dr. ___ you have:
-bright red vaginal bleeding
-severe abdominal pain
-fever
-difficulty voiding
.
Please avoid ibuprofen/motrin
You may use Tylenol for mild aches/pains
.
Make sure you keep your appointment with Dr. ___ on ___ 
for further discussion about treatment.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___

Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Adenocarcinoma in situ cervix
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Total laparoscopic hysterectomy, cystoscopy.
 
History of Present Illness:
___ gravida 2, para 2 status post cold knife cone x 2 ___ 
and ___ for adenocarcinoma in situ of the cervix.  No 
further cancer was identified.  There was no evidence of 
dysplasia.  She is here for definitive therapy.  
Postoperatively, she had a problem with respect to vaginal 
bleeding.  She was admitted to the hospital and a small LEEP bed 
was cauterized.  She denies any dysfunctional bleeding at this 
point.  She is anxious to have this taken care of.

 
Past Medical History:
OBHx:
SVD x 2, full term, no complications

GynHx:
LMP ___
Regular menses, lasting 5 days, moderate flow
Contraception: tubal ligation
Denies STIs
Abnl pap smear, s/p cold knife cone x 2 
 - ___ adenocarcinoma in situ, extending to margins 
 - ___ benign

PMH:
Mild mitral regurg
Labile HTN, no meds

PSH:
___ Tubal ligation thru small mini lap
___ excision breast fibroma x 2
Cold knife cone x 2

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
nc
 
Physical Exam:
AVSS
NAD
RRR
CTAB
ABD: soft, NT, ND, no R/G
EXT: NT
Incision: C/D/I
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ underwent an uncomplicated total laparoscopic 
hysterectomy on ___.  Please see operative report for full 
deteails.  Her Foley was discontinued on POD1, and she voided 
spontaneously.  Her pain was initially controlled with IV 
Dilaudid/Toradol, and switched to PO Percocet/Motrin when she 
was tolerating a regular diet.  Her diet was advanced as 
tolerated.  Her vital signs remained stable throughout her 
admission.  At the time of discharge on POD2, she was tolerating 
a regular diet, ambulating well, and her pain was 
well-controlled on PO pain medication.
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain: do not exceed 4g tylenol 
in 24hours.
2. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain.
3. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day.

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Adenocarcinoma in situ of the cervix

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent

 
Discharge Instructions:
You underwent a total laparoscopic hysterectomy, cystoscopy.  
Your surgery was uncomplicated.  Please keep all of your follow 
up appointments as outlined below.  Please take all of your 
medications as directed.  You have steri-strips on your 
incisions.  They should fall off on their own in the next 
2weeks.  
Please avoid heavy lifting.  Do not place anything in the vagina 
or have intercourse until after your post-operative appointment. 
 Please call for fever >100.4, chills, nausea, vomiting, chest 
pain, shortness of breath, heavy vaginal bleeding, abdominal 
pain not relieved by pain medication, redness or purulent 
drainage from your incision, or any other questions or concerns.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Total laparoscopic hysterectomy, cystoscopy.
History of Present Illness:
___ gravida 2, para 2 status post cold knife cone x 2 ___
and ___ for adenocarcinoma in situ of the cervix. No
further cancer was identified. There was no evidence of
dysplasia. She is here for definitive therapy.
Postoperatively, she had a problem with respect to vaginal
bleeding. She was admitted to the hospital and a small LEEP bed
was cauterized. She denies any dysfunctional bleeding at this
point. She is anxious to have this taken care of.
Past Medical History:
OBHx:
SVD x 2, full term, no complications
GynHx:
LMP ___
Regular menses, lasting 5 days, moderate flow
Contraception: tubal ligation
Denies STIs
Abnl pap smear, s/p cold knife cone x 2 - ___ adenocarcinoma in situ, extending to margins - ___ benign
PMH:
Mild mitral regurg
Labile HTN, no meds
PSH:
___ Tubal ligation thru small mini lap
___ excision breast fibroma x 2
Cold knife cone x 2
Social History:
___
Family History:
nc
Physical Exam:
AVSS
NAD
RRR
CTAB
ABD: soft, NT, ND, no R/G
EXT: NT
Incision: C/D/I
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ underwent an uncomplicated total laparoscopic
hysterectomy on ___. Please see operative report for full
deteails. Her Foley was discontinued on POD1, and she voided
spontaneously. Her pain was initially controlled with IV
Dilaudid/Toradol, and switched to PO Percocet/Motrin when she
was tolerating a regular diet. Her diet was advanced as
tolerated. Her vital signs remained stable throughout her
admission. At the time of discharge on POD2, she was tolerating
a regular diet, ambulating well, and her pain was
well-controlled on PO pain medication.
Medications on Admission:
none
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain: do not exceed 4g tylenol
in 24hours.

hours) as needed for pain.
3. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day.

Home

Adenocarcinoma in situ of the cervix
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent
Discharge Instructions:
You underwent a total laparoscopic hysterectomy, cystoscopy.
Your surgery was uncomplicated. Please keep all of your follow
up appointments as outlined below. Please take all of your
medications as directed. You have steri-strips on your
incisions. They should fall off on their own in the next
2weeks.
Please avoid heavy lifting. Do not place anything in the vagina
or have intercourse until after your post-operative appointment. Please call for fever >100.4, chills, nausea, vomiting, chest
pain, shortness of breath, heavy vaginal bleeding, abdominal
pain not relieved by pain medication, redness or purulent
drainage from your incision, or any other questions or concerns.

Calcium-8.3* Phos-2.5* Mg-2.___ y/o female with metastatic colorectal cancer to the liver, 
taken to the OR with Dr ___ for exploratory laparotomy, 
intraoperative ultrasound, segment 4A resection with additional 
margin and segment II resection. She had an epidural placed for 
the surgery.
Please see the operative note for surgical detail. There were no 
reported complications and the patient was extubated and 
transferred to PACU in stable condition.

Post operatively the epifural was effective in manageing her 
pain. Diet was advanced slowly as she ws initially distended, 
and had one episode of emesis. 
On POD 2 the patient had a fever to 102. Chest xray showed low 
lung volumes. Blood cultures were sent, these are all negative 
at discharge although not finalized. The urine culture was no 
growth. The epidural was removed and the tip was cultured/ as 
well as the central line, also showing no growth.
The foley was removed and she voided without difficulty. Patient 
was ambulating and tolerating regular diet, pain was managed 
with PO pain meds. The JP drain was removed prior to discharge, 
the incision was C/D/I

RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth q 4 hours Disp #*60 
Tablet Refills:*0
4. Senna 1 TAB PO BID 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Metastatic colorectal cancer to the liver; final pathology 
pending

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call Dr ___ office at ___ for fever > 101, 
chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, increased 
abdominal pain, pain not controlled with pain medication, 
incisional redness, drainage or bleeding, inability to tolerate 
food, fluids or medications, swelling of the abdomen or lower 
legs or any other concerning symptoms.
You may shower, allow water to run over incision and pat dry. No 
lotions or powders to the incision area.
No tub baths or swimming until notified by the surgeon you may 
do so.
No lifting more than 10 pounds
No driving if taking narcotic pain medication

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
epinephrine
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Right Hip Pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Right Total Hip Replacement ___
 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old women with right hip osteoarthritis, no relief with 
conservative treatment
 
Past Medical History:
Hyperlipdemia, Hypertension, osteoporosis

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
n/c
 
Physical Exam:
GEN: AOx3. NAD
HEART: NSR
LUNGS: No Wheezing
EXT: Knee; dressing is clean, dry and intact
         + Capillary refill, and pedal pulse
         + FROM of all extremities

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:40AM BLOOD WBC-11.3* RBC-3.11* Hgb-9.1* Hct-27.8* 
MCV-90 MCH-29.4 MCHC-32.8 RDW-13.5 Plt ___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by 
a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1.  The patient 
received lovenox for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of 
POD#1.  The foley was removed on POD#2 and the patient was 
voiding independently thereafter. The patient was seen daily by 
physical therapy.   

At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating a regular 
diet and feeling well.  The patient was afebrile with stable 
vital signs.  The patient's  pain was adequately controlled on 
an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly 
intact.   The patient is weight bearing as tolerated.
 
Ms. ___ is discharged rehab in stable condition.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Losartan Potassium 50 mg PO DAILY 
2. Rosuvastatin Calcium 50 mg PO HS 
3. Triamterene-Hydrochlorothiazide 1 CAP PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right Hip Osteoarthritis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.

2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 

3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.

4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy. 

5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon or your primary physician.

6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in two (2) weeks.

7. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
medications (NSAIDs such as celebrex, ibuprofen, advil, aleve, 
motrin, etc).

8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your lovenox for three weeks 
to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).

9. ACTIVITY: Partial Weight Bearing. No strenuous exercise or 
heavy lifting until follow up appointment.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
1. Cervical stenosis with radiculopathy right C7.
2. Previous C5-6 anterior cervical decompression and
    fusion.

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
C67 ACDF

 
History of Present Illness:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is a ___ male
being seen in the ___ with a history of C5-C6 ACDF 
___
years ago.  At that time, the patient had left-sided
radiculopathy.  Today, he presents with new onset of right-sided
radicular symptoms for about three weeks.  He felt pain in his
shoulder, some numbness and tingling in his arm.  This has
acutely gotten worse in the past week and the patient has been
prescribed Flexeril and Percocet by his primary care physician,
which helps him get some sleep, but the pain is acutely worse. 
He is right-hand dominant.  He experiences pain in his neck and
this does radiate from his shoulder to the back of his upper arm
and somewhat into the radial fingers.  He get some pins and
needle sensation.  The patient had done very well after his 
prior
surgery and returns for evaluation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Includes hypertension, both bone forearm
fracture, right forearm, and carpal tunnel syndrome.  The
patient's review of systems is otherwise negative.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  The patient has ___ strength on the right
triceps.  Otherwise, he has ___ strength throughout bilateral
upper extremities and bilateral lower extremities.  Negative
___.  Reflexes are symmetric, 2+ at the patella, 1+ at 
the
Achilles, 1+ at the biceps, not elicited at the triceps.  The
patient does have a positive Spurling sign with tilting the head
back into the right as well as forward into the left causing
symptoms to be exacerbated on the right upper extremity.

IMAGING:  Includes flexion and extension films of the cervical
spine obtained today.  The fusion seems solid at C5-C6 without
any noticeable motion on flexion and extension.

 
Past Medical History:
hypercholesterolemia, fatty liver, GERD, radial/ulnar fracture
 
Family History:
Father with ___ syndrome, Mother with endometrial cancer, 
maternalGF with hodgkins disease, maternal uncle with colon 
cancer diagnosed at age ___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and 
taken to the Operating Room for the above procedure.  Refer to 
the dictated operative note for further details.  The surgery 
was without complication and the patient was transferred to the 
PACU in a stable condition.  TEDs/pnemoboots were used for 
postoperative DVT prophylaxis.  Intravenous antibiotics were 
continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initial postop 
pain was controlled with a PCA.  Diet was advanced as tolerated. 
 The patient was transitioned to oral pain medication when 
tolerating PO diet.  Foley was removed on POD#2.  Physical 
therapy was consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate.  
Hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.  On the day of 
discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs, 
comfortable on oral pain control and tolerating a regular diet.

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Diazepam ___ mg PO Q8H:PRN spasm 
RX *diazepam 2 mg ___ tablets by mouth every eight (8) hours 
Disp #*50 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0
3. Metoprolol Tartrate 12.5 mg PO Q12H:PRN SBP>170 
4. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q4H:PRN for 
breakthrough pain  
RX *oxycodone-acetaminophen 5 mg-325 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth 
q4-6h Disp #*100 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
C6-C7 Disc Herniation

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
ACDF:
You have undergone the following operation: Anterior Cervical 
Decompression and Fusion
 
Immediately after the operation:
                Activity: You should not lift anything greater 
than 10 lbs for 2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do 
not sit in a car or chair for more than ~45 minutes without 
getting up and walking around.
 
                Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy:
___                ___ times a day you should go for a walk 
for ___ minutes as part of your recovery.  You can walk as 
much as you can tolerate.  
___                Isometric Extension Exercise in the 
collar: 2x/day x ___xercises as 
instructed.
 
                Swallowing: Difficulty swallowing is not 
uncommon after this type of surgery. This should resolve over 
time.  Please take small bites and eat slowly.  Removing the 
collar while eating can be helpful  however, please limit your 
movement of your neck if you remove your collar while eating.
 
                Cervical Collar / Neck Brace: You have been 
given a soft collar for comfort. You may remove the collar to 
take a shower or eat.  Limit your motion of your neck while the 
collar is off. You should wear the collar when walking, 
especially in public
 
                Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If 
the incision is draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  
If it is dry then you can leave the incision open to the air.  
Once the incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Call the office at that 
time. If you have an incision on your hip please follow the same 
instructions in terms of wound care.
 
                You should resume taking your normal home 
medications.
 
                You have also been given Additional Medications 
to control your pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of 
narcotic prescriptions, so plan ahead.  You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___.  We are not allowed to call in narcotic (oxycontin, 
oxycodone, percocet) prescriptions to the pharmacy.   In 
addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications for 
90 days from the date of surgery.
 
                Follow up:        
___                Please Call the office and make an 
appointment for 2 weeks after the day of your operation if this 
has not been done already.
___                At the 2-week visit we will check your 
incision, take baseline x rays and answer any questions.
___                We will then see you at 6 weeks from the 
day of the operation. At that time we will most likely obtain 
Flexion/Extension X-rays and often able to place you in a soft 
collar which you will wean out of over 1 week.  
 
 
Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit, drainage from your wound, or have any questions.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

being seen in the ___ with a history of C5-C6 ACDF
___
years ago. At that time, the patient had left-sided
radiculopathy. Today, he presents with new onset of right-sided
radicular symptoms for about three weeks. He felt pain in his
shoulder, some numbness and tingling in his arm. This has
acutely gotten worse in the past week and the patient has been
prescribed Flexeril and Percocet by his primary care physician,
which helps him get some sleep, but the pain is acutely worse.
He is right-hand dominant. He experiences pain in his neck and
this does radiate from his shoulder to the back of his upper arm
and somewhat into the radial fingers. He get some pins and
needle sensation. The patient had done very well after his
prior
surgery and returns for evaluation.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Includes hypertension, both bone forearm
fracture, right forearm, and carpal tunnel syndrome. The
patient's review of systems is otherwise negative.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: The patient has ___ strength on the right
triceps. Otherwise, he has ___ strength throughout bilateral
upper extremities and bilateral lower extremities. Negative
___. Reflexes are symmetric, 2+ at the patella, 1+ at
the
Achilles, 1+ at the biceps, not elicited at the triceps. The
patient does have a positive Spurling sign with tilting the head
back into the right as well as forward into the left causing
symptoms to be exacerbated on the right upper extremity.
IMAGING: Includes flexion and extension films of the cervical
spine obtained today. The fusion seems solid at C5-C6 without
any noticeable motion on flexion and extension.
Past Medical History:
hypercholesterolemia, fatty liver, GERD, radial/ulnar fracture
Family History:
Father with ___ syndrome, Mother with endometrial cancer,
maternalGF with hodgkins disease, maternal uncle with colon
cancer diagnosed at age ___
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and
taken to the Operating Room for the above procedure. Refer to
the dictated operative note for further details. The surgery
was without complication and the patient was transferred to the
PACU in a stable condition. TEDs/pnemoboots were used for
postoperative DVT prophylaxis. Intravenous antibiotics were
continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initial postop
pain was controlled with a PCA. Diet was advanced as tolerated. The patient was transitioned to oral pain medication when
tolerating PO diet. Foley was removed on POD#2. Physical
therapy was consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate.
Hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. On the day of
discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs,
comfortable on oral pain control and tolerating a regular diet.
Discharge Medications:
1. Diazepam ___ mg PO Q8H:PRN spasm
RX *diazepam 2 mg ___ tablets by mouth every eight (8) hours
Disp #*50 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day
Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0
3. Metoprolol Tartrate 12.5 mg PO Q12H:PRN SBP>170
4. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q4H:PRN for
breakthrough pain
RX *oxycodone-acetaminophen 5 mg-325 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth
q4-6h Disp #*100 Tablet Refills:*0
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
C6-C7 Disc Herniation
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
ACDF:
You have undergone the following operation: Anterior Cervical
Decompression and Fusion
Immediately after the operation:
 Activity: You should not lift anything greater
than 10 lbs for 2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do
not sit in a car or chair for more than ~45 minutes without
getting up and walking around.
 Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy:
___ ___ times a day you should go for a walk
for ___ minutes as part of your recovery. You can walk as
much as you can tolerate.
___ Isometric Extension Exercise in the
collar: 2x/day x ___xercises as
instructed.
 Swallowing: Difficulty swallowing is not
uncommon after this type of surgery. This should resolve over
time. Please take small bites and eat slowly. Removing the
collar while eating can be helpful  however, please limit your
movement of your neck if you remove your collar while eating.
 Cervical Collar / Neck Brace: You have been
given a soft collar for comfort. You may remove the collar to
take a shower or eat. Limit your motion of your neck while the
collar is off. You should wear the collar when walking,
especially in public
 Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days. If
the incision is draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.
If it is dry then you can leave the incision open to the air.
Once the incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a
bath or pool. If the incision starts draining at anytime after
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Call the office at that
time. If you have an incision on your hip please follow the same
instructions in terms of wound care.
 You should resume taking your normal home
medications.
 You have also been given Additional Medications
to control your pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of
narcotic prescriptions, so plan ahead. You can either have them
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on
___. We are not allowed to call in narcotic (oxycontin,
oxycodone, percocet) prescriptions to the pharmacy. In
addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications for
90 days from the date of surgery.
 Follow up:
___ Please Call the office and make an
appointment for 2 weeks after the day of your operation if this
has not been done already.
___ At the 2-week visit we will check your
incision, take baseline x rays and answer any questions.
___ We will then see you at 6 weeks from the
day of the operation. At that time we will most likely obtain
Flexion/Extension X-rays and often able to place you in a soft
collar which you will wean out of over 1 week.
Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees
Fahrenheit, drainage from your wound, or have any questions.
Followup Instructions:
___
