Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with oral pain 
medications on POD#1.  At the time of discharge the patient was 
tolerating a regular diet and feeling well.  The patient was 
afebrile with stable vital signs.  The patient's  pain was 
adequately controlled on an oral regimen. 
 
Ms. ___ is discharged home in stable condition with 
prescriptions for colace and percocet.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Losartan Potassium 100 mg PO DAILY 
2. Mobic (meloxicam) 7.5 mg oral daily 
3. Rosuvastatin Calcium 10 mg PO Q48H 
4. Forteo (teriparatide) 20 mcg/dose - 600 mcg/2.4 mL 
subcutaneous monthly 
5. Triamterene-HCTZ (37.5/___) 1 CAP PO DAILY 
6. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H prn 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Losartan Potassium 100 mg PO DAILY 
2. Rosuvastatin Calcium 10 mg PO Q48H 
3. Triamterene-HCTZ (37.5/25) 1 CAP PO DAILY 
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice 
a day Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*0
5. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H prn 
6. Forteo (teriparatide) 20 mcg/dose - 600 mcg/2.4 mL 
subcutaneous monthly 
7. Mobic (meloxicam) 7.5 mg ORAL DAILY 
8. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q4H:PRN pain 
please do not operate heavy machinery,drink alcohol or drive 
RX *oxycodone-acetaminophen [Percocet] 5 mg-325 mg ___ tablet(s) 
by mouth every four (4) hours Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
L2 and L3 compression fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.

2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 

3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.

4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy. 

5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon or your primary physician.

6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment, to be seen within the next two (2) weeks.

7. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
medications (NSAIDs such as celebrex, ibuprofen, advil, aleve, 
motrin, etc).

8. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated.  No strenuous exercise 
or heavy lifting until follow up appointment. Ambulate 5 times 
per day

 
Followup Instructions:

Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Codeine
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
admit after complication from colonoscopy
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
Mrs. ___ is a ___ year old healthy female who had a screening
colonoscopy earlier today at about 10am. Hot snare polypectomies
were performed in the cecum x 2 and at the splenic flexure. A
cold biopsy forceps was used in the descending colon. Per the GI
physician, the colon was tortuous but the prep was good and the
colonoscopy was relatively straightforward. No concerns during
the procedure itself.

She felt discomfort in the recovery area but improved and was
sent home. She was visiting a family member in the hospital 
later
in the day but felt unwell with abdominal discomfort and went
home. She had low grade temperatures at home. The pain continued
to worsen and she presented to the ED for evaluation. Plain film
on arrival is negative for free air. 

Labs are significant for a WBC of 14 with a lactate of 1.5,
otherwise normal. CT scan with IV contrast shows inflammatory
changes in the cecum and ascending colon with stranding and a
small amount of free fluid. No free air or significant amount of
free fluid. 

On my evaluation, the patient describes right lower quadrant
abdominal pain that is worse with movement. Denies nausea,
vomiting. Did have some loose stool earlier in the day. Had a
small amount of PO intake around 12pm. Felt subjective fevers
earlier today. No urinary symptoms. 
 
Past Medical History:
PNC:
1. ___ of ___
2. Labs: O pos/Ab neg/RPRNR/RI/HepBSAg neg/HIV neg/GBS neg 
(___)
3. negative materniT21
4. nl FFS, posterior placenta, no e/o previa
5. GLT wnl by report (not in chart)
6. Issues:
- Enterococcus UTI, treated and neg TOC
- Admitted ___ with mild abruption, made steroid complete ___.
Last EFW ___ (50%)

POBHx: SAB with D&C.  This pregnancy product of ___ IVF cycle,
first with donor egg.
PGynHx: denies known fibroids or STDs
PMHx: denies
PSHx: egg retrievals, D&C

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
nc
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM
99.5, 81 98/41, 16, 99RA
nontoxic, NAD, AAOx3
CTA ___
RRR
abdomen soft nondistended mild to moderate tenderness in the
right lower quadrant, some discomfort with flexion of the right
leg at the knee and external rotation, mild tenderness with left
lower quadrant palpation felt in the left and right quadrants,
minimal amount of rebound tenderness, no guarding

DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM
General - NAD
CV - RRR
Resp - unlabored breathing, no distress
Abd - soft, mildly distended, no ttp
 
Pertinent Results:
Plain films: no free air

CT A/P with IV contrast:
Wall edema of the cecum and proximal ascending colon likely
related to recent polypectomies.  Adjacent stranding and small
amount of free fluid.  No extraluminal air nor drainable
collection.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female s/p colonoscopy with multiple polypectomies, 
presenting now with persistent abdominal pain, low grade fever, 
and leukocytosis. She was admitted to the ACS service, kept NPO, 
and started on IV fluids and IV empiric antibiotics. Over the 
course of hospitalization, she remained hemodynamically stable 
and her abd pain present on admission improved. She was 
transitioned to a regular diet and PO antibiotics which she 
tolerated well without nausea or vomiting. By discharge she had 
a BM and was voiding without difficulty.
 
Medications on Admission:
unisom
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H Duration: 2 Days 
Take 500 mg two times per day. Take for 2 days total. 
RX *ciprofloxacin HCl [Cipro] 500 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice 
a day Disp #*4 Tablet Refills:*0 
2.  MetroNIDAZOLE 500 mg PO TID Duration: 2 Days 
Take 500 mg three times a day. Take for a total of 2 days 
RX *metronidazole [Flagyl] 500 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth three 
times day Disp #*6 Tablet Refills:*0 
3.  Unisom (doxylamine) (doxylamine succinate) 12.5-25 mg oral 
QHS:PRN insomnia   

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Colonic perforation, postpolypectomy syndrome

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You had a colonic perforation after your colonoscopy. You were 
treated with IV antibiotics and your pain improved. We will 
discharge with a two day course of oral antibiotics.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female s/p colonoscopy with multiple polypectomies,
presenting now with persistent abdominal pain, low grade fever,
and leukocytosis. She was admitted to the ACS service, kept NPO,
and started on IV fluids and IV empiric antibiotics. Over the
course of hospitalization, she remained hemodynamically stable
and her abd pain present on admission improved. She was
transitioned to a regular diet and PO antibiotics which she
tolerated well without nausea or vomiting. By discharge she had
a BM and was voiding without difficulty.

unisom

referred to triage after cMFM scan today with no measurable

Physical Exam:

___ 08:06PM BLOOD WBC-9.1 RBC-3.81* Hgb-10.2* Hct-30.8* 
MCV-81* MCH-26.8* MCHC-33.2 RDW-14.4 Plt ___
___ 08:06PM BLOOD Neuts-77.8* Lymphs-17.2* Monos-4.1 
Eos-0.6 Baso-0.3

Lymphs-17* Monos-83*
___ 07:06AM OTHER BODY FLUID Glucose-22
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the antepartum service for 
observation. Options for management of significant cervical 
insufficiency at this gestational age were discussed including : 
a) expectant management b) amnio to rule out infection followed 
by attempt at rescue cerclage c) termination. Patient opted for 
amniocentesis and rescue cerclage. An amniocentesis was 
performed on hospital day 2, which was negative for an 
infectious process. She was then taken to the OR for an exam 
under anesthesia that revealed no visible cervix and a bulging 
bag of water. Therefore, a rescue cerclage was not able to be 
performed. After discussing this with the patient, she desired 
expectant management. She was seen by the NICU team to further 
discuss prognosis of infants delivered between the gestational 
ages of ___s the boundaries of resuscitation 
at these gestational ages. She was also seen by social work. The 
patient was given the option of remaining inpatient with 
expectant management versus discharge home. She opted for 
discharge home. Precautions were carefully reviewed prior to 
discharge. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Vaginal progesterone 
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Cervical insufficiency 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Ms. ___, you were admitted for observation after being 
diagnosed with Cervical insufficiency. We were not able to place 
a cerclage because of how dilated your cervix was. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the post-partum service after 
undergoing vaginal delivery of an intrauterine fetal demise due 
to cervical insufficiency. Her post-partum course was 
uncomplicated. Patient declined autopsy and chaplaincy. Social 
work was consulted and followed patient throughout. She was 
discharged on post-partum day 1 with appropriate follow-up 
scheduled.

tylenol
 
Discharge Medications:

2. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q4H:PRN pain

RX *oxycodone-acetaminophen 5 mg-325 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth 
every four (4) hours Disp #*25 Tablet Refills:*0
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID

RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0

Home

cervical insufficiency

 
Discharge Condition:

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Nothing in the vagina for 6 weeks (No sex, douching, tampons)
Do not drive while taking Percocet
Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs
Do not take more than 2400mg ibuprofen in 24 hrs
Please call if you develop shortness of breath, dizziness, 
palpitations, fever of 101 or above, abdominal pain, heavy 
vaginal bleeding, nausea/vomiting or any other concerns

2. Latanoprost 0.005 % Drops Sig: One (1) Drop Ophthalmic HS (at 
bedtime).  
3. Donepezil  Oral
4. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 
hours) as needed for pain, fever for 1 weeks. Tablet(s) 
5. Phenazopyridine 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO TID (3 
times a day) as needed for bladder discomfort for 3 days.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Bladder tumor

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
The operation you have experienced is a "scraping" operation; 
that is to say, the bladder tumor or biopsy sample was "scraped" 
off the bladder wall. Bleeding was controlled with 
electrocautery which will produce a "scab" in the inside bladder 
wall. About ___ weeks after the operation, pieces of the scab 
will fall off and come out with the urine. As this occurs, 
bleeding may be noted which is normal. You should not worry 
about this. Simply lie down and increase your fluid intake for a 
few hours. In most cases, the urine will clear. Because of this 
tendency for bleeding, aspirin (or Advil) must be avoided for 2 
weeks following your operation (Tylenol is okay). If bleeding 
occurs or persists for more than 12 hours or if clots appear 
impairing your stream, call your urologist.

If you develop a fever over 101°, or have chills, call your 
urologist. Although not common, this may indicate infection that 
has developed beyond the control of the antibiotics that you 
have taken. 

It will take 6 weeks from the date of surgery to fully recover 
from your operation. This can be divided into two parts -- the 
first 2 weeks and the last 4 weeks. During the first 2 weeks 
from the date of your surgery, it is important to be "a person 
of leisure". You should avoid lifting and straining, which also 
means that you should avoid constipation. This can be done by 
any of 3 ways: 1) modify your diet, 2) use stool softeners which 
have been prescribed for you, and 3) use gentle laxatives such 
as Milk of Magnesia which can be purchased at your local drug 
store. It is important for you to avoid prolonged sitting. You 
should avoid sexual activity during this time. Also, avoid 
driving. The danger is not so much the driving, but it may delay 
you from urinating if you have the urge; and, "holding" urine 
may cause bleeding. If you return to work before 2 weeks, you 
may feel fatigued and require a decreased work load. 

During the second 4 week period of your recovery, you may begin 
regular activity, but only on a graduated basis. For example, 
you may feel well enough to return to work, but you may find it 
easier to begin on a half-day basis. It is common to become 
quite tired in the afternoon, and if such occurs, it is best to 
take a nap! Also, you may begin to drive as well as lift objects 
such as a briefcase, etc. If you are a golfer, you may begin to 
swing a golf club at this time. Sexual activity may be resumed 
during this time, but only on a limited basis. In general, your 
overall activity may be escalated to normal as you progress 
through this second time period, such that by ___ weeks 
following the date of surgery, you should be back to normal 
activity. If you take aspirin as a regular medication, it may be 
resumed at this time.

Finally, call Dr. ___ in one week after your surgery for the 
results of your biopsy and your next appointment

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o G1 with known short cervix admitted at 26w6d with a 
visually dilated cervix with hourglassing membranes. On arrival 
to triage, she appeared comfortable and had no contractions on 
toco. Fetal testing was reassuring. She was transferred to the 
antepartum floor for further observation. The pessary was left 
in place and she was continued on vaginal progesterone. She 
received a rescue course of betamethasone (complete on ___ and 
remained clinically stable until 28 weeks when she had preterm 
premature rupture of membranes. She was transferred to labor and 
delivery at that time. She was afebrile and without any evidence 
of chorioamnionitis or preterm labor. She was started on latency 
antibiotics, as well as magnesium sulfate for neuroprotection. 
She remained stable without any evidence of preterm labor or 
chorioamnionitis. The magnesium was discontinued and she was 
transferred back to the antepartum floor. She underwent close 
maternal and fetal surveillance until 31w1d when she went into 
preterm labor and subsequently had an uncomplicated spontaneous 
vaginal delivery on ___ (at 31w2d). She delivered a liveborn 
male weighing 1780 grams and apgars of 2, 5, and 7. Neonatology 
staff was present for delivery and transferred the neonate 
immediately for prematurity. Ms ___ had an uncomplicated 
postpartum course and was discharged home on PPD#2.
 
Medications on Admission:
PNV
vaginal progesterone

Home

vaginal birth
preterm labor

per instruction sheets

___

History of Present Illness:
 Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man who resides at ___ 
___, who was sent into the ER after having a syncopal episode 
and then was found to be hypoxic to 83% on RA placed on a 
non-rebreathing and remained hypoxic. There was also concern for 
a small bowel obstruction with a possible perforation as well. A 
CXR showed multifocal opacities w/ pleural effusions and a 
lactate of 6. Given his co-morbidities a family meeting was held 
with his son ___ his HCP, where it was decided to pursue CMO 
care.  
.  
On the floor, he was non responsive breathing in the low ___ and 
appeared to be comfortable in no distress.  

 
Past Medical History:
hypertension
hyperlipidemia
syncope
heart block
dementia
renal insufficiency
diatolic dysfunction
glaucoma
BPH
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Admission Physical Exam:
Gen- sleeping comfortably, NAD, RR 24  
Lungs- upper airway sounds coarse breath sounds, crackles 
present b/l  
Neuro-not responsive, not following commands  

 
Pertinent Results:
Labs on Admission:
___ 06:20PM BLOOD WBC-12.0*# RBC-3.45* Hgb-11.3* Hct-35.9* 
MCV-104* MCH-32.9* MCHC-31.6 RDW-15.1 Plt ___

Eos-0.1 Baso-0.3 ___ Myelos-0
___ 06:20PM BLOOD ___ PTT-35.8 ___
___ 06:20PM BLOOD Glucose-227* UreaN-71* Creat-2.8*# 
Na-147* K-4.6 Cl-105 HCO3-24 AnGap-23*
___ 06:20PM BLOOD ALT-86* AST-88* AlkPhos-101 TotBili-0.5
___ 06:20PM BLOOD proBNP-89___*
___ 06:20PM BLOOD cTropnT-0.08*
___ 06:20PM BLOOD Albumin-3.3*
___ 06:33PM BLOOD ___ pO2-45* pCO2-58* pH-7.23* 
calTCO2-26 Base XS--4 Comment-GREEN TOP
___ 06:33PM BLOOD Lactate-5.8*
.
Imaging:
CHEST (PORTABLE AP) Study Date of ___ 5:58 ___ 
FINDINGS: A dual-lead pacemaker/ICD device appears in unchanged. 
The heart 
is probably normal in size but not well imaged because of 
overlapping 
opacities. The aortic arch appears calcified. In the right lung, 
there is 
diffuse mild opacification that is confluent near the base of 
the lung with layering opacity suggesting a substantial pleural 
effusion is likely present.  Increased interstitial 
opacification is also noted along the right mid-to-lower lung. 
In the left lung, mostly aeration is good in the mid to upper 
lungs, but at the left lung base, there is also confluent 
retrocardiac opacity. No definite pleural effusion is seen on 
the left side.  
IMPRESSION: Multifocal opacities, much more extensive in the 
right lung than left, which may represent extensive pneumonia in 
the appropriate clinical setting, including a moderate suspected 
right-sided pleural effusion. 
. 
PORTABLE ABDOMEN Study Date of ___ 6:18 ___   
FINDINGS/IMPRESSION: There are multiple gas distended dilated 
loops of colon measuring up to 11 cm in caliber, concerning for 
colonic obstruction, volvulus, or colonic ileus; CT may be 
considered for further evaluation.   
Findings were discussed with ___ at 6:30 p.m. on 
___ by 
___ over the phone. 
 
 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ yo M w/ a multifocal pneumonia, elevated 
lactate and small bowel obstruction. The pt was severely hypoxic 
on ABG. Considering his significant co-morbidities and grave 
state of health a family meeting was held while the pt was in 
the ED and he was made CMO by his son ___ who is also his 
health care proxy. On the floor the pt was made comfortable with 
a Dilaudid gtt, scopolamine patch and lorazepam. He passed away 
today peacefully with his family at his bedside around 12:30pm.  


 
Medications on Admission:
Per omr
 
Discharge Medications:
pt is deceased

Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Pt deceased from respiratory failure
 
Discharge Condition:
Pt is deceased

N/A

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
morphine / erythromycin base
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
R hip pain 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
incision and drainage 

 
History of Present Illness:
HPI: ___ male with history of hypertension who presents with a
complaint of right thigh pain with CT significant for fluid
collection within the right lateralis muscle.  Patient states
that several days ago he was injecting IM testosterone into his
right thigh and subsequently noted progressively worsening
swelling and pain over that area.  He has had difficulty
ambulating over the past day mostly because of pain but denies
any weakness or numbness.  Patient denies any fever/chills, 
chest
pain, shortness of breath.

 
Past Medical History:
ACHALASIA                                                       
INSURANCE MEMBER ID NUMBER                                      
MILD HYPERCHOLESTEROLEMIA                                       
S/P LACERATION OF RIGHT RADIAL NERVE                            
GASTROESOPHAGEAL REFLUX                                         
H/O ECZEMA                                                      
H/O INTRAVENOUS DRUG ABUSE   
 
Physical Exam:
RLE: dressings c/d/I. non tender, non erythematous. 
motor/sensory intact throughout leg. full strength. foot is wwp. 
soft compartments. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Hospitalization Summary (ED Admit)
The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have R thigh abscess and was admitted to the orthopedic 
surgery service. The patient was taken to the operating room on 
___ for incision and drainage which the patient tolerated 
well. For full details of the procedure please see the 
separately dictated operative report. The patient was taken from 
the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory 
recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The 
patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, 
and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. 
The patient was given ___ antibiotics and 
anticoagulation per routine. The patient's home medications were 
continued throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked 
with ___ who determined that discharge to home was appropriate. 
The ___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.

He will be sent out on clindamycin PO. Please follow up with us 
in clinic per instructions.
 
Medications on Admission:
lisinopril 5mg
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H:PRN Pain - Mild 
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg 2 tablet(s) by mouth every 8 hours Disp 
#*100 Tablet Refills:*0 
2.  Clindamycin 300 mg PO Q6H 
RX *clindamycin HCl 300 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth every 6 hours 
Disp #*56 Capsule Refills:*0 
3.  Enoxaparin Sodium 40 mg SC DAILY Duration: 28 Days 
RX *enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL 1 syringe subc once daily Disp #*28 
Syringe Refills:*0 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
R hip infection 

 
Discharge Condition:
avss
aox3

 
Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions:

INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- weight bearing as tolerated 

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take lovenox daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented as a same day admission for surgery. The 
patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for irrigation 
and debridement of a right thigh abscess, which the patient 
tolerated well. A wound vac was placed. The patient was 
subsequently taken back to the operating room on ___ for repeat 
irrigation and debridement and wound closure. For full details 
of these procedures please see the separately dictated operative 
report. The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable 
condition and after satisfactory recovery from anesthesia was 
transferred to the floor, following both operative procedures. 
The patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain 
medications, and progressed to a regular diet and oral 
medications. The patient was given anticoagulation per routine. 
The patient's home medications were continued throughout this 
hospitalization, with the exception of his home lisinopril. 
Elevated potassium was noted on routine laboratory work. The 
potassium levels were trended. ID was consulted for management 
of this patient's infection. ID recommended treatment with IV 
cefazolin to be continued until ___. Please see their notes for 
details. A ___ line was placed on ___. The patient worked with 
___ who determined that discharge to home was appropriate. The 
___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.

Omeprazole 20 mg PO Q12H

every eight (8) hours Disp #*46 Intravenous Bag Refills:*0 
4.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
don't drink/drive/operate heavy machinery while taking 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 4 hours as 
needed Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet by mouth every four (4) hours Disp 
#*12 Tablet Refills:*0 
5.  Omeprazole 20 mg PO Q12H

Home With Service

right thigh abscess

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- WBAT in RLE
- NO strenuous activity until you follow-up with your surgeon 
and are given clearance

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon. Please follow up with your primary care 
doctor before resuming your home lisinopril.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take ASA 325mg 1 tablet by mouth daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.

Physical Therapy:
WBAT RLE
NO strenuous activity until cleared by your surgeon at 
follow-up.
Treatments Frequency:
-Outer dressing can be removed in 2 days. There are small strips 
of tape covering your incision (steri-strips). These will fall 
off on their own; do not remove.
 
Followup Instructions:
___
